title: Let Us Continue
added: {{Infobox event

'''Let Us Continue''' is a [[Speech (address)|speech]] that [[President of the United States|President]] [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] delivered to [[Bicameralism|both houses]] of [[United States Congress|Congress]] on November 27, 1963, five days after the [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassination of his predecessor John F. Kennedy]]. It was a [[eulogy]] for the [[murder]]ed president, an attempt to lift up the shaken American nation, a [[legitimation]] of Johnson's new [[Powers of the president of the United States|presidential power]] and a sketch of his political program. The almost 25-minute speech is considered one of the most important in his political career.

title: Let Us Continue
deleted:
The speech opened with Johnson being introduced to members of the joint session by [[John W. McCormack]], the [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|speaker of the House of Representatives]]. Johnson began by his tribute to President Kennedy and his work. He said: "All I have I would have given gladly not to be standing here today."{{Sfn|Transcript {{endash}} LBJ Library|1963}} He called Kennedy the "greatest leader of our time", and emphasized at the outset that no word was sad enough to gauge the grief that Kennedy's assassination had caused.{{Sfn|Transcript {{endash}} LBJ Library|1963}} He continued,
"The dream of conquering the vastness of space--the dream of partnership across the Atlantic{{Endash}}and across the Pacific as well{{Endash}}the dream of a Peace Corps in less developed nations{{Endash}}the dream of education for all of our children{{Endash}}the dream of jobs for all who seek them and need them{{Endash}}the dream of care for our elderly{{Endash}}the dream of an all-out attack on mental illness{{Endash}}and above all, the dream of equal rights for all Americans, whatever their race or color{{Endash}}these and other American dreams have been vitalized by his drive and by his dedication.{{Sic|?}}"{{Sfn|Johnson|1964|pp=149-156}}
Johnson then declared his intention to maintain continuity in [[Foreign policy of the United States|foreign policy]]. It was followed by a passage devoted primarily to [[domestic policy]].{{Sfn|Witherspoon|1987|pp=536-537}} He said: "This Nation will keep its commitments from [[South Vietnam]] to [[West Berlin]]."{{Sfn|Transcript {{endash}} LBJ Library|1963}} He then asked the members of Congress to decide on [[tax reform]] and a bill to reduce [[Racism in the United States|racial discrimination]].{{Sfn|Witherspoon|1987|p=536-538}} He asked all Americans for their help,{{Sfn|Dallek|1998|p=56}} saying: "An assassin’s bullet has thrust upon me the awesome burden of the Presidency. I am here today to say I need your help; I cannot bear this burden alone."{{Sfn|Transcript {{endash}} LBJ Library|1963}} Referring to Kennedy's 1960 inaugural address,{{Sfn|Witherspoon|1987|p=536-538}} he said:
"On the 20th day of January, in 1961, John F. Kennedy told his countrymen that our national work would not be finished 'in the first thousand days, nor in the life of this administration, nor even perhaps in our lifetime on this planet'. But, he said, 'let us begin'. Today, in this moment of new resolve, I would say to all my fellow Americans, ''let us continue.''"{{Sfn|Transcript {{endash}} LBJ Library|1963}}
Johnson requested for the earliest possible passing of the civil rights law, for which Kennedy had fought for so long.{{Sfn|Bornet|1988|pp=46-47}} He emphasized that [[Equality before the law|equal rights]] had been talked about long enough:{{Sfn|Witherspoon|1987|p=536-538}} "It is time now to write the next chapter, and to write it in the books of law. All traces of discrimination and oppression based on race or skin color should be eliminated."{{Sfn|Johnson|1964|pp=149-156}} He also demanded from Congress to pass a tax reform that would bring tax relief.{{Sfn|Gittinger|Fisher|2004}} The tax reform was conceived in the spirit of a [[Supply-side economics|supply-oriented economic policy]].{{Sfn|Gittinger|Fisher|2004}}{{Sfn|Dallek|1998|pp=71–74}} He said: "As one who has long served in both Houses of the Congress, I firmly believe in the independence and the integrity of the legislative branch. And I promise you that I shall always respect this{{Nbsp}}... With equal firmness, I believe in the capacity and I believe in the ability of the Congress, despite the divisions of opinions which characterize our Nation, to act--to act wisely, to act vigorously, to act speedily when the need arises."{{Sfn|Transcript {{endash}} LBJ Library|1963}} Johnson was aware that such demands could give the appearance of disregarding the autonomy of Congress. He countered this impression by asserting that he firmly believed in the independence and integrity of the legislature. Respect for this autonomy was in line with his deep conviction. With equal steadfastness, he assumed that the Congress was capable of intelligent, energetic, and immediate action. He emphasized: "The need is here. The need is now. I ask your help."{{Sfn|Johnson|1964|pp=149-156}}

title: Let Us Continue
deleted: Johnson's call for action was expressed in the speech by the frequent use of the term "action", which he used ten times. He had already repeatedly asked for help in talks with representatives of various interest groups and with individuals.{{Sfn|Caro|2012|pp=334, 365, 368, 406, 419, 421}} He also used [[Repetition (rhetorical device)|repetitions]] in other parts of the speech to convey his message.{{Sfn|Unger|1999|p=293}} This stylistic device was used right at the beginning of the speech when Johnson spoke that " Kennedy lives on in the immortal words and works that he left behind."{{Sfn|Johnson|1964|pp=149-156}} Also at the beginning, he used the means of repetition when he recalled the political dreams that Kennedy had begun to realize: "The dream of conquering the vastness of space{{Nbsp}}... "{{Sfn|Johnson|1964|pp=149-156}} Toward the end of his speech, he alluded to a phrase from [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s famous [[Gettysburg Address]] of 1863:{{Sfn|Bornet|1988|p=47}} "So let us here highly resolve that John Fitzgerald Kennedy did not live – or die – in vain."{{Sfn|Johnson|1964|pp=149-156}} He closed the speech with a stanza from "[[America the Beautiful]]",{{Sfn|Witherspoon|1987|p=536-538}} saying:<blockquote>And on this Thanksgiving eve, as we gather together to ask the Lord’s blessing, and give Him our thanks, let us unite in those familiar and cherished words:

title: Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election
added: ==Post-election voter suppression efforts==

Following the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 election]] and attempts by Donald Trump and [[Republican Party (US)|Republican]] officials to overturn it, Republican lawmakers initiated a sweeping effort to make voting laws more restrictive.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Izaguirre|first1=Anthony|last2=Coronado|first2=Acacia|date=January 31, 2021|title=GOP lawmakers seek tougher voting rules after record turnout|url=https://apnews.com/article/bills-voting-rights-elections-coronavirus-pandemic-voter-registration-0e94844d72d2a2bf8b51b1c950bd64fc|url-status=live|website=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=McCaskill|first=Nolan D.|date=March 15, 2021|title=After Trump's loss and false fraud claims, GOP eyes voter restrictions across nation|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/15/voting-restrictions-states-475732|url-status=live|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref> According to the [[Brennan Center for Justice]], as of March 24, 2021, more than 361 bills that would restrict voting access have been introduced in 47 states,<ref name="Brennan-March">{{Cite web|date=April 1, 2021|title=Voting Laws Roundup: March 2021|url=https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/voting-laws-roundup-march-2021|url-status=live|website=[[Brennan Center for Justice]]}}</ref> with most aimed at limiting [[postal voting|mail-in voting]], strengthening [[Voter identification laws in the United States|voter ID laws]], shortening [[early voting]], eliminating [[Voter registration in the United States#Automatic|automatic]] and [[Voter registration in the United States#Election Day / same-day|same-day voter registration]], curbing the use of [[ballot drop box]]es, and allowing for increased purging of [[Electoral roll|voter rolls]].<ref name="Bill-Tracker">{{Cite web|date=February 24, 2021|title=State Voting Bills Tracker 2021|url=https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/state-voting-bills-tracker-2021|url-status=live|website=[[Brennan Center for Justice]]}}</ref><ref name="NYT-practices"/>

title: Langdon Cheves
added: After leaving public office, Cheves was an active advocate for unified Southern resistance to protective tariffs and the abolition of slavery, though an opponent of unilateral action by South Carolina or any one state. Originally, Cheves advocated for a convention of Southern states to pressure Congress into adopting these positions, but eventually became one of the earliest advocates for outright regional secession from the United States.

title: Spark Matsunaga
deleted: Senator Matsunaga's greatest legacy is The United States Institute of Peace, an American non-partisan, independent, federal institution that provides analysis of and is involved in conflicts around the world. The United States Institute of Peace Act, passed in 1984, calls for the Institute to "serve the people and the Government through the widest possible range of education and training, basic and applied research opportunities, and peace information services on the means to promote international peace and the resolution of conflicts among the nations and peoples of the world without recourse to violence".

The Institute carries out this mission by operating programs in conflict zones, conducting research and analysis, operating a training academy and public education center, providing grants for research and fieldwork, convening conferences and workshops, and building the academic and policy fields of international conflict management and peacebuilding. On many of its projects, the Institute works in partnership with nongovernmental organizations, higher and secondary educational institutions, international organizations, local organizations, and U.S. government agencies, including the State Department and the Department of Defense.

title: Rohit Chopra
deleted: Chopra later became a Senior Fellow at the [[Consumer Federation of America]] (CFA), a consumer advocacy group.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Schumer Recommends Consumer Advocate Rohit Chopra to the President to Serve as FTC Commissioner – Says Chopra is Eminently Qualified and has Been Putting Interests of Consumers First His Entire Career {{!}} Senate Democratic Leadership|url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/schumer-recommends-consumer-advocate-rohit-chopra-to-the-president-to-serve-as-ftc-commissioner-says-chopra-is-eminently-qualified-and-has-been-putting-interests-of-consumers-first-his-entire-career|access-date=2021-09-10|website=www.democrats.senate.gov|language=en}}</ref> In 2017, Chopra released a report showing that over 1 million Americans defaulted on a student loan in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mitchell|first=Josh|date=March 14, 2017|title=Student-Loan Defaults Rose by 1.1 Million in 2016|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/student-loan-defaults-rose-by-1-1-million-in-2016-1489498222|access-date=|website=[[Wall Street Journal]]|via=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Berman|first=Jillian|title=More than 1 million borrowers defaulted on their student loans last year|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/more-than-1-million-student-loan-borrowers-were-in-default-last-year-2017-03-14|access-date=July 3, 2018}}</ref>

title: Fumio Kishida
added: On 29 September 2021, Fumio Kishida defeated [[Taro Kono]] in a runoff vote to become the leader of the ruling [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (LDP) and replaced the outgoing party leader [[Yoshihide Suga]]. He received a total of 257 votes, from 249 parliament members and eight rank-and-file members, to become Japan's next Prime Minister.<ref>{{cite_web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/29/asia/japan-leadership-election-kishida-intl-hnk/index.html|title=Fumio Kishida likely to become Japan's next Prime Minister after winning leadership election|accessdate=29 September 2021|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: Gavin Newsom
added: In August of 2021, Newsom sold a Marin County home for $5.9 million in an off-market transaction. He had originally put the property up for sale in early 2019 for $5.895 million, but removed the property from the market after a price reduction to $5.695 million. The property then sold off-market in August 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-08-23|title=Photos: Amid recall madness, Gavin Newsom sells Marin County home in lucrative $5.9 million off-market deal|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2021/08/23/photos-amid-recall-madness-gavin-newsom-sells-marin-county-home-in-lucrative-5-9-million-off-market-deal|access-date=2021-09-02|website=The Mercury News|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Gavin Newsom
added: On September 14, 2021, the [[Associated Press]] announced the failure of the recall to obtain the majority of votes required to remove Newsom.<ref name="AP NEWS 2021">{{cite web | title=California Gov. Gavin Newsom stays in power as recall fails | website=AP NEWS | date=2021-09-14 | url=https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-donald-trump-california-climate-elections-a590782877be099d44f1766b2d138394 | access-date=2021-09-15}}</ref><ref name="Bernstein 2021">{{cite web | last=Bernstein | first=Sharon | title=TV networks | website=Reuters | date=2021-09-15 | url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/californians-decide-governors-fate-republican-backed-recall-2021-09-14/ | access-date=2021-09-15}}</ref>

title: Gavin Newsom
deleted: In November, before the [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] holiday, Newsom was widely criticized for attending a birthday party for a lobbyist and political advisor at the Michelin [[List of Michelin 3-star restaurants|3-star restaurant]] [[The French Laundry]] in [[Napa County]], where more than three families were in attendance, despite his administration issuing guidelines for the holiday season that would limit private gatherings to only three households.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-11-18/newsom-french-laundry-dinner-explanation-photos-jason-kinney-california-medical-association-covid-19|title=Photos raise doubts about Newsom's claim that dinner with lobbyist was outdoors amid COVID-19 surge|first=Taryn|last=Luna|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 18, 2020|access-date=December 21, 2020|language=en-US}}</ref> The incident was said to have severely damaged Newsom's image and credibility amidst the public health crisis.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Fuller|first=Thomas|date=November 18, 2020|title=For California Governor the Coronavirus Message Is Do as I Say, Not as I Dine|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/18/us/newsom-california-covid-french-laundry.html|access-date=November 19, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

In January 2021, the ''Los Angeles Times'' reported that Newsom's administration had mismanaged $11.4 billion by disbursing unemployment benefits to ineligible claimants, especially those paid through the federally funded [[Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act#Unemployment benefits|Pandemic Unemployment Assistance]] program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://calmatters.org/economy/2020/12/who-will-pay-for-all-of-californias-unemployment-fraud/?|title = Who will pay for all of California's unemployment fraud?|date = December 22, 2020}}</ref> Another $19 billion in claims remained under investigation for fraud.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-01-25/california-unemployment-fraud-11-billion-investigations|title = California officials say unemployment fraud now totals more than $11 billion|date = January 25, 2021}}</ref> At the same time, legitimate claimants faced lengthy delays in receiving benefits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/opinion/story/2021-02-11/editorial-julie-su-and-californias-unemployment-insurance-meltdown?_amp=true|title = Editorial: California's unemployment system collapsed on Julie Su's watch|date = February 11, 2021}}</ref> Political opponents attributed the crisis to Newsom's administration's failure to heed multiple warnings by federal officials of the potential for fraud, while Newsom's administration said the Trump administration's failure to provide appropriate guidance for the new federally funded program contributed to the fraud.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2021-02-05/california-house-republicans-hit-newsom-over-fraudulent-unemployment-claims?_amp=true|title=House Republicans from California demand Gov. Newsom answer for unemployment failings|date=February 5, 2021}}</ref> Experts said much of the fraud appeared to originate from international criminal gangs in 20 different countries.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=McGreevy|first1=Patrick|last2=Chabria|first2=Anita|last3=Winton|first3=Richard|date=December 4, 2020|title=California may have sent $1 billion in jobless benefits to people outside the state, D.A.s warn|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-12-04/california-unemployment-benefits-out-of-state-district-attorney|access-date=December 4, 2020|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Dec. 7|first=Patrick McGreevy|date=December 7, 2020|title=California unemployment fraud amid COVID-19 pandemic may total $2 billion, Bank of America says|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-12-07/bank-of-america-estimate-2-billion-california-unemployment-fraud|access-date=December 16, 2020|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-01-15/unemployment-benefit-fraud-california-billions-edd?_amp=true|title = California unemployment fraud could top $9 billion, double previous estimate, expert warns|date = January 15, 2021}}</ref> According to the ''Los Angeles Times'', $400 million in claims were disbursed to claims made on behalf of prison inmates.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|last2=|date=2020-12-03|title=Column: Newsom endures two embarrassments with French Laundry dinner and unemployment scam|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-12-03/skelton-edd-inmate-unemployment-fraud-scandal-french-laundry-embarassment|url-status=live|access-date=2021-08-16|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Walsh worked with Councilor [[Ayanna Pressley]] on an ordinance requiring municipal trucks to have side-guards in order to protect [[cyclists]].<ref name="sideguard1"/> It passed unanimously in the City Council in November 2014.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Poff |first1=Sarah |title=New city ordinance requires truck-side guards to reduce bicyclist fatalities – The Daily Free Press |url=https://dailyfreepress.com/2014/11/04/new-city-ordinance-requires-truck-side-guards-to-reduce-bicyclist-fatalities/ |website=The Daily Free Press |access-date=11 September 2021 |date=November 4, 2013}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: In January 2016, Boston struck a deal for [[General Electric]] to move their [[headquarters]] to the city. Some critics argued that Boston had given General Electric a "sweetheart deal".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Reilly |first1=Adam |title='We Won Powerball': Marty Walsh On General Electric's Move To Boston |url=https://www.wgbh.org/news/2016/01/13/local-news/we-won-powerball-marty-walsh-general-electrics-move-boston |website=www.wgbh.org |access-date=13 September 2021 |language=en |date=14 January 2016}}</ref> However, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' jointly four deputies of Walsh and Governor [[Charlie Baker]] who had been involved in striking the deal as their "Bostonians of the Year".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Leung |first1=Shirley |title=Dealmakers: The four players who really brought GE to town - The Boston Globe |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/magazine/2016/12/14/dealmakers-the-four-players-who-really-brought-town/7JQsUqgSIz49yIuT7HtGwM/story.html |website=The Boston Globe |access-date=13 September 2021 |date=December 14, 2016}}</ref>

Here's what to know. |url=https://www.boston.com/news/racial-justice/2020/06/25/marty-walsh-equity-and-inclusion-cabinet/ |website=www.boston.com |access-date=18 September 2021 |date=June 25, 2020}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: While Walsh, in 2019, outlined plans to deal with the homelessness crisis on Boston's so-called "Methadone Mile" (also known as "Mass & Cass" for the intersection of Massachusetts Avenue and Melena Cass Boulevard), it persisted to be a problem when he left office in 2021.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cotter |first1=Sean Philip |title=Marty Walsh floats outline of plan for Methadone Mile |url=https://www.bostonherald.com/2019/09/10/marty-walsh-floats-outline-of-plan-for-methadone-mile/ |website=Boston Herald |access-date=20 September 2021 |date=11 September 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Chan |first1=Kelly |title=Abutters struggle with Mass & Cass problems |url=https://www.baystatebanner.com/2021/01/07/abutters-struggle-with-mass-cass-problems/ |website=The Bay State Banner |access-date=20 September 2021 |date=7 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Walsh was mayor during much of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Mayor Marty Walsh gives update on COVID-19 in Boston |url=https://www.wcvb.com/article/mayor-marty-walsh-gives-update-on-covid-19-in-boston02102021/35472180 |website=WCVB |access-date=21 September 2021 |language=en |date=10 February 2021}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Under Walsh, the city of Boston took party in [[Barack Obama]]'s [[My Brother's Keeper Challenge]].<ref name="gavincouncilors1">{{cite web |last1=Gavin |first1=Christopher |title=Boston councilors again approve Commission on Black Men & Boys |url=https://www.boston.com/news/racial-justice/2021/09/16/after-walsh-veto-boston-councilors-again-approve-commission-on-black-men-boys/ |website=Boston.com |access-date=23 September 2021 |date=September 16, 2021}}</ref> In 2014, Walsh [[veto]]ed an ordinance by the Boston City Council to create a commission on black men and boys, claiming that he did so because such a commission, "duplicate and complicate efforts that my administration is already engaged in".<ref name="gavincouncilors1"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Under Walsh, the city of Boston tookpartin [[Barack Obama]]'s [[My Brother's Keeper Challenge]].<ref name="gavincouncilors1">{{cite web |last1=Gavin |first1=Christopher |title=Boston councilors again approve Commission on Black Men & Boys |url=https://www.boston.com/news/racial-justice/2021/09/16/after-walsh-veto-boston-councilors-again-approve-commission-on-black-men-boys/ |website=Boston.com |access-date=23 September 2021 |date=September 16, 2021}}</ref> In 2014, Walsh [[veto]]ed an ordinance by the Boston City Council to create a commission on black men and boys, claiming that he did so because such a commission, "duplicate and complicate efforts that my administration is already engaged in".<ref name="gavincouncilors1"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Under Walsh, the city of Boston took part inthe[[My Brother's Keeper Challenge]].<ref name="gavincouncilors1">{{cite web |last1=Gavin |first1=Christopher |title=Boston councilors again approve Commission on Black Men & Boys |url=https://www.boston.com/news/racial-justice/2021/09/16/after-walsh-veto-boston-councilors-again-approve-commission-on-black-men-boys/ |website=Boston.com |access-date=23 September 2021 |date=September 16, 2021}}</ref> In 2014, Walsh [[veto]]ed an ordinance by the Boston City Council to create a commission on black men and boys, claiming that he did so because such a commission, "duplicate and complicate efforts that my administration is already engaged in".<ref name="gavincouncilors1"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Under Walsh, the city of Boston took part in the [[My Brother's Keeper Challenge]].<ref name="gavincouncilors1">{{cite web |last1=Gavin |first1=Christopher |title=Boston councilors again approve Commission on Black Men & Boys |url=https://www.boston.com/news/racial-justice/2021/09/16/after-walsh-veto-boston-councilors-again-approve-commission-on-black-men-boys/ |website=Boston.com |access-date=23 September 2021 |date=September 16, 2021}}</ref> In 2014, Walsh [[veto]]ed an ordinance by the Boston City Council to create a commission on black men and boys, claiming that he did so because such a commission, "duplicate and complicate efforts that my administration is already engaged in"and would violate the city charter.<ref name="gavincouncilors1"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Under Walsh, the city of Boston took part in the [[My Brother's Keeper Challenge]].<ref name="gavincouncilors1">{{cite web |last1=Gavin |first1=Christopher |title=Boston councilors again approve Commission on Black Men & Boys |url=https://www.boston.com/news/racial-justice/2021/09/16/after-walsh-veto-boston-councilors-again-approve-commission-on-black-men-boys/ |website=Boston.com |access-date=23 September 2021 |date=September 16, 2021}}</ref> In 2014, Walsh [[veto]]ed an ordinance by the Boston City Council to create a commission on black men and boys, claiming that he did so because such a commission, "duplicate and complicate efforts that my administration is already engaged in",andthat the ordinance was written in such a way that he believed itwould violate the city charter.<ref name="gavincouncilors1"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Walsh cancelled the 2020 edition of the [[Boston Marathon]] due to pandemic concerns.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mayor Walsh Cancels This Year's Boston Marathon Amid COVID-19 Pandemic |url=https://wbznewsradio.iheart.com/content/2020-05-28-mayor-walsh-cancels-this-years-boston-marathon-amid-covid-19-pandemic/ |website=WBZ NewsRadio 1030 |access-date=23 September 2021 |language=en |date=May 28, 2020}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Walsh established a rent relief fund in April 2020, using $3 million of city funds.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Vervaeke |first1=Abby |title=Who Qualifies for Boston's Rental Relief Fund |url=https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/who-qualifies-for-bostons-rental-relief-fund/2102138/ |website=NBC Boston |access-date=24 September 2021 |date=April 3, 2020}}</ref> He later added an additional $5 million in June 2020.<ref>{{cite web |title=Marty Walsh adding $5M to Boston coronavirus rental relief fund |url=https://www.bostonherald.com/2020/06/03/walsh-adding-5m-to-boston-coronavirus-rental-relief-fund/ |website=Boston Herald |access-date=24 September 2021 |date=3 June 2020}}</ref>

Due to the pandemic, in 2020, Walsh extended the due date for [[property tax]] bills from May 1 to June 1, and waived the interest fees on delayed payments of motor vehicle and property taxes.<ref name="curfew1"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Ben Penn of [[Bloomberg Law]] reported that, as labor secretary, Walsh lobbied trade unions not to criticize the prospective appointment of [[David Weil]], which helped to clear the path for Biden to nominate Weil to serve as the administrator of the [[Wage and Hour Division]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Penn |first1=Ben |title=How Marty Walsh Saved David Weil From Building Trades Opposition |url=https://news.bloomberglaw.com/daily-labor-report/how-marty-walsh-saved-david-weil-from-building-trades-opposition |website=news.bloomberglaw.com |publisher=Bloomberg Law |access-date=25 September 2021 |language=en |date=September 14, 2021}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: In January 2021, Walsh made [[Dennis White (police commissioner)|Dennis White]] the new comissioner of the Boston Police Department.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.boston.gov/news/william-gross-retire-mayor-appoints-dennis-white-43rd-boston-police-commissioner |title=William Gross to Retire; Mayor Appoints Dennis White as 43rd Boston Police Commissioner |website=boston.gov |date=January 28, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.boston.com/news/local-news/2021/02/01/dennis-white-police-reform-boston-commissioner |title=Dennis White vows to see through reforms as Boston's police commissioner |first=Christopher |last=Gavin |website=[[Boston.com]] |date=February 1, 2021 |access-date=February 1, 2021}}</ref> Days after appointing White, Walsh suspended him pending an investigation into allegations of [[domestic violence]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ryan |first1=Andrew |title=Walsh administration refuses to release internal affairs files of embattled police commissioner - The Boston Globe |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/2021/03/06/metro/walsh-administration-refuses-release-internal-affairs-files-embattled-police-commissioner/ |website=The Boston Globe |access-date=27 September 2021 |date=March 5, 2021}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: After Walsh left office, the [[editorial board]] of ''The Boston Globe'' would opine that, as mayor, Walsh, "kept Boston on an even keel financially and invited economic growth".<ref name="andreaendorse"/>

title: Marty Walsh
added: In his 2018 second mayoral inauguration address, Walsh announced establishment of the Boston's Way Home Fund, with the aim of raising $10 million to establish 200 units of permanent supportive housing for the chronically homeless.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mayor Walsh announces creation of Boston's Way Home Fund |url=https://www.boston.gov/news/mayor-walsh-announces-creation-bostons-way-home-fund |website=Boston.gov |access-date=22 October 2021 |language=en |date=1 January 2018}}</ref> The fund met its $10 million goal in 2020, two years earlier than its target.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jolicoeur |first1=Lynn |title=2 Years Early, Boston Raises $10 Million To Help House People Who've Been Chronically Homeless |url=https://www.wbur.org/news/2020/01/29/boston-way-home-fund-homeless-housing |website=WBUR |access-date=22 October 2021 |language=en |date=January 29, 2020}}</ref>

title: Marty Walsh
added: Walsh is also the first former union leader to serve in the position in roughly 45 years.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Zahn |first1=Max |title='A blue-collar guy': Labor Secretary pick Marty Walsh would mark a dramatic shift from Eugene Scalia |url=https://www.yahoo.com/now/a-bluecollar-guy-labor-secretary-nominee-marty-walsh-supported-by-top-unions-144342811.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAABvYsBvXMwqUUT7gtUx51tzsEzRNhrnUFTTR2yxlFejttXYAxVruce_5Fn1Wpyas82fs5dR5quxS-hAT1f6BE3sbWd2AcZt2K2Q6ufIxqCgPP51I_5IACaSWjBXltwun4eh0fx0l7p0nP1wurIwSA-99TzUXwYUkONe5UrWHkY0r |website=www.yahoo.com |access-date=26 October 2021 |date=February 4, 2021}}</ref>

title: Maia Bellon
added: Bellon is married to Bill S. Kallappa II, a member of the [[Washington State Board of Education]] and an enrolled member of the [[Makah Tribe]]. The two reside in [[Tumwater, Washington]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Bill S. Kallappa II Appointed to the State Board of Education {{!}} SBE|url=https://www.sbe.wa.gov/news/bill-s-kallappa-ii-appointed-state-board-education|access-date=2021-10-16|website=www.sbe.wa.gov}}</ref>

title: Abigail Spanberger
added: ===Joe Biden===

As of September 2021, Spanberger had voted in line with [[Joe Biden]]'s stated position 100% of the time.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bycoffe |first1=Anna Wiederkehr and Aaron |title=Does Your Member Of Congress Vote With Or Against Biden? |url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-congress-votes/abigail-spanberger/|website=FiveThirtyEight |access-date=14 September 2021 |language=en |date=2021-04-22}}</ref>

title: Dan Helmer
deleted: During the race, Helmer focused heavily on campaign financing. According to Helmer, his campaign “refused all donations from corporate PACs, the NRA, and Dominion Energy.”<ref>{{Cite web|title=Helmer campaign shatters Q1 Fundraising Records in Effort to Flip Virginia House — Dan Helmer for Delegate|url=https://www.danhelmer.com/campaign-news/helmer-campaign-shatters-q1-fundraising-records-in-effort-to-flip-virginia-house|access-date=2020-07-22|website=Dan Helmer|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Dan Helmer
deleted: In the first quarter of 2019, his campaign manager reported that he had received more than 500 individual contributions and amassed more than $124,000, the largest total raised by a challenger to a Republican House incumbent in Virginia history. Helmer would go on to raise $729,547 from individual donations, more than any candidate in House of Delegates history.<ref>{{Cite web|title=General Assembly Member Funding Sources, 2018-19|url=https://www.vpap.org/visuals/visual/candidate-funding-sources-2018-19/|access-date=2020-07-22|website=The Virginia Public Access Project|language=en}}</ref>

As a freshman in the [[Virginia General Assembly]], Helmer sat on four committees: Agriculture Chesapeake and Natural Resources Communications, Technology and Innovation, Public Safety, and Transportation. On those four committees, Helmer was a member of five subcommittees: Chesapeake, Firearms, Transportation Systems, Motor Vehicles, and Communications.<ref>{{Cite web|title=House of Delegates Committees|url=https://virginiageneralassembly.gov/house/members/members.php?committee=H01&id=H0317|access-date=2020-07-22|website=virginiageneralassembly.gov}}</ref>

title: Dan Helmer
deleted: Helmer was chief co-patron of Virginia's HB 2,<ref>{{cite act|title=HB 2 Firearm transfers; criminal history record information checks, penalty. |url=https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?ses=201&typ=bil&val=hb2 |legislature=Virginia General Assembly |date={{date|2020-04-10|mdy}} |language=en}}</ref> providing for Universal Background Checks. He was also a co-patron of [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+sum+HB674 HB 674] and HB 1004, both [[red flag laws]], as well as a patron on [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+sum+HB567 HB 567], which banned indoor shooting ranges in buildings not owned or leased by the Commonwealth.

Helmer was a patron of [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+sum+HB714 HB 714], the Virginia Energy Plan, and [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+sum+HB1526 HB 1526], which regulates electric utilities.

Helmer is a strong supporter of worker's rights. He served as chief-co patron of [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+sum+HB438#:~:text=Provides%20that%20post%2Dtraumatic%20stress,post%2Dtraumatic%20stress%20disorder%20as HB 438] which mandates that law-enforcement officers and firefighters must be compensated for any post-traumatic stress disorder incurred because of their profession.

Helmer was a chief co-patron of [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+sum+HB972 HB 972], which decriminalized [[Cannabis (drug)|Marijuana]] in the Commonwealth of Virginia. He has stated his support for [[marijuana legalization]].
Helmer was a patron of [https://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?201+cab+HC10211HB1268+RCHB3 HB 1268], which proposed a personal property tax exemption for motor vehicle of a disabled veteran.

title: Dan Helmer
deleted: Helmer was a vocal supporter of and voted for HJ1, passage of which made Virginia the 38th state to ratify the [[Equal Rights Amendment]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Williams|first=Timothy|date=2020-01-15|title=Virginia Approves the E.R.A., Becoming the 38th State to Back It|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/us/era-virginia-vote.html|access-date=2020-07-22|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Dan Helmer
deleted: During the 2019 Virginia House of Representatives race, Helmer criticized his opponent, Tim Hugo, for taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from the [[Payday loan|predatory lending industry]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Following the Money from High-Interest Lenders to Virginia Lawmakers|url=http://www.connectionnewspapers.com/news/2017/nov/01/campaign-cash-high-interest-lenders/|access-date=2020-07-22|website=www.connectionnewspapers.com}}</ref>

title: Dan Helmer
added: ==Alleged antisemitic campaign attack==

A Republican flier was distributed to homes in the Virginia suburbs of Washington which depicted a cartoon of Helmer, who is Jewish, with a pronounced nose and at a table stacked with gold coins. It was distributed by Helmer’s Republican challenger, Howard Pyon. Helmer said "“People are deeply upset by this... They expect us to be talking about the issues, not to be using antisemitic tropes.” A Pyon spoken denied a racist intent and said the depiction could apply to any politician accused of voting for tax hikes.<ref>[https://www.timesofisrael.com/gop-flier-in-virginia-house-race-depicts-jewish-democrat-with-pile-of-gold-coins/ GOP flier in Virginia House race depicts Jewish Democrat with pile of gold coins] Ron Kampeas. The Times of Israel. September 30, 2021. Retrieved October 5, 2021</ref>

title: BlackRock
added: ===China===

In August 2021, BlackRock set up its first mutual fund in China after raising over one billion dollars from 111,000 Chinese investors. BlackRock became the first foreign-owned company allowed by the Chinese government to operate a wholly-owned business in China's mutual fund industry.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chandler |first1=Clay |last2=Gordon |first2=Nicholas |title=BlackRock is 'blundering' in China—all the way to the bank |url=https://fortune.com/2021/09/09/blackrock-china-mutual-fund-investment-soros-mistake/ |access-date=25 October 2021 |work=Fortune |date=September 9, 2021 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Madhok |first1=Diksha |title=Chinese investors pour $1 billion into BlackRock's new fund |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/08/investing/blackrock-china-fund-intl-hnk/index.html |access-date=25 October 2021 |work=CNN |date=September 8, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=BlackRock's China unit raises $1 bln in maiden mutual fund |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/blackrocks-china-unit-raises-1-bln-maiden-mutual-fund-2021-09-08/ |work=Reuters |date=8 September 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Writing in ''The Wall Street Journal'', [[George Soros]] described BlackRock's initiative in China as a "tragic mistake" that would "damage the national security interests of the U.S. and other democracies."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Meredith |first1=Sam |title=BlackRock responds to George Soros' criticism over China investments |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/08/blackrock-responds-to-george-soros-criticism-over-china-investments.html |access-date=25 October 2021 |work=CNBC |date=8 September 2021 |language=en}}</ref>

title: Crossfire Hurricane (FBI investigation)
deleted: On September 19,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|date=2021-09-16|title=Grand Jury Indicts D.C. Attorney with Making False Statements to the FBI in 2016 Regarding Alleged Communications Between Trump Organization and Russian Bank|url=https://www.justice.gov/sco/pr/grand-jury-indicts-dc-attorney-making-false-statements-fbi-2016-regarding-alleged|access-date=2021-09-19|website=www.justice.gov|language=en}}</ref> 2016, lawyer Michael Sussmann briefed FBI legal counsel James Baker with information about online connections between the Trump Organization and russian Alfa Bank, delivering a thumb drive with digital information.<ref>{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=Evan Perez and Katelyn Polantz|title=Lawyer indicted on charges of lying to FBI as part of Durham probe into Trump-Russia investigation|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/16/politics/john-durham-probe-nears-end-trump-russia/index.html|access-date=2021-09-19|website=CNN}}</ref> Sussmann falsely stated to the General Counsel that he was not bringing these allegations to the FBI on behalf of any client, although he had retained as counsel of the National Democratic Comittee and the Hillary Clinton campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|title=In Durham probe, grand jury indicts attorney with ties to Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/durham-report-probe-michael-sussmann-attorney-clinton-campaign/|access-date=2021-09-19|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en-US}}</ref> On 2021, special counsel John Durham obtain from a federal jury an indictment against Sussmann for making false statements to the FBI.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Trump-Russia Probe's Special Counsel Has Charged A Lawyer With Lying To The FBI|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/09/16/1038035231/the-trump-russia-probe-special-counsel-has-charged-a-lawyer-with-lying-to-the-fb|access-date=2021-09-19|website=NPR.org|language=en}}</ref> Sussmann worked with an investigative firm and several cyber researchers to mine the data in order to establish a narrative of alleged ties between VIP from the Trump campaign and the Russia-based bank.<ref name=":0" />

On August 14th, 2020, lawyer Kevin Clinesmith admitted that he, while a FBI lawyer working on the Crossfire Hurricane Investigation, doctored an email to get the third extension of the FISA warrant against Carter Page on 2017. Clinesmith was later part of the Special Counsel Investigation of 2017-2019, but was later dismissed.<ref>{{Cite web|last=McBride|first=Jessica|date=2018-06-20|title=Kevin Clinesmith: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|url=https://heavy.com/news/2018/06/kevin-clinesmith-e/|access-date=2021-09-19|website=Heavy.com|language=en-US}}</ref> Clinesmith was convicted to one year of probation.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Trump-Russia Probe's Special Counsel Has Charged A Lawyer With Lying To The FBI|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/09/16/1038035231/the-trump-russia-probe-special-counsel-has-charged-a-lawyer-with-lying-to-the-fb|access-date=2021-09-19|website=NPR.org|language=en}}</ref>

title: George W. Bush
deleted: Bush opened the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in Salt Lake City, Utah. Departing from previous practice, he stood among a group of U.S. athletes rather than from a ceremonial stand or box, saying: "On behalf of a proud, determined, and grateful nation, I declare open the Games of Salt Lake City, celebrating the Olympic Winter Games."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/02/20020209-2.html |title=President Bush Opens 2002 Olympic Games |date=February 8, 2002 |access-date=June 23, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514195905/http://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/02/20020209-2.html |archive-date=May 14, 2011 |via=[[NARA|National Archives]] |work=[[whitehouse.gov]] |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2008, in the course of a good-will trip to Asia, he attended the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in Beijing.<ref>{{cite news |date=August 22, 2008 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/id/26131736 |title=Bush: Olympics exceeded my expectations |agency=Associated Press }}</ref>

Bush twice invoked [[Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution#Section 3: President's declaration of inability|Section{{nbs}}3 of the Twenty-fifth Amendment]], which allows a president to temporarily transfer the powers and duties of his office to the vice president, who then becomes [[Acting President of the United States|acting president]]. On June 29, 2002, Bush underwent a [[colonoscopy]] and invoked the provision, making Vice President Cheney the acting president. Bush was awake and resumed his presidential powers after two hours. On July 21, 2007, Bush again invoked the provision in preparation for another colonoscopy. Again, Bush resumed his presidential powers after two hours.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/acting_presidents.php |title=Acting Presidents Under the 25th Amendment |publisher=American Presidency Project |access-date=November 14, 2014}}</ref>

title: Scott Perry
deleted: Perry is a member of the [[Freedom Caucus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.rollcall.com/218/house-freedom-caucus-forms-fight-club/|title=House Freedom Caucus Forms 'Fight Club' in House|work=218|date=July 22, 2015|access-date=February 7, 2018|archive-date=March 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305072103/http://blogs.rollcall.com/218/house-freedom-caucus-forms-fight-club/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

In October 2017, in the aftermath of [[Hurricane Maria]], Perry accused [[CNN]] anchor [[Chris Cuomo]] of exaggerating the crisis in [[Puerto Rico]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tornoe |first1=Rob |title=Pa. congressman gets into heated argument with CNN host over Puerto Rico |url=https://www.inquirer.com/philly/news/politics/puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-trump-cnn-death-toll-scott-perry-20171012.html |date=October 12, 2017 |newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer |access-date=June 14, 2019 }}</ref>

In January 2018, Perry suggested that [[ISIS]] might have been involved in the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]]. ISIS claimed responsibility for the attack, but authorities have maintained that gunman [[Stephen Paddock]] acted alone.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/369672-gop-lawmaker-somethings-not-adding-up-on-las-vegas-shooting|title=GOP lawmaker: 'Something's not adding up' on Las Vegas shooting|last=Samuels|first=Brett|date=January 18, 2018|work=TheHill|access-date=January 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Pennsylvania's Rep. Scott Perry, on Fox News, suggested that the Las Vegas shooter had terrorist ties |url=https://www.post-gazette.com/news/politics-nation/2018/01/21/Pennsylvania-s-Rep-Scott-Perry-on-Fox-News-suggested-that-the-Las-Vegas-shooter-had-terrorist-ties/stories/201801210174 |access-date=20 October 2020 |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=January 21, 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Swenson |first1=Kyle |title=Channeling conspiracy theory, congressman says Las Vegas attack linked to 'possible terrorist nexus' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/01/19/channeling-conspiracy-theory-congressman-says-las-vegas-attack-linked-to-possible-terrorist-nexus/ |access-date=20 October 2020 |work=Washington Post |date=January 19, 2018}}</ref>

In December 2019, Perry was one of 195 Republicans to vote against both articles of [[First impeachment of Donald Trump|impeachment against President Trump]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/12/trump-impeached-house-members-vote-191217154034821.html |title=Trump is impeached: How did House members vote? |newspaper=Al Jazeera |date=December 19, 2019 |access-date=January 16, 2020 }}</ref>

In October 2020, Perry was one of 17 Republicans to vote against a House resolution to formally condemn the [[QAnon]] conspiracy theory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/sarahmimms/house-condemns-qanon-trump-death-threats-republicans?scrolla=5eb6d68b7fedc32c19ef33b4 |title=17 Republicans Voted Against Condemning QAnon After A Democrat Got Death Threats From Its Followers |date=October 2, 2020 |access-date=October 2, 2020 }}</ref> He said he voted against the resolution because he was concerned about infringements on free speech, saying, "it's very dangerous for the government ... to determine what is okay to like and what is not okay to like."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kornbluh |first1=Jacob |title=Rep. Scott Perry clarifies opposition to QAnon after vote against House condemnation |url=https://jewishinsider.com/2020/10/rep-scott-perry-clarifies-opposition-to-qanon-after-vote-against-house-condemnation/ |access-date=20 October 2020 |work=Jewish Insider |date=6 October 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Caruso |first1=Stephen |title=Perry and DePasquale clash over Obamacare, QAnon at second debate |url=https://www.penncapital-star.com/election-2020/perry-and-depasquale-exchange-words-over-obamacare-qanon-at-second-debate/ |access-date=20 October 2020 |work=Pennsylvania Capital-Star |date=20 October 2020}}</ref>

After the 2020 elections, Perry promoted false claims of fraud in the elections.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gorsegner|first=Michael|date=2020-11-10|title='Fraud does exist': Despite winning reelection, Rep. Perry believes count was fraudulent|url=https://local21news.com/news/local/fraud-does-exist-despite-winning-reelection-perry-believes-count-was-fraudulent|access-date=2021-01-07|website=WHP}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|last1=Benner|first1=Katie|last2=Edmondson|first2=Catie|date=2021-01-24|title=Pennsylvania Lawmaker Played Key Role in Trump's Plot to Oust Acting Attorney General|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/23/us/politics/scott-perry-trump-justice-department-election.html|access-date=2021-01-24|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

In December 2020, Perry was one of 126 Republican House members to sign an [[amicus brief]] in support of ''[[Texas v. Pennsylvania]]'', a lawsuit filed at the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] contesting the results of the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]], in which [[Joe Biden]] defeated<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blood|first1=Michael R.|last2=Riccardi|first2=Nicholas|date=December 5, 2020|title=Biden officially secures enough electors to become president|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-elections-electoral-college-3e0b852c3cfadf853b08aecbfc3569fa|url-status=live|access-date=December 12, 2020|website=[[Associated Press|AP News]]|archive-date=December 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208201209/https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-elections-electoral-college-3e0b852c3cfadf853b08aecbfc3569fa}}</ref> Trump. The Supreme Court declined to hear the case on the basis that Texas lacked [[Standing (law)|standing]] under [[Article Three of the United States Constitution|Article III of the Constitution]] to challenge the results of an election held by another state.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|author-link=Adam Liptak|date=2020-12-11|title=Supreme Court Rejects Texas Suit Seeking to Subvert Election|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/us/politics/supreme-court-election-texas.html|access-date=2020-12-12|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211234955/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/us/politics/supreme-court-election-texas.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Order in Pending Case|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121120zr_p860.pdf|date=2020-12-11|publisher=[[Supreme Court of the United States]]|access-date=December 11, 2020|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211234004/https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121120zr_p860.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/politics/read-house-republicans-texas-supreme-court/index.html|title=Brief from 126 Republicans supporting Texas lawsuit in Supreme Court|first=Daniella |last=Diaz|work=[[CNN]]|access-date=December 11, 2020|archive-date=December 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201212000435/https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/politics/read-house-republicans-texas-supreme-court/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

On January 6, 2021, Perry joined Missouri senator [[Josh Hawley]] in objecting to counting Pennsylvania's electoral votes in the 2020 presidential election.<ref>{{Cite news|agency=The Associated Press|date=2021-01-07|title=Rep. Scott Perry, Missouri senator object to Pa. electoral votes, triggering debate|url=https://www.pennlive.com/nation-world/2021/01/pa-rep-scott-perry-missouri-senator-object-to-pa-electoral-votes-triggering-debate.html|access-date=2021-01-07|work=PennLive}}</ref> During [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|the storming of the U.S. Capitol that day]], Perry and his congressional colleagues were ushered to a secure location.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/09/politics/republican-congress-members-refuse-masks-trnd/index.html |title=Republican members of Congress refuse to wear masks during Capitol insurrection |date=January 9, 2021 |work=CNN |first=Keri |last=Enriquez |access-date=January 11, 2021 }}</ref>

Perry reportedly played a role in a December 2020 crisis at the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] in which Trump considered firing acting attorney general [[Jeffrey A. Rosen]] and replacing him with [[Jeffrey Clark]], the acting chief of the civil division of the [[United States Department of Justice|DOJ]].<ref name=":0" /> ''The New York Times'' reported Perry introduced Clark to Trump because Clark's "openness to conspiracy theories about election fraud presented Mr. Trump with a welcome change from the acting attorney general, Jeffrey A. Rosen, who stood by the results of the election and had repeatedly resisted the president's efforts to undo them."<ref name=":0" /> Before the certification of the electoral college vote on January 6, Perry and Clark reportedly discussed a plan in which the Justice Department would send Georgia legislators a letter threatening an investigation into voter fraud and an invalidation of Georgia's electoral votes, even though the DOJ had investigated reports of fraud but found nothing significant, as attorney general [[Bill Barr]] had publicly announced weeks earlier.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news |first=Mike |last=Balsamo |url=https://apnews.com/article/barr-no-widespread-election-fraud-b1f1488796c9a98c4b1a9061a6c7f49d |title=Disputing Trump, Barr says no widespread election fraud |date=December 1, 2020 |work=AP NEWS}}</ref> Clark drafted a letter to Georgia officials and presented it to Rosen and his deputy [[Richard Donoghue]]. It claimed the DOJ had "identified significant concerns that may have impacted the outcome of the election in multiple States" and urged the Georgia legislature to convene a special session for the "purpose of considering issues pertaining to the appointment of Presidential Electors." Rosen and Donoghue rejected the proposal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/doj-officials-rejected-colleagues-request-intervene-georgias-election/story?id=79243198|title=DOJ officials rejected colleague's request to intervene in Georgia's election certification: Emails|website=ABC News}}</ref> In August 2021, CNN reported that [[Director of National Intelligence]] [[John Ratcliffe (American politician)|John Ratcliffe]] had briefed top Justice Department officials that no evidence had been found of any foreign powers' interference with voting machines. Clark was reportedly concerned that intelligence community analysts were withholding information and believed Perry and others knew more about possible foreign interference. Clark requested authorization from Rosen and Donoghue for another briefing from Ratcliffe, asserting that hackers had found "a [[Dominion Voting Systems|Dominion]] machine accessed the Internet through a smart thermostat with a net connection trail leading back to China."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Polantz |first1=Katelyn |last2=Cohen |first2=Zachary |last3=Perez |first3=Evan |title=How a Trump environmental lawyer tried to weaponize the Justice Department to help the President |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/06/politics/doj-clark-trump-election/index.html |access-date=August 7, 2021 |work=CNN |date=August 6, 2021}}</ref>

In March 2021, Perry voted against the [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 49|url=https://clerk.house.gov/evs/2021/roll049.xml#NV|url-status=live|access-date=2021-04-27|website=clerk.house.gov}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wtae.com/article/covid-19-relief-bill-how-pennsylvania-congress-members-voted/35800458 |title=COVID-19 relief bill passes: Here's how the Congress members from Pennsylvania voted |website=[[WTAE-TV]] |agency=The Associated Press |access-date=April 27, 2021 }}</ref> He said only 9% of the act's spending was allotted to defeat the COVID-19 virus, while the rest would advance Democratic policies.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ydr.com/story/opinion/2021/03/23/scott-perry-biden-bailout-bill-brings-long-term-taxpayer-pain/6967342002/ |title=Biden bailout bill brings long-term taxpayer pain |date=March 23, 2021 |work=York Daily Record |first=Scott |last=Perry |access-date=June 16, 2021 |url-access=limited }}</ref>

In April 2021, at a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee meeting, Perry said, "For many Americans, what seems to be happening or what they believe right now is happening is, what appears to them is we're replacing national-born American—native-born Americans to permanently transform the political landscape of this very nation." Philip Bump of ''The Washington Post'' criticized his comments.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bump |first1=Philip |title=Analysis {{!}} Tucker Carlson's toxic 'replacement' rhetoric gets picked up in the House |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/04/14/tucker-carlsons-toxic-replacement-rhetoric-gets-picked-up-house/ |access-date=27 April 2021 |work=Washington Post |date=April 14, 2021}}</ref>

In June 2021, Perry was one of 21 House Republicans to vote against a resolution to give the [[Congressional Gold Medal]] to police officers who defended the U.S. Capitol on [[2021 United States Capitol attack|January 6]].<ref name=twsCNN99078>{{cite news|first1=Annie|last1=Grayer|first2=Kristin|last2=Wilson|date=June 16, 2021|publisher=CNN|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/15/politics/congressional-gold-medal-house-vote/index.html|title=21 Republicans vote no on bill to award Congressional Gold Medal for January 6 police officers|access-date=June 16, 2021}}</ref> He cosponsored a bill, introduced the same day, that would give the same medal to police officers without mentioning the attack.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.yorkdispatch.com/story/news/local/2021/06/16/scott-perry-votes-against-awarding-medal-police-who-defended-capitol-jan-6/5294366001/ |title=Scott Perry votes against awarding medal to police who defended Capitol on Jan. 6 |date=June 16, 2021 |work=York Dispatch |first=Logan |last=Hullinger |access-date=June 16, 2021 |url-access=limited }}</ref>

At the June 2021 Republican Pennsylvania Leadership Conference, Perry said Democrats "are not the loyal opposition. They are the opposition to everything you love and believe in" and "want to destroy the country you grew up in", invoking comparisons to [[Nazism|Nazis]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/republican-congressman-nazi-democrats-video-b1872959.html|title=Republican congressman invokes Nazis as he argues Democrats hate 'everything you love and believe in'|date=June 25, 2021|website=The Independent}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/diaspora/antisemitism/republican-congressman-compares-democrats-to-nazi-in-recent-speech-672137|title=Republican congressman compares Democrats to Nazi in recent speech|website=The Jerusalem Post | JPost.com}}</ref>

title: John Durham
added: ==Personal life==

According to CNN, Durham is "press-shy" and is known for his tendency to avoid the media.<ref name="cnn"/> United States Attorney [[Deirdre Daly]] once described him as "tireless, fair and aggressive" while [[United States Senator]] [[Chris Murphy]] characterized him as "tough-nosed ... apolitical and serious".<ref name="cnn">{{cite news |last1=Cohen |first1=Marshall |title=US attorney’s ‘apolitical’ reputation on the line as he helps Barr review the Russia probe |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/05/14/politics/john-durham-barr-russia-probe/index.html |access-date=September 16, 2021 |work=[[CNN]] |date=May 14, 2019}}</ref>

title: John Durham
added: The only "evidence" of wrongdoing actually relied upon in the indictment are the allegation that the person to whom Attorney Sussman spoke, James Baker, does not remember Attorney Sussman stating who he represented and that purportedly contemporaneous notes indicate that Attorney Sussman stated that he was not reporting the allegations of Trump campaign ties to Russia on behalf of a client.  However, the notes themselves explicitly state that Attorney Sussman previously represented the DNC and Clinton Foundation.  The rest of the indictment reads like a conspiracy theory diatribe straight from the Fox News fever swamps, setting forth extraneous every fact not relevant to the actual charges brought that Attorney Durham believes will help establish a grand plot to create allegations of Trump campaign ties to Russia, feed them to the FBI and put Trump under investigation.  However, it alleges no facts that would establish any crimes other than the thin factual basis for the indictment against Attorney Sussman.

title: Kathy Hochul
added: {{Election box begin no change|title=May 24, 2011special election results

U.S. House of Representatives, NY-26<ref name="Hochul victory"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.ny.gov/NYSBOE/elections/2011/Special/26CDSpecialVoteResults.pdf|title=Official Election Results from the New York State Board of Elections|access-date=February 16, 2018}}</ref>}}

title: Kathy Hochul
added: On May 30, 2018, State Senate Democrats hoped to force a vote on an abortion rights bill known as the Reproductive Health Act. Hochul was prepared to cast a potential tiebreaking vote on a hostile amendment; with one Republican senator away from Albany on military duty, the Senate Republican Conference and the Senate Democratic conference each had 31 members in the chamber. However, Senate Republicans "abruptly shut down business and pulled all the bills for the day" when Hochul entered the Senate chamber. Hochul called the GOP’s actions "'reprehensible'" and "'cowardly'", adding, "'The governor and I are offended by the actions taken here today in the Senate'".<ref> https://www.wamc.org/new-york-news/2018-05-31/gridlock-and-finger-pointing-in-ny-senate </ref>

Hochul presided over the Senate chamber on June 5, 2018 when Senate Republicans called for the override of a veto by Gov. Andrew Cuomo of a bill relating to full-day kindergarten classes. The override passed by a large margin, and was the first veto override to occur during Cuomo's gubernatorial tenure.<ref> https://www.timesunion.com/news/article/Senate-touts-historic-override-of-governor-s-12969095.php </ref>

At a July 2018 rally with Planned Parenthood, Hochul called upon the Republican-led State Senate to reconvene in Albany for the purpose of passing abortion rights legislation. Hochul asserted that the potential confirmation of then-Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh made it necessary to pass abortion rights legislation.<ref>https://spectrumlocalnews.com/nys/buffalo/politics/2018/07/23/hochul-planned-parenthood-roe-v--wade</ref><ref>https://www.wbfo.org/local/2018-07-23/hochul-pushes-reproductive-health-act</ref>

title: 2021 United States elections
deleted: As part of the [[2020 United States Senate elections]], Georgia held run-off elections for both of its [[United States Senate|Senate]] seats on January 5, 2021. The run-off elections were triggered because of a Georgia law requiring a second round when no individual wins a majority of the vote in most federal, state, and local elections.{{efn|Georgia's run-off law applies to all races except for presidential elections.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sullivan |first1=Kate |last2=Levy |first2=Adam |title=These states have unique election rules |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/03/politics/unique-voting-laws-by-state/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=November 3, 2020}}</ref>}} Democrats [[Jon Ossoff]] and [[Raphael Warnock]] were the victors in those special elections, which gave the Democrats a total of 48 seats to the Republicans' 50. However, the victories resulted in a shift of power to the Democrats; the other two Senators, [[Bernie Sanders]] of Vermont and [[Angus King]] of Maine, are both [[Independent politician|independents]] who belong to the Democrats' [[caucus]], and since any tied vote is broken by the [[President of the Senate#United States|President of the Senate]] — in this case Vice President [[Kamala Harris]], also a Democrat — the Democrats technically hold a one-seat majority.

title: 2021 United States elections
deleted: The 2021 Virginia gubernatorial election was won by Glenn Youngkin in an enormous upset. For months, the liberal mainstream media had said the Virginia would never vote for a Republican and that Creepy Clintonite Terry McAuliffe would win in a rout, but they had no idea how much BACKLASH and OUTRAGE the Democrat party had stirred. All over the great Commonwealth, people were fed up with the far-left agenda of Joe Biden, the most unpopular and hated president in American history. While Joe and Terry were pushing Critical Race Theory, Virginians realized that Democrat socialist policies had wrecked the economy, skyrocketed inflation, and created shortages of anything and everything. Then, in an act of total desperation, Terry and his campaign disgracefully tried to slander Glenn Youngkin as a Neo-Nazi. The people of Virginia were not fooled by these lies, however, and Glenn won BIG, proving that a massive RED WAVE had begun for Republicans across the country!

title: Jake Corman
added: In the lead-up to the 2020 elections, Corman and other Republicans in the state legislature refused to implement changes that would allow Pennsylvania officials to process mail-in ballots before election day. As a result of the inaction, counting of ballots in Philadelphia took several days, leaving it unclear for days who had won the 2020 presidential election. After Joe Biden won the 2020 election and Donald Trump refused to concede while making false claims of fraud, Corman called for an audit of the election in Pennsylvania and called on Pennsylvania Secretary of State Kathy Boockvar to resign. He supported Republican efforts to obtain a wide range of data and personal information on voters to pursue baseless claims of fraud

title: Justice for J6 rally
deleted: In April 2021, both Senate Majority Whip Dick Durbin (D-IL) and Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) had denounced the treatment of the January 6th prisoners as abusive: “Solitary confinement is a form of punishment that is cruel and psychologically damaging,” Warren said, adding: “And we’re talking about people who haven’t been convicted of anything yet.” Warren also stated that she was “worried that law enforcement officials are deploying it to ‘punish’ the Jan. 6 defendants or to ‘break them so that they will cooperate.” Durbin added that such conditions should be a “rare exception."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/04/19/capitol-riot-defendants-warren-483125|title=Jan. 6 defendants win unlikely Dem champions as they face harsh detainment|publisher=Politico|last1=Cheney|first1=Kyle|last2=Desiderio|first2=Andrew|last3=Gerstein|first3=Josh|date=April 19, 2021|accessdate=October 20, 2021|url-status=live}}</ref>

In August, a rally titled "Justice for J6", organized by Look Ahead America, a [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] led by former Trump campaign staffer Matt Braynard, was scheduled to be held on the grounds of the U.S. Capitol starting at 12:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|ET]] on September 18. The rally was intended as a show of support for people charged for participating in the attack. Lawmakers and law enforcement officials expressed their concerns over possible unrest at the rally.<ref name="bckgrnd1">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/27/politics/renewed-fears-of-political-violence-grip-capitol-hill/index.html|title=Renewed fears of political violence grip Capitol Hill ahead of right-wing rally|publisher=CNN|last1=Zanona|first1=Melanie|last2=Wild|first2=Whitney|date=August 27, 2021|accessdate=September 6, 2021|archive-date=September 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210907145754/https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/27/politics/renewed-fears-of-political-violence-grip-capitol-hill/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="bckgrnd2">{{Cite news|last=LeBlanc|first=Paul|date=September 15, 2021|title=Here's everything we know about the September 18 right-wing rally in DC|work=CNN|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/15/politics/september-18-rally-capitol-security-explainer/index.html|access-date=September 16, 2021|archive-date=September 16, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210916102524/https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/15/politics/september-18-rally-capitol-security-explainer/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="bckgrnd3">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/06/politics/september-18-rally-dc-andrew-mccabe-cnntv/index.html|title=Ex-FBI official says law enforcement needs to take upcoming right-wing rally in DC 'very seriously'|publisher=CNN|last=LeBlanc|first=Paul|date=September 6, 2021|accessdate=September 6, 2021|archive-date=September 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210907025246/https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/06/politics/september-18-rally-dc-andrew-mccabe-cnntv/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>{{sp}}</onlyinclude>

Lawmakers and law enforcement officials expressed their concerns over possible unrest at the rally.<ref name="bckgrnd1">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/27/politics/renewed-fears-of-political-violence-grip-capitol-hill/index.html|title=Renewed fears of political violence grip Capitol Hill ahead of right-wing rally|publisher=CNN|last1=Zanona|first1=Melanie|last2=Wild|first2=Whitney|date=August 27, 2021|accessdate=September 6, 2021|archive-date=September 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210907145754/https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/27/politics/renewed-fears-of-political-violence-grip-capitol-hill/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="bckgrnd2">{{Cite news|last=LeBlanc|first=Paul|date=September 15, 2021|title=Here's everything we know about the September 18 right-wing rally in DC|work=CNN|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/15/politics/september-18-rally-capitol-security-explainer/index.html|access-date=September 16, 2021|archive-date=September 16, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210916102524/https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/15/politics/september-18-rally-capitol-security-explainer/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="bckgrnd3">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/06/politics/september-18-rally-dc-andrew-mccabe-cnntv/index.html|title=Ex-FBI official says law enforcement needs to take upcoming right-wing rally in DC 'very seriously'|publisher=CNN|last=LeBlanc|first=Paul|date=September 6, 2021|accessdate=September 6, 2021|archive-date=September 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210907025246/https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/06/politics/september-18-rally-dc-andrew-mccabe-cnntv/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>{{sp}}</onlyinclude>

title: Justice for J6 rally
added: Since the Justice for J6 rally, A DC judge inquired about the treatment of January 6th protestors. Once this inquiry went unfulfilled, District Judge Royce Lamberth held the warden in contempt. On October 18th, 2021, United States Marshalls visited D.C.'s Central Detention Facility to witness first hand the conditions of alleged January 6th protestors. <ref>{{Cite web|title=US marshals inspect DC jail and speak with Jan. 6 inmates|url=https://news.yahoo.com/us-marshals-inspect-dc-jail-210600746.html|access-date=2021-10-20|website=news.yahoo.com|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Justice for J6 rally
added: Matt Braynard  stated in interviews that the rally is “100% about #JusticeforJ6 and not the election or any candidate."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/572268-sept-18-rally-organizer-asks-attendees-not-to-wear-pro-trump|title=Sept. 18 rally organizer asks attendees not to wear pro-Trump clothing|publisher=The Hill|last=Schnell|first=Mychael|date=September 14, 2021|accessdate=October 22, 2021}}</ref>. The official Look Ahead America website discouraged attendees from wearing political gear, stating "Do not wear or bring political, candidate, or another organization’s paraphernalia. This includes clothing or banners supportive of President Trump or President Biden."<ref>https://lookaheadamerica.org/rally/</ref>

title: Andrew Yang
added: ==Founding of the Forward Party==

In Yang's 2021 book, ''Forward: Notes on the Future of Our Democracy'', he announced that he would be founding a new [[Third party (United States)|third party]], which would be named the Forward Party.<ref name="Forward">{{{Cite web|title=Andrew Yang's new 3rd party will be called 'The Forward Party,' according to his forthcoming book|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/andrew-yang-new-3rd-party-name-forward-party-book-2021-9|access-date=2021-09-23|website=[[Insider Inc.]]}}</ref> Yang founded the party under the premise that "Trust is fading ... Our political system is a fixed duopoly that will want to move slowly, if at all.".<ref name="Forward" /> The party's key principles include [[ranked-choice voting]], [[open primaries]], human-centered [[capitalism]] and [[universal basic income]].<ref name="Forward" />

title: Jason Miller (communications strategist)
added: ===Detainment in Brazil===

In September 2021, Miller and other American right-wing media personalities in his traveling party were detained and questioned for three hours at the international airport in [[Brasília]], [[Brazil]] before returning to the U.S. following participation in a [[Conservative_Political_Action_Conference#Brazil|CPAC Brasil Conference]]. The investigation was part of an inquiry by Brazilian Supreme Court Justice [[Alexandre de Moraes]] into misinformation allegedly perpetuated by the administration of President [[Jair Bolsonaro]]. Miller noted that Brazil was the second-largest market for Gettr and praised Bolsonaro’s supporters as "proud patriots".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sonmez |first1=Felicia |last2=McCoy |first2=Terrence |title=Former Trump adviser Jason Miller briefly detained in Brazil as political tumult grips country |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-jason-miller-brazil-bolsonaro/2021/09/07/a3422d10-0ff8-11ec-bc8a-8d9a5b534194_story.html |access-date=September 8, 2021 |publisher=Washington Post |date=September 7, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210908152218/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-jason-miller-brazil-bolsonaro/2021/09/07/a3422d10-0ff8-11ec-bc8a-8d9a5b534194_story.html |archive-date=September 8, 2021}}</ref>

title: Republican Party (United States)
added: == Sources ==

* {{cite book |last1=Badiou|first1=Alain |title=Trump |date=2019 |publisher=Polity Press|isbn=9781509536092|location=Cambridge, UK|edition=e-book|author1-link=Alain Badiou|quote=...we could speak of these new figures in terms of a kind of “democratic fascism,” a paradoxical but effective designation. After all, the [[Silvio Berlusconi|Berlusconis]], the [[Nicolas Sarkozy|Sarkozys]], the [[Marine Le Pen|Le Pens]], the Trumps, are operating inside the democratic apparatus, with its elections, its oppositions, its scandals, etc. But, within this apparatus, they are playing a different score, another music. This is certainly the case with Trump, who is racist, a male chauvinist, violent – all of which are fascist tendencies – but who, in addition, displays a contempt for logic and rationality and a muffled hatred of intellectuals. The music proper to this type of democratic fascism is a discourse that does not worry in the least bit about coherence, a discourse of impulse, comfortable with a few nighttime tweets, and that imposes a sort of dislocation of language, positively flaunting its ability to say everything and its opposite. For these new political figures, the aim of language is no longer to explain anything or to defend a point of view in an articulate manner. Its aim is to produce affects, which are used to create a fleetingly powerful unity, largely artificial but capable of being exploited in the moment.}}

* {{cite web |last1=Butler |first1=Judith|last2=Salmon|first2=Christian |date=December 29, 2016 |title=Trump, fascism, and the construction of "the people": An interview with Judith Butler |work=VersoBooks |publisher=Verso |url=https://www.versobooks.com/blogs/3025-trump-fascism-and-the-construction-of-the-people-an-interview-with-judith-butler |access-date=May 14, 2021|translator-last1=Broder |translator-first1=David |author-link1=Judith Butler |ref={{sfnRef|Butler|2016}} }}

* {{Cite news|last=Cockburn|first=Patrick|date=November 4, 2020|title=Trump's bid to stop the count risks turning America into an 'illiberal democracy' like Turkey|work=The Independent (U.K.)|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/trump-biden-us-election-erdogan-illiberal-democracy-b1591328.html|url-status=live|access-date=June 25, 2021 }}

* {{Cite news|last=Drutman|first=Lee|date=June 8, 2021|title=The Republican party is now an explicitly illiberal party|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/jun/08/american-democracy-fighting-for-its-life-republicans|url-status=live|access-date=June 25, 2021 }}

* {{cite magazine |last1=Foster |first= John Bellamy |date=June 1, 2017 |title= This Is Not Populism |magazine= [[Monthly Review]] |publisher= New York University Press |url=https://monthlyreview.org/2017/06/01/this-is-not-populism/ |access-date=May 14, 2015|quote=Commenting on the hegemonic framing of the radical right as populist, and the analytical problems that it presents, Andrea Mammone observes in his ''Transnational Neofascism in France and Italy'' that "the terms populism and national populism" were deliberately introduced in recent decades by liberal European commentators in order to "replace fascism/neofascism as the used terminology." This move was designed to "provide a sort of political and democratic legitimization of right-wing extremism."}}

* {{cite journal |last1=Giroux|first1=Henry A. |date=2021 |title= Trumpism and the challenge of critical education |journal=Educational Philosophy and Theory |author-link1= Henry Giroux |doi= 10.1080/00131857.2021.1884066| page=5|quote=As the social state came under severe attack, the punishing state grew with its ongoing militarization of civil society and its increasing criminalization of social problems. War, dehumanization, divisiveness, hate, and the language of racial cleansing and sorting became central governing principles and set the stage for the rebirth of an updated fascist politics. Trumpism reached into every niche and crack of civil and political society and in doing so cross-pollinated politics, culture, and everyday life with a range of right-wing policies, authoritarian impulses, and the emerging presence of right-wing movements.}}

* {{Cite news|last=Ibish|first=Hussain|date=April 12, 2020|title=Is Donald Trump's US sliding towards illiberal democracy?|work=The National (Abu Dhabi)|url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/opinion/comment/is-donald-trump-s-us-sliding-towards-illiberal-democracy-1.1005011|url-status=live|access-date=June 25, 2021 }}

* {{cite book |last1=Traverso|first1=Enzo |title=The New Faces of Fascism |date=2017 |publisher=Verso |isbn=978-1-78873-046-4|location=Brooklyn, NY|author1-link=Enzo Traverso|quote=‘Populism’ is a category used as a self-defence mechanism by political elites who stand ever further from the people. According to [[Jacques Rancière]]: "Populism is the convenient name under which is [[wikt:dissimulation|dissimulated]] the exacerbated contradiction between popular legitimacy and expert legitimacy, that is, the difficulty the government of science has in adapting itself to manifestations of democracy and even to the mixed form of representative system. This name at once masks and reveals the intense wish of the [[oligarchy|oligarch]]: to govern without people, in other words, without any dividing of the people; to govern without politics.}}
