deleted: In 2013, Barron was recruited by the American Bar Association Death Penalty Representation Project to handle, pro bono, the appeal in ''Isaiah McCoy v. State of Delaware,'' in which McCoy was convicted of capital murder and sentenced to death. On appeal before the Delaware Supreme Court, the Court decided, unanimously, to reverse McCoy's convictions and death sentence based on prosecutorial misconduct and voir dire error.<ref>{{cite web |title=Isaiah W. McCoy v. State of Delaware |url=https://courts.delaware.gov/opinions/download.aspx?ID=217920 |website=courts.delaware.gov |publisher=The Delaware Judiciary |access-date=July 26, 2021 |date=January 20, 2015}}</ref> The original prosecutor on the case was suspended for his misconduct in the case.<ref>{{cite web |title=Matter of a Member of the Bar: Favata |url=https://courts.delaware.gov/opinions/download.aspx?ID=227320 |website=courts.delaware.gov |publisher=The Delaware Judiciary |access-date=July 26, 2021 |date=July 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://deathpenaltyinfo.org/news/delaware-prosecutor-suspended-for-misconduct-in-capital-trial |title=Delaware Prosecutor Suspended for Misconduct in Capital Trial |website=deathpenaltyinfo.org |publisher=[[Death Penalty Information Center]] |access-date=July 26, 2021 |date=July 29, 2015}}</ref> On remand, McCoy was acquitted on all charges after a bench trial.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/crime/2017/01/19/not-guilty-former-death-row-inmate-go-free/96786930/ |title=Former death row inmate goes free after acquittal |first=Jessica Masulli |last=Reyes |newspaper=[[The News Journal]] |location=[[Wilmington, Delaware]] |access-date=July 26, 2021 |date=January 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |first=Maurice |last=Possley |url=https://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=5081 |title=Isaiah McCoy |publisher=[[National Registry of Exonerations]] |website=www.law.umich.edu |access-date=July 26, 2021 |date=February 3, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://deathpenaltyinfo.org/news/isaiah-mc-coy-exonerated-from-delaware-death-row-the-157th-death-row-exoneration-since-1973 |title=Isaiah McCoy Exonerated from Delaware Death Row, the 157th Death Row Exoneration Since 1973 |website=deathpenaltyinfo.org |publisher=Death Penalty Information Center |access-date=July 26, 2021 |date=January 20, 2017}}</ref>

title: James Madison
added: Retrospectively, in 1974, historian James Banner criticized Madison for his protection of a corrupt General [[James Wilkinson]] in the Army. Wilkinson had been involved in the [[Burr Conspiracy|Aaron Burr conspiracy]] during the Jefferson Administration, was on retainer of Spain, and had a high mortality rate among soldiers. Wilkinson had also botched a campaign during the [[War of 1812]]. Madison finally mustered Wilkinson out of the Army in 1815.{{sfn|Banner Jr.|1974|pp=35–37, 45}}

title: James Madison
deleted: Madison was small in stature, had bright blue eyes, a strong demeanor, and was known to be humorous at small gatherings. Madison suffered from serious illnesses, nervousness, and was often exhausted after periods of stress. Madison often feared for the worst and was a [[hypochondriac]]. However, Madison was in good health, while he lived a long life, without the common maladies of his times.{{sfn|Ketcham|2002|p=58}}

1964 United States presidential election
added: Meanwhile, President Johnson was concerned he could lose the election by appearing soft on Communism.<ref>Karnow (1983, p. 371).</ref> On July 10 the [[USS Maddox (DD-731)|USS ''Maddox'']] was ordered into the [[Gulf of Tonkin]], authorized to "maintain contact with the U.S. military command in Saigon ... and arrange 'such communications ... as may be desired.'"<ref>Karnow (1983, p. 366).</ref> On July 30, South Vietnamese commandos tried to attack the North Vietnamese radar station on the island of Hon Me,<ref>Karnow (1983, p=367).</ref> with the USS ''Maddox'' sufficiently close that the North Vietnamese believed it was there to provide cover for that commando raid.<ref>Karnow (1983, p. 370).</ref> North Vietnam filed an official complaint with the [[International Control Commission]], accusing the United States of being behind the raid.<ref>Karnow (1983, p. 367).</ref> On August 2, the ''Maddox'' reported having been attacked by three North Vietnamese Navy torpedo boats.<ref>Moise (1996, pp. 50, 78).</ref> Johnson called Soviet Premier Khrushchev, saying the US did not want war and asking the Soviets to convince North Vietnam to not attack American warships.<ref>Karnow (1983, p. 368-369).</ref> The next day, August 3, South Vietnamese raided Cape Vinhson and Cua Ron.<ref>Karnow(1983, p. 370)</ref> That night in the middle of a thunderstorm, the ''Maddox'' intercepted radio messages that gave them "the 'impression' that Communist parol boats were bracing for an assault."  They called for air support from the [[USS Ticonderoga (CV-14)|USS ''Ticonderoga'']].  The pilots didn't see anything, but the ''Maddox'' and the nearby [[USS Turner Joy|USS ''Turner Joy'']] started shooting in all directions.  However, after the incident, all US personnel involved acknowledge they had neither seen nor heard Communist gunfire. Nevertheless, Johnson and an aide Kenneth O'Donnell agreed that Johnson "would have to respond firmly to defend himself against Goldwater and the Republican right wing." Johnson denounced the attack as "unprovoked" and [[Gulf of Tonkin Resolution|secured essentially a blank check to do anything he thought necessary in Vietnam]], and left Goldwater looking like an irresponsible hawk.<ref>Karnow (1983, pp. 368-374). Moïse (1996) noted that the Johnson administration did not ''intentionally'' fake the incident.  However, it's clear that Johnson was under pressure to do something, the attacks that actually occurred earlier were ''not'' "unprovoked", as Johnson claimed, and once he had taken action, he could not easily admit that the evidence was overstated.</ref>

title: Links between Trump associates and Russian officials
deleted: On September 16, 2021, Grand Jury indicted [[Michael Sussmann|Michael A. Sussmann]], a Washington, D.C.-based attorney with making false statements to the FBI in 2016 regarding alleged communications between [[The Trump Organization|Trump Organization]] and [[Alfa-Bank|Alfa Bank]], an allegedly Russian Government-linked financial institution.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|last=Goldman|first=Adam|last2=Savage|first2=Charlie|date=2021-09-17|title=A prominent lawyer pleads not guilty in the inquiry examining the Russia investigation.|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/17/us/politics/michael-sussman-russia-investigation.html|access-date=2021-09-26|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|date=2021-09-16|title=Grand Jury Indicts D.C. Attorney with Making False Statements to the FBI in 2016 Regarding Alleged Communications Between Trump Organization and Russian Bank|url=https://www.justice.gov/sco/pr/grand-jury-indicts-dc-attorney-making-false-statements-fbi-2016-regarding-alleged|access-date=2021-09-26|website=www.justice.gov|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Sussmann Indictment.pdf {{!}} Department of Justice|url=https://www.justice.gov/sco/press-release/file/1433511|access-date=2021-09-26|website=www.justice.gov}}</ref> The indictment alleged "that researchers were tasked to mine this internet data to establish “an inference” and “narrative” that would tie then-presidential candidate Donald Trump to Russia."<ref name=":2" /> It is further alleged that Sussmann falsely stated "he was not bringing these allegations to the FBI on behalf of any client", even though he "coordinated with representatives and agents of the [[Hillary Clinton 2016 presidential campaign|Clinton Campaign]] in these efforts".<ref name=":2" /> The FBI ultimately found no sufficient evidence to support the allegations of secret communication between the Trump Organization and Alfa Bank and thus [[Robert Mueller|Robert S. Mueller III]] did not use the matter in his final report to the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] on March 22, 2019.<ref name=":1" />

title: Links between Trump associates and Russian officials
deleted: In January 2021, an FBI agent, Kevin Clinesmith was sentenced on a probation for intentionally altering an internal FBI email and creating a false record in order to seeking a court's permission to continue government surveillance of former Trump campaign official Carter Page in 2016 and 2017.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title=Ex-FBI lawyer to plead guilty to falsifying claim made to continue surveillance of key figure in Mueller probe|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/justice-department/ex-fbi-lawyer-plead-guilty-falsifying-claim-made-continue-surveillance-n1236767|access-date=2021-09-26|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|last=Department|first=Pete WilliamsPete Williams is an NBC News correspondent who covers the Justice|last2=Court|first2=the Supreme|last3=Washington|first3=based in|title=Ex-FBI lawyer gets probation for falsifying Carter Page surveillance application|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/justice-department/ex-fbi-lawyer-gets-probation-falsifying-carter-page-surveillance-application-n1256179|access-date=2021-09-26|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|last=Lucas|first=Ryan|date=2021-01-29|title=Ex-FBI Lawyer Sentenced To Probation For Actions During Russia Investigation|language=en|work=NPR|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/01/29/962140325/ex-fbi-lawyer-sentenced-to-probation-for-actions-during-russia-investigation|access-date=2021-09-26}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|title=Ex-FBI lawyer avoids prison after admitting he doctored email in investigation of Trump’s 2016 campaign|language=en-US|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/kevin-clinesmith-fbi-john-durham/2021/01/28/b06e061c-618e-11eb-afbe-9a11a127d146_story.html|access-date=2021-09-26|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|last=Savage|first=Charlie|date=2021-01-29|title=Ex-F.B.I. Lawyer Who Altered Email in Russia Case Is Sentenced to Probation|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/29/us/politics/kevin-clinesmith-probation.html|access-date=2021-09-26|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential election
deleted: As ballots were still being counted two days after Election Day, Trump asserted without evidence that there was "tremendous corruption and fraud going on", adding: "If you count the legal votes, I easily win. If you count the illegal votes, they can try to steal the election from us."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dale|first=Daniel|date=November 5, 2020|title=Fact check: Trump delivers most dishonest speech of his presidency as Biden closes in on victory|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/05/politics/fact-check-trump-speech-thursday-election-rigged-stolen/index.html|work=CNN}}</ref> Trump has repeatedly claimed that the results of mail-in ballots showing significantly more support for Biden is suspicious.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Boehm|first1=Eric|date=November 5, 2020|title=Trump Says Mail-in Votes Are Suspicious Because They Overwhelmingly Favor Joe Biden. He's Wrong.|url=https://reason.com/2020/11/05/trump-says-mail-in-votes-are-suspicious-because-they-overwhelmingly-favor-joe-biden-hes-wrong/|access-date=November 11, 2020|work=Reason}}</ref> This is a common phenomenon known as the [[Blue shift (politics)|blue shift]], since more Democrats than Republicans tend to vote by mail, and mail ballots are counted after Election Day in many states. Leading up to the 2020 election, the effect was predicted to be even greater than usual, as Trump's attacks on mail-in voting may have deterred Republicans from casting mail ballots.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wasserman|first1=Dave|date=November 4, 2020|title=Beware the 'blue mirage' and the 'red mirage' on election night|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/beware-blue-mirage-red-mirage-election-night-n1245925|access-date=November 11, 2020|work=NBC News}}</ref>

Many claims of purported voter fraud were discovered to be true . In Fulton County, Georgia the number of votes affected was 342, with no breakdown of which candidates they were for.<ref>{{cite web|date=November 7, 2020|title=UPDATE: Fulton County ballot scanning issue affected just 342 votes|url=https://www.wsbtv.com/news/politics/update-fulton-county-ballot-scanning-issue-affected-just-342-votes/W5OF32LWFRFFXGOHQ365UVQAOA/|access-date=November 11, 2020|work=WSBTV}}</ref> A [[viral video]] of a Pennsylvania poll worker filling out a ballot was found to be a case of a damaged ballot being replicated to ensure proper counting, while a video claimed to show a man taking ballots illegally to a [[Detroit]] counting center was found to be actually depicting a photographer transporting his equipment.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Iati|first1=Marisa|last2=Usero|first2=Adriana|title=A viral video implied a man was illegally moving ballots. It was a photographer and his equipment.|work=The Washington Post|date=November 5, 2020|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/11/05/video-claiming-detroit-ballot-fraud-debunked/|access-date=November 11, 2020|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pennsylvania poll worker was copying information from a damaged ballot, to ensure it was counted|url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/nov/06/facebook-posts/pennsylvania-poll-worker-was-copying-information-d/|access-date=November 11, 2020|date=November 6, 2020|last1=O'Rourke|first1=Clara|website=Politifact}}</ref> Another video of a poll watcher being turned away in [[Philadelphia]] was found to be real, but the poll watcher had subsequently been allowed inside after a misunderstanding had been resolved.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fauzia|first=Miriam|title=Fact check: Poll watcher turned away at Philadelphia polling station in misunderstanding|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/11/03/fact-check-philadelphia-poll-watcher-turned-away-mistake/6144601002/|access-date=November 11, 2020|date=November 3, 2020|website=USA Today}}</ref> A tweet that went viral claimed 14,000 votes in [[Wayne County, Michigan]], were cast by dead people, but the list of names included was found to be incorrect.<ref>{{cite web|title=List does not show over 14,000 dead people cast ballots in Michigan's Wayne County|url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/nov/07/tweets/list-does-not-show-over-14000-dead-people-cast-bal/|access-date=November 11, 2020|date=November 6, 2020|last1=Hendrickson|first1=Clara|website=Politifact}}</ref> The Trump campaign and [[Tucker Carlson]] also claimed a James Blalock had voted in Georgia despite having died in 2006, though his 94-year-old widow had registered and voted as Mrs. James E. Blalock.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Keefe |first1=Brendan |title=Two accused 'dead' Georgia voters very much alive despite claims – and they voted legally|url=https://www.11alive.com/article/news/politics/elections/2-georgians-accused-of-being-dead-and-voting-are-alive/85-88dff3c1-8e78-4ac2-ae9c-96838e5b02a8 |work=11Alive News|location=Atlanta, Georgia|date=November 13, 2020}}</ref> In [[Erie, Pennsylvania]], a postal worker who claimed the postmaster had instructed postal workers to backdate ballots mailed after Election Day later admitted he had fabricated the claim. Prior to his recantation, Republican senator [[Lindsey Graham]] cited the claim in a letter to the Justice Department calling for an investigation, and the worker was praised as a patriot on a [[GoFundMe]] page created in his name that raised $136,000.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Boburg|first1=Shawn|last2=Bogage|first2=Jacob|title=Postal worker recanted allegations of ballot tampering, officials say|date=November 10, 2020|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/postal-worker-fabricated-ballot-pennsylvania/2020/11/10/99269a7c-2364-11eb-8599-406466ad1b8e_story.html|access-date=November 11, 2020|website=The Washington Post}}</ref>

Days after Biden had been declared the winner, White House press secretary [[Kayleigh McEnany]] asserted without evidence that the Democratic Party was welcoming fraud and illegal voting.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Izadi|first1=Elahe|last2=Ellison|first2=Sarah|date=November 9, 2020|title=Fox News cuts away from Kayleigh McEnany news conference after she alleges vote fraud with no evidence|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/media/2020/11/09/fox-news-kayleigh-mcenany-cut-away-fraud/|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Republican former speaker of the House [[Newt Gingrich]] stated on Fox News, "I think that it is a corrupt, stolen election."<ref>{{cite news|last=Broadwater|first=Luke|date=November 8, 2020|title=As Biden Plans Transition, Republicans Decline to Recognize His Election|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/08/us/politics/republicans-trump-concede-election.html|website=The New York Times}}</ref> Appearing at a [[Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference|press conference outside a Philadelphia landscaping business]] as Biden was being declared the winner, Trump's personal attorney [[Rudy Giuliani]] asserted without evidence that hundreds of thousands of ballots were questionable.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shannon|first1=Joel|last2=Ciavaglia|first2=Jo|last3=McGinnis|first3=James|date=November 8, 2020|title=Giuliani holds press conference at landscaping business, prompting confusion|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/11/07/giuliani-holds-press-conference-four-seasons-total-landscaping/6209235002/|website=USA Today}}</ref> Responding to Giuliani, a spokesperson for Pennsylvania Attorney General [[Josh Shapiro]] said "Many of the claims against the commonwealth have already been dismissed, and repeating these false attacks is reckless. No active lawsuit even alleges, and no evidence presented so far has shown, widespread problems."<ref name="NY Times Officials" />

One week after the election, Republican [[Philadelphia City Commissioners|Philadelphia city commissioner]] Al Schmidt said he had not seen any evidence of widespread fraud, stating, "I have seen the most fantastical things on social media, making completely ridiculous allegations that have no basis in fact at all and see them spread." He added that his office had examined a list of dead people who purportedly voted in Philadelphia but "not a single one of them voted in Philadelphia after they died." Trump derided Schmidt, tweeting, "He refuses to look at a mountain of corruption & dishonesty. We win!"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stracqualursi|first1=Veronica|date=November 11, 2020|title=Republican election official in Philadelphia says he's seen no evidence of widespread fraud|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/11/politics/philadelphia-city-commissioner-2020-election-cnntv/index.html|work=CNN}}</ref>

Attorneys who brought accusations of voting fraud or irregularities before judges were unable to produce actual evidence to support the allegations. In one instance, a Trump attorney sought to have ballot counting halted in Detroit on the basis of a claim by a Republican poll watcher that she had been told by an unidentified person that ballots were being backdated; [[Michigan Court of Appeals]] judge [[Cynthia Stephens]] dismissed the argument as "inadmissible hearsay within hearsay".<ref>{{cite web|last=Blake|first=Aaron|date=November 12, 2020|title=Trump lawyers suffer embarrassing rebukes from judges over voter fraud claims|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/11/11/trump-lawyers-suffer-embarrassing-rebukes-judges-over-voter-fraud-claims/|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Klasfield|first1=Adam|date=November 5, 2020|title='Come on Now': Michigan Judge Scoffs at and Tosses Trump Campaign Lawsuit Backed by 'Hearsay' Evidence|url=https://lawandcrime.com/2020-election/come-on-now-michigan-judge-scoffs-at-and-tosses-trump-campaign-lawsuit-backed-by-hearsay-evidence/|website=Law & Crime}}</ref> Some senior attorneys at law firms working on Trump's behalf, notably [[Jones Day]], expressed concerns that they were helping to undermine the integrity of American elections by advancing arguments lacking evidence.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Silver-Greenberg|first1=Jessica|last2=Abrams|first2=Rachel|last3=Enrich|first3=David|date=November 9, 2020|title=Growing Discomfort at Law Firms Representing Trump in Election Lawsuits|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/09/business/jones-day-trump-election-lawsuits.html|work=The New York Times}}</ref>

Trump and his lawyers Giuliani and [[Sidney Powell]] repeatedly made the false claim that the [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]-based firm [[Dominion Voting Systems]], which had supplied voting machines for 27 states, was a "[[communist]]" organization controlled by billionaire [[George Soros]], former Venezuelan president [[Hugo Chávez]] (who died in 2013), or the [[Chinese Communist Party]], and that the machines had "stolen" hundreds of thousands of votes from Trump. The false claims about the company circulated on social media, amplified by more than a dozen tweets or retweets by Trump. The [[disinformation]] campaign prompted threats and harassment against Dominion employees.<ref>

* {{cite web|url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/11/trumps-dominion-vote-fraud-election-conspiracy-theory-crazy.html|title=Trump's New Vote Fraud Theory Is So Much Crazier Than You Realize|work=New York Intelligencer|last1=Chait|first1=Jonathan|date=November 16, 2020 |ref=none}}

* {{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-trump-legal-team-false-claims-5abd64917ef8be9e9e2078180973e8b3|title=AP FACT CHECK: Trump legal team's batch of false vote claims|work=Associated Press|last1=Swenson|first1=Ali|date=November 19, 2020 |ref=none}}

* {{cite news|author=Olivia Rubin, Lucien Bruggeman & Matthew Mosk|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/dominion-employees-latest-face-threats-harassment-wake-trump/story?id=74288442|work=ABC News|title=Dominion employees latest to face threats, harassment in wake of Trump conspiracy|date=November 19, 2020 |ref=none}}

* {{cite news|title=Dominion Voting CEO says Antrim County report part of 'reckless disinformation campaign'|url=https://www.freep.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/15/dominion-voting-ceo-antrim-county/3906017001/|newspaper=Detroit Free Press|author=Paul Egan|date=December 15, 2020 |ref=none}}

* {{cite news|author1=Lori Robertson|author2=Eugene Kiely|author3=Jessica McDonald|author4=D'Angelo Gore|title=Trump Repeats Baseless, False Claims About the Election|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/11/trump-repeats-baseless-false-claims-about-the-election/|work=FactCheck.org|date=December 1, 2020 |ref=none}}</ref>

A December 2020 poll showed 77% of Republicans believe widespread fraud occurred during the election. 35% of independent voters also said they believe widespread voter fraud took place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/quinnipiac-poll-77-republicans-believe-204100654.html |title=Quinnipiac Poll: 77% of Republicans believe there was widespread fraud in the presidential election; 60% overall consider Joe Biden's victory legitimate |work=Yahoo! News|last1=Keating|first1=Christopher|via=Hartford Courant |date=December 10, 2020 |access-date=December 15, 2020}}</ref> Overall, 60% of Americans believed Biden's win was legitimate, 34% did not, and 6% were unsure. Another poll taken in late December showed a similar result, with 62% of Americans polled believing Biden was the legitimate winner of the election, while 37% did not.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/12/24/donald-trump-failed-president-50-usa-today-poll-say/3926190001/|title=Exclusive: As Trump leaves office, 50% of Americans say he'll be seen as 'failed' president|last1=Page|first1=Susan|last2=Elbeshbishi|first2=Sarah|date=December 24, 2020|website=USA Today}}</ref> This split in popular opinion remained largely stable, with a January 10, 2021, poll commissioned by ABC News showing 68% of Americans believed Biden's win was legitimate and 32% did not.<ref>{{cite web|date=January 10, 2021|title=ABC News/Ipsos Poll Jan 10|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/490283649/ABC-News-Ipsos-Poll-Jan-10|access-date=January 11, 2021|website=Scribd|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> These numbers remained largely stagnant, with a June 2021 poll from Monmouth showing 61% believed Biden won fair and square, 32% believed he won due to fraud, and 7% were unsure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.monmouth.edu/polling-institute/reports/monmouthpoll_us_062121/|title=Public Supports Both Early Voting And Requiring Photo ID to Vote|first=Monmouth University 400 Cedar AvenueWest Long|last=BranchNJ07764732.571.3400}}</ref>

Motivated by the myth of widespread fraud, Republican state lawmakers initiated a [[Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election|push to make voting laws more restrictive]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Wines|first=Michael|date=27 February 2021|title=In Statehouses, Stolen-Election Myth Fuels a G.O.P. Drive to Rewrite Rules|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/27/us/republican-voter-suppression.html|website=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>

title: Woodrow Wilson
deleted: In 1917, the U.S. finally acquired by purchase the [[Danish Virgin Islands]], which was justified for security reasons of keeping a potential base of German activity in the Western Hemisphere as World War I raged.<ref>Loveman, Brian. ''No Higher Law: American Foreign Policy and the Western Hemisphere since 1776''. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press 2010, 195.</ref>

title: Woodrow Wilson
added: Wilson took office during the [[Mexican Revolution]], which had begun in 1911 after liberals overthrew the military dictatorship of [[Porfirio Díaz]]. Shortly before Wilson took office, conservatives retook power through a coup led by [[Victoriano Huerta]].<ref>Clements (1992), pp. 96–97</ref> Wilson rejected the legitimacy of Huerta's "government of butchers" and demanded Mexico hold democratic elections.<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 1007454|title = Woodrow Wilson, Victoriano Huerta, and the Recognition Issue in Mexico|journal = The Americas|volume = 41|issue = 2|pages = 151–176|last1 = Henderson|first1 = Peter V. N.|year = 1984|doi = 10.2307/1007454}}</ref> After Huerta arrested U.S. Navy personnel who had accidentally landed in a restricted zone near the northern port town of [[Tampico]], Wilson [[United States occupation of Veracruz|dispatched the Navy to occupy]] the Mexican city of [[Veracruz]]. A strong backlash against the American intervention among Mexicans of all political affiliations convinced Wilson to abandon his plans to expand the U.S. military intervention, but the intervention nonetheless helped convince Huerta to flee from the country.<ref>Clements (1992), pp. 98–99</ref> A group led by [[Venustiano Carranza]] established control over a significant proportion of Mexico, and Wilson recognized Carranza's government in October 1915.<ref name="Clements (1992), pp. 99–100">Clements (1992), pp. 99–100</ref>

Carranza continued to face various opponents within Mexico, including [[Pancho Villa]], whom Wilson had earlier described as "a sort of [[Robin Hood]]."<ref name="Clements (1992), pp. 99–100"/> In early 1916, Pancho Villa raided the village of [[Columbus, New Mexico]], killing or wounding dozens of Americans and causing an enormous nationwide American demand for his punishment. Wilson ordered General [[John J. Pershing]] and 4,000 troops across the border to capture Villa. By April, Pershing's forces had broken up and dispersed Villa's bands, but Villa remained on the loose and Pershing continued his pursuit deep into Mexico. Carranza then pivoted against the Americans and accused them of a punitive invasion, leading to several incidents that nearly led to war. Tensions subsided after Mexico agreed to release several American prisoners, and bilateral negotiations began under the auspices of the Mexican-American Joint High Commission. Eager to withdraw from Mexico due to tensions in Europe, Wilson ordered Pershing to withdraw, and the last American soldiers left in February 1917.<ref>Link (1964), 194–221, 280–318; Link (1965), 51–54, 328–339</ref>

title: Woodrow Wilson
deleted: Carranza continued to face various opponents within Mexico, including his former ally, General [[Pancho Villa]], whom Wilson had earlier described as "a sort of [[Robin Hood]]."<ref name="Clements (1992), pp. 99–100"/> In early 1916, having been soundly beaten by Carranza's best general in 1915, Villa's army disintegrated, but still Villa operated in northern Mexico. He raided the town of [[Columbus, New Mexico]], killing or wounding dozens of civilian residents and causing an enormous nationwide American demand for his punishment. Wilson ordered General [[John J. Pershing]] and 4,000 troops across the border to capture Villa, violating Mexico's territorial sovereignty. By April, Pershing's forces had broken up and dispersed Villa's bands, but Villa remained at liberty in his home territory. Pershing continued his pursuit deep into Mexico. Carranza  accused the U.S. of a punitive invasion, leading to several incidents that nearly led to war. Tensions subsided after Mexico agreed to release several American prisoners, and bilateral negotiations began under the auspices of the Mexican-American Joint High Commission. Eager to withdraw from Mexico without capturing of killing Villa as tensions rose in Europe, Wilson ordered Pershing to withdraw, and the last U.S. Army personnel left Mexico in February 1917.<ref>Link (1964), 194–221, 280–318; Link (1965), 51–54, 328–339</ref>

title: Wendy Rogers (politician)
added: ===="Thooperman"==== On Oct.11, 2021, following DC Comic's announcement that Jon Kent, the son of Superman and Lois Lane, was bisexual, Rogers posted a tweet stating "Superman loves Louis Lane. Period. Hollywood is trying to make Superman gay and he is not. Just rename the new version Thooperman so we can all know the difference and avoid seeing it."<ref>{{https://twitter.com/WendyRogersAZ/status/1447666540732637190?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1447666540732637190%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediaite.com%2Fnews%2Farizona-republican-ridiculed-for-tweet-declaring-bisexual-superman-is-supposed-to-love-louis-lane%2F}}.  Opponents were quick to point out 1) the irony that Rogers misnamed Lois Lane as "Louis Lane," a masculin name; and that 2) It is Jon Kent, not Clark Kent, who is bisexual, and thaqt a relationship with Lois Lane would be incestuous.  Rogers was also called out for the lisping steriotype.

title: Scott Atlas
deleted: From 1998 to 2012, Atlas was Professor and Chief of Neuroradiology at [[Stanford University Medical Center]] in [[California]]. He trained more than 100 neuroradiology fellows in his teaching career.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |title=Scott W. Atlas' Profile |url=https://profiles.stanford.edu/Scott_Atlas |website=Stanford |language=en}}</ref> According to the [[American Board of Radiology]], he is board certified in diagnostic radiology, while his certification in neuroradiology lapsed in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |title=Verify Board Certification Status |url=https://www.theabr.org/myabr/find-a-radiologist?fn=scott&ln=atlas |website=The American Board of Radiology |access-date=16 November 2020}}</ref>

He is the editor of ''Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the Brain and Spine'', a 2,000-page illustrated textbook with 83 contributors.<ref>{{Cite journal|publisher=American Society of Neuroradiology|date=May 1, 2009|title=Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the Brain and Spine, 4th ed., Vol. 1 and 2|url=http://www.ajnr.org/content/30/5/e76|journal=American Journal of Neuroradiology|language=en|volume=30|issue=5|pages=e76–e77|doi=10.3174/ajnr.A1553|issn=0195-6108|doi-access=free}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Alexander|first1=Joseph T.|last2=Hair|first2=Regis W.|date=October 1, 1997|title=Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the Brain and Spine, Second Edition|url=https://academic.oup.com/neurosurgery/article/41/4/989/2915691|journal=Neurosurgery|language=en|volume=41|issue=4|pages=989–990|doi=10.1097/00006123-199710000-00053|issn=0148-396X}}</ref> He has also written four books on health care policy.<ref name="Hoover"/>

Atlas is the Robert Wesson Senior Fellow at the [[Hoover Institution]], a conservative public policy think tank.<ref name=":7">{{cite web|last1=Do|first1=Huy M.|last2=Quencer|first2=Robert|date=September 1, 2003|title=Scott W. Atlas Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution|url=http://www.ajnr.org/content/24/8/1729|website=American Journal of Neuroradiology|pages=1729|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> He joined the Hoover Institution in 2003.<ref name=":7" />

He served as a senior advisor for health care to the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential campaigns of [[Rudy Giuliani]] in 2008 and [[Mitt Romney]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |title=Romney's new health care adviser once attacked 'Romneycare' |url=https://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/03/23/romneys-new-health-care-adviser-once-attacked-romneycare/ |website=[[CNN]] |date=March 23, 2012|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rudy Giuliani's health care proposal|url=https://pnhp.org/news/rudy-giulianis-health-care-proposal-2/|website=PNHP}}</ref>

He has advocated eliminating the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] and replacing it with modified tax deductions and incentives. He has also called for changes to [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]<ref name=CNN>{{Cite web|last=Atlas|first=Scott|title=Replace Obamacare with a system that cuts costs and values quality care|url=https://www.cnn.com/2016/12/27/opinions/what-it-will-take-to-replace-obamacare-atlas/index.html|date=December 27, 2016|access-date=August 16, 2020|website=[[CNN]]}}</ref> and "aggressive reforms" to turn [[Medicaid]] "into a bridge to private insurance"<ref name=BeckersHospital>{{cite web |title=Opinion: Medicaid fails the poor |url=https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/finance/opinion-medicaid-fails-the-poor.html |website=Becker's Hospital Review}}</ref> and encourage [[health savings account]]s.<ref name=CNN/> Atlas views the [[Medicaid expansion]] as "one of the most misguided parts" of the Affordable Care Act.<ref name=BeckersHospital/> He opposes proposals to establish a [[public health insurance option]]<ref>{{Cite web |last=Atlas |first=Scott W. |date=July 16, 2019 |title=Public Option Kills Private Insurance |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/public-option-kills-private-insurance-11563309118 |website=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> or [[single-payer healthcare]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Atlas |first=Scott W. |date=March 9, 2020 |title=The Dangers of Medicare for All |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/09/opinion/medicare-for-all-cost.html |website=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>

title: Scott Atlas
deleted: ===COVID-19 misinformation, controversial statements, and policy influence===

Atlas has spread [[misinformation about COVID-19]].<ref name = AlbaLee/> He is a proponent of the "herd immunity" theory that infection of low-risk people should be encouraged.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-coronavirus-scott-atlas-herd-immunity/2020/08/30/925e68fe-e93b-11ea-970a-64c73a1c2392_story.html|title=New Trump pandemic adviser pushes controversial 'herd immunity' strategy, worrying public health officials|last1=Abutaleb|first1=Yasmeen|last2=Dawsey|first2=Josh|date=August 31, 2020|work=The Washington Post|access-date=1 January 2021}}</ref> He claimed that children "have virtually zero risk of dying, and a very, very low risk of any serious illness from this disease" and "children almost never transmit the disease"<ref name="NYTSept1" /><ref name=KUSI/> although children can carry, transmit, and in very rare cases be killed by the [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2|COVID-19 virus]].<ref name="NYTSept1"/> He argued that only symptomatic individuals should be tested for the coronavirus, and pushed for the August 24, 2020, change on the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] website saying that people who had been exposed to the virus but showed no symptoms should not be tested.<ref name=":3" /><ref name="NYTSept1">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/02/us/politics/trump-scott-atlas-coronavirus.html |date=September 2, 2020|first1=Noah|last1=Weiland|first2=Sheryl Gay|last2=Stolberg|author-link2=Sheryl Gay Stolberg|first3=Michael D.|last3=Shear|first4=Jim|last4=Tankersley|access-date=September 2, 2020|title=A New Coronavirus Adviser Roils the White House With Unorthodox Ideas|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> This position was opposed by many public health experts including CDC scientists, as 40% of people infected with the virus are [[asymptomatic carrier|asymptomatic but can still transmit the virus]].<ref name=":3" /> On September 18 it was reported that the change to the testing recommendation had been written by the White House coronavirus task force, and had been placed on the CDC website by political appointees in the [[Department of Health and Human Services]] without the knowledge of CDC scientists.<ref name =Mandavilli>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/health/coronavirus-testing-cdc.html|title=C.D.C. Testing Guidance Was Published Against Scientists' Objections|last=Mandavilli|first=Apoorva|date=September 17, 2020|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 18, 2020}}</ref> The original CDC recommendation — that anyone exposed to the virus should be tested whether or not they showed symptoms – was restored to the website the next day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/18/health/covid-19-testing-guidance-cdc-hhs/index.html|title=Controversial coronavirus testing guidance came from HHS and didn't go through CDC scientific review, sources say|date=September 18, 2020|publisher=CNN|access-date=September 18, 2020}}</ref>

Whilst many scientists believe [[Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|face masks]] help prevent the spread of COVID-19, Atlas has expressed skepticism that they are effective at halting the spread of the virus.<ref name=":3" /> In October 2020, Twitter removed a tweet by Atlas claiming that masks do not prevent the spread of coronavirus, which Twitter determined was not accurate. Later that day, HHS official [[Brett Giroir]], the [[Assistant Secretary for Health]], reaffirmed that masks do work to prevent transmission of the virus.<ref name="Giroir">{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Allan |date=October 18, 2020 |title=Twitter removes tweet from top Trump Covid adviser saying masks don't work |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/twitter-removes-tweet-top-trump-covid-adviser-saying-masks-don-n1243841 |work=[[NBC News]] |access-date=October 18, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201130091344/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/twitter-removes-tweet-top-trump-covid-adviser-saying-masks-don-n1243841 |archive-date=November 30, 2020}}</ref> Dr. [[Deborah Birx]], the White House coronavirus response coordinator, was reported to be "relieved" by the removal of Atlas's tweet.<ref name="Birx">{{cite news |last=Klein |first=Betsy |date=October 19, 2020 |title=Birx tells friends she was relieved after Trump adviser Scott Atlas' inaccurate mask tweet was removed |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/19/politics/scott-atlas-deborah-birx-task-force/index.html |website=cnn.com |publisher=[[CNN]] |access-date=October 19, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201121082911/https://edition.cnn.com/2020/10/19/politics/scott-atlas-deborah-birx-task-force/index.html |archive-date=November 21, 2020}}</ref>

Atlas has advocated for physical school reopening and resumption of college sports during the pandemic.<ref name=":4">{{cite web | last1=Ballhaus | first1=Rebecca | title=Trump Adds Coronavirus Adviser Whose Views Closely Align With His Own |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-adds-coronavirus-adviser-whose-views-closely-align-with-his-own-11597350585 | date=August 13, 2020 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | access-date=August 16, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201003073746/https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-adds-coronavirus-adviser-whose-views-closely-align-with-his-own-11597350585 |archive-date=October 3, 2020}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web | last1=Colvin | first1=Jill | title=Trump makes call for new White House doctor's virus advice |url=https://apnews.com/886b59d445a3d20739e2f77600976ea0 | date=August 16, 2020 | publisher=[[Associated Press]] | access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news |last1=Abutaleb |first1=Yasmeen |last2=Dawsey |first2=Josh |date=August 31, 2020 |title=New Trump pandemic adviser pushes controversial 'herd immunity' strategy, worrying public health officials |work=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-coronavirus-scott-atlas-herd-immunity/2020/08/30/925e68fe-e93b-11ea-970a-64c73a1c2392_story.html}}</ref><ref name="NYTSept1" /><ref name="KUSI">{{cite news |url=https://www.kusi.com/dr-scott-atlas-pushes-for-reopening-and-asks-arent-schools-an-essential-business/ |date=July 8, 2020|title=Dr. Scott Atlas pushes for reopening and asks, 'aren't schools an essential business?'}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that Atlas was the leading proponent within the Trump administration for a "[[herd immunity]]" approach to the virus, which would kill hundreds of thousands more Americans.<ref name=":3" /><ref name="Costa"/> Atlas denied later that he advocated for the herd immunity strategy,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gander |first=Kashmira |date=September 1, 2020 |title='Overt Lie': White House Adviser Scott Atlas Denies Herd Immunity Strategy Claims |url=https://www.newsweek.com/scott-atlas-herd-immunity-deny-strategy-1528827 |website=Newsweek}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/dr-atlas-denies-promoting-herd-immunity-coronavirus|title=Dr. Atlas blasts reports he backed 'herd immunity': 'I've never said that to the president'|first=Angelica|last=Stabile|date=September 1, 2020|website=Fox News}}</ref> said "there's never been a desire to have cases spread through the community," and said it "has never been the president's policy."<ref>{{Cite web|title=President Trump News Conference |url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?476162-1/president-declines-commit-peaceful-transfer-power-loses-election|access-date=September 26, 2020|publisher=[[C-SPAN]] |language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Stolberg |first=Sheryl Gay |date=October 14, 2020 |title=White House embraces a declaration from scientists that opposes lockdowns and relies on 'herd immunity' |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/13/world/white-house-embraces-a-declaration-from-scientists-that-opposes-lockdowns-and-relies-on-herd-immunity.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=October 14, 2020}}</ref> In October and November 2020, he touted the [[Great Barrington Declaration]], an open letter that calls for encouraging herd immunity.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Peltz|first1=Madeline|date=16 November 2020|title=Scott Atlas pushes herd immunity on Fox after denying|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/coronavirus-covid-19/scott-atlas-pushes-herd-immunity-fox-after-denying-he-pushes-herd-immunity-fox|website=Media Matter for America|publisher=MediaMatters.org|quote=Atlas touted the Great Barrington Declaration, an online movement backed by a libertarian think tank that calls for “herd immunity,” a policy of deliberately spreading the coronavirus as widely as possible, causing millions of unnecessary deaths in the process and straining our health care system.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Mandavilli|first1=Apoorva|last2=Stolberg|first2=Sheryl Gay|date=2020-10-19|title=A Viral Theory Cited by Health Officials Draws Fire From Scientists|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/19/health/coronavirus-great-barrington.html|access-date=2020-11-17|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

Atlas quickly became influential within the administration, and Trump welcomed his recommendations such as faster reopening and less testing, which were in accord with Trump's own preferences.<ref name = Cook/><ref name= "NYTSept1" /> Atlas was the only doctor to share the stage at Trump's pandemic briefings in the week after his appointment was announced,<ref name=":1"/> and he also prepared Trump's briefing materials.<ref name="NYTSept1"/> Trump publicly disagreed with or reduced the roles of other members of the [[White House Coronavirus Task Force]], including Birx and Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]],<ref name = Cook>{{cite web | last1=Cook | first1=Nancy | title=Trump elevates Scott Atlas, a doctor with a rosier coronavirus outlook |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/17/trump-scott-atlas-coronavirus-doctor-396741 | date=August 17, 2020 | work=[[Politico]] | access-date=August 18, 2020}}</ref><ref name="Dawsey"/> with whom Atlas repeatedly clashed.<ref name = AlbaLee/> [[Robert R. Redfield]] of the CDC was heard privately commenting on Atlas that "everything he says is false".<ref name=":2">{{cite news |last1=Alba |first1=Monica |title=Redfield voices alarm over influence of Trump's new coronavirus task force adviser |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/redfield-voices-alarm-over-influence-trump-s-new-coronavirus-task-n1241221 |access-date=September 28, 2020 |work=[[NBC News]] |date=September 28, 2020}}</ref> When Fauci was asked whether Atlas was providing misleading information to Trump, Fauci replied, without naming Atlas, that "sometimes there are things that are said that are really taken either out of context or actually incorrect".<ref name=":5">{{cite news |last1=Weixel |first1=Nathan |title=Atlas, health officials feuds add to Trump coronavirus turmoil |url=https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/518847-atlas-health-officials-feuds-add-to-trump-coronavirus-turmoil |access-date=September 30, 2020 |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=September 30, 2020}}</ref> Starting in August 2020, Birx avoided meetings where Atlas was present.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Bennett |first1= Kate |last2=Cohen |first2=Elizabeth |title=Birx cedes White House turf to Atlas while hitting the road to spread her public health gospel |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/29/politics/deborah-birx-task-force-scott-atlas/index.html |access-date=2020-11-06 |website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Birx vows she won't sit with Trump-picked task force member|url=https://www.cnn.com/videos/health/2020/10/29/deborah-birx-scott-atlas-coronavirus-task-force-bennett-lead-vpx.cnn|access-date=6 November 2020|website=www.cnn.com|publisher=CNN}}</ref> Fauci said of Atlas, "I have real problems with that guy. He's a smart guy who's talking about things that I believe he doesn't have any real insight or knowledge or experience in. He keeps talking about things that when you dissect it out and parse it out, it doesn't make any sense."<ref name="Dawsey"/> In mid-November 2020, it was reported that Atlas had not attended White House task force meetings in person since late September amid his clashes with Fauci and Birx.<ref name = AlbaLee/>

During stimulus negotiations in fall 2020, Atlas opposed funds for widespread COVID-19 testing; in an email to an economist, Atlas wrote that the push for testing was "a fundamental error of the public health people perpetrated on the world."<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Tankersley |first1=Jim |last2=Weiland |first2=Noah |last3=Cochrane |first3=Emily |date=2020-10-16 |title=White House Opposes Expanded Virus Testing, Complicating Stimulus Talks |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]]  |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/16/business/white-house-coronavirus-testing.html |access-date=2020-10-17 |issn=0362-4331 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201122080029/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/16/business/white-house-coronavirus-testing.html |archive-date=2020-11-22}}</ref> After [[White House COVID-19 outbreak|Trump was diagnosed with coronavirus in early October 2020]], Atlas appeared on Fox News to predict a "complete and full and rapid recovery" for Trump and to urge viewers not to panic.<ref>{{Cite web|date=October 2, 2020|title=Controversial coronavirus tsar accused of playing down pandemic says 'no reason to panic' over Trump diagnosis|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-coronavirus-scott-atlas-diagnosis-recovery-b747030.html|access-date=October 3, 2020|website=The Independent|language=en}}</ref> On October 31, Atlas was interviewed for 26 minutes on a broadcast of the [[RT (TV network)|RT]] network (formerly Russia Today), a Russian state-controlled outlet classified by U.S. intelligence agencies as part of [[Russian propaganda|Russia's propaganda apparatus]]. The next day, Atlas apologized, writing: "I regret doing the interview and apologize for allowing myself to be taken advantage of."<ref name="Treisman">{{cite news |last=Treisman |first=Rachel |date=November 1, 2020 |title=WH Adviser Scott Atlas Apologizes For Interview With Kremlin-Backed News Outlet |url=https://www.npr.org/2020/11/01/930149143/wh-adviser-scott-atlas-apologizes-for-interview-with-kremlin-backed-news-outlet |publisher=[[NPR]] |access-date=November 2, 2020}}</ref> On November 15, Atlas wrote a tweet urging [[Michigan]] residents to "rise up" against the state's newly announced COVID-19 restrictions, which included a requirement that high school and college classes must be conducted remotely and a three-week ban on many indoor activities including restaurant dining.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.clickondetroit.com/health/2020/11/15/here-are-14-changes-going-into-effect-under-michigans-new-covid-19-restrictions/#//|title=Here are 14 changes going into effect under Michigan's new COVID-19 restrictions|last=Hutchinson|first=Derrick|date=November 15, 2020|work=Click On Detroit|access-date=17 November 2020}}</ref> Atlas' tweet included the hashtags #FreedomMatters and #StepUp.<ref name="LeBlanc">{{cite news |last1=LeBlanc|first1=Paul |last2=Diamond |first2=Jeremy |date=November 15, 2020 |title=Trump coronavirus adviser Scott Atlas urges Michigan to 'rise up' against new Covid-19 measures |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/15/politics/scott-atlas-coronavirus-michigan/index.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |access-date=November 15, 2020}}</ref>

Deborah Birx, the former White House coronavirus coordinator, said Trump was fed "parallel data" that she hadn't approved. Somebody had been creating graphics for Trump to present "that were not transparently utilized." Atlas was involved, she said.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Kate Duffy |title=Deborah Birx, the former White House coronavirus coordinator, said Trump was fed 'parallel data' that she hadn't approved, which he then presented to the public |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/deborah-birx-trump-covid-parallel-data-scott-atlas-2021-1 |website=Business Insider |date=25 January 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Kelly Hooper |title=Deborah Birx: 'Parallel set of data' on Covid-19 was delivered to Trump |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/24/birx-trump-parallel-covid-data-461928 |website=Politico |date=24 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Scott Atlas
deleted: On August 10, 2020, President [[Donald Trump]] announced that Atlas would join his administration as an advisor on [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Morrison|first1=Cassidy|date=August 10, 2020|title=Critic of coronavirus lockdowns and school closures made adviser to President Trump|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/critic-of-coronavirus-lockdowns-and-school-closures-made-adviser-to-president-trump|access-date=August 11, 2020|work=[[Washington Examiner]]}}</ref> Atlas, a radiologist, is not a specialist in [[public health]] or [[Infectious disease (medical specialty)|infectious diseases]].<ref name="NYTSept1"/><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Perez|first=Matt|title=Who Is Dr. Scott Atlas? Trump's New Covid Health Adviser Seen As Counter To Fauci And Birx|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mattperez/2020/08/12/who-is-dr-scott-atlas-trumps-new-covid-health-adviser-seen-as-counter-to-fauci-and-birx/|access-date=August 17, 2020 |website=Forbes |language=en}}</ref> He reportedly caught Trump's eye because of his frequent appearances on Fox News that summer.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/30/us/politics/scott-atlas-trump-coronavirus-adviser-resigns.html|title=Scott Atlas, a Trump Coronavirus Adviser, Resigns|last=Stolberg|first=Sheryl Gay|date=November 30, 2020|work=The New York Times|access-date=1 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Scott Atlas
deleted: Atlas's influence on policy alarmed many doctors and health experts.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brumfiel |first1=Geoff |last2=Keith |first2=Tamara |title=President Trump's New COVID-19 Adviser Is Making Public Health Experts Nervous|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/09/04/909348915/president-trumps-new-covid-19-advisor-is-making-public-health-experts-nervous |access-date=September 12, 2020 |website=NPR.org |language=en |url-status=live |publisher=[[NPR]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201129081955/https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/09/04/909348915/president-trumps-new-covid-19-advisor-is-making-public-health-experts-nervous |archive-date=November 29, 2020}}</ref><ref name="Costa"/><ref name="Dawsey"/> In September 2020, 78 of Atlas's former colleagues at the [[Stanford University School of Medicine|Stanford Medical School]] signed an open letter criticizing Atlas, writing that he had made "falsehoods and misrepresentations of science" that "run counter to established science" and "undermine public health authorities and the credible science that guides effective public health policy."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://int.nyt.com/data/documenttools/read-the-open-letter-from-stanford-doctors-on-scott-atlas/813b50f72b6543b4/full.pdf |title=Dear Colleages |author1=Philip A. Pizzo, MD |author2=Upi Singh, MD |author3=Bonnie Maldonado, MD |date=September 9, 2020  |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=December 1, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201126235901/https://int.nyt.com/data/documenttools/read-the-open-letter-from-stanford-doctors-on-scott-atlas/813b50f72b6543b4/full.pdf |archive-date=November 26, 2020}}</ref><ref name="abc1">{{cite web |last1=Bruggeman |first1=Lucien |last2=Cathey |first2=Libby |title=Former Stanford colleagues warn Dr. Scott Atlas fosters 'falsehoods and misrepresentations of science' |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/stanford-colleagues-warn-dr-scott-atlas-fosters-falsehoods/story?id=72926212 |access-date=September 12, 2020 |work=[[ABC News]] |language=en |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120122756/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/stanford-colleagues-warn-dr-scott-atlas-fosters-falsehoods/story?id=72926212 |archive-date=November 20, 2020}}</ref> Atlas's lawyer [[Marc Kasowitz]] threatened to sue the researchers.<ref>{{cite web |last=Niedzwiadek |first=Nick |title=Scott Atlas lawyer threatens defamation suit over critical Stanford open letter |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/17/scott-atlas-stanford-defamation-suit-416992 |access-date=September 18, 2020 |website=[[Politico]] |language=en |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201122164808/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/17/scott-atlas-stanford-defamation-suit-416992 |archive-date=November 22, 2020}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|title=Scott Atlas, White House adviser on coronavirus, threatens to sue colleagues back at Stanford|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2020/09/23/scott-atlas-white-house-adviser-coronavirus-threatens-sue-colleagues-back-stanford|access-date=2020-10-27|website=www.insidehighered.com|language=en}}</ref>

Atlas's comment urging Michiganders to "rise up" against measures to prevent COVID-19 transmission was widely condemned by health professionals and by Stanford University, home of the Hoover Institute where Atlas is a senior fellow.<ref name = Cathey/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/Stanford-rebukes-Scott-Atlas-following-his-15732313.php|title=Stanford rebukes Scott Atlas following his controversial rise up tweet|last=Williams|first=Michael|date=November 16, 2020|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=17 November 2020}}</ref> In November 2020, Michigan Governor [[Gretchen Whitmer]] denounced the tweet as "incredibly reckless"<ref name = Cathey>{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/dr-scott-atlas-fire-telling-michigan-rise-covid/story?id=74234276|title=Dr. Scott Atlas under fire for telling Michigan to 'rise up' against COVID-19 restrictions|last=Cathey|first=Libby|date=November 16, 2020|work=ABC News|access-date=17 November 2020}}</ref> and Fauci said: "I totally disagree with it, and I made no secret of that. ... I don't want to say anything against Dr. Atlas as a person but I totally disagree with the stand he takes. I just do, period."<ref name = AlbaLee/>

The same month, the Stanford University [[Academic senate#United States|Faculty Senate]], by an 85% vote, adopted a resolution condemning Atlas for his actions that "promote a view of COVID-19 that contradicts medical science." The resolution cited Atlas's statements and said they endangered the public.<ref>{{cite journal |title= Stanford Faculty Senate Condemns Dr. Scott Atlas Over His Covid-19 Conduct |last= Nietzel |first= Michael T. |date= 2020-11-21 |access-date= 2020-11-22 |journal= [[Forbes]] |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaeltnietzel/2020/11/21/stanford-faculty-senate-condems-dr-scott-atlas-over-his-covid-19-conduct/}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: The 2021 Virginia gubernatorial election was won by Glenn Youngkin in an enormous upset. For months, the liberal mainstream media had said the Virginia would never vote for a Republican and that Creepy Clintonite Terry McAuliffe would win in a rout, but they had no idea how much BACKLASH and OUTRAGE the Democrat party had stirred. All over the great Commonwealth, people were fed up with the far-left agenda of Joe Biden, the most unpopular and hated president in American history. While Joe and Terry were pushing Critical Race Theory, Virginians realized that Democrat socialist policies had wrecked the economy, skyrocketed inflation, and created shortages of anything and everything. Then, in an act of total desperation, Terry and his campaign disgracefully tried to slander Glenn Youngkin as a Neo-Nazi. The people of Virginia were not fooled by these lies, however, and Glenn won BIG, proving that a massive RED WAVE had begun for Republicans across the country!

title: Andrea Campbell
added: ====COVID-19 crisis====

Campbell's platform on addressing the COVID-19 pandemic proposes requiring vaccination for access to "high transmission locations" (such as restaurants, bars, concert venues, and gyms), partnering with surrounding municipalities to create a vaccine verification system for the city, and requiring all municipal employees to either be vaccinated or submit to weekly testing. It also proposes reopening [[Boston Public Schools]] with improvements to ventilation, sufficient [[personal protective equipment]], and routine testing for both staff and students. It also proposes investments in "resilient public health infrastructure". It also proposes steps to improve transparency, testing, as well as surveillance. It also calls for various steps to ensure equity in regards to vaccines. It also outlines priorities that it argues are important for enabling the city to get "back to work".<ref>{{cite web |title=A Roadmap to COVID-19 Recovery |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/covid-recovery/ |website=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

title: Andrea Campbell
added: ====Public health====

Campbell's public health plan outline the aim to "build the #1 city health department in the United States". Campbell's health plan also calls for the city to address violence and trauma, including addressing [[gun violence]] and [[racism]] as public health crises. Her health plan also proposes making investments in behavioral and [[mental health]], including by redirecting funds from Boston Police Department overtime costs to mental health crisis responders.<ref>{{cite web |title=Public Health |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/public-health/ |website=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

Campbell's platform on addressing the COVID-19 pandemic proposes requiring vaccination for access to "high transmission locations" (such as restaurants, bars, concert venues, and gyms), partnering with surrounding municipalities to create a vaccine verification system for the city, and requiring all municipal employees to either be vaccinated or submit to weekly testing. It also proposes reopening [[Boston Public Schools]] with improvements to ventilation, sufficient [[personal protective equipment]], and routine testing for both staff and students. It also proposes investments in "resilient public health infrastructure". It also proposes steps to improve transparency, testing, as well as surveillance. It also calls for various steps to ensure equity in regards to vaccines. It also outlines priorities that it argues are important for enabling the city to get "back to work".<ref>{{cite web |title=A Roadmap to COVID-19 Recovery |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/covid-recovery/ |website=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

title: Andrea Campbell
added: Campbell's campaign released numerous plans aimed at creating, "a more inclusive Boston". These plans are focused on investing in the city's youth, ensuring that residents "are able to age with dignity", making the city more inclusive to the [[LGBTQ+]] community, making the city more welcoming and inclusive for [[immigrant]]s and [[refugee]]s, "cultivate racial equality in City Hall", fighting for gender equity, creating "a welcoming city for [[veteran]]s and servicemembers", and making the city more livable for those with [[disabilities]].<ref>{{cite web |title=A More Inclusive Boston |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/a-more-inclusive-boston/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

title: Andrea Campbell
deleted: Campbell's campaign had a "[[climate justice]]" plan, that called for environmental justice to be central in addressing [[climate change]].<ref name="climatejustice">{{cite web |title=Climate Justice |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/climate-justice/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref> Her plan called for "climate action, sustainability, and resiliency" to be made "a top priority for Boston".<ref name="climatejustice"/> Campbell's public health plan called for treating climate change as a "health justice priority."<ref name="publichealth"/>

Campbell's housing plan called housing a, "fundamental human right". It called for, among other things, steps to overhaul the city's [[zoning]] code, promote [[affordable housing]], address [[homelessness]], and promote "equitable planning".<ref name="housing">{{cite web |title=Housing - Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/housing/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

To address the homelessness crisis in the area of Boston near Massachusetts Avenue and Melnea Cass Boulevard ("Mass & Cass"), Campbell had laid out a number of proposed actions. She had proposed appointing a "Mass & Cass Chief", who would directly report to the mayor, and would to lead a team to address the homelessness crisis and coordinate with decentralized services. She also proposed creative a dedicated first responder unit for Mass & Cass.<ref name="Mass and Cass">{{cite web |title=Mass and Cass |url=https://andreacampbell.org/mass-and-cass/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref><ref name="WintersmithJan22">{{cite web |last1=Wintersmith |first1=Saraya |title=Mayoral Candidate Andrea Campbell Unveils Plan For Boston's Problematic Mass & Cass |url=https://www.wgbh.org/news/local-news/2021/01/22/mayoral-candidate-andrea-campbell-unveils-plan-for-bostons-problematic-mass-cass |website=www.wgbh.org/ |access-date=17 September 2021 |language=en |date=22 January 2021}}</ref> To address Mass & Cass' crisis, Campbell also proposed "reactivating" [[Long Island (Massachusetts)|Long Island]] by creating a [[ferry]] service to allow people to reach the Island, where spaces for recovery and treatment would be available.<ref name="Mass and Cass"/><ref name="WintersmithJan22"/> Campbell also promotes establishing more safe spaces, increasing treatment locations, and creating permanent supportive housing to address Mass & Cass' crisis.<ref name="Mass and Cass"/><ref name="WintersmithJan22"/>

Campbell's public health plan outlined an aim to "build the #1 city health department in the United States". Campbell's health plan also called for the city to address violence and trauma, including addressing [[gun violence]] and [[racism]] as public health crises. Her health plan also proposed making investments in behavioral and [[mental health]], including by redirecting funds from Boston Police Department overtime costs to mental health crisis responders. It proposed addressing climate change as a "health justice priority". It also proposed creating a "resilient [[food system]]", in part by empowering the city's Office of Food Access. It also considers economic mobility and the "housing crisis" to be public health concerns.<ref name="publichealth">{{cite web |title=Public Health |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/public-health/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021 }}</ref>

Campbell's platform on addressing the COVID-19 pandemic proposed requiring vaccination for access to "high transmission locations" (such as restaurants, bars, concert venues, and gyms), partnering with surrounding municipalities to create a vaccine verification system for the city, and requiring all municipal employees to either be vaccinated or submit to weekly testing. It also proposed reopening [[Boston Public Schools]] with improvements to ventilation, sufficient [[personal protective equipment]], and routine testing for both staff and students. It also proposed investments in "resilient public health infrastructure". It also proposed steps to improve transparency, testing, as well as surveillance. It also called for various steps to ensure equity in regards to vaccines. It also outlines priorities that it argues are important for enabling the city to get "back to work".<ref>{{cite web |title=A Roadmap to COVID-19 Recovery |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/covid-recovery/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021 }}</ref> In addition, Campbell's campaign released a separate plan for providing relief to restaurants, an industry impacted by COVID-19.<ref>{{cite web |title=Restaurant Recovery |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/restaurant-recovery/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

Campbell's public safety platform sets the aim of reimagining, "public safety and criminal justice to address root causes of violence and crime". She proposed a 10% ($50 million) reduction of the Boston Police Department's budget in order to fund. "public health, economic justice, and youth development strategies".<ref name="publicsafety">{{cite web |title=Public Safety |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/public-safety/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021 }}</ref> Her public safety plan proposed changing school safety from a "law enforcement model" to a "[[restorative justice]] model. It also proposed increasing investment in both youth jobs and the Youth Development Fund.<ref name="publicsafety"/> Campbell had set the goal of making the Boston Police Department, "the most transparent and accountable police department in the country".<ref>{{cite web |title=Andrea Campbell pledges to make Boston Police the most transparent and accountable police department in the country in new public safety and criminal justice plan |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andrea-in-the-news/press-releases/andrea-campbell-pledges-to-make-boston-police-the-most-transparent-and-accountable-police-department-in-the-country-in-new-public-safety-and-criminal-justice-plan/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021 |date=24 February 2021}}</ref> Her public safety plan proposed creating a new "co-responder crisis system" to respond to non-violent [[9-1-1]] calls.<ref name="publicsafety"/>

Campbell's transit plan called for, "building a more livable Boston through equitable transportation and environmental justice".<ref name="transporation"/> Campbell's transit plan, among other things, promotes "15-minute neighborhoods". This goal would aim see an increase in the number of jobs, services, and amenities located within 15 minutes of all residential areas.<ref>{{cite web |last1=MilNeil |first1=Christian |title=Councilor Campbell's Mayoral Campaign Releases Transportation Platform |url=https://mass.streetsblog.org/2021/03/11/councilor-campbells-mayoral-campaign-releases-transportation-platform/ |website=StreetsblogMASS |access-date=14 March 2021 |date=11 March 2021}}</ref><ref name="transporation">{{cite web |title=Transportation |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/transportation/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref> It called for [[MBTA]] bus services to be made fare-free.<ref name="transporation"/> It also called for improvements to be made to bus services and investments to made (in partnership with the state of Massachusetts) to the MBTA.<ref name="transporation"/> It called for an increase in the implementation of dedication [[bus lanes]] and [[Bus priority signal|signal prioritization]].<ref name="transporation"/>

Campbell's campaign released numerous plans aimed at creating, "a more inclusive Boston". These plans include ones focused on investing in the city's youth, ensuring that residents "are able to age with dignity", making the city more inclusive to the [[LGBTQ+]] community, making the city more welcoming and inclusive for [[immigrant]]s and [[refugee]]s, "cultivate racial equality in City Hall", fighting for gender equity, creating "a welcoming city for [[veteran]]s and servicemembers", and making the city more livable for those with [[disabilities]].<ref>{{cite web |title=A More Inclusive Boston |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/a-more-inclusive-boston/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

Campbell also released plans on education,<ref>{{cite web |title=Education |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/education/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref> reforming municipal government,<ref>{{cite web |title=City Government |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/city-government/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref> and economic matters.<ref>{{cite web |title=Economy |url=https://andreacampbell.org/andreas-vision/economy/ |website=andreacampbell.org |publisher=Andrea Campbell for Boston Mayor |access-date=10 September 2021}}</ref>

title: Andrea Campbell

title: Terry McAuliffe
added: '''Transgender Rape'''

The political peril inflicted by Virginia Democratic gubernatorial nominee Terry McAuliffe’s education stances deepened when a father accused the Loudoun County School Board of covering up the rape of his teenage daughter in a high school bathroom.
The father was dragged out of a school board meeting and arrested when he attempted to confront the members about the assault of his daughter by a boy wearing a skirt in the girls’ bathroom.

title: Terry McAuliffe
added: ====Pardons====

McAuliffe pardoned 227 people during his tenure, the most of any Virginia governor, and three times as many as his predecessor [[Bob McDonnell]].<ref>Sandy Hausman, [https://www.wvtf.org/news/2018-01-23/mcauliffe-pardoned-record-number-of-prisoners-but-hundreds-are-still-waiting McAuliffe Pardoned Record Number of Prisoners, But Hundreds Are Still Waiting], WVTF (January 23, 2018).</ref> In 2017, he granted pardons to the [[Norfolk Four]], a group of [[U.S. Navy]] sailors who were [[Wrongful conviction|wrongly convicted]] of a 1997 rape and murder and were declared [[actually innocent]] by a federal court in 2016.<ref>Priyanka Boghani, [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/norfolk-four-pardoned-20-years-after-false-confessions/ "Norfolk Four" Pardoned 20 Years After False Confessions], ''Frontline'', PBS (March 22, 2017).</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2017/03/21/norfolk-4-wrongly-convicted-of-rape-and-murder-pardoned-by-gov-mcauliffe/ 'Norfolk 4' wrongly convicted of rape and murder, pardoned by Gov. McAuliffe], ''Washington Post'' (March 21, 2017).</ref> He rejected an application for pardon from [[Jens Soering]].<ref>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/mcauliffe-wont-act-on-soering-pardon-before-leaving-office/2017/12/14/0d25d14c-e126-11e7-8679-a9728984779c_story.html McAuliffe won’t act on Soering pardon before leaving office], ''Washington Post'' (December 14, 2017).</ref>

title: Vernon Jones
added: ===Behavior toward women===

According to a 2021 examination of Jones' record by the ''[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'', "Jones has a long history of problematic behavior toward women, repeatedly accused of threatening, intimidating and harassing women in his personal and professional lives" over three decades.<ref name=Judd>Alan Judd, [https://www.ajc.com/politics/election/vying-for-trumps-support-vernon-jones-faces-history-of-misconduct-toward-women/BP65PSEHAJFOPOS2BGB34G4BEA/ Vying for Trump’s support, Vernon Jones faces history of misconduct toward women], ''Atlanta Journal Constitution'' (May 14, 2021).</ref> The newspaper reviewed several previously reported episodes, as well as new details that had not been reported.<ref name=Judd/> Jones has denied "any improper conduct with anyone, at any time."<ref name=Judd/>

In June 1989, three years before his election to the state legislature, Jones (who was then 28 years old) was arrested on a charge of pointing a pistol at a woman in her home in [[Doraville, Georgia|Doraville]].<ref name=Judd/> Criminal charges were dismissed, and Jones was ordered to attend [[anger management]] classes instead.<ref name=Judd/>

In 2003, a community activist who complained about Jones' handling of flooding issues said that a disheveled Jones, accompanied by a plainclothes county police officer, confronted her in the evening at her home, approaching her with waving arms and clenched fists and mentioning her husband's recent death.  The activist said that she felt threatened and intimidated by Jones.<ref name=Judd/> A prosecutor declined to charge Jones with [[criminal trespass]], but warned Jones to stay away from the activist. The activist sued Jones for trespass and [[Assault (tort)|assault]]; the case was settled out of court on confidential terms in 2009.<ref name=Judd/>

In 2004, DeKalb County Commissioner Elaine Boyer made a complaint to Decatur police that Jones "deliberately walked into her and made hard shoulder-to-shoulder contact" after a heated public meeting; she did not pursue charges against Jones, but accused him of verbal abusing commissioners and staff and making "derogatory and degrading comments."<ref name=Judd/>

A woman accused Jones of raping her in late December 2004 at a party at his home.<ref name=Judd/> Before detectives could take the statement of the women, the police chief of DeKalb telephoned Jones to inform him of the allegation; a [[Georgia Attorney General]]'s Office investigation concluded that the chief's call was inappropriate. The women's name was later leaked to the media, and the women declined to press charges, citing the emotional distress that it would entail.<ref name=Judd/>  Jones was not prosecuted, and the allegation did not cause him significant political damage.<ref name=Judd/> A different woman accused Jones of threatening her with a gun in her home.<ref name=Judd/>

Mark Esper
deleted: ==== Withdrawal of U.S. forces from Afghanistan ====

On February 29, 2020, the Trump administration signed a conditional [[Afghan peace process|peace agreement with the Taliban]], which calls for the [[Withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan|withdrawal of foreign troops]] in 14 months if the Taliban uphold the terms of the agreement.<ref>{{cite news |title=Esper: US troops can withdraw 'with or without' Afghan peace deal |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/12/esper-troops-drawdown-afghan-peace-deal-191217054412919.html |work=Al Jazeera |date=December 17, 2020 |access-date=July 14, 2020 |archive-date=August 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200803173844/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/12/esper-troops-drawdown-afghan-peace-deal-191217054412919.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Defense Secretary Gives Go-Ahead For U.S. Troops To Start Afghan Drawdown |url=https://www.npr.org/2020/03/02/811276808/defense-secretary-gives-go-ahead-for-u-s-troops-to-start-afghan-drawdown?t=1594713965097 |work=[[NPR]] |date=March 2, 2020 |access-date=July 14, 2020 |archive-date=July 14, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200714150257/https://www.npr.org/2020/03/02/811276808/defense-secretary-gives-go-ahead-for-u-s-troops-to-start-afghan-drawdown?t=1594713965097 |url-status=live }}</ref> In May 2020, Esper said: "I don’t put a timeline on it. We have a timeline of May of next year but that timeline was premised on everything moving at a set pace."<ref>{{cite news |title=Esper not confident in Afghanistan troop withdrawal before election |url=https://www.militarytimes.com/news/your-army/2020/05/27/secdef-not-confident-in-afghanistan-troop-withdrawal-before-election/ |work=Military Times |date=May 27, 2020 |access-date=July 14, 2020 |archive-date=July 14, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200714144118/https://www.militarytimes.com/news/your-army/2020/05/27/secdef-not-confident-in-afghanistan-troop-withdrawal-before-election/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
