title: History of the Democratic Party (United States)
added: *[[Andrew Jackson]]
*[[Martin Van Buren]]

title: History of the Democratic Party (United States)
added: {{Infobox political party

The [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] is the oldest voter-based [[political party]] in the world and the oldest existing [[Political parties of the United States|political party in the United States]]. The party's modern institutions were formed in the 1830s and 1840s.<ref>{{citation|title=Party of the People: A History of the Democrats|last=Witcover|first=Jules|year=2003|chapter=Chapter 1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=John|last=Micklethwait|author-link=John Micklethwait|author2=Wooldridge, Adrian|title=The Right Nation: Conservative Power in America|url=https://archive.org/details/rightnationconse00mick|url-access=registration|year=2004|page=[https://archive.org/details/rightnationconse00mick/page/15 15]}} "The country possesses the world's oldest written constitution (1787); the Democratic Party has a good claim to being the world's oldest political party.”</ref><ref>{{cite book|first1=Kenneth|last1=Janda|first2=Jeffrey M.|last2=Berry|first3=Jerry|last3=Goldman|title=The Challenge of Democracy: American Government in Global Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t_lC8k3SELMC&pg=PA276|year=2010|publisher=Cengage Learning|page=276|isbn=9780495906186}}</ref> Known as the party of the "common man," the early Democratic Party stood for individual rights and state sovereignty, but opposed banks and high tariffs. During the [[Second Party System]] (from 1832 to the mid-1850s) under Presidents [[Andrew Jackson]], [[Martin Van Buren]] and [[James K. Polk]], the Democrats usually bested the opposition [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig Party]] by narrow margins.

The Democratic Party has changed significantly during its more than two centuries of existence. During the 19th century the party supported or tolerated slavery, and it opposed civil rights reforms after the American Civil War in order to retain the support of Southern voters. From 1860 to 1932 in the era of the [[American Civil War]] to the [[Great Depression]], the opposing [[History of the United States Republican Party|Republican Party]], organized in the mid-1850s from the ruins of the Whig Party and some other smaller splinter groups, was dominant in [[United States presidential election|presidential politics]]. The Democrats elected [[List of United States Presidents|only two Presidents]] during this period: [[Grover Cleveland]] (in 1884 and 1892) and [[Woodrow Wilson]] (in 1912 and 1916). Over the same period, the Democrats proved more competitive with the Republicans in [[United States midterm election|Congressional politics]], enjoying [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] majorities (as in the [[65th United States Congress|65th Congress]]) in 15 of the 36 [[United States Congress|Congresses]] elected, although only in five of these did they form the majority in the [[United States Senate|Senate]]. Furthermore, the Democratic Party was split between the [[Bourbon Democrat]]s, representing Eastern business interests; and the agrarian elements comprising poor farmers in the South and West. The agrarian element, marching behind the slogan of [[free silver]] (i.e. in favor of inflation), captured the party in 1896 and nominated [[William Jennings Bryan]] in the 1896, 1900 and 1908 presidential elections, although he lost every time. Both Bryan and Wilson were leaders of the [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive movement in the United States]] (1890s–1920s) and opposed imperialistic expansion abroad while sponsoring liberal reforms at home.

Starting with 32nd President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], the party dominated during the [[Fifth Party System]], which lasted from 1932 until about 1970s. In response to the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] and the ensuing [[Great Depression]], the party employed [[Social liberalism|liberal]] policies and programs with the [[New Deal coalition]] to combat financial crises and emergency bank closings, with policies continuing into [[World War II]]. The Party kept the [[White House]] after Roosevelt's death in April 1945, reelecting former Vice President [[Harry S. Truman]] in 1948. During this period, the [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] only successfully elected one president (Eisenhower in 1952 and 1956) and was the minority in Congress all but twice (the exceptions being 1946 and 1952). Powerful committee chairmanships were awarded automatically on the basis of seniority, which gave power especially to long-serving Southerners.  Important Democratic leaders during this time included Presidents Harry S. Truman (1945–1953), [[John F. Kennedy]] (1961–1963) and [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] (1963–1969). Republican [[Richard Nixon]] won the White House in 1968 and 1972, leading to the end of the New Deal era.

Democrats have won six out of the last twelve presidential elections, winning in the presidential elections of [[1976 United States presidential election|1976]] (with 39th President [[Jimmy Carter]], 1977–1981), [[1992 United States presidential election|1992]] and [[1996 United States presidential election|1996]] (with 42nd President [[Bill Clinton]], 1993–2001), [[2008 United States presidential election|2008]] and [[2012 United States presidential election|2012]] (with 44th President [[Barack Obama]], 2009–2017), and [[2020 United States presidential election|2020]] (with 46th President [[Joe Biden]], 2021–present). Democrats have also won the [[Plurality voting|popular vote]] in [[2000 United States presidential election|2000]] and [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]], but lost the [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]] in both elections (with candidates [[Al Gore]] and [[Hillary Clinton]], respectively). These were two of the four [[United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote|presidential elections in which Democrats won the popular vote but lost the Electoral College]], the others being the presidential elections in [[1876 United States presidential election|1876]] and [[1888 United States presidential election|1888]].

Newton Blanchard, who is tied with Kennedy. <ref>{{cite news |title=Even with cornpone jokes, John N. Kennedy leverages his position for state|url=https://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/opinion/article_cc0f6da6-099b-11ec-bbf2-b71c32ff6b72.html|access-date=9 September 2021 |work=The Advocate |date=1 September 2021 |language=en}}</ref>

title: John Kennedy (Louisiana politician)
added: === Banking ===
In March 2019, Kennedy introduced the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which became law on December 18, 2020. <ref>{{cite news |title=S.945 - Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act |url=
https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/945/actions?r=3&s=2

The law requires certain issuers of securities to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government, including China. Specifically, an issuer must make this certification if the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board is unable to audit specified reports because the issuer has retained a foreign public accounting firm not subject to inspection by the board. Furthermore, if the board is unable to inspect the issuer's public accounting firm for three consecutive years, the issuer's securities are banned from trade on a national exchange or through other methods. <ref>{{cite news |title=S.945 - Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/945?r=3&s=2|work=Congress.gov |date=18 December 2020 |language=en}}</ref>

In 2016, his legislative aide, Jessica Koehler, joined Ohio's Right to Life as its director of legislative affairs.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.ohiolife.org/ohio_right_to_life_announces_new_director_and_staff |title = Ohio Right to Life Announces New Director and Staff}}</ref>
In 2015, Larose voted for SB 127, a 20-week abortion ban, and cosponsored HB 294, which prohibited public funds for abortion services.

In 2016, Larose supported HB 493, a "[[heartbeat bill]]", even though similar bills have been unanimously blocked by the judiciary in several other states.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.cleveland.com/court-justice/index.ssf/2016/12/ohio_heartbeat_bill_how_conser_1.html |title = Ohio's 'heartbeat bill': How conservative judges in other states gutted similar laws|website=Cleveland.com|date =December 8, 2016}}</ref> In 2017, he voted for SB 28, which would require the burial or cremation of fetal remains, identical to a similar bill which had been blocked in Texas.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://verdict.justia.com/2017/01/31/federal-judge-buries-unconstitutional-texas-law-treatment-fetal-remains |title = Federal Judge Buries Unconstitutional Texas Law on the Treatment of Fetal Remains}}</ref>

In 2017, he sponsored legislation to prevent women from having abortions after a fetal diagnosis of [[Down syndrome]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/11/ohio_senate_passes_down_syndro.html|title=Ohio Senate passes Down syndrome abortion ban|date=November 15, 2017|access-date=November 27, 2017|work=The Cleveland Plain Dealer}}</ref> He also voted for SB 145, which bans certain abortion procedures.
The [[American Conservative Union]] gave him a 100% evaluation for 2017.{{Citation needed|date=August 2020}}

title: Politics of Louisiana
added: Louisiana was long known for its toleration of corruption in government. [[Bill Dodd]], former lieutenant governor and education superintendent, in his book ''Peapatch Politics: The [[Earl Long]] Era in Louisiana Politics'' describes corruption as "a way of life, inherited, and made quasi-respectable and legal by the French freebooters who founded, operated, and left us as the governmental blueprint that is still Louisiana's constitutional and civil law." Dodd notes furthermore that some attribute the corruption to "outlaws, gamblers, and fortune hunters who came off the [[Appalachian Mountains|mountains]] and down the [[Mississippi River]] to add their flavor to the Louisiana pot.

title: Criminal proceedings in the January 6 United States Capitol attack
added: Most defendants face "two class-B misdemeanor counts for demonstrating in the Capitol and disorderly conduct, and two class-A misdemeanor counts for being in a restricted building and disruptive activity," according to BuzzFeed, and therefore most plea deals address those misdemeanors. Some defendants have been additionally charged with felonies.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tillman|first=Zoe|date=13 October 2021|title=Reading Between The Lines Of Plea Deals In The Capitol Riot Cases|url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/zoetillman/january-6-plea-deals|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-13|website=BuzzFeed News|language=en}}</ref>

added: As of October 2021, approximately 250 people were still wanted for assaulting police officers.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Reilly|first=Ryan J.|date=2021-10-20|title='I'm Invincible': FBI Arrests Capitol Rioter Who Was 'Not Too Worried' He'd Be Charged|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/landon-mitchell-capitol-riot-donald-trump_n_6170543ae4b066de4f5d49e7|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-21|website=HuffPost|language=en}}</ref>

title: Warren E. Burger
added: == Views on Homosexuality ==

title: Warren E. Burger
deleted: Burger was opposed to [[gay rights]], as he wrote a famous concurring opinion in the Court's 1986 decision upholding a Georgia law criminalizing sodomy (''[[Bowers v. Hardwick]]''); he relied on historical evidence that laws criminalizing homosexuality were of ancient vintage. Burger pointed out that the famous legal author [[William Blackstone]] had written that sodomy was a {{"'}}crime against nature'... of 'deeper malignity than rape', a heinous act 'the very mention of which is a disgrace to human nature' and 'a crime not fit to be named{{'"}}.<ref>''Bowers'', 478 U.S. at 196–197 (Burger, C.J., concurring).</ref>  That decision was overturned in 2003 by the decision in ''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]'', which sought relief against a Texas law, which sanctioned heterosexual sodomy but criminalized it between homosexuals.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://slate.com/human-interest/2015/12/the-supreme-courts-overturning-of-bowers-v-hardwick-provided-a-critical-precedent-for-marriage-equality.html/ |title=How the Battle Over Anti-Sodomy Laws Became the Lynchpin of Marriage Equality  |publisher=The Slate Group |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |access-date=2020-06-15}}</ref>

title: Warren E. Burger
deleted: Burger was deeply prejudiced against [[Gays]], to an extent which bordered on hysteria. <ref>{{cite book |last1=Collins |title=Accidental activists |publisher=University of North Texas Press |isbn=9781574417036 |pages=66 |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Accidental_Activists/7FExDwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=warren+burger+homosexuality&pg=PA66&printsec=frontcover}}</ref>  Burger sent [[Byron White]] who wrote the majority opinion a letter, telling him to include harsh anti-gay language. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.law.com/dailyreportonline/almID/1202551080125/ |publisher=Law.com}}</ref>. White, no fan of homosexuality, but unwilling to take a public position on the issue as a judge, declined. Burger wrote his own concurring opinion denouncing homosexuality.<ref>{{cite web |url=upreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/478/186/#tab-opinion-1956747 |publisher=Justia}}</ref> Burger quoted approvingly a description of homosexuality as "worse than [[rape]]". He even implied that homosexuals should be executed, as he cited an [[ancient Roman]] law making homosexual acts a capital crime. Burger's extreme  views were virtually unheard of among mainstream conservatives such as the Reverend [[Jerry Falwell Sr.]], and aligned him with fringe figures such as [[R.J. Rushdoony]].

On September 23, 2021, Heller announced his candidacy for [[Governor of Hawaii]] on the Republican ticket, in [[2022 Nevada gubernatorial election|2022]] primary race.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Seitz-Wald|first1=Alex|title=Dean Heller, running for governor of Nevada, refuses to say Joe Biden won presidency|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/elections/dean-heller-running-governor-nevada-refuses-say-joe-biden-won-n1279869|access-date=7 Sep 2021 |work=[[NBC News]]|date=September 23 2021}}</ref>

title: Dean Heller
added: On September 23, 2021, Heller announced his candidacy for [[Governor ofNevada]] on the Republican ticket, in [[2022 Nevada gubernatorial election|2022]] primary race.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Seitz-Wald|first1=Alex|title=Dean Heller, running for governor of Nevada, refuses to say Joe Biden won presidency|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/elections/dean-heller-running-governor-nevada-refuses-say-joe-biden-won-n1279869|access-date=7 Sep 2021 |work=[[NBC News]]|date=September 23 2021}}</ref>

title: Jim Jordan
added: ===Ohio State University abuse scandal===

Jordan was an assistant wrestling coach with [[Ohio State University]]'s [[Ohio State Buckeyes#Wrestling|wrestling program]] from 1987 to 1995.<ref name="wp172">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/jim-jordan-r-ohio/gIQAjcfUAP_print.html |title=Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) |date=September 29, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |quote=Career History: ... Assistant wrestling coach at The Ohio State University (OSU) (1987–1995) ... After graduating in 1986, Jordan returned to his home state to work as an assistant wrestling coach at OSU for nine years. |access-date=July 6, 2018 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225811/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/jim-jordan-r-ohio/gIQAjcfUAP_print.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Ohio State University began an independent investigation in April 2018<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://news.osu.edu/investigation-underway-into-allegations-of-sexual-misconduct-against-former-wrestling-team-physician/ |date=April 5, 2018 |title=Investigation underway into allegations of sexual misconduct against former wrestling team physician |website=Ohio State News |language=en-us |access-date=November 24, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225752/https://news.osu.edu/investigation-underway-into-allegations-of-sexual-misconduct-against-former-wrestling-team-physician/ |url-status=live }}</ref> into allegations of sexual misconduct against former wrestling team physician Richard Strauss; Strauss was the team physician during Jordan's tenure as assistant coach.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thelantern.com/2018/04/ohio-state-investigating-allegations-of-sexual-misconduct-by-former-wrestling-team-doctor/ |title=Ohio State investigating allegations of sexual misconduct by former wrestling team doctor |last=Stankiewicz |first=Kevin |date=April 5, 2018 |newspaper=The Lantern |access-date=July 6, 2018 |archive-date=October 18, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191018125907/https://www.thelantern.com/2018/04/ohio-state-investigating-allegations-of-sexual-misconduct-by-former-wrestling-team-doctor/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="kesling182">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-ohio-state-wrestlers-say-rep-jim-jordan-knew-of-team-doctors-alleged-misconduct-1530836633/ |title=Former Ohio State wrestlers say Rep. Jim Jordan knew of team doctor's alleged misconduct |last1=Kesling |first1=Ben |date=July 5, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706031205/https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-ohio-state-wrestlers-say-rep-jim-jordan-knew-of-team-doctors-alleged-misconduct-1530836633/ |archive-date=July 6, 2018 |url-status=live |last2=Peterson |first2=Kristina |quote=Former Ohio State wrestler Mike DiSabato has led a campaign to publicize Dr. Strauss's alleged wrongdoings for months and only recently began to criticize Mr. Jordan for allegedly ignoring athletes' concerns. }}</ref> Strauss died by suicide in 2005.<ref name="Strauss2">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/rep-jim-jordan-returns-to-washington-as-scrutiny-over-alleged-sexual-abuse-at-ohio-state-intensifies/2018/07/08/4c772ef4-82c0-11e8-8553-a3ce89036c78_story.html |title=Representative Jim Jordan returns to Washington as scrutiny over alleged sexual abuse at The Ohio State intensifies |last1=Viebeck |first1=Elise |date=July 9, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=July 9, 2018 |last2=Crites |first2=Alice |archive-date=October 24, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191024144238/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/rep-jim-jordan-returns-to-washington-as-scrutiny-over-alleged-sexual-abuse-at-ohio-state-intensifies/2018/07/08/4c772ef4-82c0-11e8-8553-a3ce89036c78_story.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

In June 2018, at least eight former wrestlers said that Jordan had been aware of, but did not respond to, allegations of sexual misconduct by Strauss.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/11/us/politics/jim-jordan-sexual-abuse-scandal.html |title=Unshaken by Abuse Scandal, Conservatives Are Sticking With Jim Jordan |last1=Edmonsen |first1=Catie |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 11, 2018 |access-date=July 27, 2018 |archive-date=October 18, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191018173625/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/11/us/politics/jim-jordan-sexual-abuse-scandal.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="viebeck182">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/rep-jim-jordan-faces-new-accusation-he-must-have-known-about-alleged-sexual-abuse-at-ohio-state/2018/07/07/5f21f5ca-822f-11e8-b9a5-7e1c013f8c33_story.html |date=July 7, 2018 |title=Rep. Jim Jordan faces new accusation that he must have known about alleged sexual abuse at The Ohio State |last1=Viebeck |first1=Elise |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180708050522/https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/rep-jim-jordan-faces-new-accusation-he-must-have-known-about-alleged-sexual-abuse-at-ohio-state/2018/07/07/5f21f5ca-822f-11e8-b9a5-7e1c013f8c33_story.html |archive-date=July 8, 2018 |url-status=live |last2=Crites |first2=Alice |quote=David Range ... said Jordan had to have known about alleged sexual misconduct by Richard Strauss ... because it happened regularly to team members and people talked about it. }}</ref> Jordan's locker was next to Strauss's, and Jordan spent so much time in the locker room that he created and awarded a "King of the Sauna" certificate to the member of the team who spent the most time in the sauna "talking smack".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.dispatch.com/news/20180705/trump-says-he-doesnt-believe-allegations-against-jim-jordan-new-victim-emerges |title=Trump says he doesn't believe allegations against Jim Jordan; new victim emerges |date=2018-07-05 |last=Smola |first=Jennifer |newspaper=The Columbus Dispatch |language=en |access-date=November 24, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225734/https://www.dispatch.com/news/20180705/trump-says-he-doesnt-believe-allegations-against-jim-jordan-new-victim-emerges |url-status=live }}</ref>

In July 2018, Jordan's congressional spokesman Ian Fury released a statement in which Ohio State wrestling coach [[Russ Hellickson]] reportedly said: "At no time while Jim Jordan was a coach with me at Ohio State did either of us ignore abuse of our wrestlers. This is not the kind of man Jim is, and it is not the kind of coach that I was."<ref>{{cite web |first=Tara |last=Goldshan |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/7/6/17536388/jim-jordan-ohio-state-sexual-abuse-accuser |title=Jim Jordan is accused of turning a blind eye to The Ohio State sexual abuse. Now he's attacking the accusers. |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |location=New York City |date=July 6, 2018 |access-date=July 6, 2018 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225740/https://www.vox.com/2018/7/6/17536388/jim-jordan-ohio-state-sexual-abuse-accuser |url-status=live }}</ref>

Former wrestling team members David Range,<ref name="viebeck182"/> Mike DiSabato and Dunyasha Yetts asserted that Jordan knew of Strauss's misconduct. Yetts said, "For God's sake, Strauss's locker was right next to Jordan's and Jordan even said he'd kill him if he tried anything with him".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Siemaszko|first=Corky|date=July 3, 2018|title=Powerful GOP politician accused of turning blind eye to sexual abuse at Ohio State|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/powerful-gop-rep-jim-jordan-accused-turning-blind-eye-sexual-n888386|access-date=March 23, 2021|website=[[NBC News]]|language=en}}</ref> No wrestlers have accused Jordan of sexual misconduct, but four former wrestlers named him as a defendant in a lawsuit against the university.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.daytondailynews.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/congressman-jim-jordan-knew-about-sex-abuse-former-wrestlers-say/lzfhebNU5mZ5WrRbfg3aFM/ |title=Congressman Jim Jordan knew about sex abuse at OSU, former wrestlers say |last1=Wehrman |first1=Jessica |last2=Bischoff |first2=Laura A. |newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]]  |date=July 3, 2018 |access-date=October 31, 2019 |last3=Smola |first3=Jennifer}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{cite web |first1=Rachael |last1=Bade |first2=John |last2=Bresnehan |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/06/jim-jordan-harassment-ohio-state-wrestling-699192 |title='A cesspool of deviancy': New claims of voyeurism test Jordan denials |website=[[Politico]] |publisher=[[Capitol News Company]] |location=Arlington, Virginia |date=July 6, 2018 |access-date=July 7, 2018 |language=en }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Moser|first=Bob|date=July 18, 2018|title=Rep. Jim Jordan Is Named in New OSU Sexual Abuse Lawsuit|language=en-US|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/jim-jordan-ohio-state-700578/|access-date=March 23, 2021}}</ref> Several former wrestlers, including ex-UFC fighter [[Mark Coleman]], allege that Hellickson contacted two witnesses in an attempt to pressure them to support Jordan the day after they accused Jordan of turning a blind eye to the abuse.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Varda|first=Zach|date=August 1, 2018|title=Former wrestlers reportedly pressured by coach to support Jim Jordan|language=en-US|newspaper=The Lantern|url=https://www.thelantern.com/2018/08/former-wrestlers-pressured-by-coach-to-support-jim-jordan/|url-status=live|access-date=November 24, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225755/https://www.thelantern.com/2018/08/former-wrestlers-pressured-by-coach-to-support-jim-jordan/|archive-date=January 9, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Siemaszko|first=Corky|date=August 2, 2018|title=Former Ohio State wrestling coach urged Rep. Jim Jordan's accusers to recant, texts show|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/former-ohio-state-wrestling-coach-urged-rep-jim-jordan-s-n896551|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225811/https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/former-ohio-state-wrestling-coach-urged-rep-jim-jordan-s-n896551|archive-date=January 9, 2021|access-date=March 23, 2021|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref>

Jordan has refused to cooperate with investigations into Strauss.<ref name="NBCBlindI">{{Cite web |first=Corky |last=Siemaszko |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/powerful-gop-rep-jim-jordan-accused-turning-blind-eye-sexual-n888386 |title=Powerful GOP politician accused of turning blind eye to sexual abuse at Ohio State |website=[[NBC News]] |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]] |location=New York City |language=en |date=July 3, 2018 |access-date=October 31, 2019}}</ref> He described his accusers as "pawns in a political plot"<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/07/ohio-state-sexual-abuse-scandal-jim-jordan-implausibly-says-he-and-others-didnt-know.html |title=Now Jim Jordan Is Covering Up for His Ohio State Colleagues, Too |last=Saletan |first=William |date=July 30, 2018 |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |publisher=The Slate Group |location=San Francisco, California |language=en |access-date=November 3, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225800/https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/07/ohio-state-sexual-abuse-scandal-jim-jordan-implausibly-says-he-and-others-didnt-know.html |url-status=live }}</ref> and said he did not even hear any locker room talk about Strauss or sexual abuse at OSU.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Siemaszko|first=Corky|date=September 12, 2019|title=Ohio rep wants to put Rep. Jim Jordan on hot seat|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ohio-lawmaker-wants-slap-congressman-jim-jordan-subpoena-n1052596|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225734/https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ohio-lawmaker-wants-slap-congressman-jim-jordan-subpoena-n1052596|archive-date=January 9, 2021|access-date=November 24, 2019|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref> In response to Jordan's denials, DiSabato said, "I considered Jim Jordan a friend. But at the end of the day, he is absolutely lying if he says he doesn't know what was going on."<ref name="NBCBlindI" /><ref name="newsweek-groveling">{{Cite web |url=https://www.newsweek.com/jim-jordan-osu-wrestling-sexual-abuse-richard-strauss-1487016 |title=Former wrestler alleges GOP Rep. Jim Jordan called him "crying, groveling," wanted help covering up OSU abuse scandal |last=Crowley |first=James |date=February 12, 2020 |website=Newsweek |language=en |access-date=February 13, 2020 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225825/https://www.newsweek.com/jim-jordan-osu-wrestling-sexual-abuse-richard-strauss-1487016 |url-status=live }}</ref>

On July 13, 2018, the editorial board of the ''[[Cleveland Plain Dealer]]'' wrote, "Jim Jordan must acknowledge what he knew".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cleveland.com/opinion/2018/07/no_more_denials_jim_jordan_mus.html |title=No more denials. Jim Jordan must acknowledge what he knew: editorial |date=July 13, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Plain-Dealer]] |location=Cleveland, Ohio |language=en |access-date=October 31, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225814/https://www.cleveland.com/opinion/2018/07/no_more_denials_jim_jordan_mus.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

In May 2019, DiSabato filed a Title IX lawsuit against OSU. In one count of the court papers, DiSabato claimed that a second cousin of Jordan's attempted to "intimidate and retaliate" against DiSabato.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.dispatch.com/news/20180718/man-who-first-spoke-up-about-ohio-state-docs-sex-abuse-complicated-figure |title=Man who first spoke up about Ohio State doc's sex abuse a complicated figure |last=Rabinowitz |first=Bill |website=The Columbus Dispatch |language=en |access-date=November 24, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225735/https://www.dispatch.com/news/20180718/man-who-first-spoke-up-about-ohio-state-docs-sex-abuse-complicated-figure |date=July 18, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cleveland.com/metro/2018/07/rep_jim_jordan_disputes_claims.html |title=Rep. Jim Jordan again disputes allegations he knew Ohio State wrestlers were sexually abused (videos) |last=Eaton |first=Sabrina |date=July 5, 2018 |website=Cleveland.com |language=en |access-date=November 24, 2019}}</ref> In 2019, DiSabato shared text messages with NBC News, corroborated by another former wrestler,<ref name="Siemaszko">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/former-osu-wrestler-who-accused-rep-jim-jordan-ignoring-abuse-n899416 |title=Former OSU wrestler who accused Rep. Jim Jordan of ignoring abuse changes story |last=Siemaszko |first=Corky |date=August 9, 2018 |website=[[NBC News]] |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]] |location=New York City |language=en |access-date=November 3, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225743/https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/former-osu-wrestler-who-accused-rep-jim-jordan-ignoring-abuse-n899416 |url-status=live }}</ref> indicating that Jordan, [[Russ Hellickson]], and high school wrestling coach Jeff Jordan (Jim Jordan's younger brother)<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.daytondailynews.com/sports/end-era-jordan-retires-graham-wrestling-coach/whgP6n5jTVDnMXN6pFrc2H/ |title=End of an era: Jordan retires as Graham wrestling coach |last=Pendleton |first=Marc |date=September 13, 2018 |newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]] |access-date=October 31, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225838/https://www.daytondailynews.com/sports/end-era-jordan-retires-graham-wrestling-coach/whgP6n5jTVDnMXN6pFrc2H/ |url-status=live }}</ref> conspired to engage in witness tampering and intimidation when they called Coleman and Coleman's parents to pressure Coleman to recant his accusation that Jordan was aware of the abuse.<ref name="Siemaszko" />

In November 2019, a retired wrestling referee filed a lawsuit alleging that he had warned Jordan and Hellickson about Strauss's misconduct but they had dismissed his warning.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/08/referee-told-rep-jim-jordan-about-ohio-state-dr-richard-strauss-sex-abuse-suit-says.html |title=Wrestling referee warned Rep. Jim Jordan about Ohio State doctor's sex misconduct, new lawsuit says |last=Dzhanova |first=Yelena |date=November 8, 2019 |website=CNBC |language=en |access-date=November 17, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225811/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/08/referee-told-rep-jim-jordan-about-ohio-state-dr-richard-strauss-sex-abuse-suit-says.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/ohio-state-team-doctor-richard-strauss-abuse-allegations-referee-told-representitive-congress-jim-jordan-investigation-041337777.html |title=Referee files lawsuit, claims Rep. Jim Jordan ignored abuse allegations against Ohio State doctor |last=Young |first=Ryan |date=November 8, 2019 |website=Yahoo! Sports |language=en-US |access-date=November 17, 2019 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225740/https://sports.yahoo.com/ohio-state-team-doctor-richard-strauss-abuse-allegations-referee-told-representitive-congress-jim-jordan-investigation-041337777.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Referee says he told Rep. Jim Jordan that Ohio State doctor performed sex act in shower |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/referee-says-he-told-rep-jim-jordan-ohio-state-doctor-n1078476 |work=NBC News |date=November 8, 2019 |access-date=May 27, 2021 |first=Corky |last=Siemaszko }}</ref> Jordan said that the referee was "another person making a false statement".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.limaohio.com/news/383183/jim-jordan-referees-claim-ridiculous |title=Jim Jordan: Referee's claim 'ridiculous' |last=Ellerbrock |first=Josh |date=November 12, 2019 |newspaper=Lima News |access-date=November 21, 2019}}</ref>

In February 2020, Adam DiSabato, the brother of Mike DiSabato, testified before the Ohio House Civil Justice Committee that Jordan called him "crying, groveling... begging me to go against my brother" and described Jordan as a "coward".<ref name="newsweek-groveling"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/02/12/adam-disabato-rep-jordan-begged-him-deny-osu-abuse-claims/4741555002/ |title=Ex-OSU wrestler: Rep. Jordan called 'crying, groveling, begging' to deny sexual abuse claims |last=Behrmann |first=Savannah |website=USA Today |language=en-US |access-date=February 13, 2020 |archive-date=January 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210109225744/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/02/12/adam-disabato-rep-jordan-begged-him-deny-osu-abuse-claims/4741555002/ |date=2020-02-12 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="crying">{{Cite web|date=February 12, 2020|title=Brother of OSU whistleblower said Rep. Jim Jordan asked for support amid allegations he turned a blind eye to sex abuse |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/brother-osu-whistle-blower-said-rep-jim-jordan-asked-support-n1135321 |access-date=March 23, 2021|website=NBC News|language=en |first=Corky |last=Siemaszko }}</ref>

title: 2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries
deleted: In the weeks following the election of [[Donald Trump]] in the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 election]], media speculation regarding potential candidates for the 2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries began to circulate. As the Senate began confirmation hearings for members of the cabinet, speculation centered on the prospects of the "hell-no caucus", six senators who went on to vote against the majority of Trump's nominees. According to [[Politico]], the members of the "hell-no caucus" were [[Cory Booker]], [[Kamala Harris]], [[Kirsten Gillibrand]], [[Bernie Sanders]], [[Jeff Merkley]], and [[Elizabeth Warren]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/interactives/2017/hell-no-caucus/ |title=Senate Dems eyeing 2020 tell Trump 'hell no' |last=Schor |first=Elana |website=Politico |access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dailykos.com/story/2017/5/26/1666408/-The-Senate-Democrats-hell-no-caucus-takes-shape-laying-the-groundwork-for-2020 |title=The Senate Democrats' 'hell-no' caucus takes shape, laying groundwork for 2020 |website=Daily Kos |last1=Elevald |first1=Kerry |date=May 27, 2017 |access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref> Other speculation centered on then-[[Vice President of the United States|Vice-President]] [[Joe Biden]] making a third presidential bid following failed attempts in [[Joe Biden 1988 presidential campaign|1988]] and [[Joe Biden 2008 presidential campaign|2008]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2016/12/05/politics/joe-biden-2020-run-election/index.html |title=Joe Biden leaves the door open for a 2020 run |first1=Ted |last1=Barrett |first2=Daniella |last2=Diaz |access-date=June 15, 2019 |publisher=CNN}}</ref>

* '''July 28''': Representative [[John Delaney (Maryland politician)|John Delaney]] of [[Maryland]] announced [[John Delaney 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]] in an [[op-ed]] in ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref name="DelaneyAnnouncementOpEd" /> which broke the record for earliest major candidacy declaration in history.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dailykos.com/story/2017/7/29/1685409/-John-Delaney-s-Presidential-Campaign-Announcement-is-the-Earliest-in-History |title=John Delaney's Presidential Campaign Announcement is the Earliest in History |website=Daily Kos |author=MAINEiac4434 |date=July 30, 2017 |access-date=August 3, 2019}}</ref>

* '''November 6''': Entrepreneur [[Andrew Yang]] of [[New York (state)|New York]] announced [[Andrew Yang 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]].<ref name=":1">{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/03/politics/2020-dem-announcements/index.html |title=Here's how 2020 Democrats announced their campaigns |work=[[CNN]] |date=February 13, 2019 |first=Schwarz |last=Hunter |access-date=March 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190308010007/https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/03/politics/2020-dem-announcements/index.html |archive-date=March 8, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

The [[Democratic National Committee]] (DNC) made changes to the role of superdelegates, deciding to allow them to vote on the first ballot only if the nomination is uncontested.<ref name="superdelegates">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2018/03/10/dnc-advances-changes-presidential-nominating-process/413876002/ |title=DNC advances changes to presidential nominating process |work=USA TODAY |last1=Gaudiano |first1=Nicole |date=March 10, 2018|access-date=August 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180812023551/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2018/03/10/dnc-advances-changes-presidential-nominating-process/413876002/ |archive-date=August 12, 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref>

Democratic Party officials and television networks began discussions as to the nature and scheduling of the following year's debates and the nomination process.<ref name=":42">{{cite news |url=https://www.apnews.com/5068444bc8d549229b1c2b8fb079055b |title=APNewsBreak: DNC, TV networks discuss presidential debates |last1=Barrow |first1=Bill |date=August 25, 2018 |access-date=November 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181125204151/https://www.apnews.com/5068444bc8d549229b1c2b8fb079055b |archive-date=November 25, 2018 |url-status=live |work=Associated Press}}</ref>

*'''November 6''': The [[2018 United States elections|2018 midterm elections]] were held. The election was widely characterized as a [[Wave elections in the United States|"blue wave" election]]. Mass canvassing, voter registration drives and deep engagement techniques drove turnout high. Despite this, eventual presidential candidates [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Beto O'Rourke]] of [[Texas]] and [[State senator|State Senator]] [[Richard Ojeda]] of [[West Virginia]] both lost their respective races.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-11-08/what-do-the-2018-midterms-results-mean-for-democrats/10475752 |title=Democrats won power at the midterm elections. Here's how they could use it |last1=Olson |first1=Emily |last2=Marsh |first2=Peter |date=November 8, 2018 |work=ABC News |language=en-AU |access-date=August 3, 2019}}</ref>

*'''November 11''': Former state senator [[Richard Ojeda]] of [[West Virginia]] announced his candidacy.<ref>{{cite news |last=Grim |first=Ryan |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/11/11/richard-ojeda-2020-president/ |title=Richard Ojeda, West Virginia Lawmaker Who Backed Teachers Strikes, Will Run for President |date=November 12, 2018 |work=The Intercept |access-date=February 22, 2020 |language=en-US}}</ref>

*'''December 20''': The [[Democratic National Committee|DNC]] announced the preliminary schedule for the 12 official DNC-sanctioned debates, set to begin in June 2019, with six debates in 2019 and the remaining six during the first four months of 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/12/20/dnc-announces-12-presidential-debates-2020/2375649002/ |title=Democratic officials schedule 12 debates for 2020 presidential primary as they brace for huge field |work=USA Today |date=December 20, 2018}}</ref>

*'''December 31''': [[Elizabeth Warren|U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren]] of [[Massachusetts]] announced the formation of an exploratory committee to run for president.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Herndon|first1=Astead W.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/31/us/politics/elizabeth-warren-2020-president-announcement.html|title=Elizabeth Warren Announces Iowa Trip as She Starts Running for President in 2020|date=December 31, 2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=March 29, 2020|last2=Burns|first2=Alexander|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

* '''January 11''': [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Tulsi Gabbard]] of [[Hawaii]] announced [[Tulsi Gabbard 2020 presidential campaign|her candidacy]] during an interview on ''[[The Van Jones Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/01/11/politics/tulsi-gabbard-van-jones/index.html |title=Tulsi Gabbard says she will run for president in 2020 |last=Kelly |first=Caroline |date=January 11, 2019 |access-date=January 11, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190111233547/https://www.cnn.com/2019/01/11/politics/tulsi-gabbard-van-jones/index.html |archive-date=January 11, 2019 |url-status=live |language=en-US |publisher=CNN}}</ref>

* '''January 12''': Former [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]] [[Julian Castro]] officially announced his candidacy at a rally in [[San Antonio]], Texas.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/local/article/San-Antonio-s-Juli-n-Castro-announces-his-13528907.php |title=San Antonio's Julián Castro announces his candidacy for president |website=Houston Chronicle |last1=McGuinness |first1=Dan |date=January 12, 2019 |access-date=February 12, 2020}}</ref>

* '''January 15''': Senator [[Kirsten Gillibrand]] of [[New York (state)|New York]] announced the formation of an exploratory committee during an interview on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]''.<ref name="nyt2">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/15/us/politics/gillibrand-president-election.html |title=Kirsten Gillibrand, New York Senator, Joins Democratic Race for President |last=Goldmacher |first=Shane |date=January 15, 2019 |access-date=January 16, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190116024027/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/15/us/politics/gillibrand-president-election.html |archive-date=January 16, 2019 |url-status=live |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>

* '''January 21''': Senator [[Kamala Harris]] of [[California]] announced [[Kamala Harris 2020 presidential campaign|her candidacy]] during an interview on ''[[Good Morning America]]''.<ref name="harris announcement2">{{cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/beta-story-container/Politics/sen-kamala-harris-announces-run-president-2020/story?id=60472358 |title=Sen. Kamala Harris announces she will run for president in 2020 |last=Kelsey |first=Adam |date=January 21, 2019 |work=[[ABC News]] |access-date=January 21, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190121223318/https://abcnews.go.com/beta-story-container/Politics/sen-kamala-harris-announces-run-president-2020/story?id=60472358 |archive-date=January 21, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

* '''January 23''': Mayor [[Pete Buttigieg]] of [[South Bend, Indiana]], formed an exploratory committee.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/01/23/pete-buttigieg-2020-exploratory-committee-1120095 |title=Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg announces 2020 exploratory committee |last=Oprysko |first=Caitlin |date=January 23, 2019 |newspaper=[[Politico]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190413075509/https://www.politico.com/story/2019/01/23/pete-buttigieg-2020-exploratory-committee-1120095 |archive-date=April 13, 2019 |url-status=live |access-date=April 14, 2019}}</ref>

* '''January 28''': Author, activist, and spiritual leader [[Marianne Williamson]] announced her candidacy at a rally in [[Los Angeles, California]].<ref name="williamson " />
* '''February 1''': Senator [[Cory Booker]] of [[New Jersey]] announced [[Cory Booker 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]].<ref name="BookerAnnounce" />

* '''February 9''': Warren formally announced [[Elizabeth Warren 2020 presidential campaign|her candidacy]] at a rally in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-elizabeth-warren-20190209-story.html |title=Elizabeth Warren officially kicks off bid for White House |agency=Associated Press |access-date=February 9, 2019 |date=February 9, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190209232532/https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-elizabeth-warren-20190209-story.html |archive-date=February 9, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

* '''February 10''': Senator [[Amy Klobuchar]] of [[Minnesota]] announced [[Amy Klobuchar 2020 presidential campaign|her candidacy]] at a rally in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]].<ref name="klobuchar announcement2"/>

* '''February 19''': Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] of [[Vermont]] announced [[Bernie Sanders 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]] via an email to supporters and appeared on [[Vermont Public Radio]] as well as ''[[CBS This Morning]]'' as part of his campaign launch.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/02/19/676923000/bernie-sanders-enters-2020-presidential-campaign-no-longer-an-underdog |title=Bernie Sanders Enters 2020 Presidential Campaign, No Longer An Underdog |agency=NPR |first1=Scott |last1=Detrow |first2=Jessica |last2=Taylor |access-date=February 19, 2019 |date=February 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190219112714/https://www.npr.org/2019/02/19/676923000/bernie-sanders-enters-2020-presidential-campaign-no-longer-an-underdog |archive-date=February 19, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

Jay Inslee announces 2020 presidential bid |agency=CNN |last1=Merica |first1=Dan |access-date=March 1, 2019 |date=March 1, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190301121742/https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/01/politics/inslee-2020-presidential-campaign/index.html |archive-date=March 1, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

* '''March 11''': The DNC announced [[Milwaukee]], Wisconsin, as the site of the [[2020 Democratic National Convention]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Glauber |first1=Bill |last2=Spicuzza |first2=Mary |title=DNC: Milwaukee picked to host 2020 Democratic National Convention |url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2019/03/11/dnc-milwaukee-picked-host-2020-democratic-national-convention/2836684002/ |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |date=March 11, 2019 |access-date=March 11, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190311204119/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2019/03/11/dnc-milwaukee-picked-host-2020-democratic-national-convention/2836684002/ |archive-date=March 11, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
* '''March 13''': Mayor [[Wayne Messam]] of [[Miramar, Florida]], formed an exploratory committee.<ref name="Messam" />
* '''March 14''': Former Representative [[Beto O'Rourke]] of [[Texas]] announced [[Beto O'Rourke 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]].<ref name="Beto-announce" />

* '''March 17''': Gillibrand formally announced [[Kirsten Gillibrand 2020 presidential campaign|her candidacy]] via an online video.<ref>{{cite news |title=Senator Kirsten Gillibrand formally launches presidential campaign |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/17/senator-kirsten-gillibrand-formally-launches-presidential-campaign.html |agency=Reuters |date=March 17, 2019 |access-date=November 13, 2019}}</ref>

* '''March 28''': Messam formally announced his candidacy in an online video.<ref name="Messam" />

Issues like [[Electoral reform|democracy reform]] were discussed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/20/politics/progressive-summit-2020/index.html |title=Progressive groups to host April summit with 2020 candidates |last=Saenz |first=Arlette |access-date=March 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190320215117/https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/20/politics/progressive-summit-2020/index.html |archive-date=March 20, 2019 |url-status=live |publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://wethepeople2019.org/ |title=We The People Membership Summit 2019 |website=Wethepeople2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190427140155/https://wethepeople2019.org/ |archive-date=April 27, 2019 |url-status=live |access-date=April 24, 2019}}</ref>

* '''April 25''': Former Vice President [[Joe Biden]] of [[Delaware]] announced [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]] in an online video<ref name="jb " /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/joe-biden-launches-2020-presidential-run-n998236 |title=Biden launches 2020 presidential bid, says 'we are in a battle for the soul of this nation' |website=NBC News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200327135251/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/joe-biden-launches-2020-presidential-run-n998236 |archive-date=March 27, 2020 |url-status=live |access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref>

[[Economic issues]] affecting [[Poverty in the United States|low-income Americans]] were discussed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/top-2020-democrats-booked-las-vegas-labor-forum-april-n987686 |title=Top 2020 Democrats booked for Las Vegas labor forum in April |work=NBC News |last1=Allen |first1=Jonathan |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328032459/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/top-2020-democrats-booked-las-vegas-labor-forum-april-n987686 |archive-date=March 28, 2019 |url-status=live |access-date=March 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.workersforum.org/ |title=National Forum on Wages and Working People: Creating an Economy that Works for All |publisher=[[Center for American Progress|CAPAF]] and [[SEIU]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190424203122/https://www.workersforum.org/ |archive-date=April 24, 2019 |url-status=live |access-date=April 24, 2019}}</ref>

The reporting delays, errors, and inconsistencies surrounding the caucuses prompted DNC Chairman [[Tom Perez]] and both campaigns to call for a recanvass.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/live-blog/iowa-caucuses-live-updates-2020-democrats-make-their-final-pitches-n1128596 |title=Iowa caucus live updates: Democrats in limbo after results chaos |date=February 8, 2020 |website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/iowa-democratic-party-release-majority-caucus-results-tuesday-afternoon-n1129916 |title=Iowa Democratic Party to release 'majority' of caucus results by 5 p.m. ET on Tuesday |first1=Dartunurro |last1=Clark |first2=Ali |last2=Vitali |first3=Vaughn |last3=Hillyard |date=February 5, 2020 |website=NBC News}}</ref>

title: Elections in Nebraska
added: ==Voter Qualifications==

To register to vote in Nebraska, each applicant must be a citizen of the United States, a resident of the Nebraska county in which they are registering, and at least 18 years old by the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November. Citizens are eligible to register to vote on January 1 of the year they will turn 18 before the November general election. Individuals who have been convicted of a felony are ineligible to register to vote until two years after the terms of their sentence have been completed, and individuals who have been declared mentally incompetent by a court are ineligible to register to vote.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-09-30|title=Nebraska Voter Registration Background|url=https://sos.nebraska.gov/elections/nebraska-voter-registration-background|access-date=2021-09-28|website=Nebraska Secretary of State|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-09-27|title=Felon Voting Rights|url=https://sos.nebraska.gov/elections/felon-voting-rights|access-date=2021-09-28|website=Nebraska Secretary of State|language=en}}</ref>

title: QAnon
deleted: Flynn became active on speaking tours in 2021. A controversy arose in September 2021 when during a prayer he gave in Nebraska he invoked the terms "sevenfold rays" and "legions," terms  some of his QAnon followers said were not consistent with Christian doctrine and suggested he had turned to Satanism. Flynn attempted to dispel this, but some followers remained unconvinced. During the prayer, Flynn used language strikingly similar to that used by [[Elizabeth Clare Prophet]], leader of the [[Church Universal and Triumphant]], an anticommunist [[doomsday cult]] that about thirty years earlier had built fallout shelters and stockpiled guns in Montana in anticipation of a [[nuclear holocaust]]. Flynn had also appeared at a QAnon conference in April 2021 with an Oklahoma gubernatorial candidate whom Flynn had endorsed. The candidate later posted on social media a photo of his daughter wearing red shoes;  QAnon followers consider red shoes to be a sign of their Satanic sex-trafficking cabal theory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/michael-flynn-to-qanon-believers-im-not-a-satanist|title=Michael Flynn to QAnon Believers: I’m Not a Satanist!|first=Will|last=Sommer|date=October 8, 2021|via=www.thedailybeast.com}}</ref>

title: Doug LaMalfa
deleted: LaMalfa has a B+ rating from [[NumbersUSA]], an organization that advocates lower rates of legal immigration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.numbersusa.com/content/my/congress/9494/gradescoresheet|title=Representative Doug LaMalfa, Report Card | NumbersUSA - For Lower Immigration Levels|website=NumbersUSA.com|access-date=April 3, 2017|archive-date=April 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404045637/https://www.numbersusa.com/content/my/congress/9494/gradescoresheet|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Doug LaMalfa
deleted: LaMalfa's website states that he is "proud to have earned an A rating and the endorsements of the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] and [[Gun Owners of America]]."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.douglamalfa.com/issues-and-solutions/|title=Issues and Solutions {{!}} Doug LaMalfa for U.S. Representative|website=www.douglamalfa.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-03|archive-date=March 4, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304054658/http://www.douglamalfa.com/issues-and-solutions/|url-status=live}}</ref> He has received $13,500 from the NRA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opensecrets.org/industries/summary.php?ind=Q13&recipdetail=H&sortorder=S&cycle=All|title=Gun Rights: Money to Congress | OpenSecrets|website=www.opensecrets.org|access-date=March 3, 2018|archive-date=March 4, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304113212/https://www.opensecrets.org/industries/summary.php?ind=Q13&recipdetail=H&sortorder=S&cycle=All|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Doug LaMalfa
added: ===Joe Biden===

As of October 2021, LaMalfa had voted in line with [[Joe Biden]]'s stated position 10.3% of the time.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bycoffe |first1=Anna Wiederkehr and Aaron |title=Does Your Member Of Congress Vote With Or Against Biden? |url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-congress-votes/doug-lamalfa/|access-date=28 October 2021 |language=en |date=2021-10-22}}</ref>

title: Nebraska's 2nd congressional district
added: In 2021, Republicans proposed a new map for district 2 which encompasses southern Douglas County, Sarpy and Saunders counties. Another map backed by Democrats would keep Douglas County whole but move Bellevue, in Sarpy County, back into the 2nd District, where it was located prior to the Legislature’s 2011 redistricting. The Democratic plan would also remove suburban areas of the 2nd District that lean Republican.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nebraska redistricting panel hits impasse, turns to public |url=http://sandhillsexpress.com/state-news/nebraska-redistricting-panel-hits-impasse-turns-to-public-ncnidstory44702793/}}</ref>

title: Jacky Rosen
deleted: During the [[2018–2019 United States federal government shutdown|2018–2019 government shutdown]], Rosen co-sponsored the No Budget, No Pay Act.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rosen.senate.gov/rosen-co-sponsors-no-budget-no-pay-act-2019-calls-republicans-allow-vote-reopen-government|title=Rosen Co-sponsors No Budget, No Pay Act of 2019, Calls on Republicans to Allow a Vote to Reopen the Government |language=en-US|access-date=January 18, 2019}}</ref> On February 14, 2019, she voted to reopen the government without Trump's border wall.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rosen.senate.gov/rosen-votes-fund-government-calls-presidents-decision-declare-national-emergency-reckless|title=Rosen Votes to Fund the Government, Calls President's Decision to Declare a National Emergency Reckless |language=en-US|access-date=February 15, 2019}}</ref>

Rosen, [[Steve Daines]], [[Joe Manchin]], [[John Hoeven]], [[John Boozman]], and [[Jon Tester]], introduced the bipartisan TRICARE Reserve Improvement Act.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rosen.senate.gov/rosen-announces-co-sponsorship-bipartisan-tricare-reserve-improvement-act|title=Rosen Announces Co-sponsorship of Bipartisan Tricare Reserve Improvement Act |language=en-US|access-date=January 17, 2019}}</ref>

title: Jonathan Jackson (Illinois politician)
deleted: In 2011, Jackson assisted the wrongful conviction crusade of John Walker, an African American man from Buffalo, New York, who, in 1976, when he was just 16 years old, was falsely charged along with four of his closest friends, of having committed a brutal robbery/murder. The victim was an elderly Caucasian man named William Crawford. Mr. Crawford, who also lived in Buffalo, was assaulted after leaving a bar across the street from his home, on Friday, January 2, 1976. Walker and his friends were innocent and had verifiable alibis, but the Buffalo Police Department, and the Erie County District Attorney's Office, pursued them as suspects nonetheless. Moreover, when one of the youths caved in under what he would years later describe as having been intense intimidation and coercion antics on the part of the Buffalo Police Department personnel who interrogated him, the youths were indicted. In 1977, four of the youths were tried for the crime. Three were convicted, one was acquitted. Walker, Darryl Boyd, and Darryn Gibson were sentenced to 17-to-life, 20-to-life, and 25-to-life, respectively, and they were all sent to adult-population New York State prisons. Walker, after having been incarcerated for a total of 22 years, was released on lifetime parole terms, in 2000. In Upstate Western New York, the youths are referred to as [https://facebook.com/thebuffalo5 The Buffalo 5], but their birth names, are John Walker, Darryl Boyd, Darryn Gibson (deceased), Floyd Martin (deceased), and Tyrone Woodruff. Update: In August 2021, the wrongful 1977 convictions of Buffalo 5 members John Walker and Darryl Boyd were vacated, by New York State Supreme Court, in Buffalo.
NYS Supreme Court Justice Christopher J. Burns, presided.

title: Jonathan Jackson (Illinois politician)
added: In 2011, Jackson aided the wrongful conviction crusade of John Walker, an African American man from Buffalo, New York, who, in 1976, when he was just 16 years old, was falsely charged along with four of his closest friends, of having committed a brutal robbery/murder. The victim was an elderly Caucasian man named William Crawford. Walker and his friends were innocent and had verifiable alibis, but they were pursued as suspects nonetheless. In 1977, four of the youths were tried for the crime. Three were convicted, one was acquitted. Walker, Darryl Boyd, and Darryn Gibson were sentenced to 17-to-life, 20-to-life, and 25-to-life, respectively, and they were all sent to adult-population New York State prisons. Walker, after having been incarcerated for a total of 22 years, was released on lifetime parole terms, in 2000. In 2011, a mini-documentary concerning Walker's perspective of the episode, was written, directed, and produced by Dr. Peter K.B. St. Jean. Jonathan Jackson, and his father The Reverend Jesse L. Jackson, under the auspices of the elder Jackson's RainbowPUSH organization, made cameo appearances in that short film. In his cameo, the younger Jackson states "If it could happen to John Walker, it could happen to you"!. In Upstate Western New York, Walker and his four childhood friends are referred to as [https://facebook.com/thebuffalo5 The Buffalo 5]. Update: In August 2021, the wrongful 1977 convictions of Buffalo 5 members John Walker and Darryl Boyd were vacated, by New York State Supreme Court, in Buffalo.

title: Barack Obama
deleted: When Trump announced his withdrawal of the United States from the [[Paris Agreement]] on June 1, Obama released a statement disagreeing with the choice.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/01/politics/obama-paris-climate/ |title=Obama pans Trump withdrawal from climate deal|first=MJ|last=Lee|date=June 1, 2017|publisher=CNN}}</ref>

After Senate Republicans revealed the [[Better Care Reconciliation Act of 2017]], their discussion draft of a health care bill to replace the Affordable Care Act, Obama released a Facebook post on June 22 calling the bill "a massive transfer of wealth from middle-class and poor families to the richest people in America."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/339035-obama-slams-fundamental-meanness-at-the-core-of-senate-healthcare-bill |title=Obama slams 'fundamental meanness' of Senate healthcare bill|date=June 22, 2017|first=Max|last=Greenwood|newspaper=The Hill}}</ref> On September 19, while delivering the keynote address at Goalkeepers, Obama admitted his frustration with Republicans backing "a bill that will raise costs, reduce coverage, and roll back protections for older Americans and people with pre-existing conditions."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://time.com/4949837/obamacare-repeal-barack-obama-graham-cassidy/ |title=Barack Obama Criticizes '50th or 60th' Attempt to Repeal the Affordable Care Act|date=September 20, 2017|first=Alana|last=Abramson|work=Time}}</ref>

After Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] announced the termination of the [[Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals]] (DACA) program on September 5, Obama released a Facebook post criticizing the decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/05/politics/obama-daca/index.html |title=Obama slams Trump for rescinding DACA, calls move 'cruel'|first=Kevin|last=Liptak|publisher=CNN|date=September 5, 2017}}</ref> Two days later, Obama partnered with former presidents Jimmy Carter, George H. W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush to work with [[One America Appeal]] to help the victims of [[Hurricane Harvey]] and [[Hurricane Irma]] in the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] and [[Texas]] communities.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/349993-former-presidents-add-irma-recovery-to-fundraising-appeal |title=Former presidents fundraise for Irma disaster relief|last=Shelbourne|first=Mallory|date=September 10, 2017|work=The Hill|access-date=September 11, 2017}}</ref>

title: 1804 United States presidential election
deleted: The February 1804 Democratic-Republican [[congressional nominating caucus]] selected the ticket. Unlike the previous election, the nominating caucus did not meet in secret. Jefferson's re-nomination was never in any real doubt, with the real issue being seen as who the party would nominate to replace Vice President [[Aaron Burr]], whose relationship with Jefferson had soured. Governor [[George Clinton (vice president)|George Clinton]] of New York was chosen as Jefferson's running mate, continuing the party's tradition of nominating a ticket consisting of a Virginian and a New Yorker.<ref name="deskins1">{{cite book|last1=Deskins|first1=Donald Richard|last2=Walton|first2=Hanes|last3=Puckett|first3=Sherman|title=Presidential Elections, 1789-2008: County, State, and National Mapping of Election Data|date=2010|publisher=University of Michigan Press|pages=41–42}}</ref>
* [[John Breckinridge (U.S. Attorney General)|John Breckinridge]] ([[Kentucky]]), U.S. Senator
* [[George Clinton (vice president)|George Clinton]] ([[New York (state)|New York]]), Governor
* [[John Langdon (politician)|John Langdon]] ([[New Hampshire]]), former U.S. Senator
* [[Levi Lincoln Sr.|Levi Lincoln]] ([[Massachusetts]]), U.S. Attorney General

The Federalists did not hold a nominating caucus, but Federalist Congressional leaders informally agreed to nominate a ticket consisting of [[Charles Cotesworth Pinckney]] of South Carolina and former Senator [[Rufus King]] of New York.<ref name="deskins1"/> Pinckney's public service during and after the [[American Revolutionary War]] had won him national stature, and Federalists hoped that Pinckney would win some Southern votes away from Jefferson, who had dominated the Southern vote in the previous election.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zahniser|first1=Marvin|title=Charles Cotesworth Pinckney: Founding Father|url=https://archive.org/details/charlescoteswort00zahn|url-access=registration|date=1967|publisher=University of North Carolina Press|pages=[https://archive.org/details/charlescoteswort00zahn/page/243 243–246]}}</ref>

title: False or misleading statements by Donald Trump
deleted: In March 2019, Trump asserted that the special counsel investigation was "illegal". Previously in June 2018, Trump argued that "the appointment of the Special Counsel is totally UNCONSTITUTIONAL!" However, in August 2018, [[Dabney L. Friedrich|Dabney Friedrich]], a Trump-appointed judge on the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|DC District Court]] ruled the appointment was constitutional, as did a unanimous three-judge panel of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit|Court of Appeals for the DC Circuit]] in February 2019.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/21/politics/fact-check-trump-says-mueller-investigation-is-illegal/index.html |title=Fact-check: Trump claims Mueller investigation 'illegal', ignoring multiple court rulings |first1=Holmes |last1=Lybrand |first2=Marshall |last2=Cohen |publisher=CNN |access-date=March 23, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190322211918/https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/21/politics/fact-check-trump-says-mueller-investigation-is-illegal/index.html |archive-date=March 22, 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Dukakis |first1=Ali |title=Appeals court says special counsel Robert Mueller 'properly appointed'; orders ex-Stone aide to testify |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/appeals-court-mueller-properly-appointed-orders-stone-aide/story?id=61327058 |work=[[ABC News]] |access-date=March 23, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190327085953/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/appeals-court-mueller-properly-appointed-orders-stone-aide/story?id=61327058 |archive-date=March 27, 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref>

title: Greg Rothman
added: In 1991, Rothman was charged with [[Conspiracy (law)|conspiracy]] to commit [[forgery]], a [[misdemeanor]]. He pleaded guilty in March 1994 and was sentenced to 5 months' probation, a $2,000 fine, and 160 hours' community service. Rothman was 27 years old at the time. The conspiracy charge arose from a campaign mailer attacking William F. Kane, a candidate for county commission; the mailer included a bogus return address and was falsely attributed to an organization.<ref name=Marroni>Steve Marroni, [https://www.pennlive.com/midstate/2015/07/greg_rothman_87th_special_elec.html 'I did something stupid': GOP candidate in Pa. House race on decades-old charge],

''PennLive'' (July 8, 2015).</ref> The conviction was later [[expunged]], and [[Ed Rendell]] issued Rothman a pardon in January 2011.<ref name=Marroni/> Rothman said in 2015 that he had learned from the mistake and took responsibility for it.<ref name=Marroni/>

After [[Donald Trump]] was defeated by [[Joe Biden]] in the [[2020 presidential election]] (including in Pennsylvania, where Biden won by over 80,000 votes), Rothman was one of 26 Pennsylvania House Republicans who called for the election to be overturned by withdrawing the Pennsylvania's certification of its [[Electoral College (United States)|presidential electors]]. The group of Republicans falsely claimed that the election was marred by fraud. The letter came after Trump's campaign lost multiple court cases due to lack of evidence.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Murphy |first1=Jan |author1-link=Jan Murphy |title=26 Pa. House Republicans call for withdrawing certification of presidential electors |url=https://www.pennlive.com/elections/2020/11/26-pa-house-republicans-call-for-withdrawing-certification-of-presidential-electors.html |work=[[The Patriot-News]] |date=27 November 2020 |language=en}}</ref><ref>[https://www.witf.org/2021/01/28/witf-is-connecting-these-lawmakers-to-their-actions-on-the-election-fraud-lie-heres-why/ WITF is connecting these lawmakers to their actions on the election-fraud lie. Here’s why], WITF (January 28, 2021).</ref>

title: Mia Mottley
added: Mottley addressed the [[United Nations General Assembly]] in New York  on 24 September 2021 with a short speech to support [[UN Secretary-General]] [[António Guterres]]' warnings that the world is moving in the wrong direction. She threw away her original script and instead gave a passionate post in which she called for global, moral leadership in the fight against climate change, economic and technological inequality, racism and unfair distribution of coronary vaccines.

title: Environmental policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: === Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) ===

In September 2021, the EPA planned to issue its final rule to reduce [[hydrofluorocarbon]] (HFC) emissions by 85% within 15 years. HFCs are greenhouse gases that are thousands of times more potent than {{CO2}}.<ref>{{Cite web|last=D'Angelo|first=Chris|date=2021-09-23|title=Biden Administration Finalizes Rule To Slash Super-Pollutant HFCs|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/hydrofluorocarbons-epa-final-rule-biden_n_614be8cfe4b098483a71b4a9|access-date=2021-09-23|website=HuffPost|language=en}}</ref>

title: Abdullah Gül
deleted: Fırat Averbek, 10.09.1988 tarihinde Batman'da doğdu. Çocukluğundan beri teknolojiye ve bilgisayara ilgisi oldu. Şimdi ise Türkiye'nin sayılı Siber Güvenlik Uzmanlarından bir tanesi. Asıl uzmanlık alanı Siber Terörizm Uzmanı. Aynı zamanda Siber Suçlar ve Güvenliği Eğitmeni olan Fırat Averbek 'Siber Vatan' terimini Türkçe'mize katmıştır. Son ABD seçimlerinden sonra bütün sosyal medya platformlarından banlanan ve erişimi engellenen Donald Trump Milli Siber Güvenlik Uzmanımız Fırat Averbek ile yeni bir sosyal medya platformu oluşturmaya hazırlanıyor. Trump'ın Siber Güvenlik Danışmanı olan Fırat Averbek uygulamanın çok kısa bir süre içerisinde hayata geçeceği ve büyük sükse yaratacağını söyledi.

title: Lloyd Austin
deleted: On December 8, 2006, Austin was promoted to [[Lieutenant General (United States)|lieutenant general]], and assumed command of the [[XVIII Airborne Corps (United States)|XVIII Airborne Corps]], Fort Bragg, North Carolina.<ref>{{Cite news|date=August 28, 2006|title=Maj. Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III to Command Fort Bragg 18th Airborne Corps|pages=36–37|work=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bDoDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36|url-status=live|access-date=December 10, 2020|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211042346/https://books.google.com/books?id=bDoDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36}}</ref> In February 2008, Austin became the second highest ranking commander in [[Iraq]], taking command of the Multi-National Corps{{snd}}Iraq (MNC-I). As commander of MNC-I, he directed the operations of approximately 152,000 joint and coalition forces in all sectors of Iraq.<ref name="Briefing">{{cite web|access-date=December 2, 2020|url=http://www.defenselink.mil/transcripts/transcript.aspx?transcriptid=4248|title=DoD News Briefing with Lt. Gen. Austin III from Iraq|format=News Transcript|date=June 23, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121011921/http://www.defenselink.mil/transcripts/transcript.aspx?transcriptid=4248|archive-date=January 21, 2009|url-status=dead|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] }} {{Include-USGov|agency=United States Department of Defense}}</ref>

title: Lloyd Austin
added: On September 1, 2010, Austin became Commanding General (CG) of [[United States Forces – Iraq]] (USF-I) at a ceremony at [[Al-Faw Palace]] in Baghdad. He assumed the role from General [[Ray Odierno]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.army.mil/article/44757/austin_leads_usf_i_into_new_dawn|title=Austin leads USF-I into New Dawn|last=Dey|first=Roger M.|publisher=[[United States Army]]|access-date=May 18, 2016|date=September 4, 2010|archive-date=January 26, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190126232248/https://www.army.mil/article/44757/austin_leads_usf_i_into_new_dawn|url-status=live}}</ref>{{sfn|Gordon|Trainor|2013|p=637}} As CG, USF-I, Austin was the senior military commander in charge of all US and remaining coalition forces in Iraq.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usf-iraq.com/usf-iraq-commanding-general/|title=USF-Iraq Commanding General|date=December 5, 2010|publisher=[[United States Forces – Iraq]]|access-date=December 2, 2020|archive-date=October 20, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201020144545/https://www.usf-iraq.com/usf-iraq-commanding-general/|url-status=live}}</ref> Their mission was to advise, train, assist, and equip the [[Iraqi Armed Forces]] and the security agencies part of the [[Ministry of Interior (Iraq)|Ministry of the Interior]]. As commander, Austin requested an additional troop presence in Iraq from 14,000 to 18,000.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Singh|first=Robert|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YQnrSo2YyTEC&pg=PA106|title=Barack Obama's Post-American Foreign Policy: The Limits of Engagement|year=2012|publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-78093-113-5|page=106|language=en|access-date=December 8, 2020|archive-date=December 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208212744/https://books.google.com/books?id=YQnrSo2YyTEC&pg=PA106|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: 2019 Kentucky gubernatorial election
added: Bevin carried 97 of Kentucky's 120 counties. However, Beshear swamped Bevin in urban areas. Beshear carried the state's two largest counties, [[Jefferson County, Kentucky|Jefferson]] and [[Fayette County, Kentucky|Fayette]]–home to Louisville and Lexington, respectively–with over 60 percent of the vote. He also narrowly carried the state's third-largest county, [[Kenton County, Kentucky|Kenton County]], which is normally very Republican.
