journalist [[Lauren Windsor]],<ref name=VICEstunt></ref> who would later also admit her role.<ref>{{cite web |title=https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1jMJgeVbNlmKL |url=https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1jMJgeVbNlmKL |website=Twitter |access-date=29 October 2021 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=VICEstunt></ref> A spokesperson for Democratic nominee McAuliffe called the hoax "disgusting and distasteful, and we condemn it in the strongest terms", adding that "Those involved should immediately apologize.”<ref name=VICEstunt></ref><ref name=APstunt></ref> Democratic delegate [[Sally L. Hudson]] tweeted that "Charlottesville is not a prop. Our community is still reeling from years of trauma — especially this week. Don’t come back, @ProjectLincoln. Your stunts aren’t welcome here"<ref>{{cite news |title=Anti-Trump group takes credit for Virginia tiki torch stunt |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/anti-trump-group-takes-credit-for-virginia-tiki-torch-stunt/2021/10/29/1a25c968-390d-11ec-9662-399cfa75efee_story.html |access-date=29 October 2021 |work=Washington Post}}</ref>

title: Jackie Lacey
added: you ==Criticism==
===Refusal to prosecute Ed Buck===

Lacey was heavily criticized for refusing to prosecute [[Ed Buck]], a wealthy [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] donor, following the 2017 drug overdose death of a young Black man named Gemmel Moore in Buck's apartment. At the time, [[Los Angeles County Sheriff]]'s deputies found "nearly two grams of [[methamphetamine]], syringes and drug paraphernalia throughout the residence".<ref>{{cite web | title=It took two years to arrest Democratic donor Ed Buck despite shocking allegations, red flags. Why?| url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-09-28/gemmel-moore-died-25-months-ago-why-did-it-take-so-long-to-charge-ed-buck-with-a-crime |work= Los Angeles Times}}</ref> Black and LGBTQ community activists and local attorneys called on Lacey to prosecute Buck, and Moore's family "provided authorities with substantial evidence, including the names of several other victims, that Buck engaged in a pattern of drugging, video-taping, and sexually assaulting black men."<ref>{{cite web | title=Judge Scorches DA in Lawsuit Alleging Racial Bias in Case of Democratic Donor Ed Buck| url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/judge-demands-answers-from-da-jackie-lacey-about-racial-bias-in-ed-buck-case |work= The Daily Beast}}</ref>

Six months after Lacey declined to prosecute Ed Buck for Gemmel Moore's death, another Black man, Timothy Dean, was found dead of a drug overdose in Buck's apartment in January 2019.<ref>{{cite web | title=Man Who Died in Democratic Donor Ed Buck's Home Called Him 'The Devil'| url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/man-who-died-in-democratic-donor-ed-bucks-home-called-him-the-devil |work= The Daily Beast}}</ref> Activists renewed their calls to Lacey to prosecute Buck, but again she declined. In an October 2019 meeting of the Stonewall Democratic Club, a [[LGBT social movements|gay rights]] organization in Los Angeles, Lacey claimed that Sheriff's deputies' illegal search and seizure of evidence in Buck's residence at the time of Moore's death rendered the evidence inadmissible in court, and therefore "presented a challenge" to her efforts to prosecute. She did not respond to participants' criticism that deputies should not have taken legal advice from a coroner, as Lacey claimed they had.<ref>{{cite web | title=D.A. Jackie Lacey faults errors by Sheriff's Department, coroner's investigator in Ed Buck probe| url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-10-29/jackie-lacey-ed-buck-investigation-problems |work= Los Angeles Times}}</ref>

Ed Buck was arrested in September 2019 following a 911 call by a young Black man who was experiencing an overdose of methamphetamine administered by Buck. The man was taken to a hospital and survived.<ref>{{cite web | title=Democratic donor arrested after third man overdoses at his West Hollywood home| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2019/09/18/ed-buck-drug-den-arrest-hollywood-overdose-democratic-donor/ |work= Washington Post}}</ref> Lacey's office then charged Buck with "one felony count each of battery causing serious injury, administering methamphetamine and maintaining a drug house."<ref>{{cite web | title=Man Charged With Running Drug Den in West Hollywood Apartment| url=https://da.lacounty.gov/sites/default/files/press/091819_Man_Charged_With_Running_Drug_Den_in_West_Hollywood_Apartment.pdf |work= Los Angeles County District Attorney}}</ref>

In spite of Buck's eventual arrest and prosecution, Black and LGBTQ activists in Los Angeles have continued to protest Lacey, her office, and the lengthy delay in charging Buck. In February 2020, the Los Angeles New Frontier Democratic Club, “the oldest and largest [[African American]] Democratic club in the state of California”, declined to endorse Lacey's reelection. Rep. [[Maxine Waters]] of Los Angeles and California's junior U.S. Senator [[Kamala Harris]], both Black women, endorsed Lacey's opponent, former [[San Francisco District Attorney]] [[George Gascón]], in their November 2020 runoff, and Black Lives Matter activists have protested outside Lacey's home in March, June, and July 2020.<ref>{{cite web | title=Banks: For some black Angelenos, the Jackie Lacey glow has dimmed as she seeks reelection as D.A.| url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-02-25/jackie-lacey-district-attorney-race-black-community |work= Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref name="Los Angeles Times">{{cite web | title=D.A. Jackie Lacey's husband pulls gun on Black Lives Matter protesters at his home| url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-03-02/police-called-to-jackie-laceys-home-in-response-to-protesters-outside |work= Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Amid police brutality protests, demonstrators target D.A. Jackie Lacey| url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-06-10/amid-weeks-of-protest-expressing-outrage-at-police-brutality-demonstrators-target-d-a-jackie-lacey |work= Los Angeles Times| date=10 June 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Protesters Gather Near DA Jackie Lacey's Home, Call For Her Resignation| url=https://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2020/07/02/protesters-gather-near-da-jackie-laceys-home/ |work= CBS Los Angeles| date=2 July 2020 }}</ref>
===Celebrity cases===

Lacey has been criticized for not charging [[Bikram Choudhury]] criminally: there is a "reluctance of the district attorney to go after powerful men" as described in [[Netflix]]'s 2019 documentary film, ''[[Bikram: Yogi, Guru, Predator]]'',<ref name="Bikram">{{cite web | title=new documentary delves into charges against Bikram yoga founder| url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/movies/story/2019-11-22/bikram-choudhury-netflix-documentary-yoga-sexual-assault |work= Los Angeles Times| date=22 November 2019 }}</ref> despite numerous women coming forward with allegations of sexual assault and rape. Her office has refused to comment publicly on their lack of action on this matter. Choudhury fled the country after receiving an arrest warrant.<ref name="Bikram"/>

Lacey has similarly been criticized for inaction in the case of four women who report having been raped by actor [[Danny Masterson]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2019/08/15/harassment-stalking-cover-up-scientology-faces-new-scrutiny-with-danny-masterson-lawsuit/|title = Harassment, stalking, cover-up: Scientology faces new scrutiny with Danny Masterson lawsuit|date = 15 August 2019}}</ref><ref name=lapd-confirmed>{{cite news|first1=Natalie|last1=Stone|title=That '70s Show's Danny Masterson Is Being Investigated by LAPD Over Sexual Assault Claims|url=http://people.com/celebrity/danny-masterson-being-investigated-sexual-assault-claims/|access-date=March 4, 2017|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|location=New York City|date=March 3, 2017|archive-date=November 9, 2017|archive-url=https://archive.today/20171109003321/http://people.com/celebrity/danny-masterson-being-investigated-sexual-assault-claims/|url-status=live}}</ref>
=== Campaign contributions from law enforcement unions ===

In June 2020, a group of high-profile prosecutors from California's most heavily populated counties, lobbied the [[State Bar of California|California State Bar]] to prohibit District Attorneys from accepting donations from law enforcement unions, citing the possible conflicts of interest with respect to how district attorneys investigate, prosecute, or interact with police officers.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-01|title=In wake of George Floyd killing, California prosecutors lobby to stop DA's from accepting police union money|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/in-wake-of-george-floyd-killing-ca-prosecutors-lobby-to-stop-das-from-accepting-police-union-money|access-date=2020-06-07|website=The Mercury News|language=en-US}}</ref> Lacey has publicly opposed this proposed prohibition.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Martin|first=Brittany|date=2020-06-05|title=Jackie Lacey Rejects Calls to Keep Police Union Money Out of DA Campaigns|work=Los Angeles Magazine|url=https://www.lamag.com/citythinkblog/jackie-lacey-police-union-money/}}</ref> During the 2020 Los Angeles County District Attorney primary election, law enforcement unions had contributed over 75% of the $2.2 million raised by Lacey.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-02-24|title=Police unions, justice reformers battle for dollars in bitter L.A. County D.A. race|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-02-24/political-donations-jackie-lacey-george-gascon-los-angeles-district-attorney|access-date=2020-06-01|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref> Lacey ultimately won a plurality of votes in the race, given broad financial support from these law enforcement unions, including [[Association for Los Angeles Deputy Sheriffs]] (ALADS) and [[Los Angeles Police Protective League]] (LAPPL).<ref>{{Cite web|last=Stuart|first=Gwynedd|date=2020-03-09|title=How Jackie Lacey Managed to Dominate the DA's Race Despite Strong Opposition|url=https://www.lamag.com/citythinkblog/jackie-lacey-primary-results/|access-date=2020-06-01|website=Los Angeles Magazine|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Eric Adams
added: In the 1990s, Adams began to eye a political career, with the ultimate goal to become the Mayor of New York City. He spoke to [[William Lynch Jr.]], who was an advisor to Mayor [[David Dinkins]], about a political career.<ref name="Kind" /> Lynch encouraged Adams to first obtain a bachelors degree, rise within the NYPD's ranks and successfully run for a lower political office.<ref name="Kind" />

title: Eric Adams
added: Following his primary victory, Adams hosted a series of pricey political fundraisers in [[The Hamptons]] and [[Martha’s Vineyard]] and vacationed in [[Monte Carlo]], which critics contend contradicts his message of being a "blue-collar" mayor.<ref name="Kind" />

title: Eric Adams
added: ====Gentrification====

In 2017 when speaking about gentrification, Adams said  "Our young people coming in need to understand that they are not the modern-day Christopher Columbus: They did not discover Brooklyn. Brooklyn was here long before they set sail, and if anything they need to be part of the greatness of Brooklyn and add their flavor, but not destroy what we are."<ref name="Town" />

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Arizona
added: Even after the election had come and gone, the [[Arizona Republican Party|Republican]]-majority [[Arizona Senate]] established a [[2021 Maricopa County presidential ballot audit|Maricopa County-based taxpayer-funded inquiry]] into the “voter fraud” alleged by the former President and his radical supporters. This audit took till September 2021 to be completed, and was considered something of a humiliation for its instigators because not only did it reaffirm there being no evidence of any voter irregularities, but it actually revealed Biden’s margin was larger than previously thought. <ref>{{Cite news|last=Schwartz|first=David|last2=Layne|first2=Nathan|date=2021-09-27|title='Truth is truth': Trump dealt blow as Republican-led Arizona audit reaffirms Biden win|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/arizona-republicans-release-findings-widely-panned-election-audit-2021-09-24/|access-date=2021-09-28}}</ref> The audit revealed an additional 99 votes for Biden, and 261 less for Trump- increasing Biden’s victory by 360 votes.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Corse|first=Alexa|date=2021-09-25|title=Arizona GOP’s Election Audit Confirms Biden Win in State|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/arizona-gops-election-audit-confirms-biden-win-in-draft-report-11632467822|access-date=2021-09-28|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

title: Rachael Rollins
added: ===U.S. Attorney nomination===

In July 2021, President [[Joe Biden]] nominated Rollins to be the [[United States Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts|District of Massachusetts]]. Republican U.S. Senator [[Tom Cotton]] said he would try to prevent Rollins from being confirmed, saying she supported policies that have contributed to an increase in violent crime. In September 2021, a committee vote to advance Rollins' nomination was delayed after Cotton wanted more time to convince colleagues to oppose her.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Estes |first1=Andrea |title=Rachael Rollins confirmation vote for U.S. attorney delayed by GOP senator |url=https://www.boston.com/uncategorized/politics/2021/09/23/rachael-rollins-confirmation-vote-for-u-s-attorney-delayed-by-gop-senator/ |access-date=30 September 2021 |work=www.boston.com |date=September 23, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Rachael Rollins' US Attorney Nomination Held Up By Republican Senator |url=https://boston.cbslocal.com/2021/09/23/rachael-rollins-us-attorney-nomination-tom-cotton-vote-republicans/ |access-date=30 September 2021 |publisher=CBS Boston |date=23 September 2021}}</ref>

title: COVID-19 pandemic in the United States
COVID-19 pandemic in the United States
COVID-19 pandemic in the United States
added: ===Endorsements by celebrities===

Many celebrities have actively promoted getting vaccinated for COVID-19.<ref name=Glamour/> In previous pandemics, such as polio in the 1950s, famous people were setting an example. For example, in 1956, [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Debbie Reynolds]] were photographed being vaccinated with a news story in the "New York Times" when less than 1% of teenagers had yet received their polio vaccination.<ref name=Glamour/> Such celebrity endorsements were considered essential to help raise vaccine rates.

Similarly, the COVID-19 vaccines are also endorsed for the same reasons. Media celebrities have publicized themselves getting vaccinated, giving their firsthand accounts. They did so to help quell skepticism at a time vaccinations were being given across the world. Among them were [[Anthony Anderson]], who was initially "on the fence" about it but then changed his mind. He wanted to encourage others to do the same. [[Britney Spears]] received her vaccine dose, which she posted with a video on social media, stating how she "felt nothing" and was "fine" after her shot.<ref name=USAToday>[https://www.usatoday.com/picture-gallery/entertainment/celebrities/2021/01/11/queen-elizabeth-joan-collins-more-celebs-getting-covid-19-vaccine/6630401002/ "Duchess Kate, Ellen DeGeneres and more celebs who got the COVID-19 vaccine"], ''USA Today'', June 4, 2021</ref>

{{quote box | align = right | width = 25em | bgcolor = MistyRose | quote = I am so proud of and grateful to the doctors, nurses, and medical staff who are wading through the red tape and confusion of the distribution of these very important vaccines. I am excited to have received my dosage and look forward to the booster. | source = —[[Martha Stewart]]<ref name=USMagazine>[https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/stars-whove-spoken-out-about-getting-the-covid-19-vaccine/sarah-hyland/ "Steve Martin, Martha Stewart and More Stars Who’ve Spoken Out About Getting the COVID-19 Vaccine"], ''US Magazine'', Sept. 16, 2021</ref>

To further those efforts, in April 2021, President [[Joe Biden]], former President [[Barack Obama]] and a slew of celebrities appeared on an NBC Prime Time Special, "Roll Up Your Sleeves," which they hoped would boost vaccination rates.  Among them were [[Billy Crystal]], [[Jennifer Hudson]] and [[Lin-Manuel Miranda]]. Actor [[Matthew McConaughey]] was shown interviewing Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]] to eliminate vaccine confusion and misinformation.<ref name=APNews-2>[https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-lin-manuel-miranda-jennifer-lopez-anthony-fauci-faith-hill-20566e45ea06db8c9e651e91f5efc6d5 "Celebrities make a stand for COVID vaccines on TV special"], ''AP News'', April 16, 2021</ref>

A month later, at Global Citizen’s "Vax Live: The Concert to Reunite the World" at [[SoFi Stadium]] in [[Inglewood, California]], also aimed to promote distribution of vaccines. Biden again stated that the vaccination was safe, while others, such as [[Prince Harry]], urged widespread vaccine distribution. Singers [[Jennifer Lopez]] and [[Foo Fighters]] were among the performers in what was the largest concert in Southern California since the pandemic began.<ref>[https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/6/171294/Harry,-Jennifer-Lopez-join-Biden-to-assure-vaccination-safety "Harry, Jennifer Lopez join Biden to assure vaccination safety"], "The Standard", May 3, 2021</ref>

Along with public events, some magazines such as ''Glamour'', began grading celebrities on their efforts to promote the vaccine.<ref name=Glamour>[https://www.glamour.com/story/celebrities-who-have-gotten-the-vaccine "Grading Celebrities on How Much They've Hyped the Vaccine"], "Glamour", August 17, 2021</ref> While other publications included photos of them as they received a vaccination, to make the event public.<ref>[https://people.com/health/celebrities-and-politicians-get-covid-19-vaccine-photos/?slide=2a1fc19c-6e2f-4fc5-b038-56a68db39093#2a1fc19c-6e2f-4fc5-b038-56a68db39093 "Celebrities and Politicians Getting the COVID-19 Vaccine: See the Photos"], ''People'' magazine, June 1, 2021</ref> Teenage activist [[Greta Thunberg]], for instance, posted a photo of herself and wrote, "Today I got my first COVID-19 vaccination dose. I am extremely grateful and privileged to live in a part of the world where I can already get vaccinated. The vaccine distribution around the world is unequal. … No one is safe until everyone is safe. But when you get offered a vaccine, don't hesitate. It saves lives." <ref name=USMagazine/>

title: COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

title: COVID-19 pandemic in the United States
added: The '''COVID-19 pandemic in the United States''' is part of the [[COVID-19 pandemic|worldwide pandemic]] of coronavirus disease 2019 ({{nowrap|[[COVID-19]]}}). </noinclude>{{COVID-19 data/Text|US|cases}} confirmed cases have been reported<includeonly> in the United States</includeonly> since January 2020, with {{COVID-19 data/Text|US|deaths}} deaths, the most of any country, and [[COVID-19 pandemic death rates by country|the twenty-second-highest]] per capita worldwide.<ref name="JH Mortality">{{cite web|url= https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/data/mortality|title=Mortality Analyses|publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University]]|access-date=December 17, 2020}}</ref> As many infections have gone undetected, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) estimated that, as of May 2021, there could be a total 120.2{{nbsp}}million infections in the United States, or more than a third of the total population.<ref name=CNN.Third>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-04-29-21/h_40d99e1d1aab9c3a21ec4aab66071f86|title=More than a third of the US has been infected with Covid-19, CDC estimates|publisher=CNN|last=Nedelman|first=Michael|date=April 29, 2021|access-date=April 29, 2021|name-list-style=vanc}}</ref><ref name=CDC-Estimated>{{Cite web|first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Estimated COVID-19 Burden |website=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC)|date=July 27, 2021 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/burden.html  |access-date=August 11, 2021|name-list-style=vanc}}</ref> COVID-19 is the[[List of disasters in the United States by death toll|deadliest pandemic in U.S. history]];<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-09-21|title=COVID-19 surpasses 1918 flu as deadliest pandemic in U.S. history|url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/history/article/covid-19-is-now-the-deadliest-pandemic-in-us-history|access-date=2021-10-02|website=History|language=en}}</ref> itwas the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. in 2020, behind heart disease and cancer.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/us-coronavirus-deaths-top-3-million-e2bc856b6ec45563b84ee2e87ae8d5e7|title=US deaths title: Steele dossier
added: ==== Against Oath Inc. (Verizon Media). Filed by Carter Page ====

Page's suit targeted Oath for 11 articles, especially one written by Michael Isikoff and published by Yahoo! in September 2016. The judge dismissed the suit on February 14, 2021, noting that "Page's arguments regarding Isikoff's description of the dossier and Steele were 'either sophistry or political spin'." He also said that Page "failed to allege actual malice by any of the authors, and that the three articles written by HuffPost employees were true".<ref name="Chase_2/14/2021">{{cite web | last=Chase | first=Randall | date=February 14, 2021 | title=Judge tosses Page defamation suit against Verizon company | agency=[[Associated Press]] | url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/judge-tosses-page-defamation-suit-verizon-company-75894421 | access-date=September 14, 2021 }}</ref>

title: Steele dossier
added: Following the dossier's release, Steele completely avoided on-camera interviews until he participated in an ABC News documentary that was released on October 18, 2021. In that documentary, Steele maintained that his sources were credible and that it was typical in intelligence investigations to "never get to the point where you're 99% certain of the evidence to secure a conviction." Steele also acknowledged that one of his sources had faced repercussions; he confirmed that the source was still alive, but he would not provide further details.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Pellish|first=Aaron|last2=Herb|first2=Jeremy|date=18 October 2021|title=Ex-intel official who created controversial Trump Russia dossier speaks out|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/17/politics/christopher-steele-dossier-trump/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-18|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: Lee Atwater
added: === "Southern strategy" ===

As a member of the Reagan administration in 1981, Atwater gave an anonymous interview to political scientist Alexander P. Lamis. Part of the interview was printed in Lamis' book ''The Two-Party South'', then reprinted in ''Southern Politics in the 1990s'' with Atwater's name revealed. [[Bob Herbert]] reported on the interview in the October 6, 2005, issue of ''[[The New York Times]]''. On November 13, 2012, ''[[The Nation]]'' magazine released a 42-minute audio recording of the interview.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Rick Perlstein |date=November 13, 2012 |title=Exclusive: Lee Atwater's Infamous 1981 Interview on the Southern Strategy |work=[[The Nation]] |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/170841/exclusive-lee-atwaters-infamous-1981-interview-southern-strategy |url-status=live |access-date=November 18, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117195357/http://www.thenation.com/article/170841/exclusive-lee-atwaters-infamous-1981-interview-southern-strategy |archive-date=November 17, 2012}}</ref> James Carter IV, grandson of former president [[Jimmy Carter]], had asked and been granted access to these tapes by Lamis' widow. Atwater talked about the Republican Southern strategy:

<blockquote>''Atwater'': As to the whole Southern strategy that [[Harry S. Dent, Sr.]] and others put together in 1968, opposition to the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965|Voting Rights Act]] would have been a central part of keeping the South. Now you don't have to do that. All that you need to do to keep the South is for Reagan to run in place on the issues that he's campaigned on since 1964, and that's fiscal conservatism, balancing the budget, cut taxes, you know, the whole cluster.

''Questioner'': But the fact is, isn't it, that Reagan does get to the Wallace voter and to the racist side of the Wallace voter by doing away with legal services, by cutting down on [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program|food stamps]]?

''Atwater:'' Y'all don't quote me on this. You start out in 1954 by saying, "Nigger, nigger, nigger". By 1968 you can't say "nigger"—that hurts you. Backfires. So you say stuff like [[desegregation busing|forced busing]], [[states' rights]] and all that stuff. You're getting so abstract now [that] you're talking about cutting taxes, and all these things you're talking about are totally economic things and a byproduct of them is [that] blacks get hurt worse than whites. And subconsciously maybe that is part of it. I'm not saying that. But I'm saying that if it is getting that abstract, and that coded, that we are doing away with the racial problem one way or the other. You follow me—because obviously sitting around saying, "We want to cut this", is much more abstract than even the busing thing, and a hell of a lot more abstract than "Nigger, nigger". So, any way you look at it, race is coming on the back-burner.{{Cite book |last=Lamis |first=Alexander P. |url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/18051532 |title=The Two Party South |date=1988 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-505680-9 |location=New York |pages=26 |oclc=18051532}}
Atwater also argued that Reagan did not need to make racial appeals, suggesting that Reagan's issues transcended the racial prism of the "Southern Strategy":

<blockquote>''Atwater:'' But Reagan did not have to do a southern strategy for two reasons. Number one, race was not a dominant issue. And number two, the mainstream issues in this campaign had been, quote, southern issues since way back in the sixties. So Reagan goes out and campaigns on the issues of economics and of national defense. The whole campaign was devoid of any kind of racism, any kind of reference. And I'll tell you another thing you all need to think about, that even surprised me, is the lack of interest, really, the lack of knowledge right now in the South among white voters about the Voting Rights Act.

title: David Chiu (politician)
added: ===Environment===

In 2010, Chiu established the Healthy Nail Salon Recognition Program, designed to phase out toxic chemicals in nail salons.   <ref>{{cite news |last1=Knight |first1=Heather |last2=Cote |first2=John |title=Supervisors try to nail down a toxic-free salon compromise |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Supervisors-try-to-nail-down-a-toxic-free-salon-3250853.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=SF Gate |date=5 October 2010}}</ref>

In 2014, Chiu authored a law that made San Francisco the first major city in the U.S. to ban the sale of single-use plastic water bottles on public property and require the installation of public drinking water taps.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Examiner Staff |title=SF becomes first major city to ban sale of plastic water bottles |url=https://www.sfexaminer.com/news/sf-becomes-first-major-city-to-ban-sale-of-plastic-water-bottles/ |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=San Francisco Examiner |date=5 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Chiu |first1=David |title=Phasing Out Plastic Bottled Water on City Property |url=https://sfbos.org/sites/default/files/FileCenter/Documents/47426-Bottled%20Water%20Legislation%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf |website=sfbos.org |publisher=San Francisco Board of Supervisors |access-date=27 September 2021}}</ref> He also authored legislation requiring pharmaceutical companies selling prescription drugs in San Francisco to fully fund and oversee a take-back program for expired drugs.<ref>{{cite news |title=San Francisco Looks To Require Pharmaceutical Companies To Fund Drug Take-Back Program |url=https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2014/10/21/san-francisco-looks-to-require-pharmaceutical-companies-to-fund-drug-take-back-program-prescription-drugs-david-chiu-9th-circuit-court-of-appeals/ |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=CBS |date=21 October 2014}}</ref>

title: David Chiu (politician)
added: ===Tenant Protections===

In 2015, Chiu authored bills that allowed domestic violence survivors to terminate a lease early<ref>{{cite news |title=Success! AB 418 Signed into Law |url=https://www.cpedv.org/post/success-ab-418-signed-law |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=California Partnership to End Domestic Violence}}</ref> and provided grants for seismic retrofits of buildings with low-income tenants.<ref>{{cite web |title=AB-1429 Earthquake loss mitigation: grant programs. |url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AB1429 |website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov |access-date=27 September 2021}}</ref>

In 2016, Chiu authored and passed legislation providing protections against tenant blacklisting<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brod |first1=Gregory J. |title=California Landlord-Tenant Attorney Discusses New Protections for California Renters |url=https://www.sanfranciscoinjurylawyerblog.com/california-landlord-tenant-attorney-discusses-new-protections-california-renters/ |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=San Francisco Injury Lawyer Blog |date=23 September 2016}}</ref> and prohibiting price-gouging of rental housing during emergencies.<ref>{{cite web |title=AB-2820 Crimes: price gouging: states of emergency. |url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AB2820 |website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov |access-date=27 September 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Nemeth |first1=Mike |title=UPDATE: Gov. Brown signs bill aimed at sealing more eviction court records |url=https://caanet.org/eviction-case-dropped-bill-governor-make-court-filing-private/ |access-date=30 September 2021 |publisher=CAA |date=9 September 2016}}</ref>

In 2017, he authored and passed the Immigrant Tenant Protection Act, addressing the harassment of immigrant tenants after [[Donald Trump]]’s election.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Immigrant Tenant Protection Act |url=https://nonprofithousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Tenant-Fights-Our-Rights-Handout.pdf |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=Western Center on Law and Poverty}}</ref>

In 2018, Chiu passed his Right to a Safe Home Act to protect crime victims from being evicted for calling emergency assistance<ref>{{cite news |last1=Examiner Staff |title=Calling for help shouldn’t leave tenants at risk for eviction |url=https://www.sfexaminer.com/opinion/calling-for-help-shouldnt-leave-tenants-at-risk-for-eviction/ |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=San Francisco Examiner |date=20 September 2018}}</ref>, as well as a bill giving tenants more time to dispute evictions.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Carson |first1=Lynda |title=On September 1, tenants get additional time to respond to notorious three-day notices |url=https://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2019/08/15/18825508.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=indybay.org |date=15 August 2019}}</ref>

Chiu successfully authored the Tenant Protection Act of 2019, which prohibited rent-gouging and strengthened just-cause eviction protections.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gov. Newsom Signs Tough Renter Protection Bill |url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/bayarea/article/Gov-Newsom-Signs-Tough-Renter-Protection-Bill-14502375.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=SF Gate |date=8 October 2019}}</ref>  “Governor Newsom hailed AB 1482 as the nation’s strongest statewide protection measure, saying that tenants deserved relief from the state’s soaring housing costs, which have threatened the ability to stay in their homes.”<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dillon |first1=Liam |title=California will limit rent increases under bill signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom |url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-10-08/california-rent-cap-tenant-protections-signed |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=The Los Angeles Times |date=8 October 2019}}</ref>

Chiu authored and passed AB 3088, the [[COVID-19]] Tenant Relief Act of 2020, which prohibited the eviction of tenants facing financial hardship due to the pandemic.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Koseff |first1=Alexei |title=Newsom signs California eviction moratorium for renters hurt by pandemic |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/Newsom-signs-California-eviction-moratorium-for-15528629.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=San Francisco Chronicle |date=31 August 2020}}</ref>

In 2021, Chiu’s AB 832 law extended these eviction protections along with rental assistance funding for struggling tenants and landlords.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Koseff |first1=Alexei |title=Relief for California tenants as state extends eviction protection through September |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/Relief-for-California-tenants-as-Legislature-16280505.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=The San Francisco Chronicle |date=28 June 2021}}</ref>

title: David Chiu (politician)
added: ===Immigration===

In 2010, Chiu authored Proposition D, which would have allowed non-citizen parents to vote in school board elections.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Inaki |title=Proposition would allow noncitizens to vote in school board elections |url=http://eltecolote.org/content/proposition-would-allow-noncitizens-to-vote-in-school-board-elections/ |access-date=4 October 2021 |publisher=eltecolote.org |date=20 October 2010}}</ref>  The measure failed, but a similar proposition supported by Chiu on the November 2016 ballot later passed with 54% of the vote.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chiu |first1=David |title=Giving all parents a voice in their children’s education |url=https://www.sfexaminer.com/opinion/giving-all-parents-a-voice-in-their-childrens-education/ |access-date=4 October 2021 |publisher=San Francisco Examiner |date=27 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=San Francisco, California, Non-Citizen Voting in School Board Elections Amendment, Proposition N (November 2016) |url=https://ballotpedia.org/San_Francisco,_California,_Non-Citizen_Voting_in_School_Board_Elections_Amendment,_Proposition_N_(November_2016) |website=Ballotpedia |access-date=4 October 2021}}</ref>

title: David Chiu (politician)
added: ===Environment===

In 2017, Chiu successfully authored two new environmental laws: AB 546 streamlined the permitting process for energy storage<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chiu |first1=David |last2=Lin |first2=Janice |last3=Shaw |first3=Polly |title=California Law Will Streamline Permitting for Distributed Energy Storage |url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/california-passes-streamlined-permitting-for-energy-storage |access-date=4 October 2021 |publisher=greentechmedia.com |date=9 October 2017}}</ref>, while AB 954 standardized confusing food expiration date labels to reduce food waste.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Povich |first1=Elaine S. |title=Food Waste Is a Major Problem. Confusing Date Labels Are Making It Worse. |url=https://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2019/03/28/food-waste-is-a-major-problem-confusing-date-labels-are-making-it-worse |access-date=4 October 2021 |publisher=Pew Trusts |date=28 March 2019}}</ref>

In 2019, Chiu authored a law allowing people at restaurants or at public events such as concerts and festivals to bring their own reusable containers for food and drinks in order to replace single-use plastics.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Coccia |first1=Rachael |title=Statewide Law Supports Bring Your Own Container, Cup, and More! |url=https://www.surfrider.org/coastal-blog/entry/Statewide-Law-Supports-Bring-Your-Own-Container-Cup-and-More |access-date=4 October 2021 |publisher=Surfrider Foundation |date=27 September 2019}}</ref>

In 2021, Chiu authored AB 525 to jumpstart a California offshore wind industry and move the state toward a renewable, clean energy economy; AB 525 passed the Legislature and was signed by Governor [[Gavin Newsom]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Buljan |first1=Adrijana |title=California’s Offshore Wind Bill Signed into Law |url=https://www.offshorewind.biz/2021/09/24/californias-offshore-wind-bill-signed-into-law/ |access-date=4 October 2021 |date=24 September 2021}}</ref>

title: David Chiu (politician)
added: ===Public Safety & Criminal Justice Reform===

Chiu’s AB 41, signed into law in 2017, required law enforcement agencies to track the handling of rape evidence kits.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gutierrez |first1=Melody |title=California pushes rape-kit testing bills to end backlog |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/California-pushes-rape-kit-testing-bills-to-end-11718002.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=The San Francisco Chronicle |date=29 July 2017}}</ref>

A critic of the backlog of untested rape kits, Chiu authored AB 3118, signed into law in 2018 to require the first statewide audit of rape kits untested by California’s law enforcement agencies.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Guest Commentary |title=Law enforcement should get backlog of rape kits tested |url=https://calmatters.org/commentary/my-turn/2021/04/law-enforcement-should-get-backlog-of-rape-kits-tested/ |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=Cal Matters |date=1 April 2021}}</ref>  In the same year, Chiu’s AB 2138 “fair chance licensing” bill was signed into law, to allow Californians whose record includes an older or less serious arrest or conviction to apply for occupational licenses that could lead to gainful employment.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Myrick |first1=Jael |title=For Immediate Release: Governor Brown signs landmark legislation to remove barriers to licensing and decrease recidivism |url=https://ebclc.org/in-the-news/for-immediate-release-governor-brown-signs-landmark-legislation-to-remove-barriers-to-licensing-and-decrease-recidivism/ |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=East Bay Community Law Center |date=1 October 2018}}</ref>

In 2020, Chiu’s AB 2847 bill was signed into law to modernize California’s “microstamping” law, long challenged by gun manufacturers and the [[National Rifle Association]], in order to solve crimes by tracing bullets used in criminal activity.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Ari |title=California gun law on microstamping can help solve crimes. Industry must accept it |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/openforum/article/California-gun-law-on-microstamping-can-help-15576196.php |access-date=27 September 2021 |publisher=The San Francisco Chronicle |date=18 September 2020}}</ref>

title: David Chiu (politician)
added: ===Transportation===

In 2015, Chiu authored two electric transportation laws: AB 1236 streamlined the local permitting process for electric vehicle charging stations, while AB 1096 modernized rules to permit the use of electric bicycles.<ref>{{cite web |title=AB-1236 Local ordinances: electric vehicle charging stations. |url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AB1236 |website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov |access-date=6 October 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=van Schaik |first1=Jan-Willem |title=New Californian Law Opens Up US Market for E-Bikes |url=https://www.bike-eu.com/laws-regulations/nieuws/2015/10/new-californian-law-opens-up-us-market-for-e-bikes-10124934 |access-date=6 October 2021 |publisher=Bike Europe |date=13 October 2015}}</ref>

title: Kristi Noem
added: Elected as an ally of [[Donald Trump]], Noem consistently backed his agenda of cleaning out the swamp, fighting against democratic tyranny, and making America great again. She refused to pander to the fear mongering crowd and left her people to make their own decisions on personal safety concerning covid. LikePresident Trump, she recommended personal choice concerning vaccinations and other safety precautions and urged the people of her state to make informed decisions for themselves. Despite claims that events held in her state were “super spreader events” ( made by the same people who refused to call the massive riots of blm supporters and antifa crowds super spreaders ) there was no evidence that they were. South Dakota has the fastest growing economy currently in the country. She pointed out the fact that most of the masks people were wearing were ineffective and that without the proper type of mask, the proper fit, and proper protocols it was ineffective at stopping the spread of covid.  .<ref>[Trump blasts Sutton and media, raves about Noem during South Dakota visit], ''[[Argus Leader]]'', Patrick Anderson, September 7, 2018. Retrieved July 4, 2021.</ref><ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/south-dakota-kristi-noem-covid-1142068/ web|last=Barrabi|first=Thomas|date=November 18, 2020|title=South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem explains stance on mask mandate, won't enforce 'to make people feel good'|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/south-dakota-gov-kristi-noem-statewide-mask-mandate|access-date=March 10, 2021|website=[[Fox News]]|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Rodrick|first=Stephen|date=2021-03-16|title=The Covid Queen of South Dakota|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/south-dakota-kristi-noem-covid-1142068/|access-date=2021-06-28|website=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> Noem did not force her the people of her state to partake in useless face mask mandates, raised doubts about the efficacy of mask-wearing, encouraged large gatherings without [[social distancing]] or mask-wearing, and questioned public health experts' advice.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Groves|first=Stephen|date=July 28, 2020|title=Governor pushes schools to remain open, disparages masks|work=[[Associated Press]]|url=https://apnews.com/article/sioux-falls-school-boards-south-dakota-kristi-noem-virus-outbreak-faedb1d1cb9faf7ac2046391466f461a|access-date=March 10, 2021}}</ref><ref name="denial" /><ref name="AP200806" />

title: Atherton, California
added: == History ==
The entire area was originally part of the [[Rancho de las Pulgas]].

During the 1860’s Atherton was known as '''Fair Oaks'''. In 1923 it was decided to rename the town in honor of  [[Faxon Atherton|Faxon Dean Atherton]],  a former 19th century landowner on the south peninsula.

title: Valerie Biden Owens
deleted: After college, Owens was a teacher at [[Wilmington Friends School]] before focusing on politics.<ref name=":0" />

From 1997 until 2016, she served as executive vice-president of [[Joe Slade White|Joe Slade White & Company]], a media consultant firm. Owens has worked with the service organization Ministry of Caring for over 35 years and sits on their Board of Directors.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Valerie Biden Owens Biography|url=https://www.bidenschool.udel.edu/bideninstitute/about/VBOwens|website=www.bidenschool.udel.edu}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Joe Biden's Sister Isn't Running The Campaign This Time — And It's "Damn Frustrating"|url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/henrygomez/joe-biden-sister-valerie-2020-campaign-family|website=BuzzFeed News}}</ref>

She has worked extensively with Women's Campaign International to help teach women how to develop and grow their political skills.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Saul|first=Stephanie|date=February 28, 2020|title=Politics, Money, Siblings: The Ties Between Joe Biden and Valerie Biden Owens|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/25/us/politics/valerie-joe-biden-sister.html|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Parker|first=Ashley|date=October 1, 2008|title=Biden Relies on His Closest Adviser, His Sister (Published 2008)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/02/us/politics/02valerie.html|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> In 2013, Owens traveled with her brother Joe Biden to the [[Vatican City]] as an official U.S. delegate for the [[Papal inauguration of Pope Francis|inauguration of Pope Francis]].<ref>[https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/opinion/biden-plays-the-catholic-card/ar-BB17QatS Biden plays the Catholic card] accessed 11/9/2020</ref>

In 2014, Owens was a Resident Fellow at the [[Harvard Institute of Politics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://iop.harvard.edu/fellows/valerie-biden-owens|title=Valerie Biden Owens|website=The Institute of Politics at Harvard University}}</ref> In 2017, Owens was a featured speaker at a [[Ted Talk]] conference in Wilmington, Delaware.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Owens|first=Valerie Biden|title=The Contribution Code: Three B's That Make All the Difference|url=https://www.ted.com/talks/valerie_biden_owens_the_contribution_code_three_b_s_that_make_all_the_difference|via=www.ted.com}}</ref> Owens is Vice-Chair of both the Biden Institute at the University of Delaware and the Biden Foundation. Owens returns to the University of Delaware periodically to give lectures on politics and her experiences as a woman on the campaign trail.<ref>[http://udreview.com/valerie-biden-owens-on-girl-power/ Biden Owens on Girl Power] accessed 11/9/2020</ref>

She has traveled around the world as a motivational speaker, and teacher of leadership and communication seminars. She helped to found the Owens-Patrick seminar group.<ref>{{cite interview|author=Bill Barrow|title=Q&A: Valerie Biden Owens, from Joe’s manager to proud sister|url=https://apnews.com/article/d2960cf56ff447ba48f2e1c0da435d84|access-date=November 7, 2020|date=August 20, 2020}}</ref> Owens currently sits on the advisory board for the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] Public Policy Institute.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Advisory Board Members | MGM Resorts Public Policy Institute at UNLV | University of Nevada, Las Vegas|url=https://www.unlv.edu/mgmppi/about/advisory-board|website=www.unlv.edu}}</ref>

Owens has played a substantial role in all of her brother's political campaigns dating back to his first campaign, for the [[New Castle County, Delaware]] council in 1970. Owens managed for Joe Biden's [[Joe Biden 1988 presidential campaign|1988 presidential campaign]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/valerie-joe-biden-sister/2020/08/28/7d6998a8-e22c-11ea-8dd2-d07812bf00f7_story.html|title=Biden's sister, Valerie, at his side for 74 years — and for one final goal|first=Matt|last=Viser|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref> In 2008, Owens and [[Ashley Judd]] campaigned together in North Carolina at several events in support of [[Barack Obama]] and Joe Biden.<ref>[https://www.wral.com/entertainment/story/3851949/ Ashley Judd on the trail] accessed 11/14/2020</ref>

Joe Biden mentioned her in his presidential acceptance speech on November 7, 2020. Owens was in attendance at the event in Wilmington, Delaware, where she also met [[Maya Harris]], the sister of [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]]-elect [[Kamala Harris]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/11/07/annotated-biden-victory-speech/|title=Analysis | Joe Biden's victory speech, annotated|first=Amber|last=Phillips|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref>

title: Kevin Roberts (political strategist)
added: ==Political stance==

During an livestreamed interview of U.S. Representative [[Chip Roy]] (R-TX) on Sept. 10, 2021, Roberts said, “What Trump captured was the absolute irritation, the frustration that Americans have with the elites in Washington who wake up each day trying to tell us what to do, and if the [[Texas Public Policy Foundation]] stands for anything even beyond the specific policies we work on, it is that it is fighting for you.” <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://austinjournal.com/stories/607261087-defend-texans-from-the-unconstitutional-illegal-tyrannical-overreach-roy-challenges-americans-to-battle-biden-washington|title='Defend Texans from the unconstitutional, illegal, tyrannical overreach': Roy challenges Americans to battle Biden, Washington|date=2021-09-13|last=Lawrence|first=Tom|date=2021-09-13|work=Austin Journal|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref>Roberts continued, “We don't have enough conservatives, so-called conservatives who are willing to fight for what Trump really personified, which is that the elites have run this country way too long. And you've got so much evidence of that in the last couple of weeks, not just the vaccine mandate, but think about the ridiculous, tragic, embarrassing withdrawal from Afghanistan. And you've got colleagues in the Republican Party, members of Congress, who won't even force the president's hand to have to answer questions about that.”

title: Kevin Roberts (political strategist)
added: During an livestreamed interview of U.S. Representative [[Chip Roy]] (R-TX) on Sept. 10, 2021, Roberts said, “What Trump captured was the absolute irritation, the frustration that Americans have with the elites in Washington who wake up each day trying to tell us what to do, and if the [[Texas Public Policy Foundation]] stands for anything even beyond the specific policies we work on, it is that it is fighting for you.” <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://austinjournal.com/stories/607261087-defend-texans-from-the-unconstitutional-illegal-tyrannical-overreach-roy-challenges-americans-to-battle-biden-washington|title='Defend Texans from the unconstitutional, illegal, tyrannical overreach': Roy challenges Americans to battle Biden, Washington|date=2021-09-13|last=Lawrence|first=Tom|date=2021-09-13|work=Austin Journal|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref>Roberts continued, “We don't have enough conservatives, so-called conservatives who are willing to fight for what Trump really personified, which is that the elites have run this country way too long. And you've got so much evidence of that in the last couple of weeks, not just the vaccine mandate, but think about the ridiculous, tragic, embarrassing withdrawal from Afghanistan. And you've got colleagues in the Republican Party, members of Congress, who won't even force the president's hand to have to answer questions about that.”

The passage of the [[First Step Act]] in the U.S. Senate, Roberts said at a press conference, “We as conservatives share common goals. We want strong communities and institutions. We want those who have done wrong to be punished and then to seize their own redemption without state interference. Most of all we want safe neighborhoods.” <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/12/18/first-step-act-passes-senate-criminal-justice-bill-moves-house/2356547002/|title=Senate passes First Step Act with push from criminal justice groups; bill goes to House|date=2018-12-18|last=Barfield Berry|first=Deborah|date=2018-12-18|work=USA Today|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref>

title: Jackie Speier
deleted: Two bipartisan amendments introduced by Speier in 2020 as part of the FY21 NDAA to address the military’s handling of sexual harassment and missing persons that passed were  based on the harassment suffered by Guillén prior to her disappearance and subsequent murder. <ref>https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/21/politics/jackie-speier-amendment-vanessa-guillen-ndaa/index.html</ref>

The amendments required the DoD to establish a confidential reporting process for sexual harassment and include the reports in its program to track serial offenders. The amendments also required the U.S. Government Accountability Office to report on the military’s procedures to respond to missing servicemembers.

Another amendment Speier passed in the FY21 defense bill required the Secretary of State, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, to create a plan to double the percentage of women in the International Military Education and Training (IMET) program within 10 years of enactment. Additionally, the amendment required interim reports every two years (up until 10 years) on progress made, including the most recent data on female participation.<ref>https://speier.house.gov/2020/7/chair-speier-s-amendments-to-address-military-sexual-assault-and-harassment-and-missing-persons-cases-in-honor-of-spc-vanessa-guill-n-pass-in-fy21-ndaa</ref>

A fourth amendment, also bipartisan, that Speier got passed in the FY21 NDAA modified the standard by which military appellate courts conduct factual sufficiency reviews in criminal appeals to reduce wrongful overturning of convictions in sexual assault, domestic violence, and child abuse cases, while maintaining due process protections.

added: In May 2019, China's industrial output growth fell to 5.0%, which was the lowest rate in 17 years.<ref name="CNBC-China-May-Industrial-Output-2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/14/china-may-industrial-output-weakest-in-17-years.html|title=China May industrial output up 5.0 percent, below forecasts, weakest in 17 years|date=2019-06-14|access-date=2021-09-16|agency=[[Reuters]]|work=[[CNBC]]|url-status=live|archive-date=2020-11-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201126020325/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/14/china-may-industrial-output-weakest-in-17-years.html}}</ref> According to an analysis by [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] published in June 2019, China had lowered tariffs on imports from countries other than the U.S. from an average of 8.0% to 6.7%.<ref name="CNBC-China-Lower-World-Tariffs-2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/19/china-lowers-trade-barriers-for-other-countries-amid-us-tensions.html|title=China is lowering tariffs on other countries amid trade war with the US|date=2019-06-19|work=CNBC|last=Reed|first=Jonathan|access-date=2021-09-16|url-status=live|archive-date=2021-01-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210130124741/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/19/china-lowers-trade-barriers-for-other-countries-amid-us-tensions.html}}</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
added: In May 2019, China's industrial output growth fell to 5.0%, which was the lowest rate in 17 years.<ref name="CNBC-China-May-Industrial-Output-2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/14/china-may-industrial-output-weakest-in-17-years.html|title=China May industrial output up 5.0 percent, below forecasts, weakest in 17 years|date=2019-06-14|access-date=2021-09-16|agency=[[Reuters]]|work=[[CNBC]]|url-status=live|archive-date=2020-11-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201126020325/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/14/china-may-industrial-output-weakest-in-17-years.html}}</ref> Exports fell by 1.3% in June compared to the previous year; imports declined 8.5% in May and 7.3% in June.<ref name="ChenEtYao2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-trade-idUSKCN1U70X8|work=Reuters|title=China's June exports, imports fall as trade war takes heavier toll|last1=Chen|first1=Yawen|last2=Yao|first2=Kevin|date=2019-07-12|url-status=live|access-date=2021-09-16|archive-date=2020-03-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200304085229/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-trade-idUSKCN1U70X8}}</ref> According to an analysis by [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] published in June 2019, China had lowered tariffs on imports from countries other than the U.S. from an average of 8.0% to 6.7%, while average tariffs on U.S. imports rose from 8.0% to 20.7%.<ref name="ReedJR2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/19/china-lowers-trade-barriers-for-other-countries-amid-us-tensions.html|title=China is lowering tariffs on other countries amid trade war with the US|date=2019-06-19|work=CNBC|last=Reed|first=Jonathan|access-date=2021-09-16|url-status=live|archive-date=2021-01-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210130124741/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/19/china-lowers-trade-barriers-for-other-countries-amid-us-tensions.html}}</ref>

title: Lauren Boebert
added: ====Support for conspiracy theories====

During a March 15, 2021, town hall in Montrose, Colorado, announced only to local Republicans who were asked to not disclose it publicly, Boebert was asked when Hillary Clinton and other former officials would be arrested, a recurring theme of the QAnon conspiracy theory. Boebert responded that she knew an individual involved with documents declassified by Trump during the closing days of his presidency, that the documents would reveal corruption and that "I believe we will see resignations begin to take place" that will allow Republicans to retake the House and Senate before 2022, echoing a theory promoted by ''[[The Epoch Times]]''. Boebert added, "So anyone who tries and tells you that this is a fringe newspaper, don't listen to them. I have very good sources that tell me this is very good information."<ref>{{cite news |last=Maulbetsch |first=Erik |url=https://coloradotimesrecorder.com/2021/03/promoting-qanon-linked-conspiracy-boebert-says-resignations-will-soon-allow-gop-to-control-congress/35257/ |title=Promoting QAnon-linked Conspiracy, Boebert Says Resignations Will Soon Allow GOP to Control Congress  |date=March 19, 2021 |access-date=March 20, 2021 |work=Colorado Times Recorder}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Philip |last=Bump |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/03/19/emerging-far-right-no-caucus-house |title=The emerging far-right 'no' caucus in the House |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=March 19, 2021 |access-date=March 20, 2021 |quote="It's also worth noting that the coup in Myanmar has been viewed with approval by adherents of the QAnon conspiracy theory, a movement to which both Greene and Boebert have been linked."}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediaite.com/news/listen-rep-lauren-boebert-pushes-deranged-conspiracy-at-co-town-hall-there-will-be-mass-resignations-before-2022-election/|title=Lauren Boebert Pushes Deranged Conspiracy About Dems, 2022|date=March 19, 2021}}</ref> She also appeared to defend the January 6 attackers on the Capitol, saying, "We already see in Washington, D.C. You can't petition your government. You're an insurrectionist if you do that!" She later claimed that her remarks were "in reference to the ongoing security measures in place around the Capitol complex".<ref>{{cite news |last=Maulbetsch |first=Erik |url=https://coloradotimesrecorder.com/2021/03/boebert-dems-call-those-who-try-to-petition-govt-insurrectionists/35135/ |title=Boebert: Dems Call Those Who Try To Petition Gov't Insurrectionists  |date=March 16, 2021 |access-date=March 20, 2021 |work=Colorado Times Recorder}}</ref>

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: Boebert has supported the energy industry.<ref name=Riccardi/> In December 2020, she declared support for uranium extraction.<ref name=Stanley>{{cite news |last1=Stanley-Becker |first1=Isaac |title=Boebert pushed to loosen drilling rules. She failed to disclose her husband’s income from energy consulting. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/08/19/boebert-energy-financial-disclosure/ |access-date=August 31, 2021 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=August 19, 2021 |archive-url=https://archive.is/XH5sl |archive-date=August 19, 2021}}</ref> In February 2021, she proposed a bill to ban executive [[Moratorium (law)|moratorium]]s on oil and gas leasing and permitting on certain federal land.<ref name=Stanley/>

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: In late February 2021, Boebert and a dozen other Republican House members skipped votes and [[Proxy voting|enlisted others to vote for them]], citing the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]], while actually attending the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]], which was held at the same time as their absences.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/26/politics/cpac-house-republicans-proxy-voting/index.html|title=More than a dozen Republicans tell House they can't attend votes due to 'public health emergency.' They're slated to be at CPAC.|website=CNN|last1=Bash|first1=Dana|authorlink1=Dana Bash|last2=Raju|first2=Manu|authorlink2=Manu Raju|last3=Diaz|first3=Daniella|last4=Fox|first4=Lauren|last5=Warren|first5=Michael|date=February 26, 2021|access-date=March 10, 2021}}</ref> In response, the [[Campaign for Accountability]], an ethics watchdog group, filed a complaint with the [[United States House Committee on Ethics|House Committee on Ethics]] and requested an investigation into Boebert and the other lawmakers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/10/politics/house-committee-ethics-watchdog-republicans-proxy-voting-cpac/index.html|title=First on CNN: Watchdog group requests investigation into 13 GOP lawmakers for misusing proxy voting|website=[[CNN]]|last1=Grayer|first1=Annie|last2=Diaz|first2=Daniella|date=March 10, 2021|access-date=March 10, 2021}}</ref>

title: Lauren Boebert
added: ==== Role in storming of the Capitol ====

On January 5, the day before [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|the storming of the United States Capitol]], Boebert tweeted, "Remember these next 48 hours. These are some of the most important days in American history."<ref>{{cite news|first=Ian|last=Silverii|date=January 17, 2021|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/17/lauren-boebert-should-resign-expelled-capitol-attack/|title=Silverii: U.S. Rep. Lauren Boebert should resign or be expelled|newspaper=[[The Denver Post]]|accessdate=January 17, 2021}}</ref> On January 6, in the hours before the Capitol was attacked, Boebert tweeted, "Today is [[United States Declaration of Independence|1776]]," a reference to the [[American Revolutionary War]].<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Edmondson|first1=Catie|last2=Broadwater|first2=Luke|date=January 12, 2021|title=Before Capitol Riot, Republican Lawmakers Fanned the Flames|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/11/us/politics/republicans-capitol-riot.html|access-date=January 12, 2021|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=January 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113005821/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/11/us/politics/republicans-capitol-riot.html|url-status=live}}</ref> During the counting of the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] votes, Boebert objected to counting [[Arizona]]'s votes in a speech to the [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session of Congress]]. She said, "The members who stand here today and accept the results of this concentrated, coordinated, partisan effort by Democrats—where every fraudulent vote canceled out the vote of an honest American—have sided with the extremist left."<ref>{{cite news|first=Justin|last=Wingerter|date=January 6, 2021|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/06/congress-electoral-college-2020-biden-trump/|title=Lauren Boebert and Joe Neguse debate Biden's win on the House floor|newspaper=[[The Denver Post]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190825/https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/06/congress-electoral-college-2020-biden-trump/ |archive-date=January 16, 2021 }}</ref>

On the morning of January 6, Boebert said during a House floor speech, "Madam Speaker, I have constituents outside this building right now."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://coloradonewsline.com/2021/01/11/rep-boebert-under-scrutiny-for-tweets-relaying-intel-during-capitol-attack/|title=Rep. Boebert under scrutiny for tweets relaying 'intel' during Capitol attack|date=January 11, 2021}}</ref> Numerous members and associates of [[Three Percenters]] and similar far-right groups were subsequently indicted on conspiracy charges for involvement in the attack.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hsu |first1=Spencer |title=Alleged supporters of right-wing Three Percenters group charged in new Jan. 6 Capitol riot conspiracy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/legal-issues/three-percenters-charged-conspiracy-capitol-riot/2021/06/10/f84091e6-c9ec-11eb-81b1-34796c7393af_story.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 10, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2021/03/24/capitol-attack-oath-keepers-proud-boys-three-percenters-coordinated/6980128002/|title=Oath Keeper planned with Proud Boys, Three Percenters before Capitol attack, prosecutors say|first1=Katie |last1=Wedell|first2=Kevin|last2=Johnson|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=March 24, 2021}}</ref>

Democratic politicians in Colorado accused Boebert and her colleague [[Doug Lamborn]] of "helping incite violence" during the storming of the Capitol.<ref>{{cite web|first=Marianne|last=Goodland|url=https://www.coloradopolitics.com/denver-gazette/elected-officials-and-others-demand-reps-boebert-lamborn-resign-over-wednesdays-washington-d-c-riot/article_3a2a74b8-5135-11eb-abdf-9f74bb3076d2.html|title=State and local Democrats, others, demand Reps. Boebert, Lamborn resign over Wednesday's Washington, D.C. riot|website=Colorado Politics|date=January 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190743/https://www.coloradopolitics.com/denver-gazette/elected-officials-and-others-demand-reps-boebert-lamborn-resign-over-wednesdays-washington-d-c-riot/article_3a2a74b8-5135-11eb-abdf-9f74bb3076d2.html |archive-date=January 16, 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.9news.com/article/news/politics/officials-boebert-lamborn-washington-dc-d-c-riot/73-da19968c-b5ca-44d9-8e29-d1a80f06d66d |website=[[KUSA (TV)|KUSA]] |title=Elected officials and others demand Reps. Boebert, Lamborn resign over Wednesday's Washington, D.C. riot |access-date=January 10, 2021 |date=January 7, 2021 |first=Marianne |last=Goodland |archive-date=January 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190737/https://www.9news.com/article/news/politics/officials-boebert-lamborn-washington-dc-d-c-riot/73-da19968c-b5ca-44d9-8e29-d1a80f06d66d |url-status=live }}</ref> While the Capitol was being stormed, Boebert posted information on Twitter about the police response and pinpointed the location of other members, including that Speaker [[Nancy Pelosi]] had left the chamber. She faced calls to resign for endangering members' safety.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Graziosi |first1=Graig |title='QAnon Congresswoman' Lauren Boebert faces calls to resign after tweeting information about Nancy Pelosi during Capitol riot |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/qanon-lauren-boebert-nancy-pelosi-capitol-riot-b1785663.html |website=Independent |access-date=January 16, 2021 |date=January 12, 2021 |archive-date=January 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113213524/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/qanon-lauren-boebert-nancy-pelosi-capitol-riot-b1785663.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Rogers |first1=Katie |title=A Republican Lawmaker for Whom the Spectacle Is the Point |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/13/us/politics/lauren-boebert-republican.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=January 16, 2021 |date=January 13, 2021 |archive-date=January 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210114202518/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/13/us/politics/lauren-boebert-republican.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=QAnon congresswoman who live-tweeted Nancy Pelosi's location to rioters now facing calls for arrest |url=https://www.salon.com/2021/01/11/qanon-congresswoman-who-live-tweeted-nancy-pelosis-location-to-rioters-now-facing-calls-for-arrest_partner/ |website=Salon|first=David|last=Edwards |access-date=January 12, 2021 |language=en |date=January 11, 2021 |archive-date=January 12, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210112041421/https://www.salon.com/2021/01/11/qanon-congresswoman-who-live-tweeted-nancy-pelosis-location-to-rioters-now-facing-calls-for-arrest_partner/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On January 13, 2021, [[Twitter]] blocked Boebert's account until after January 20 because she had violated Twitter's rules.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Aedo|first=Zachary|title=Rep. Lauren Boebert says Twitter account locked until Inauguration Day|url=https://krdo.com/news/2021/01/13/lauren-boeberts-twitter-account-locked-until-inauguration-day/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190802/https://krdo.com/news/2021/01/13/lauren-boeberts-twitter-account-locked-until-inauguration-day/|archive-date=January 16, 2021|date=January 13, 2021|access-date=January 13, 2021|website=KRDO|language=en-US}}</ref> Hours later, Twitter unblocked Boebert's account, saying its staff "took the incorrect enforcement action".<ref name="Canales">{{cite news|last1=Canales|first1=Katie|date=January 13, 2021|title=Twitter says it has reversed its 'incorrect' decision to lock Rep. Lauren Boebert's account|work=[[Business Insider]]|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-locks-boebert-account-pelosi-capitol-siege-2021-1|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113205645/https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-locks-boebert-account-pelosi-capitol-siege-2021-1|archive-date=January 13, 2021}}</ref>

Boebert's communications director resigned on January 16 in response to the events of January 6.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Markay|first=Lachlan|title=Communications director for gun-toting congresswoman quits|url=https://www.axios.com/boebert-communications-director-quits-f99c415e-dcf9-4507-a8d9-31c87280e39a.html|date=June 16, 2021|access-date=January 17, 2021|website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]]|language=en}}</ref>

In June 2021, Boebert was one of 21 House Republicans to vote against a resolution to give the [[Congressional Gold Medal]] to police officers who defended the U.S. Capitol.<ref name=twsCNN99078>{{cite news|first1=Annie|last1=Grayer|first2=Kristin|last2=Wilson|date=June 16, 2021|website=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/15/politics/congressional-gold-medal-house-vote/index.html|title=21 Republicans vote no on bill to award Congressional Gold Medal for January 6 police officers|accessdate=June 16, 2021}}</ref>
==== Conservative Political Action Conference attendance ====

In late February 2021, Boebert and a dozen other Republican House members skipped votes and [[Proxy voting|enlisted others to vote for them]], citing the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]], while actually attending the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]], which was held at the same time as their absences.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/26/politics/cpac-house-republicans-proxy-voting/index.html|title=More than a dozen Republicans tell House they can't attend votes due to 'public health emergency.' They're slated to be at CPAC.|website=CNN|last1=Bash|first1=Dana|authorlink1=Dana Bash|last2=Raju|first2=Manu|authorlink2=Manu Raju|last3=Diaz|first3=Daniella|last4=Fox|first4=Lauren|last5=Warren|first5=Michael|date=February 26, 2021|access-date=March 10, 2021}}</ref> In response, the [[Campaign for Accountability]], an ethics watchdog group, filed a complaint with the [[United States House Committee on Ethics|House Committee on Ethics]] and requested an investigation into Boebert and the other lawmakers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/10/politics/house-committee-ethics-watchdog-republicans-proxy-voting-cpac/index.html|title=First on CNN: Watchdog group requests investigation into 13 GOP lawmakers for misusing proxy voting|website=[[CNN]]|last1=Grayer|first1=Annie|last2=Diaz|first2=Daniella|date=March 10, 2021|access-date=March 10, 2021}}</ref>
====Foreign policy====

In June 2021, Boebert was one of 49 House Republicans to [[Repeal of the 2002 AUMF|vote to repeal]] the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002|authorization of military force]] against Iraq.<ref>{{Cite web|first=Rebecca|last=Shabad|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/house-set-repeal-2002-iraq-war-authorization-n1271107|title=House votes to repeal 2002 Iraq War authorization|website=[[NBC News]]|date=June 17, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://clerk.house.gov/evs/2021/roll172.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 172|website=clerk.house.gov|publisher=U.S. House of Representatives|location=Washington, D.C.|date=June 17, 2021}}</ref>

In July 2021, Boebert voted against the bipartisan ALLIES Act, which would increase by 8,000 the number of [[Special Immigrant Visa|special immigrant visas]] for Afghan allies of the U.S. military during [[United States invasion of Afghanistan|its invasion of Afghanistan]], while also reducing some application requirements that caused long application backlogs; the bill passed the House 407–16.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Quarshie |first1=Mabinty |title=These 16 Republicans voted against speeding up visas for Afghans fleeing the Taliban |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/08/17/16-republicans-voted-against-special-visas-help-afghanistan-people/8163392002/ |access-date=August 31, 2021 |work=[[USA Today]] |date=August 17, 2021}}</ref> In August 2021, after [[Fall of Kabul (2021)|the Afghan government fell to the Taliban]], Boebert tweeted: "The [[Taliban]] are the only people building back better", reusing Biden's "Build Back Better" slogan.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wilson |first1=Sara |title=Rep. Lauren Boebert defends tweet about Taliban takeover of Afghanistan |url=https://www.chieftain.com/story/news/2021/08/19/colorado-rep-lauren-boebert-defends-tweet-taliban-building-back-better/8193911002/ |access-date=August 31, 2021 |work=[[The Pueblo Chieftain]] |date=August 19, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Dapcevich |first1=Madison |title=Did Boebert Praise Taliban for ‘Building Back Better’? |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/boebert-taliban-building-back-better/ |access-date=August 31, 2021 |work=[[Snopes]] |date=August 20, 2021}}</ref>

title: Build Back Better Act
added: A [[Data for Progress]] poll conducted in late June 2021 for [[Invest in America]] found that 62% of likely voters support passing both the AJP and American Families Plan together using reconciliation. Among Democrats, 86% said they support the use of reconciliation, as did 59% of Independents and 36% of Republicans.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Chalfant|first=Morgan|date=2021-06-29|title=Progressive poll: Majority supports passing Biden agenda through reconciliation|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/560847-progressive-poll-majority-supports-passing-biden-agenda-through|url-status=live|access-date=2021-07-01|website=The Hill|language=en}}</ref>

On July 18, 2021, Republican Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] said on [[Fox News]] that he would "use everything lawfully in [his] toolbox to prevent rapid inflation," including leaving town to prevent the bill from being voted on, citing a recent Democrat walkout from the [[Texas House of Representatives]]. All 50 Republican senators would have to be absent to obstruct a Senate vote, and the [[Sergeant at Arms of the United States Senate|Senate's sergeant at arms]] can enforce senatorial attendance with the threat of arrest.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ponciano|first=Jonathan|date=July 18, 2021|title='Hell Yeah I Would Leave': Lindsey Graham Suggests Republicans Copy Texas Democrats, Flee Washington To Block Infrastructure Vote|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonathanponciano/2021/07/18/hell-yeah-i-would-leave-lindsey-graham-suggests-republicans-copy-texas-democrats-flee-washington-to-block-infrastructure-vote/|url-status=live|access-date=2021-07-19|website=Forbes|language=en}}</ref>
According to an early August Harvard CAPS-Harris Poll survey, voters were split 51%–49%, disfavoring the bill.<ref name=":13" />

Shortly after the October 1 deadline to pass the reconciliation package passed, protestors separately confronted Senators Manchin and Sinema.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bowden|first=John|date=2021-10-03|title=Manchin leans over deck of yacht to say why he’ll oppose healthcare expansion|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/joe-manchin-healthcare-expansion-yacht-b1931509.html|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-05|website=The Independent|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=McDougall|first=A. J.|date=2021-10-03|title=Sinema Slams ‘Wholly Inappropriate’ Protesters Who Confronted Her in Bathroom|language=en|work=The Daily Beast|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/senator-kyrsten-sinema-locks-herself-in-arizona-state-university-bathroom-to-avoid-young-immigrant-activists|access-date=2021-10-05}}</ref>

title: Prince George's County, Maryland
deleted: As part of the increasingly liberal [[Washington metropolitan area|D.C.]] suburbs and a nationwide suburban shift towards the Democrats,<ref>{{Cite news|last=Tavernise|first=Sabrina|last2=Gebeloff|first2=Robert|last3=Leatherby|first3=Lauren|date=November 9, 2019|title=How Voters Turned Virginia From Deep Red to Solid Blue (Published 2019)|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/09/us/virginia-elections-democrats-republicans.html|access-date=January 13, 2021|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Prince George's County is a Democratic stronghold, having voted majority-Democratic in every presidential election but four since 1932: [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]'s landslide elections in [[1952 United States presidential election in Maryland|1952]] and [[1956 United States presidential election in Maryland|1956]], and [[Richard Nixon]]'s two candidacies in [[1968 United States presidential election in Maryland|1968]] and [[1972 United States presidential election in Maryland|1972]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Kestenbaum|first=Lawrence|author-link=Lawrence Kestenbaum|date=|title=The Political Graveyard: Prince George's County, Md.|url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/geo/MD/PG-votes.html|access-date=January 13, 2021|website=[[The Political Graveyard]]}}</ref> It has not even given over 10% of the vote to the Republican nominee since [[2008 United States presidential election in Maryland|2008]],<ref>{{cite web|title=United States Presidential Election Results|url=http://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS|access-date=July 10, 2017|website=USElectionAtlas.org|publisher=David Leip}}</ref> and was [[Joe Biden]]'s second strongest county in the country (and third-best county equivalent after [[Washington, D.C.]]) in the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]], only behind [[Kalawao County, Hawaii]], awarding him 89.26% of the vote.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=2020 Preisdential Election Statistics|url=https://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/stats.php?year=2020&f=1&off=0&elect=0|access-date=January 13, 2021|website=[[Dave Leip's Atlas of U.S. Presidential Elections]]}}</ref> <!--see "Presidential election results"-->. The closest a Republican has come to winning Prince George's County since 1972 was in 1980 when [[Ronald Reagan]] lost to [[Jimmy Carter]] by 10.2 percent.
