title: Marc Elias
added: * Jacobson v. Lee<ref>{{cite web| title=Jacobson v. Lee | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2018-05-24-Florida-Ballot-Order-Complaint-1.pdf | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref> Lawsuit filed by individual voters, Priorities USA, Democratic National Committee (DNC), Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC), Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC), Democratic Governors Association (DGA) and Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee (DLCC) challenging Florida’s ballot order statute, which requires that candidates of the political party of the Governor be listed first on the ballot in all elections. The complaint alleges that this statute treats similarly situated candidates differently without sufficient justification and violates the First and 14th Amendments. The district court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the ballot order statute violates the First and 14th Amendments by taking “a side in partisan elections.” Republican intervenor-defendants appealed the decision to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which vacated the district court’s judgment and remanded the case with instructions to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction.

The complaint alleges that the map dilutes the votes of African American communities from the 12th Congressional District in central-southeast Georgia — where African Americans had previously elected their preferred candidates — and submerges them in surrounding majority-white districts where they can no longer elect their candidates of choice. The parties entered a stipulation of dismissal.<ref>{{cite web| title=Georgia Congressional Redistricting (2011 Map) | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/cases/georgia-congressional-redistricting/ | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref>

Raffensperger Amended Complaint | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/GA-Redistricting-Amended-Complaint-1.pdf | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref> Lawsuit filed on behalf of individual voters challenging Georgia’s 2011 congressional map for violating Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. The complaint alleges that the map dilutes the votes of African American communities from the 12th Congressional District in central-southeast Georgia — where African Americans had previously elected their preferred candidates — and submerges them in surrounding majority-white districts where they can no longer elect their candidates of choice. The parties entered a stipulation of dismissal.<ref>{{cite web| title=Georgia Congressional Redistricting (2011 Map) | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/cases/georgia-congressional-redistricting/ | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref>

title: George C. Marshall
added: In mid-1918, Pershing brought Marshall on to the AEF operations staff, G-3, where he worked closely with Pershing and was a key planner of American operations.{{sfn|George Catlett Marshall Timeline}} He was instrumental in the planning and coordination of the [[Meuse-Argonne Offensive]], which contributed to the defeat of the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in 1918.{{sfn|Lengel|2008}} Marshall held the permanent rank of [[Captain (United States O-3)|captain]] and the temporary rank of [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]].{{sfn|Tucker|Roberts|2006|p=1186}} He was recommended for promotion to temporary [[brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] in October 1918, but the Armistice occurred before the recommendation was acted on.{{sfn|Tucker|Roberts|2006|p=1186}} After the Armistice, Marshall served as chief of staff for the [[VIII Corps (United States)|U.S. Eighth Corps]].{{sfn|George Catlett Marshall Timeline}}

title: Roman Abramovich
added: ===Funding of Jewish settlements in Israel===

An investigation by [[BBC News Arabic]] into the [[FinCEN Files]] in September 2020 found Abramovich-controlled companies have donated $100m to the [[Ir David Foundation]] (known as Elad), an Israeli organization that supports Jewish settlements in [[Silwan]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Garthwaite|first1=Rosie|last2=Blau|first2=Uri|last3=Cox|first3=Simon|date=21 September 2020|title=Israeli settlers' Chelsea boss backer|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/world-middle-east-54237970/|access-date=22 September 2020|website=[[BBC News]]|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Holmes|first=Oliver|title=Leaks show Chelsea owner Abramovich funded Israeli settler group|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/21/leaks-show-chelsea-owner-abramovich-funded-israeli-settler-group/|access-date=22 September 2020|website=The Guardian|date=21 September 2020|language=en}}</ref> Due to Israel's ongoing [[Israeli occupation of the West Bank|occupation of the West Bank]], the settlements are generally considered to be a [[International law and Israeli settlements|breach of international law]], a view which Israel disputes.{{sfn|Playfair|1992|p=396}}{{sfn|Albin|2001|p=150}}<ref>{{Cite news|date=10 December 2009|title=The Geneva Convention|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/1682640.stm|access-date=18 June 2021}}</ref>

title: Jay Obernolte
deleted: Every year, California State Assemblymembers select a veteran in their district to be recognized as the Veteran of the Year and honored in Sacramento with a ceremony and luncheon. In 2015, Obernolte awarded Hesperia Chamber of Commerce President Brad Letner.<ref name="Veteran of the Year">{{cite news|last1=Cassling|first1=Steve|title=Assemblymember Obernolte Seeks Nominations for Veteran of the Year|url=http://kbhr933.com/current-news/assemblyman-obernolte-seeks-nominations-veteran-year/|access-date=June 9, 2016|publisher=KBHR933|date=May 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Letner">{{cite news|last1=Gambone|first1=L.J.|title=Letner "Veteran of the Year"|url=http://www.vvdailypress.com/article/20150623/NEWS/150629900|access-date=June 9, 2016|publisher=Daily Press|date=June 23, 2016}}</ref> In 2017, Anthony "Tony" Cooker was recognized as the 2017 Veteran of the Year for the 33rd Assembly District.<ref name="2017 Veteran award">{{cite news|title=World War II vet from Victorville honored as 2017 Veteran of the Year for 33rd Assembly District|url=http://www.vvdailypress.com/news/20170622/world-war-ii-vet-from-victorville-honored-as-2017-veteran-of-year-for-33rd-assembly-district|access-date=June 29, 2017|publisher=VV Daily Press|date=June 22, 2017}}</ref> In 2019, United States Army Veteran Ed Morgan was Veteran of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vvng.com/assemblyman-obernolte-recognizes-ed-morgan-as-veteran-of-the-year/|title=Assemblyman Obernolte Recognizes Ed Morgan as Veteran of the Year|date=December 22, 2019|website=VVNG.com}}</ref>

In 2016, Obernolte sponsored approved Assembly Concurrent Resolution 180, which dedicates a stretch of [[California State Route 247]] (SR-247) to the late Sergeant Brian L. Walker.<ref name="The Leader">{{cite news|last1=Day|first1=Peter|title=Obernolte: Walker Highway dedication next year|url=http://www.lucernevalleyleader.com/tags/assemblyman-jay-obernolte|access-date=September 29, 2016|publisher=The Leader|date=September 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002135345/http://www.lucernevalleyleader.com/tags/assemblyman-jay-obernolte#|archive-date=October 2, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>

title: Mo Brooks
added: === 2021 Capitol attack ===

Brooks was the first member of Congress to announce his objection to the January 6, 2021 [[2021 United States Electoral College vote count|certification]] of the Electoral College results.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|date=2021-01-06|title=Mo Brooks: Today patriots start 'kicking ass' in fighting vote results|url=https://www.al.com/news/2021/01/mo-brooks-today-patriots-start-kicking-ass-in-fighting-vote-results.html|access-date=2021-01-07|website=al|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|title=Here Are The Republicans Challenging Congress' Tally Of Election Results|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/congress-electoral-college-tally-live-updates/2021/01/06/953714213/here-are-the-republicans-challenging-congress-tally-of-election-results|access-date=2021-01-07|website=NPR.org|language=en}}</ref> In December he organized a series of White House meetings between Trump and a dozen Republican lawmakers to strategize about how to overturn the election results on January 6.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/21/trump-house-overturn-election-449787|title=House Republicans meet with Trump to discuss overturning election results|last=Zanona|first=Melanie|date=December 21, 2021|work=Politico|access-date=29 July 2021}}</ref> On that date, he was the first speaker at a pro-Trump rally. In the speech he harshly criticized other Republicans in Congress for not aiding him in his efforts to overturn the election<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|last=Lyman|first=Melissa Brown, Kirsten Fiscus and Brian|title='A very dark day': Alabama's congressional delegation condemns riot at U.S. Capitol|url=https://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/news/2021/01/06/trump-supporters-storm-us-capitol-dc-riot-alabama-congressman-react/4138779001/|access-date=2021-01-07|website=The Montgomery Advertiser|language=en-US}}</ref> and said, "Today is the day American patriots start taking down names and kicking ass."<ref name=":6" /> At the rally Trump gave an hourlong speech claiming that the election had been stolen and urging people to go to the [[United States Capitol|U.S. Capitol]]. The crowd did so, and shortly thereafter, pro-Trump protesters [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|stormed the Capitol]].<ref name=":7" /> Later that night, Congress reassembled to certify the Electoral College vote; Brooks raised an objection to Nevada's votes, but it did not succeed because no senator joined him in objecting.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/politics/live-news/congress-electoral-college-vote-count-2021/h_b010a790c09bad7043fdb6111936f4a5|title=Congress finalizes Biden's win after riot disrupts Capitol|date=January 7, 2021|work=CNN|access-date=28 July 2021}}</ref> Brooks later said the rioters who stormed the Capitol were associated with [[antifa (United States)|Antifa]], citing a ''[[The Washington Times|Washington Times]]'' report that was later retracted.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Scarborough|first=Rowan|title=Facial recognition identifies extremists storming the Capitol|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2021/jan/6/xrvision-firm-claims-antifa-infiltrated-protesters/|access-date=2021-03-08|website=The Washington Times|language=en-US}}</ref>

On January 11, District of Columbia [[Attorney General]] [[Karl Racine]] said that he was looking at whether to charge Brooks, along with [[Rudy Giuliani]] and [[Donald Trump Jr.]], with inciting the violent attack.<ref name="cnbc-2021">{{cite news |title=DC attorney general considers riot incitement charges against Donald Trump Jr., Giuliani, GOP Rep. Brooks |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/11/capitol-riot-donald-trump-jr-rudy-giuliani-could-face-charges-in-dc.html |access-date=January 12, 2021 |work=CNBC |archive-date=January 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113193353/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/11/capitol-riot-donald-trump-jr-rudy-giuliani-could-face-charges-in-dc.html |url-status=live}}</ref>

On March 5, 2021, Representative [[Eric Swalwell]] filed a civil lawsuit against Brooks and three others ([[Donald Trump]], [[Donald Trump Jr.]], and [[Rudy Giuliani]]), seeking damages for their alleged role in inciting the riot.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2021/06/03/eric-swalwell-sues-donald-trump-rudy-giuliani-over-capitol-riot-but-cant-find-mo-brooks/7522681002/|title=Unanswered calls and a thwarted private detective: Swalwell's lawsuit over Jan. 6 has trouble getting started|last=Jansen|first=Bart|date=June 3, 2021|work=USA Today|access-date=28 July 2021}}</ref> Brooks tried to claim immunity from the suit by saying that he had been acting as a federal employee when he gave the January 6 speech; if so, that would make the U.S. government the defendant.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/legal-issues/mo-brooks-capitol-riot-lawsuit/2021/07/06/fa69a34c-de80-11eb-9f54-7eee10b5fcd2_story.html|title=Rep. Mo Brooks says he can't be sued for inciting Capitol riot because he is a federal employee|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|date=July 6, 2021|work=The Washington Post|access-date=28 July 2021}}</ref> But the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] said it will not defend him because his speech was political, not part of his duties as a member of Congress.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/07/28/1021611663/the-doj-wont-defend-rep-mo-brooks-in-court-against-claims-he-incited-jan-6-riot|title=The DOJ Won't Defend Rep. Mo Brooks In Court Against Claims He Incited The Jan. 6 Riot|last=Diaz|first=Jaclyn|date=July 28, 2021|work=NPR|access-date=28 July 2021}}</ref> In a sworn affidavit, Brooks had stated that his fiery language in the speech was about the 2022 and 2024 elections.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2021/07/republican-mo-brooks-insurrection-lawsuit-doj.html|title=Mo Brooks Accidentally Gave Up His Immunity From Eric Swalwell's Insurrection Lawsuit|last=Stern|first=Mark Joseph|date=July 28, 2021|work=Slate|access-date=28 July 2021}}</ref>

title: Mo Brooks
added: ==Early political career==

Brooks was elected to the [[Alabama House of Representatives]] in 1982 and reelected in 1983, 1986, and 1990. While in the legislature, Brooks was elected Republican house caucus chairman three times.{{Citation needed|date=December 2020}}

In 1991, Brooks was appointed Madison County district attorney, after the incumbent, [[Robert E. Cramer]], was elected to Congress.<ref>{{Cite web|title=18 Dec 1990, 2 - The Selma Times-Journal at Newspapers.com|url=http://www.newspapers.com/image/571274000/|access-date=2021-05-08|website=Newspapers.com|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=27 Dec 1990, 2 - Abbeville Herald at Newspapers.com|url=http://www.newspapers.com/image/668591838/|access-date=2021-05-08|website=Newspapers.com|language=en}}</ref> In 1992, he ran for the office, but lost to [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] Tim Morgan.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2009-05-12|title=Madison County District Attorney Tim Morgan retiring|url=https://www.al.com/breaking/2009/05/madison_county_district_attorn.html|access-date=2021-05-08|website=al|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.al.com/breaking/2010/10/tim_morgan_who_replaced_mo_bro.html|title = Tim Morgan, who replaced Mo Brooks as district attorney 18 years ago, endorses Steve Raby|date = October 23, 2010}}</ref> A Republican had not been elected to the office since the [[Reconstruction Era of the United States|Reconstruction]] era.{{Citation needed|date=December 2020}}

In 1995–96, Brooks was appointed state special assistant attorney general for Alabama attorney general [[Jeff Sessions]]. From 1996 to 2002, he was special assistant attorney general for attorney general [[Bill Pryor]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2020}}
In 1996, Brooks ran for the Madison County commission and unseated an eight-year incumbent Republican. He was reelected to the commission in 2000, 2004, and 2008.<ref name="section9"/>

In 2006, Brooks unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination for [[Lieutenant Governor of Alabama|lieutenant governor of Alabama]], coming in third behind eventual nominee [[Luther Strange]] and former state treasurer [[George Wallace, Jr.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2014/08/war_on_whites_only_the_latest.html|title='War on whites' only the latest: Best of Mo Brooks' polarizing rhetoric|work=AL.com|date=August 6, 2014|access-date=February 9, 2015|first=Challen|last=Stephens|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209124131/http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2014/08/war_on_whites_only_the_latest.html|archive-date=February 9, 2015|url-status=live|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

title: Russia investigation origins conspiracy theory
added: On September 16, 2021, Durham indicted Michael Sussmann, a partner for the law firm [[Perkins Coie]], alleging he falsely told FBI general counsel [[James A. Baker (government attorney)|James Baker]] during a September 2016 meeting that he was not representing a client for their discussion. Durham alleged Sussman was actually representing "a U.S. Technology Industry Executive, a U.S. Internet Company and the Hillary Clinton Presidential Campaign." Sussmann focuses on  privacy and cybersecurity law and had approached Baker to discuss what he claimed to be suspicious communications between computer servers at the Russian [[Alfa-Bank]] and the [[Trump Organization]]. Sussmann had represented the [[Democratic National Committee]] regarding the [[Democratic National Committee cyber attacks|Russian hacking of its computer network]]. Sussmann's attorneys have denied he was representing the Clinton campaign. Perkins Coie represented the Clinton presidential campaign and one its partners, [[Marc Elias]], commissioned [[Fusion GPS]] to conduct [[opposition research]] on Trump, which led to the controversial [[Steele dossier]]. Sussmann, a former federal prosecutor, characterized the allegations against him as politically motivated and pleaded not guilty the day after his indictment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/justice-department/special-counsel-appointed-trump-doj-may-indict-democratic-lawyer-sussmann-n1279353|title=Special counsel named by Trump DOJ charges Democratic lawyer with false statement|author1=Ken Dilanian |author2=Tom Winter|date=September 16, 2021|website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/15/us/politics/durham-michael-sussmann-trump-russia.html|title=Durham Is Said to Seek Indictment of Lawyer at Firm With Democratic Ties|first1=Charlie|last1=Savage|first2=Adam|last2=Goldman|first3=Michael S.|last3=Schmidt|first4=William K.|last4=Rashbaum|date=September 15, 2021|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/17/politics/michael-sussmann/index.html|title=Michael Sussmann, lawyer charged in Durham probe, pleads not guilty|first=Katelyn Polantz, CNN Reporter, Crime and|last=Justice|date=September 17, 2021|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Bill Clinton
added: ===Irish peace talks===

In 1992, before his presidency, Clinton proposed sending a peace envoy to [[Northern Ireland]], but this was dropped to avoid tensions with the British government. In November 1995, in a ceasefire during [[the Troubles]], Clinton became the first president to visit Northern Ireland, examining both of the two divided communities of [[Belfast]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/30/newsid_4459000/4459860.stm|title=1995: Clinton kindles hope in Northern Ireland|date=November 30, 1995 |language=en-GB |access-date=December 12, 2019}}</ref> Despite [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]] criticism, Clinton used this as a way to negotiate an end to the violent conflict with London, Dublin, the paramilitaries and the other groups. Clinton went on to play a key role in the [[Northern Ireland peace process|peace talks]], which produced the [[Good Friday Agreement]] in 1998.<ref>Roger MacGinty, "American influences on the Northern Ireland peace process." ''Journal of Conflict Studies'' 17.2 (1997): 31-50 [https://www.erudit.org/en/journals/jcs/1997-v17-n2-jcs_17_2/jcs17_02art02.pdf online].</ref>

title: Herman Cain
deleted: Cain died from [[COVID-19]] on July 30, 2020, at the age of 74. Cain, a survivor of [[colon cancer]], downplayed the risk of Covid-19, refused to wear a mask or to take other precautions against the disease, and attended a large rally for [[Donald Trump]], held against the advice of public-health officials, shortly before becoming ill.<ref name="reuters-covid">{{cite news | publisher = Reuters | title = Herman Cain, ex-presidential candidate who refused to wear mask, dies after COVID-19 diagnosis | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-cain/herman-cain-ex-presidential-candidate-who-refused-to-wear-mask-dies-after-covid-19-diagnosis-idUSKCN24V2OD | date= July 30, 2020}}</ref><ref name="politico-covid">{{cite news | work = Politico | url = https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/30/herman-cain-death-covid-388081 | title = Political activist Herman Cain dies after Covid-19 diagnosis | date = July 30, 2020 | first1 = Caitlyn | last1= Oprisko | first2=Louis | last2= Nelson}}</ref> Following Cain's death, his verified Twitter account continued to promote [[Covid-19 misinformation|misinformation about the pandemic]], posting a month after Cain's death from Covid-19: "It looks like the virus is not as deadly as the mainstream media first made it out to be."<ref name="wapo-twitter">{{cite news | work = Washington Post | title = The curious saga of the deceased Herman Cain’s living Twitter account | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/08/31/herman-cain-twitter-account/ | date = August 31, 2020 | first = Travis | last = Andrews}}</ref>

title: Truth Social
added: TRUTH Social یک پلتفرم رسانه ای اجتماعی اعلام شده است که توسط دونالد ترامپ ، رئیس جمهور سابق ایالات متحده ، پس از سانسور فیس بوک و توییتر تأسیس شد.  TRUTH Social متعلق به گروه رسانه و فناوری Trump (TMTG) است ، شرکتی که توسط ترامپ تاسیس شده است.  که با شرکت خرید ویژه Digital World Acquisition Corp. ادغام می شود تا به یک شرکت تجاری عمومی تبدیل شود.  این پلتفرم در نوامبر 2021 ، قبل از راه اندازی عمومی عمومی در نوامبر 2021 ، در App Store اپل به صورت محدود راه اندازی می شود. title: Truth Social
deleted: On October 20, 2021, Trump Media & Technologygroupissued a press release which announced the platform, slated to enter limited beta in November 2021. Hours later, a URL was disseminated across various sites which permitted users to sign up and use the platform. Users began [[trolling]] on the site, creating parody accounts, and posting humorous and comedic content. The link was later taken offline.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Harwell|first=Drew|date=October 21, 2021|title=Pranksters have already defaced Trump’s new social network|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/10/21/trump-truth-social-fake-accounts/|url-status=live|access-date=October 21, 2021|website=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref>

title: Truth Social
added: On October 21, 2021, shares of Digital World Acquisition Corp., a Trump-linked [[special-purpose acquisition company]], rose by 400% following the announcement of Truth Social.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|last=Mangan|first=Dan|last2=Li|first2=Yun|last3=Wilkie|first3=Christina|date=2021-10-21|title=Shares of Trump-linked SPAC surge 400% following news of social media deal|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/21/trump-linked-spac-shares-soar-more-than-40percent-on-news-of-social-media-deal.html|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-21|website=[[CNBC]]|language=en}}</ref> Trading of the company's stock was halted multiple times due to its [[Volatility (finance)|volatility]].<ref name=":2" />

title: Truth Social
added: Editorialists writing in [[The Irish Times]] and [[The Independent]] identified the ironic similarity between the names Truth Social and the Soviet propaganda newspaper [[Pravda]] (literally, "Truth"),<ref name="IrishTimes1">{{citation|title=The Irish Times view on Donald Trump’s social network: Truth and lies|date=2021-10-21|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/editorial/the-irish-times-view-on-donald-trump-s-social-network-truth-and-lies-1.4707052|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211021202628/https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/editorial/the-irish-times-view-on-donald-trump-s-social-network-truth-and-lies-1.4707052|archive-date=2021-10-21|website=[[The Irish Times]] website|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Independent1">{{citation|author1-last=Berlatsky|author1-first=Noah|title=If Trump’s new social network survives its disastrous announcement, it could be a genuine threat to democracy|date=2021-10-21|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/trump-truth-social-threat-democracy-b1942866.html|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211021173527/https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/trump-truth-social-threat-democracy-b1942866.html|archive-date=2021-10-21|website=[[The Independent]] website|place=New York, NY, U.S.A.|language=en}}</ref> feeling that the new platform would "carry on in the same vein of propaganda mixed with falsehood"<ref name="IrishTimes1" /> while potentially posing a "genuine threat to democracy"<ref name="Independent1" /> and providing "the utterly supine media outlet [Trump] craves".<ref name="Independent1" />

title: Truth Social
deleted: Truth Social was accused of violating [[Mastodon (software)|Mastodon]]'s [[GNU General Public License|General Public License]], the licensing used for the software. The Software Freedom Conservancy (SFC) has said that the app has 30-days to comply with the terms of the license before its access is terminated.<ref>https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/22/22740354/trump-truth-social-network-spac-mastodon-license-software-freedom-conservancy</ref>

Taking "Truth Social" public via a SPAC the CEO of Digital World Mr. Patrick F. Orlando	is based in Wuhan, the city of origin of [[COVID-19]].<ref>https://uk.sports.yahoo.com/news/wuhan-linked-patrick-orlando-man-212753165.html</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20211022184402/https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/DWACU/profile?p=DWACU</ref>

The site although promoting the use of free speech has a disparagement clause within its [[Terms of service]] which users agree not to "disparage, tarnish, or otherwise harm, in our opinion, us and/or the Site.".<ref>https://tmtgcorp.com/terms-of-service/</ref>

title: Truth Social
added: SPACs are structured such that they first sell shares to the public and then raise funds from investors to later acquire a private company, the identity of which cannot be known by investors in advance. Some investors were surprised to learn that their investment money was being used to finance a Trump company. SPACs have long had questionable reputations because they can give companies access to public markets that would otherwise be difficult, due to a poor or nonexistent track record.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump Takes Advantage of Wall Street Fad to Bankroll New Venture |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/21/business/media/trump-spac-social-media-venture.html |work=The New York TImes |date=October 21, 2021|author1=David Enrich|author2=Matthew Goldstein|author3=Shane Goldmacher}}</ref>

title: Truth Social

title: Boris Johnson
deleted: [[Jeremy Vine]] described a speech Johnson made to a business audience before he was Mayor of London; it was shambolic, chaotic and with forgotten punchlines to jokes, but the audience loved it. But any impression of carelessness and true disorganisation was tempered when Vine was at a speech to a different audience two years later: it was identical, misfired joke by joke, the identical talking points ("SHEEP") writ large on a visible sheet of paper.<ref>{{Cite web |title=My Boris Johnson story |last=Vine |first=Jeremy |website=The Spectator |date=17 June 2019 |url= https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/my-boris-johnson-story}}</ref>

added: ====2020 election====

Moulton faced his first primary challenge since winning his own challenge in 2014. He defeated the Democratic challengers Angus McQuilken and Jamie Belsito, with 78% of the vote, and went on to defeat Republican John Paul Moran, with 65.4% of the vote.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Seth_Moulton|title=Seth Moulton|website=Ballotpedia}}</ref>

title: 2020 Republican National Convention
added: ==Controversies==
===Ann Dorn's speech===

The daughters of [[Shooting of David Dorn|David Dorn]] took objection to Ann Dorn, his widow, utilizing their father's death to support the candidacy of Trump, to whom they claimed their father was politically opposed.<ref>{{cite news |last=King |first=Chris |title=David Dorn's daughters oppose father's widow speaking at RNC |url=http://www.stlamerican.com/news/national_news/david-dorn-s-daughters-oppose-father-s-widow-speaking-at-rnc/article_da760964-e7fe-11ea-81fd-8f15f591da91.html |access-date=28 August 2020 |work=St. Louis American |date=26 August 2020 |archive-date=November 15, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115111339/http://www.stlamerican.com/news/national_news/david-dorn-s-daughters-oppose-father-s-widow-speaking-at-rnc/article_da760964-e7fe-11ea-81fd-8f15f591da91.html |url-status=live}}</ref>
===COVID-19 risks===
====Crowds during convention====

At events with in-person audiences, such as First Lady [[Melania Trump]], Vice President Mike Pence, [[Ivanka Trump]], and President Donald Trump's speeches, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]-recommended practices of protective masks and [[social distancing]] were largely absent.<ref name=vigdor1 /><ref>{{cite news |last=Colvin |first=Jill |title=What virus? At the Republican National Convention, the COVID-19 pandemic is largely ignored. |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/election-2020/ct-nw-rnc-covid-pandemic-20200828-seld4hwnsbbhfnmnbsmyygcnou-story.html |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=August 28, 2020 |date=August 27, 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828061357/https://www.chicagotribune.com/election-2020/ct-nw-rnc-covid-pandemic-20200828-seld4hwnsbbhfnmnbsmyygcnou-story.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Many audience members had not been tested for COVID-19.<ref>{{cite web |last=Orr |first=Gabby |title=Guests for Trump acceptance speech get guidance, but not Covid-19 testing |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/27/trump-acceptance-speech-no-testing-403578 |website=Politico |access-date=August 28, 2020 |language=en |date=August 27, 2020 |archive-date=August 27, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200827232918/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/27/trump-acceptance-speech-no-testing-403578 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Melania Trump Rose Garden speech attendees not all required to get coronavirus tests |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/26/politics/rose-garden-attendees-coronavirus-tests-melania-trump/index.html |last1=Zeleny |first1=Jeff |last2=Sullivan |first2=Kate |last3=Bennett |first3=Kate |website=CNN |access-date=August 28, 2020 |date=August 26, 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828012623/https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/26/politics/rose-garden-attendees-coronavirus-tests-melania-trump/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

During the convention, the first and second families were seen without masks mingling without social distancing in crowds of people also without masks.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump and Melania without masks mingle in RNC crowd |format=Video |url=https://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2020/08/27/trumps-in-crowd-pence-speech-masks-rnc-2020-collins-sot-vpx.cnn |publisher=CNN |access-date=August 28, 2020 |date=August 27, 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828020911/https://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2020/08/27/trumps-in-crowd-pence-speech-masks-rnc-2020-collins-sot-vpx.cnn |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Pence immediately fist-bumps crowd without mask after RNC speech |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election/mike-pence-speech-rnc-trump-hug-social-distancing-covid-mask-crowd-a9690746.html |last=Buncombe |first=Andrew |website=www.independent.co.uk |access-date=August 28, 2020 |language=en |date=August 27, 2020 |archive-date=August 27, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200827050957/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election/mike-pence-speech-rnc-trump-hug-social-distancing-covid-mask-crowd-a9690746.html |url-status=live }}</ref> The crowd of 1,500 at the White House on the final night also greatly flouted Washington, D.C. regulations prohibiting gatherings of more than 50 people.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Restuccia |first1=Andrew |title=Trump's White House Rally: Takeaways From the RNC's Final Night |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trumps-white-house-rally-takeaways-from-the-rncs-final-night-11598612414 |website=Wall Street Journal |access-date=31 August 2020 |date=28 August 2020 |archive-date=August 31, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200831104605/https://www.wsj.com/articles/trumps-white-house-rally-takeaways-from-the-rncs-final-night-11598612414 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Despite having been required to wear protective masks and social distance, many delegates at the morning session of the opening day, held in Charlotte, did not wear protective masks and failed to socially distance,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kuznitz |first1=Alison |title=Masks are required at RNC 2020 in Charlotte. But many are not wearing one. |url=https://www.wbtv.com/2020/08/24/masks-are-required-rnc-charlotte-many-are-not-wearing-one/ |website=www.wbtv.com |publisher=The |access-date=28 August 2020 |date=24 August 2020 |archive-date=September 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200903120242/https://www.wbtv.com/2020/08/24/masks-are-required-rnc-charlotte-many-are-not-wearing-one/ |url-status=live }}</ref> attracting controversy.<ref>{{cite web |last1=O'Connor |first1=Kristi |title=Delegates respond to criticism after some seen not wearing masks at RNC |url=https://www.wbtv.com/2020/08/25/delegates-respond-criticism-after-some-seen-not-wearing-masks-rnc/ |website=www.wbtv.com |access-date=28 August 2020 |date=25 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828230240/https://www.wbtv.com/2020/08/25/delegates-respond-criticism-after-some-seen-not-wearing-masks-rnc/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Local health officials voiced concern.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bowden |first1=John |title=RNC warned by local health officials about lack of masks at convention |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/513424-rnc-warned-by-local-health-officials-about-lack-of-masks-at-convention |website=TheHill |access-date=28 August 2020 |language=en |date=24 August 2020 |archive-date=August 26, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200826025413/https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/513424-rnc-warned-by-local-health-officials-about-lack-of-masks-at-convention |url-status=live }}</ref> Four days later, August 28, it was reported that four people associated with the Charlotte event—two attendees of the morning session and two support staff—had subsequently tested positive for COVID-19.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/28/politics/charlotte-republican-convention-coronavirus/index.html|title=Republican convention in Charlotte tied to 4 cases of Covid-19|last1=de Vries|first1=Karl|last2=Watts|first2=Amanda|date=August 28, 2020|work=CNN|access-date=30 August 2020|archive-date=August 29, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200829082456/https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/28/politics/charlotte-republican-convention-coronavirus/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

This stood in strong contrast with the [[2020 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention held the prior week]], where the only in-person audience was a parking lot of spectators socially distanced (viewing from their cars) for the fireworks finale of the final night, and where masks were worn at times by both the presidential and vice-presidential nominees and their spouses.<ref>{{cite web |title=The striking contrast between the Democratic and Republican conventions |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/striking-contrast-democratic-republican-conventions/story?id=72659882 |website=ABC News |access-date=28 August 2020 |language=en |date=27 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828035904/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/striking-contrast-democratic-republican-conventions/story?id=72659882 |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Earlier convention plans====

Safety concerns were raised over earlier plans to hold a large-scale in-person convention amid a pandemic. Despite these concerns, Trump, for an extended period of time, had resisted calls to scale-back the convention.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rambaran |first1=Vandana |title=Jacksonville sheriff warns Republican Convention amid coronavirus could put community at risk |url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/jacksonville-sheriff-warns-community-coronavirus-republican-convention |website=Fox News |access-date=August 23, 2020 |date=July 21, 2020 |archive-date=August 18, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200818090543/https://www.foxnews.com/us/jacksonville-sheriff-warns-community-coronavirus-republican-convention |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kilgore |first1=Ed |title=Republican National Convention Becoming a Dumpster Fire |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/07/covid-jacksonville-republican-national-convention.html |website=Intelligencer |publisher=NY Magazine |access-date=August 23, 2020 |language=en-us |date=July 13, 2020 |archive-date=August 21, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200821234337/https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/07/covid-jacksonville-republican-national-convention.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

When the event was slated to be held in Jacksonville, residents and business owners near the VyStar Arena filed a lawsuit asking a judge to declare the event a "[[public nuisance]]" due to the health risk it posed "under the circumstances and practices encouraged and required by the Republican National Committee", and asked the judge to thereby either block the event from using the arena, or to limit the attendance to only 2,500 people.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Justice |first1=Nick Jones, Kent |title=Lawsuit argues GOP Convention will be a 'nuisance injurious' to welfare of Jacksonville |url=https://www.news4jax.com/news/local/2020/07/08/lawsuit-argues-gop-convention-is-nuisance-injurious-to-welfare-of-jacksonville/ |website=WJXT |access-date=16 November 2020 |language=en |date=8 July 2020 |archive-date=November 18, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118063056/https://www.news4jax.com/news/local/2020/07/08/lawsuit-argues-gop-convention-is-nuisance-injurious-to-welfare-of-jacksonville/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Politicization of the office of Secretary of State===

The appropriateness of having the incumbent [[United States Secretary of State|secretary of state]], [[Mike Pompeo]], address a political convention was questioned.<ref name=mqpompeo/> Pompeo's modern predecessors had avoided political conventions while serving as secretary of state.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lee |first1=Matthew |title=Pompeo shattering precedent, sparking fury with RNC speech |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/pompeo-shattering-precedent-sparking-fury-rnc-speech-72572476 |website=ABC News |access-date=August 25, 2020 |language=en |date=August 25, 2020 |archive-date=August 24, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200824231756/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/pompeo-shattering-precedent-sparking-fury-rnc-speech-72572476 |url-status=live }}</ref> The speech came despite Pompeo having warned other diplomats against "improperly" taking part in politics.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hansler |first=Jennifer |title=Pompeo, who will address GOP convention, warned diplomats not to 'improperly' take part in politics |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/24/politics/pompeo-cable-biegun-email-political-activities/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=August 24, 2020 |date=August 24, 2020 |archive-date=August 24, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222011/https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/24/politics/pompeo-cable-biegun-email-political-activities/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Politicization of the White House===

There was criticism arguing that Trump had, during the convention. utilized the White House as a setting for purely political events in a manner which his presidential predecessors had not.<ref>{{cite web |title=RNC day 2 takeaways: Trump in the spotlight as Americans share stories of policy benefits |url=https://www.fox6now.com/news/rnc-day-2-takeaways-trump-in-the-spotlight-as-americans-share-stories-of-policy-benefits |last=Price |first=Michelle L. |website=Fox6Now.com |agency=Associated Press |access-date=August 27, 2020 |date=August 25, 2020 |archive-date=December 2, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202050223/https://www.fox6now.com/news/rnc-day-2-takeaways-trump-in-the-spotlight-as-americans-share-stories-of-policy-benefits |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Lynne Patton's Hatch Act violation===

In April 2021, [[Lynn Patton]], who was administrator of the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] for Region II at the time of the Republican National Convention, was fined $1,000 and barred for four years from federal employment as part of a settlement with the [[U.S. Office of Special Counsel]], after admitting to violating the [[Hatch Act of 1939]] by using her official federal government position to produce a video segment featuring residents of the [[New York City Housing Authority]]. She had utilized her role to develop relationships which she used to recruit participants for interviews she conducted in order to produce the video segment.<ref name="inquiry1"/><ref name="videoof">{{cite web |title=Video of NYCHA tenants during RNC should be probed for Hatch Act violations: official |url=https://www.pix11.com/news/local-news/video-of-nycha-tenants-during-rnc-should-be-probed-for-hatch-act-violations-official |website=WPIX |access-date=31 August 2020 |language=en |date=30 August 2020 |archive-date=September 2, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200902184950/https://www.pix11.com/news/local-news/video-of-nycha-tenants-during-rnc-should-be-probed-for-hatch-act-violations-official |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Jan |first1=Tracy |title=Trump HUD official disciplined for violating federal law |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/04/06/lynne-patton-hatch-act/ |website=Washington Post |access-date=6 April 2021 |date=6 April 2021}}</ref>

Shortly after the convention, Democratic New York City councilman (and congressional candidate) [[Ritchie Torres]] demanded that there be a federal probe into Patton's actions.<ref name="videoof"/> In October 2020, a report released by the office of Democratic United States Senator [[Elizabeth Warren]], compiled by her staff, on potential Hatch Act violations by the Trump administration had cited this as one of Patton's potential Hatch Act violations.<ref name="Warrenreport">{{cite web |title=LAWLESSNESS AND DISORDER: The Corrupt Trump Administration Has Made A Mockery of the Hatch Act |url=https://www.boston.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Hatch-Act-Violations-by-Trump-Administration-Final.pdf |publisher=Office of Senator Elizabeth Warren |access-date=14 November 2020 |date=October 2020 |archive-date=November 6, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201106153539/https://www.boston.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Hatch-Act-Violations-by-Trump-Administration-Final.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Other potential Hatch Act violations===
Many aspects of the convention have been cited as potential violations of the Hatch Act.

On September 3, 2020, Democrats on the [[House Committee on Oversight and Reform]] wrote a letter to the [[Office of Special Counsel]] urging them to launch an investigation of, “multiple, repeated violations” of the Hatch Act committed during the convention.<ref name="inquiry1">{{cite web |last1=Broadwater |first1=Luke |title=Democrats call for an inquiry into Hatch Act violations during the Republican convention. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/03/us/trump-vs-biden/democrats-call-for-an-inquiry-into-hatch-act-violations-during-the-republican-convention |website=The New York Times |access-date=4 September 2020 |date=4 September 2020 |archive-date=September 4, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200904010350/https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/03/us/trump-vs-biden/democrats-call-for-an-inquiry-into-hatch-act-violations-during-the-republican-convention |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Chad Wolf's participation in naturalization ceremony segment====

Acting [[United States Secretary of Homeland Security]] [[Chad Wolf]]'s appearance in the naturalization ceremony, which was part of the convention's program, has been cited by some as a potential violation of the Hatch Act.<ref name="inquiry1"/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Conradis |first1=Brandon |title=Democrats seek probe into DHS chief for possible Hatch Act violations |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/513878-democrats-seek-probe-into-dhs-chief-for-possible-hatch-act-violations |website=TheHill |access-date=28 August 2020 |language=en |date=26 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828175054/https://thehill.com/homenews/house/513878-democrats-seek-probe-into-dhs-chief-for-possible-hatch-act-violations |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]] filed a complaint with the Office of Special Counsel, arguing this was a clear violation of the Hatch Act.<ref>{{cite web |title=CREW Complaint: Chad Wolf Violated Hatch Act During RNC |url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/news/press-releases/chad-wolf-hatch-act-complaint/ |website=CREW {{!}} Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington |access-date=14 November 2020 |date=27 August 2020 |archive-date=November 16, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116130422/https://www.citizensforethics.org/news/press-releases/chad-wolf-hatch-act-complaint/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Mike Pompeo's speech====

[[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of state]] [[Mike Pompeo]]'s convention address, delivered while on a diplomatic trip to [[Israel]], has been cited as a possible Hatch Act violation.<ref name="inquiry1"/><ref name=mqpompeo>{{cite web |last1=Quinn |first1=Melissa |title=RNC chair defends plans for Pompeo to address Republican convention |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/rnc-chair-ronna-mcdaniel-defends-plans-for-pompeo-to-address-convention/ |work=CBS News |access-date=August 24, 2020 |language=en |date=August 23, 2020 |archive-date=August 24, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200824010705/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/rnc-chair-ronna-mcdaniel-defends-plans-for-pompeo-to-address-convention/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kim |first1=Seung Min |title=Trump's family members, conservative allies dominate GOP convention lineup |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-family-members-conservatives-allies-dominate-gop-convention-lineup/2020/08/23/d9d48d14-e574-11ea-970a-64c73a1c2392_story.html |website=Washington Post |access-date=August 24, 2020 |language=en |date=August 23, 2020 |archive-date=November 14, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201114135329/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-family-members-conservatives-allies-dominate-gop-convention-lineup/2020/08/23/d9d48d14-e574-11ea-970a-64c73a1c2392_story.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

On August 25, the same day that Pompeo spoke, chairman of the [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations|House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations]] and Democrat [[Joaquin Castro]] opened a congressional investigation into the legality of Pompeo's planned speech.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hansler |first1=Jennifer |title=House Democrat opens investigation into Pompeo's RNC speech |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/25/politics/castro-investigation-pompeo-rnc-speech/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=August 25, 2020 |date=August 25, 2020 |archive-date=August 25, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200825213948/https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/25/politics/castro-investigation-pompeo-rnc-speech/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref> On October 26, 2020, Democrats [[Eliot Engel]] (Chairman of the [[House Committee on Foreign Affairs]]) and [[Nita Lowey]] (Chairwoman of the [[House Committee on Appropriations]]), confirmed that the Office of Special Counsel had launched a probe into possible Hatch Act violations related to Pompeo's speech.<ref>{{cite web |title=Engel & Lowey Statement on New OSC Probe into Pompeo for Potential Hatch Act Violations |url=https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/2020/10/engel-lowey-statement-on-new-osc-probe-into-pompeo-for-potential-hatch-act-violations |website=House Foreign Affairs Committee |access-date=14 November 2020 |language=en |date=26 October 2020 |archive-date=November 20, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120221834/https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/2020/10/engel-lowey-statement-on-new-osc-probe-into-pompeo-for-potential-hatch-act-violations |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Use of the White House====

Some experts and politicians have questioned the legality of the use of the White House for convention speeches and other portions of the convention.<ref name=Subramaniam1/> The legality is in question, since any federal employees (exempting the president and vice president themselves) who assist in such campaigning activities in such a government building may be violating the Hatch Act.<ref name=Subramaniam1>{{cite news |last1=Subramaniam |first1=Tara |title=Fact Check: Is it legal for Trump to give his convention speech from the White House? |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/06/politics/hatch-act-rnc-speech-fact-check/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=August 23, 2020 |date=August 6, 2020 |archive-date=August 25, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200825074258/https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/06/politics/hatch-act-rnc-speech-fact-check/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

[[Ivanka Trump]]'s deliverance of a convention speech from the South Lawn of the White House while holding an official position in the federal government may violate the Hatch Act.<ref>{{cite web |last=Plott |first=Elaina |title=Is Ivanka Trump Going to Change Anyone's Mind? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/27/us/politics/ivanka-trump-rnc.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=August 28, 2020 |date=August 27, 2020 |archive-date=August 27, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200827235202/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/27/us/politics/ivanka-trump-rnc.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Use of National Park Service property for fireworks display====

The use of property owned by the [[National Park Service]] for the convention's closing fireworks display was argued by some experts to raise ethics concerns that may be in violation of the Hatch Act.<ref name=fireworks1>{{cite web |last1=Homan |first1=Timothy R. |title=Park Service under fire for role in GOP convention |url=https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/513856-park-service-under-fire-for-role-in-gop-convention |website=TheHill |access-date=30 August 2020 |language=en |date=27 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828060630/https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/513856-park-service-under-fire-for-role-in-gop-convention |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=fireworks2>{{cite web |last1=Ankel |first1=Sophia |title=The RNC ended with a firework display over the Washington Monument spelling out 'TRUMP' |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/last-night-rnc-ends-with-trump-fireworks-over-washington-monument-2020-8 |website=Business Insider |access-date=30 August 2020 |date=28 August 2020 |archive-date=August 31, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200831042730/https://www.businessinsider.com/last-night-rnc-ends-with-trump-fireworks-over-washington-monument-2020-8 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=fireworks3>{{Cite web|last=Henney|first=Elliot|date=2020-08-26|title=Park Service approves RNC request for fireworks on National Mall Thursday|url=https://wjla.com/news/local/rnc-fireworks-national-mall|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201029203317/https://wjla.com/news/local/rnc-fireworks-national-mall|archive-date=October 29, 2020|access-date=2020-10-26|website=WJLA}}</ref>
===Use of official acts of office in convention program===

Journalists have questioned the ethics of President Trump using video of official acts of office, such as a video of a pardon ceremony and participating in a prerecorded<ref>{{Cite web|title=President Trump Participates in a Naturalization Ceremony at the White House|via=YouTube|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vb9qXvGAQTA&t=61s|access-date=2020-08-28|archive-date=December 2, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202050223/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vb9qXvGAQTA&t=61s|url-status=live}}</ref> naturalization ceremony, as portions of the convention program.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gearan |first1=Anne |last2=Itkowitz |first2=Colby |last3=Sonmez |first3=Felicia |last4=Wagner |first4=John |title=Trump uses powers of government in service of reelection, with pardoning and naturalization ceremonies |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/elections/2020/08/25/republican-national-convention-live-updates/ |website=Washington Post |access-date=27 August 2020 |date=26 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828050724/https://www.washingtonpost.com/elections/2020/08/25/republican-national-convention-live-updates/ |url-status=live }}</ref> These have been criticized as a politicization of government functions.<ref name=TariniBender1>{{cite web |last1=Parti |first1=Tarini |last2=Bender |first2=Michael C. |title=Immigrants in Trump-Led Ceremony Didn't Know They Would Appear at RNC |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/immigrants-in-trump-led-ceremony-didnt-know-they-would-appear-at-rnc-11598481345 |website=Wall Street Journal |access-date=28 August 2020 |date=26 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828230141/https://www.wsj.com/articles/immigrants-in-trump-led-ceremony-didnt-know-they-would-appear-at-rnc-11598481345 |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Use of unwitting participants===
Several individuals featured in the convention were unwitting of their inclusion in the convention.

Several of the participants of the naturalization ceremony have come forward to complain that they were not informed that it was going to part of the Republican National Convention.<ref name=TariniBender1/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Klar |first1=Rebecca |title=Two women say they didn't know their naturalization ceremony would be used at GOP convention |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/513866-two-women-say-they-didnt-know-their-naturalization-ceremony-would-be-used |website=TheHill |access-date=28 August 2020 |language=en |date=26 August 2020 |archive-date=August 28, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828023307/https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/513866-two-women-say-they-didnt-know-their-naturalization-ceremony-would-be-used |url-status=live }}</ref>

Several of those featured in a video segment with residents of the New York City Housing Authority complained that they did not know that their interviews would be used for the Republican National Convention, and that they did not support Trump.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Richards |first1=Zoë |title=Tenants Say They Were Tricked Into RNC Video Appearance: 'I Am Not A Trump Supporter' |url=https://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/tenants-tricked-rnc-video |website=Talking Points Memo |access-date=31 August 2020 |date=29 August 2020 |archive-date=December 2, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202050221/https://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/tenants-tricked-rnc-video |url-status=live }}</ref>

That might help Gavin Newsom|website=The Sacremento Bee|date=August 23, 2021|last1=Bollag|first1=Sophia}}</ref><ref name="blah2">{{cite web|last=Reston |first=Maeve |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/14/politics/larry-elder-covid-newsom-recall/index.html |title=How Larry Elder has helped Gavin Newsom in California's recall election - CNNPolitics |publisher=Cnn.com |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2021}}</ref> as well as his history of provocative right-wing rhetoric as a radio talk show host.<ref>https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-09-13/skelton-recall-newsom-elder-poll?_amp=true</ref>

title: 2021 California gubernatorial recall election
added: On July 24, 2021, the California Republican Party's steering committee voted to allow the party to endorse a candidate in the recall election, if the candidate received at least 60 percent of delegate votes in an upcoming August 7 meeting. Some Republicans opposed the move out of concern that endorsing a single candidate would reduce Republican voter turnout.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/07/24/california-republican-party-creates-recall-endorsement-path-1388974/|title=California Republican Party creates recall endorsement path|first=Jeremy B.|last=White|date=July 24, 2021|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref> On August 7, the party voted to cancel the endorsement vote and issue no endorsement;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/08/07/california-gop-wont-endorse-a-candidate-in-newsom-recall-1389718/|title=California GOP won't endorse a candidate in Newsom recall|first=Jeremy B.|last=White|date=August 7, 2021|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref> prior to the cancellation of the endorsement vote, Republican delegates were set to choose an endorsee from the four candidates who each had received the support of at least 200 delegates, which were [[Larry Elder]], [[Kevin Faulconer]], [[Kevin Kiley (politician)|Kevin Kiley]], and [[Doug Ose]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2021-08-07/cagop-endorsement-vote-jenner-elder-faulconer-ose-kiley?_amp=true|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=State GOP votes not to endorse a candidate in the recall race|first=Seema|last=Mehta|date=August 7, 2021}}</ref>

title: Joe Biggs
added: === Activism and broadcasting ===

Biggs is a [[Far-right politics|far-right]] online personality.<ref name=CNNAnalysis>{{Cite web|author=Sara Sidner, Anna-Maja Rappard & Marshall Cohen|title=Disproportionate number of current and former military personnel arrested in Capitol attack, CNN analysis shows|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/31/us/capitol-riot-arrests-active-military-veterans-soh/index.html|publisher=CNN|date=February 4, 2021|quote=Biggs became an online personality of the far-right, spouting bombastic and sometimes violent rhetoric toward women and Antifa. As far back as 2012, there were a plethora of tweets mentioning sexual violence on his @RamboBiggs account, which has been archived by the Media Matters For America group.}}</ref> He is also a leading figure and organizer of the Proud Boys, an extremist group with nationalist, neofascist and self-proclaimed "Western-chauvinist" views.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtap.com/2021/01/21/proud-boy-organizer-arrested-in-florida-for-riot-at-capitol/|title=Proud Boy organizer arrested in Florida over riot at Capitol|agency=[[Associated Press]]|website=www.wtap.com|access-date=January 31, 2021|quote=a self-described organizer for the Proud Boys, a far-right extremist group ... neofascist group}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/proud-boys-organizer-joe-biggs-charged-capitol-riot-n1254999|title=Proud Boys organizer Joe Biggs charged in Capitol riot|website=NBC News|access-date=January 31, 2021|quote=Biggs, an organizer of the far-right, all-male group of self-described "Western chauvinists,"}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/legal-issues/joseph-biggs-arrested-capitol-riot/2021/01/20/1def0990-5b75-11eb-aaad-93988621dd28_story.html|title=Proud Boys organizer Joe Biggs arrested as FBI alleges more possible planning in U.S. Capitol breach|first=Spencer S.|last=Hsu|access-date=January 31, 2021|newspaper=Washington Post|quote=Proud Boys organizer Joseph Randall Biggs ... far-right nationalist group|archive-url=https://archive.today/20210121041416/https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/legal-issues/joseph-biggs-arrested-capitol-riot/2021/01/20/1def0990-5b75-11eb-aaad-93988621dd28_story.html|archive-date=January 21, 2021|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/20/us/proud-boys-arrest-joseph-biggs.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20210120200850/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/20/us/proud-boys-arrest-joseph-biggs.html|archive-date=January 20, 2021|title=A leader of the Proud Boys was arrested over his role at the Capitol riot|quote=Joseph Biggs, a leader of the far-right nationalist group the Proud Boys|first=Alan|last=Feuer|date=January 20, 2021|access-date=January 31, 2021|newspaper=New York Times|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nicholasreimann/2021/01/21/patrick-mccaughey---accused-of-barbaric-jamming-of-police-officer-in-a-door--among-those-arrested-after-capitol-riot/|quote=Proud Boys organizer Joe Biggs|title=Patrick McCaughey — Accused Of 'Barbaric' Jamming Of Police Officer In A Door— Among Those Arrested After Capitol Riot|first=Nicholas|last=Reimann|website=Forbes|access-date=January 31, 2021}}</ref>

From at least 2012 through 2016, Biggs posted violent, misogynistic, and sexually violent content on Twitter.<ref name=CNNAnalysis/><ref name=UnofficialVersion>{{cite news | last =Staff | first = | title =New Host For "Unofficial Version Of Trump TV" Encouraged Date Rape And Punching Transgender People: Former Infowars Reporter Joe Biggs Also Threatened To Release Revenge Porn And Commented Positively About Sexual Violence And Punching Women | newspaper =[[Media Matters for America]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =January 4, 2017|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/right-side-broadcasting/new-host-unofficial-version-trump-tv-encouraged-date-rape-and-punching | access-date =February 13, 2021 }}</ref> In 2017, [[Media Matters for America]] reported that Biggs had made comments on social media promoting "date rape and sexual violence". He had advocated using [[chloroform]] and [[Drug-facilitated sexual assault|roofies]] to have non-consensual sex with women. According to the staff writers, he threatened a past partner with [[revenge porn]] and threatened [[Trans bashing|violence against transgender people]] (posting, "Punch a tranny").<ref name=UnofficialVersion/> Biggs issued a statement to ''[[Raw Story]]'' describing his personal problems following his Army discharge: "I became very depressed and turned to alcohol and the over abuse of painkillers that had been prescribed to me while I was in."<ref name="RS">{{cite news | last =Preza | first =Elizabeth | title ='Every kiss begins with roofies': Host of unofficial Trump TV promoted rape and sexual violence| newspaper =[[Raw Story]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = January 4, 2017 |url=https://www.rawstory.com/2017/01/every-kiss-begins-with-roofies-host-of-unofficial-trump-tv-promoted-rape-and-sexual-violence/ | access-date =February 14, 2021}}</ref> Biggs said that he was suicidal at that time, and "decided to cry out for help," admitting that "I would say outlandish things on Twitter in hopes someone shocked would say 'Hey, what the hell is wrong with you?'"<ref name="RS" />

In January 2017, Biggs announced that he was doing a [[Television pilot|pilot show]] for [[Right Side Broadcasting Network]] (RSBN), a pro-Trump online channel. The show was to be dedicated to guns and the Second Amendment, and the pilot episode was posted online.<ref name=UnofficialVersion/> The online TV show was not produced following the pilot, following the reporting on Biggs' history of pro-violence comments on social media.<ref name=RSBNScales>{{cite news | last =Hananoki | first =Eric | title =Pro-Trump RSBN Scales Back, Cancels Mike Cernovich Program | newspaper =[[Media Matters for America]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =April 26, 2017 |url=https://www.mediamatters.org/mike-cernovich/pro-trump-rsbn-scales-back-cancels-mike-cernovich-program | access-date =February 14, 2021 }}</ref> RSBN's CEO Joe Seales told Media Matters that Biggs "never worked for or with us. We worked up the idea of a pilot for a show, which included him, but it wasn't meant to be."<ref name=RSBNScales/>

Biggs is an organizer for [[Proud Boys]] and a former ''[[InfoWars]]'' staff member,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bernstein|first=Maxine|date=August 9, 2019|title=Mixed messages, mounting tensions as Proud Boys and antifa prepare to face off in Portland|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/crime/2019/08/chief-says-portland-is-becoming-a-magnet-for-brawling-political-protests-while-out-of-state-proud-boys-send-message-to-mayor-city-commissioners.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 2, 2020|website=[[The Oregonian]]|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|date=August 18, 2019|title=Portland rally: Far-right and antifa groups face off|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49382386|access-date=October 15, 2020}}</ref> where he was an "on-camera personality".<ref name="DBN">{{cite news|last=Harper|first=Mark|date=January 24, 2021|title=Volusia Proud Boy facing charges claimed last fall that threats were made against his life|language=|pages=|newspaper=[[Daytona Beach News-Journal]]|publisher=|location=|url=https://www.news-journalonline.com/story/news/crime/2021/01/24/volusia-proud-boy-facing-charges-claimed-threats-made-against-his-life/6662871002/|access-date=February 13, 2021}}</ref> Biggs also hosted a show on censored.TV that has since been removed from that website.<ref name="DBN" /> His Twitter account was blocked after posting threatening comments about [[Antifa (United States)|antifa]], such as "We hunt them. Get their info. Expose them. Make them scared to be in public."<ref name="DBN" />

Biggs works as a [[talk radio]] host.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Mesh|first=Aaron|date=|title=Portland Mayor Responds to Right-Wing Organizer's Threat of Monthly Protests: "We Do Not Want Him Here in My City, Period"|url=https://www.wweek.com/news/courts/2019/08/17/portland-mayor-responds-to-right-wing-organizers-threat-of-monthly-protests-we-do-not-want-him-here-in-my-city-period/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 2, 2020|website=[[Willamette Week]]|language=en-US}}</ref> He organized the [[End Domestic Terrorism rally]] in [[Portland, Oregon]], in August 2019.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=August 15, 2019|title=Controversial organizer of planned Portland demonstration speaks to KATU|url=https://katu.com/news/local/controversial-organizer-joe-biggs-of-planned-portland-demonstration-speaks-to-katu|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 2, 2020|website=[[KATU]]}}</ref> Prior to the rally, Biggs posted memes about [[death squad]]s murdering leftists, proclaimed "Death to Antifa!", and suggested a spiked weapon would "be put to good use,” before his [[Twitter suspension|Twitter account was suspended]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gupta|first=Arun|date=August 16, 2019|title=Riotlandia: Why Portland Has Become the Epicenter of Far-Right Violence|url=https://theintercept.com/2019/08/16/portland-far-right-rally/|url-status=live|access-date=2021-03-24|website=The Intercept|language=en}}</ref> In 2019, Biggs advocated for laws to ban protesters from wearing masks.<ref name=":0" />

In March 2021, Biggs' lawyer, J. Daniel Hull, stated in a court filing that Biggs had acted as an FBI informant in 2019 and 2020, reporting on planned locations and routes for Proud Boys rallies as well as the activities by Antifa that he observed.<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 31, 2021|title=FBI enlisted Proud Boys leader to inform on antifa, lawyer says

title: Jeff Duncan (politician)
added: === Syria ===

In 2019, Duncan signed a letter led by Representative [[Ro Khanna]] and Senator [[Rand Paul]] to President Trump asserting that it is "long past time to rein in the use of force that goes beyond congressional authorization" and that they hoped this would "serve as a model for ending hostilities in the future—in particular, as you and your administration seek a political solution to our involvement in Afghanistan.”<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/04/03/congress-syria-withdrawal-1252185|title=Rand Paul, Ocasio-Cortez praise Trump for Syria withdrawal|first=Burgess|last=Everett|date=April 3, 2019|publisher=Politico}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/policy/defense/437144-rand-paul-teams-up-with-ocasio-cortez-omar-to-press-trump-on-syria-withdrawal|title=Rand Paul teams up with Ocasio-Cortez, Omar to press Trump on Syria withdrawal |first=Alexander|last=Bolton|date=April 3, 2019|work=The Hill}}</ref>
In 2019, Duncan was one of 60 representatives to vote against condemning Trump's withdrawal from [[Syria]].<ref>https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/116-2019/h560</ref>
=== Foreign policy ===

In 2020, Duncan voted against the National Defense Authorization Act of 2021, which would prevent the president from withdrawing soldiers from [[Afghanistan]] without congressional approval.<ref>https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/116-2020/h152</ref>

In July 2021, Duncan voted against the bipartisan ALLIES Act, which would increase by 8,000 the number of [[Special Immigrant Visa|special immigrant visas]] for Afghan allies of the U.S. military during [[United States invasion of Afghanistan|its invasion of Afghanistan]], while also reducing some application requirements that caused long application backlogs; the bill passed in the House 407–16.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Quarshie |first1=Mabinty |title=These 16 Republicans voted against speeding up visas for Afghans fleeing the Taliban |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/08/17/16-republicans-voted-against-special-visas-help-afghanistan-people/8163392002/ |access-date=August 18, 2021 |work=[[USA Today]] |date=August 17, 2021}}</ref>
=== ''Texas v. Pennsylvania'' ===

In December 2020, Duncan was one of 126 Republican members of the [[House of Representatives]] to sign an [[amicus brief]] in support of ''[[Texas v. Pennsylvania]]'', a lawsuit filed at the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] contesting the results of the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]], in which [[Joe Biden]] defeated<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blood|first1=Michael R.|last2=Riccardi|first2=Nicholas|date=December 5, 2020|title=Biden officially secures enough electors to become president|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-elections-electoral-college-3e0b852c3cfadf853b08aecbfc3569fa|url-status=live|access-date=December 12, 2020|website=[[Associated Press|AP News]]|archive-date=December 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208201209/https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-elections-electoral-college-3e0b852c3cfadf853b08aecbfc3569fa}}</ref> Trump. The Supreme Court declined to hear the case on the basis that Texas lacked [[Standing (law)|standing]] under [[Article Three of the United States Constitution|Article III of the Constitution]] to challenge the results of an election held by another state.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|author-link=Adam Liptak|date=2020-12-11|title=Supreme Court Rejects Texas Suit Seeking to Subvert Election|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/us/politics/supreme-court-election-texas.html|access-date=2020-12-12|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211234955/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/us/politics/supreme-court-election-texas.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Order in Pending Case|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121120zr_p860.pdf|date=2020-12-11|publisher=[[Supreme Court of the United States]]|access-date=December 11, 2020|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211234004/https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121120zr_p860.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/politics/read-house-republicans-texas-supreme-court/index.html|title=Brief from 126 Republicans supporting Texas lawsuit in Supreme Court|first=Daniella |last=Diaz|work=[[CNN]]|access-date=December 11, 2020|archive-date=December 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201212000435/https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/politics/read-house-republicans-texas-supreme-court/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

Duncan was the lead sponsor to remove Major League Baseball’s antitrust law exemption after the league pulled its 2021 All-Star Game from Atlanta in protest of Georgia's new voting law.<ref>https://thehill.com/homenews/house/546237-gop-lawmaker-to-offer-bill-revoking-mlbs-antitrust-exception</ref>

title: Kyrsten Sinema
deleted: In 2018 Sinema was the subject of public criticism in Republican campaign ads for previous comments that she made during a 2007 legislative committee hearing that debated SB1268 a senate bill that would stiffen legal penalties for people who solicited underage sex trafficking victims. In video of the "House Natural Resources and Public Safety" committee hearing on SB1268 Sinema said:

“I’m just not convinced that enforcing a strict liability on those johns who are engaging in prostitution is really the answer, and as a former social worker at an elementary school, there were children at my school who were 12, 13 years old and some of these children looked older than me. They were much more – I mean, definitely sophisticated, developed – and if I had seen a number of my former students in a place other than in a sixth-grade classroom, I would not have known that those children were 12 instead of 19 or 20. And so I do have a real concern for those individuals, and if one of those young girls were conscripted into prostitution and a john were to approach her, he’d be facing a class 2 felony for unknowingly soliciting sex from a 12-year-old who appeared to be a 20-year-old.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Attack ad hits Arizona Senate candidate Kyrsten Sinema for past comments on underage prostitution |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/11/politics/kyrsten-sinema-defend-arizona-gop-attack-ad/index.html |Television Network=CNN|access-date=September 17, 2021}}</ref>
