title: Mike Thompson
deleted: Thompson was endorsed for reelection in 2008 by the Humane USA PAC, a [[political action committee]] founded by leaders of animal rights groups such as [[Humane Society of the United States|The Humane Society of the United States]], The Fund for Animals, [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]], the [[Doris Day Animal League]], the [[Animal Welfare Institute]], [[Farm Sanctuary]] and The Ark Trust.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humaneusa.org/humaneusaendorsements.htm#CA|title=Humane USA 2008 Endorsements|publisher=Humane USA PAC|access-date=17 January 2010|location=Washington, DC}}</ref> He has an 88% lifetime rating from the Defenders of Wildlife Action Fund, which endorsed him for reelection in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defendersactionfund.org/political_campaigns/2008endorsements.html|title=DEefenders of Wildlife Action Fund announces 2008 endorsements|publisher=Defenders of Wildlife Action Fund|access-date=18 January 2010|location=Washington, DC|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207122512/http://defendersactionfund.org/political_campaigns/2008endorsements.html|archive-date=7 February 2009}}</ref> This organization is the [[501(c)(4)]] sister organization of [[Defenders of Wildlife]].

Thompson has voted against banning ivory imports<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/2822/actions|title=Actions - H.R.2822 - 114th Congress (2015-2016): Department of the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2016|last=Calvert|first=Ken|date=2015-07-08|website=www.congress.gov|access-date=2019-08-25}}</ref> and has voted several times in favor of polar bear trophy importation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/house-bill/4089|title=H.R.4089 - 112th Congress (2011-2012): Sportsmen's Heritage Act of 2012|last=Miller|first=Jeff|date=2012-04-18|website=www.congress.gov|access-date=2019-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/3590|title=H.R.3590 - 113th Congress (2013-2014): Sportsmen's Heritage And Recreational Enhancement Act|last=Latta|first=Robert E.|date=2014-02-10|website=www.congress.gov|access-date=2019-08-25}}</ref>

While a California state senator, Thompson helped defeat legislation to halt the use of dogs in hunting of black bears<ref>{{cite web |url=http://info.sen.ca.gov/cgi-bin/postquery?bill_number=sb_67&sess=9394&house=S&site=sen |title=Official California Legislative Information - Bill Information |date=1993-05-25 |access-date=2008-12-12 |publisher=[[California State Senate]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104154557/http://info.sen.ca.gov/cgi-bin/postquery?bill_number=sb_67&sess=9394&house=S&site=sen |archive-date=2009-01-04 }} Regarding California SB 67.</ref> and co-authored and voted for a bill (SB 28) to resume trophy hunting of [[cougar]]s.<ref name=SB28>{{cite web |url=http://info.sen.ca.gov/cgi-bin/postquery?bill_number=sb_28&sess=9596&house=B&site=sen |title=Official California Legislative Information - Bill Information |date=1995-09-15 |access-date=2008-12-12 |publisher=[[California State Senate]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104153859/http://info.sen.ca.gov/cgi-bin/postquery?bill_number=sb_28&sess=9596&house=B&site=sen |archive-date=2009-01-04 }} Regarding California SB 28.</ref> SB 28 would have undone provisions of California Proposition 117 (the California Wildlife Protection Act of 1990), which voters had approved in the statewide election held on June 5, 1990, that provided some protection for cougars.<ref name=SB28 /> Thompson was the House sponsor of the [[Northern California Coastal Wild Heritage Wilderness Act]], which was signed into law by President [[George W. Bush]]. The [[hunting]] [[lobbyist]] group [[Safari Club International]] recognized Thompson Federal Legislator of the Year, and he received the Hunting Heritage Award from the group.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.huntinglife.com/blog/detail/sci-recognize-federal-legislator-and-heritage-award-winners-at-2008-convention|title=SCI Recognize Federal Legislator and Heritage Award Winners at 2008 Convention|date=2008-01-28|access-date=2008-12-11|publisher=HuntingLife.com}}</ref> He is an active member and former co-chair of the Congressional Sportsmen's Caucus,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/congtravel/sponsor_report.php?sponsor=30807|title=Power Trips - Congressional Sportsmen's Foundation|year=2008|access-date=2008-12-11|publisher=[[American Public Media]]|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614173911/http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/congtravel/sponsor_report.php?sponsor=30807|archive-date=2011-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mikethompson.house.gov/biography|title=Rep. Mike Thompson biography|access-date=2008-12-11|publisher=Congressional office of Rep. Mike Thompson|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202160428/http://mikethompson.house.gov/biography/|archive-date=2008-12-02}}</ref> and is a lifelong hunter and fisherman.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}

title: Presidency of William McKinley
added: The McKinley administration brought foreign affairs to the top of the agenda for the first time since the 1840s. Most Republicans supported an expansionist foreign policy, building the American presence in the world that suited its increasing economic dominance. Opposition came from an anti-imperialist element, that include some old time Republicans, as well as most Democrats. However, in 1898 the Democrats took the lead in demanding Spain stop oppressing the independent-minded people of Cuba, while McKinley tried to stop the rush to war. <ref> Frank Ninkovich, "The United States and Imperialism." in Robert D. Schulzinger, ed. ''A Companion to U.S. Foreign Relations'' (2006) pp 79–102. </ref>

title: 2022 South Korean presidential election
added: ==Campaign==

During the primary campaign, observers noted that the presidential campaign was going down as the most negative campaign in South Korea's recent history, as the candidates were described to be busy mudslinging at each other and there was no evidence that the candidates were competing on the basis of values, platforms or policies. A Hankyoreh commentary said PPP candidates like Yoo Seong-min, Won Hee-ryong, and Choi Jae-hyung, and Lee Nak-yeon and Chung Sye-kyun on the Democratic side struggled in their respective party primaries as they were too "elite" and too "respectable". The commentary also attributed to the success of Lee Jae-myung, the Democratic candidate, and Hong Jun-pyo and Yoon Seok-youl on the PPP side due to the increasing tendency to vote with the heart instead of the brain and to prioritize candidate attributes and authentic over competence.<ref>{{cite news |date= 26 September 2021|title= The golden era of bad guys running for president in S. Korea|url=https://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/1012702.html|access-date= 14 October 2021}}</ref>

title: 2022 South Korean presidential election
added: The three main contenders, Lee for the Democratic Party, and Hong Jun-pyo and Yoon on the PPP side, were reported to have record low favourability ratings according to approval ratings compiled by Gallup Korea. Lee, has an approval rating of only 34%, while Yoon's rating was at just 30% and Hong Joon-pyo, at 28%. In contrast, President Moon Jae-in had a positive rating of 47% while running for election in 2017. <ref>{{cite news |date= 14 October 2021|title= South Korea’s Mud-Slinging Primary Campaign Nears End|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-korea-s-mud-slinging-primary-campaign-nears-end/6270150.html|access-date= 14 October 2021}}</ref>.

title: Topics of the Mueller special counsel investigation
deleted: JUST DUMPING THIS PARAGRAPH HERE FOR NOW

The [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)]] was started by Deputy Attorney General [[Rod Rosenstein]], who was serving as Acting Attorney General due to the recusal of Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]]. He authorized [[Robert Mueller]] to investigate and prosecute "any links and/or coordination between the Russian government and individuals associated with the campaign of President Donald Trump", as well as "any matters that arose or may arise directly from the investigation" and any other matters within the scope of 28 CFR 600.4 – Jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite web | title=28 CFR 600.4 – Jurisdiction | work=[[Legal Information Institute]] |publisher=[[Cornell]] | date=July 25, 2016 | url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/28/600.4 | access-date=February 21, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227020642/https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/28/600.4 | archive-date=February 27, 2018 | url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=authorizing>{{cite web|author-link=Rod Rosenstein|last=Rosenstein|first=Rod J.|date=May 17, 2017|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/press-release/file/967231/download|title=Order No. 3915-2017: Appointment of Special Counsel to Investigate Russian Interference with the 2016 Presidential Election and Related Matters|work=[[Office of the Deputy Attorney General]]|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|access-date=February 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180807044814/https://www.justice.gov/opa/press-release/file/967231/download|archive-date=August 7, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>

The investigation's broad scope allowed Mueller to investigate many topics, including: Russian election interference; links between Trump associates and Russian officials; alleged collusion between Trump campaign and Russian agents; potential obstruction of justice; financial investigations; lobbyists; Trump as a subject of investigation; other topics; and the Facebook–Cambridge Analytica data scandal.

title: Frank Kendall III
added: ===Secretary of the Air Force===

On April 27, 2021, President [[Joe Biden]] announced Kendall as his nominee to be the 26th secretary of the Air Force.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/27/president-biden-announces-key-administration-nominations-in-national-security-2/|title=President Biden Announces Key Administration Nominations in National Security|date=2021-04-26|website=whitehouse.gov}}</ref> His Senate confirmation occurred after almost three months of deliberation, due to holds by senators [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://defensecommunities.org/2021/06/senators-slow-down-kendall-confirmation/|title=Senators Slow Down Kendall Confirmation|date=2021-06-28|website=Association of Defense Communities}}</ref> [[Gary Peters]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2021/07/26/peters-ends-hold-biden-nominee-after-air-force-commits-selfridge/8090821002/|title=Peters ends hold on Biden nominee after Air Force commits to Selfridge mission|last=Burke|first=Melissa Nann|date=2021-07-26|website=Detroit News}}</ref> and [[Elizabeth Warren]],<ref name="Warren">{{cite web|url=https://www.airforcemag.com/warren-lifts-hold-on-kendall-nomination-after-ethics-agreement-extension/|title=Warren Lifts Hold on Kendall Nomination After Ethics Agreement Extension|first=Abraham|last=Mahshie|date=2021-07-13|website=Air Force Magazine}}</ref> the latter of whom released her hold after Kendall agreed to extend his post-governmental recusal agreements from two to four years.<ref name="Warren"/> Kendall was eventually confirmed by voice vote on June 26, 2021,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/nomination/117th-congress/484|title=PN484 — Frank Kendall III — Department of Defense, 117th Congress (2021-2022)|access-date=2021-09-05|website=U.S. Congress}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/2708030/senate-confirms-kendall-to-be-air-force-secretary/|title=Senate confirms Kendall to be Air Force Secretary|last=Pope|first=Charles|publisher=Secretary of the Air Force Public Affairs|date=2021-07-26|website=U.S. Air Force}}</ref> administratively sworn in on July 28, 2021,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spaceforce.mil/News/Article/2711279/kendall-sworn-in-as-26th-secretary-of-the-air-force|title=Kendall sworn in as 26th Secretary of the Air Force|author=Staff Sgt. Nicolas Z. Erwin|publisher=Secretary of the Air Force Public Affairs|date=2021-07-28|website=U.S. Space Force}}</ref> and ceremonially sworn in by secretary of defense [[Lloyd Austin]] on August 4, 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dvidshub.net/image/6766106/sd-swears-secaf-kendall|title=SD swears in SECAF Kendall [Image 9 of 24]|date=2021-08-04|website=DVIDS}}</ref>

title: Adlai Stevenson III
deleted: Born in Chicago, he received a law degree in 1957 from [[Harvard Law School]]. Stevenson was commissioned as a lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corps in 1952, and served in the Korean War. He was discharged in 1954, but continued to serve in the Marine Reserves until 1961 as a captain. In 1957, Stevenson went to work as a clerk for a Justice of the Illinois Supreme Court and worked there until 1958 when he joined the law firm of Brown and Platt.

title: List of United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote
deleted: There have been four [[United States presidential election]]s in which the successful presidential candidate did not receive a plurality of the popular vote, including the [[1824 United States presidential election|1824 election]], which was the first U.S. presidential election where the [[Direct election|popular vote]] was recorded.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/presidential-election-goes-to-the-house |title=1824 Presidential election goes to the House |publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)|History]] |access-date=December 10, 2016 |archive-date=December 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203175736/http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/presidential-election-goes-to-the-house |url-status=live }}</ref> In these cases, the successful candidate secured less of the national popular vote than another candidate who received more votes, either a [[majority]], more than half the vote, or a [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] of the vote.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ubHhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA172|title=Rethinking American Electoral Democracy|last=Streb|first=Matthew J.|date=October 30, 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317519829|pages=172|language=en|oclc=928999469|access-date=February 2, 2017|archive-date=February 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216025328/https://books.google.com/books?id=ubHhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA172|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Savage|first=David|title=For the fourth time in American history, the president-elect lost the popular vote. Credit the electoral college|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-electoral-college-20161110-story.html|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 11, 2016|access-date=November 12, 2016|archive-date=November 12, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112004746/http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-electoral-college-20161110-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

In the U.S. presidential election system, instead of the nationwide popular vote determining the outcome of the election, the [[president of the United States]] is determined by votes cast by electors of the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]]. Alternatively, if no candidate receives an entatives|House of Representatives]]. These procedures are governed by the [[Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].  It is important to note that the U.S. Constitution does not require states to hold a popular vote{{cn|date=February 2021}}, however, since [[1880 United States presidential election|1880]], electors in every state have been chosen based on a popular election held on [[Election Day (United States)|Election Day]].<ref name="CRS2017THN">{{cite web|last=Neale|first=Thomas H.|date=May 15, 2017|title=The Electoral College: How It Works in Contemporary Presidential Elections|url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL32611.pdf|access-date=July 29, 2018|work=CRS Report for Congress|publisher=Congressional Research Service|location=Washington, D.C.|page=13}}</ref>

When American voters cast ballots in a general presidential election, they are choosing electors. In 48 of the 50 states, state laws mandate the winner of the [[plurality voting|plurality]] of its statewide popular vote shall receive all of that state's electors;<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/about.html|title=What is the Electoral College?|website=National Archives|date=December 23, 2019|access-date=September 27, 2020}}</ref> in [[Maine]] and [[Nebraska]], two electors are assigned in this manner, while the remaining electors are allocated based on the plurality of votes in each of their [[congressional districts]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 6, 2020|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes |url=https://www.archives.gov/electoral-college/allocation|access-date=September 27, 2020|website=National Archives|language=en}}</ref> The federal district, [[Washington, D.C.]], allocates its 3 electoral votes to the winner of its single district election. States generally require electors to pledge to vote for that state's winning ticket; to avoid [[faithless electors]], most states have adopted various laws to enforce the electors’ pledge.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fairvote.org/faithless_elector_state_laws|title=Faithless Elector State Laws|website=Fair Vote|date=July 7, 2020|access-date=July 7, 2020|quote=There are 33 states (plus the District of Columbia) that require electors to vote for a pledged candidate. Most of those states (16 plus DC) nonetheless do not provide for any penalty or any mechanism to prevent the deviant vote from counting as cast.}}</ref> The "national popular vote" is the sum of all the votes cast in the general election, nationwide. The presidential elections of [[1876 United States presidential election|1876]], [[1888 United States presidential election|1888]], [[2000 United States presidential election|2000]], and [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]] produced an Electoral College winner who did not receive the most votes in the general election.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Edwards III|first=George C.|title=Why the Electoral College is Bad for America|publisher=Yale University Press|edition=Second|year=2011|location=New Haven and London|isbn=978-0-300-16649-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/11/9/13572112/trump-popular-vote-loss |title=Trump will be the 4th president to win the Electoral College after getting fewer votes than his opponent |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=November 9, 2016 |first=Alvin |last=Chang |access-date=November 11, 2016 |archive-date=November 10, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110235320/http://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/11/9/13572112/trump-popular-vote-loss |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/key-dates.html|title=2016 Presidential Election|website=National Archives and Records Administration|access-date=November 26, 2016|archive-date=September 20, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920101721/https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/key-dates.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Additionally, in 14 other presidential elections (1844, 1848, 1856, 1860, 1880, 1884, 1892, 1912, 1916, 1948, 1960, 1968, 1992, and 1996), the winner received a plurality but not a majority of the total popular votes cast.

Of the four winners who lost the popular vote, three (Adams, Harrison, and Trump) ran for reelection four years later and lost the popular vote again and lost the election as well, one (Bush) ran and won the election as well as the popular vote, and one (Hayes) did not run for reelection.

In 1824, there were six states in which electors were legislatively appointed rather than popularly elected, meaning the 'national' popular vote in that election does not include all states and so its significance is uncertain. When no candidate received a majority of electoral votes in 1824, the election was decided by the House of Representatives. These circumstances distinguish the 1824 election from the latter four elections, which were all held after all states had instituted the popular selection of electors, and in which a single candidate won an outright majority of electoral votes, thus becoming president without a contingent election in the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB109459688516011727 |title=Electoral College Mischief |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=September 8, 2004 |access-date=January 14, 2021 |archive-date=November 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201130220409/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB109459688516011727 |url-status=live }}</ref> The true national popular vote total was also uncertain in the [[1960 United States presidential election|1960 election]], and the plurality winner depends on how [[1960 United States presidential election in Alabama|votes for Alabama electors]] are allocated.<ref name="trende">{{cite news|title=Did JFK Lose the Popular Vote?|work=RealClearPolitics|date=October 22, 2012|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2012/10/19/did_jfk_lose_the_popular_vote_115833.html|access-date=October 23, 2012}}</ref>

The [[1824 United States presidential election|1824 presidential election]], held on October 26, 1824, was the first election in American history in which the popular vote mattered, as 18 states chose presidential electors by popular vote (six states still left the choice up to their state legislatures). When the final votes were tallied in those 18 states on December 1, [[Andrew Jackson]] polled 152,901 popular votes to [[John Quincy Adams]]'s 114,023; [[Henry Clay]] won 47,217, and [[William H. Crawford]] won 46,979. The electoral college returns, however, gave Jackson only 99 votes, 32 fewer than he needed for a majority of the total votes cast. Adams won 84 electoral votes followed by 41 for Crawford, and 37 for Clay when the Electoral College met on December 1, 1824.<ref name=JQAMC>{{cite web|title=John Quincy Adams: Campaigns and Elections|date=4 October 2016|publisher=Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia|url=http://millercenter.org/president/biography/jqadams-campaigns-and-elections#contributor|access-date=February 22, 2017|archive-date=February 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223125212/http://millercenter.org/president/biography/jqadams-campaigns-and-elections#contributor|url-status=live}}</ref> All four candidates in the election identified with the [[Democratic-Republican Party]].

As no candidate secured the required number of votes (131 total) from the Electoral College, the election was decided by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] under the provisions of the [[Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. As the 12th Amendment states the top three candidates in the electoral vote are candidates in the [[Contingent election#Presidential election of 1824|contingent election]], this meant Henry Clay, who finished fourth, was eliminated. As [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]], however, Clay was still the most important player in determining the outcome of the election.

The contingent election was held on February 9, 1825, with each state having one vote, as determined by the wishes of the majority of each state's congressional representatives. Adams narrowly emerged as the winner, with majorities of the Representatives from 13 out of 24 states voting in his favor. Most of Clay's supporters, joined by several old [[Federalist Party|Federalists]], switched their votes to Adams in enough states to give him the election. Soon after his inauguration as President, Adams appointed Henry Clay as his [[United States Secretary of State|secretary of state]].<ref name=JQAMC/> This result became a source of great bitterness for Jackson and his supporters, who proclaimed the election of Adams a "[[Corrupt bargain#Election of 1824|corrupt bargain]]," and were inspired to create the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].<ref>[http://history1800s.about.com/od/leaders/a/electionof1824.htm "The Election of 1824 Was Decided in the House of Representatives: The Controversial Election was Denounced as 'The Corrupt Bargain'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307212214/http://history1800s.about.com/od/leaders/a/electionof1824.htm |date=2009-03-07 }}, Robert McNamara, About.com</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Stenberg | first1 = R. R. | title = Jackson, Buchanan, and the "Corrupt Bargain" Calumny | journal = The Pennsylvania Magazine of History and Biography | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 61–85 | year = 1934| jstor = 20086857 }}</ref>

title: List of United States senators from Arizona
Tim Moore (North Carolina politician)
added: ===Corruption investigations===

Moore has been the subject of numerous investigations for corruption and misuse of his office for personal gain. In 2015, the FBI opened an inquiry into mysterious unitemized charges on his campaign finance reports.<ref>[https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/article52487800.html FBI to probe top House Republicans after WBTV investigation]</ref> In 2019, Moore's aides improperly intervened with the state Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) to benefit a property Moore owned.<ref>[https://campaignforaccountability.org/watchdog-again-calls-for-investigation-of-house-speaker-tim-moore-for-seeking-preferential-treatment-from-state-agency/ Watchdog Again Calls for Investigation of House Speaker Tim Moore for Seeking Preferential Treatment from State Agency]</ref> Moore and his business partners soon sold that very property to Mountaire Farms, an Arkansas-based poultry conglomerate that is a major donor to North Carolina Republicans, for a 650% profit.<ref>[https://medium.com/@longleafpineslate/chickens-in-raleigh-e365d9900272 Chickens in Raleigh]</ref>

Lang & Jon Swaine (Jan. 16, 2021), [https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2021/01/16/sullivan-video-arrested/ "Man who shot video of fatal Capitol shooting is arrested, remains focus of political storm"], ''The Washington Post'' </ref> The article included links to videos made by Sullivan under his ''[[nom de guerre]]'' "Jayden X"<ref>Matthew B. Foulger (Jan. 13, 2021), [https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.dcd.227101/gov.uscourts.dcd.227101.1.1.pdf "AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF CRIMINAL COMPLAINT AND ARREST WARRANT"] for [[John Earle Sullivan]] (including screenshots from Sullivan’s "Jayden X" video channels), District Court, District of Columbia Case 1:21-mj-00050-RMM Document 1-1 </ref> and stated: "Sullivan sold The Washington Post rights to use a portion of his video for a story on the shooting [of [[Ashli Babbitt]]]."  The article didn't reveal the amount of the Post's payment — court documents have revealed that similar agreements with media outlets paid Sullivan $35,000 by [[CNN]], $35,000 by [[NBCUniversal|NBC]], $5,000 by [[ProSiebenSat.1 Media SE#Red Arrow Studios|Left/Right, LLC]], and $2,375 by [[ABC Television (Australian TV network)|ABC]].<ref>(Feb. 16, 2021), [https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/59147023/14/united-states-v-sullivan/ "United States v. title: 1920 United States presidential election in Tennessee
First inauguration of Donald Trump
added: == Public's Response ==

Amongst the bigger demographics that showed disapproval towards Trump and the event were women who protested multiple of Trump's policies in international [[2017 Women's March|women's march]] he following day after the inauguration, on January 21, 2017. According to Heidi M. Przybyla, from [[USA Today]] the consensus, amongst the women that attended the protest, was that the incoming administration's policies would pay little attention to gender-equality issues in part due to Trump's cabinet being 90% male and 90% white. <ref>{{Cite news|last=Przybyla|first=Heidi|date=January 20 2017|title=Women march in man's world|work=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/19/womens-march-on-washington-survey-trump-clinton/96731542/|access-date=October 2 2021}}</ref> Amongst other things the protesters wanted further action from the government concerning women's rights such as equal pay and paid family leave.

===Debates===

A debate between the five candidates took place on April 6, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.progress-index.com/story/news/2021/04/05/virginia-state-university-chosen-host-upcoming-gubernatorial-democratic-debate/7092418002/|title=Virginia State University chosen to host upcoming gubernatorial Democratic debate|date=2021-04-05|access-date=2021-04-22}}</ref> Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax compared scrutiny of his sexual assault allegations to that of the cases of [[George Floyd]] and [[Emmett Till]] in the debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-democratic-governors-debate/2021/04/06/09221eac-96e0-11eb-962b-78c1d8228819_story.html|title=Justin Fairfax criticized for comparison to George Floyd, Emmett Till at debate|date=2021-04-07|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Schneider|first=Gregory}}</ref>

==Republican convention==

The Republican nomination process for the 2021 elections was the subject of a lengthy and acrimonious debate within the [[Republican Party of Virginia]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-governor-vote-counting/2021/04/21/fbb6760c-a2d6-11eb-a774-7b47ceb36ee8_story.html Three Republicans running for Virginia governor wary of vote-counting software], ''Washington Post'' (April 21, 2021).</ref><ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn>{{Cite web|title=Virginia GOP settles on nominating method with May convention looming|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/virginia-gop-settles-on-nominating-method-with-may-convention-looming/|date=April 22, 2021|author=Dean Mirshahi|publisher=WRIC}}</ref> On December 5, 2020, the state Republican Party voted to hold a convention instead of a primary by a vote of 41 to 28.<ref>{{Cite web|title=RPV State Central Committee Meeting;Voted Convention for 2021;Live Updates – Bearing Drift|url=https://bearingdrift.com/2020/12/05/rpv-state-central-committee-meeting-voted-convention-for-2021/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=bearingdrift.com|date=December 5, 2020}}</ref> State Senator [[Amanda Chase]] initially indicated that she would run as an independent,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last1=Oliver|first1=Ned|date=2020-12-05|title=Chase promises to run as independent for governor after Va. GOP opts for convention over primary|url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2020/12/05/chase-threatens-to-run-as-independent-for-governor-as-va-gop-opts-for-convention-over-primary/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=Virginia Mercury|language=en-US}}</ref> but later decided to seek nomination at the convention. (However, on the day of the convention, she acknowledged that if she did not win the nomination, she may reconsider and run as an independent, although she eventually decided against this.)<ref>{{cite tweet |last=Chase |first=Amanda |author-link=Amanda Chase |user=AmandaChaseVA |number=1391150084377677826 |date=May 8, 2021 |title=If RPV steals this election for Pete I still have plenty of time to run as an independent. Clear corruption by RPV, I will not honor a pledge if the Party cannot run a fair process. |language=en |access-date=June 12, 2021 |archive-url= |archive-date=June 12, 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref> Faced with pressure from the Chase campaign and activists to return to a primary, the state committee debated scrapping the convention on January 23, 2021. These efforts were unsuccessful and the party reaffirmed their decision to hold a convention.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Oliver |first1=Ned |title=Virginia Republicans stick with nominating convention |url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2021/01/24/virginia-republicans-stick-with-convention-as-messy-fight-continues/ |access-date=January 25, 2021 |work=Virginia Mercury |date=January 24, 2021}}</ref> On February 9, 2021, the Chase campaign sued the Republican Party of Virginia, arguing that the convention is illegal under [[COVID-19]]-related executive orders signed by Governor [[Ralph Northam]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manchester|first1=Julia|date=February 9, 2021|title=Republican gubernatorial candidate sues Virginia GOP over nominating process|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/538075-republican-state-senator-sues-virginia-gop-over-nominating-process|url-status=live|access-date=February 9, 2021|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref> The Richmond Circuit Court dismissed the Chase campaign's lawsuit on February 19, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manzanares|first1=Keyris|date=February 19, 2021|title=Judge blocks Sen. Amanda Chase's lawsuit challenging Virginia GOP nomination plans|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/judge-blocks-sen-amanda-chases-lawsuit-challenging-virginia-gop-nomination-plansw|url-status=live|access-date=February 19, 2021|website=[[WRIC-TV|WRIC]]}}</ref> The Republican Party of Virginia announced on March 26, 2021, that seven gubernatorial candidates had qualified to appear on the convention ballot.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|date=2021-03-26|title=RPV Announces Qualified Convention Candidates|url=https://virginia.gop/rpv-announces-qualified-convention-candidates/|access-date=2021-03-26|website=Republican Party of Virginia|language=en-US}}</ref> On April 11, 2021, the state Republican Party Rules Committee voted to tabulate the ballots by hand; three days later, however, the committee reversed itself and decided to use a vendor's software-based tabulation method.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

On April 20, 2021, five candidates (Amanda Chase, Kirk Cox, Sergio de la Peña, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin) participated in a forum at [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]].<ref name=wric.nom>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/5-republicans-in-virginia-governors-race-make-their-pitch-to-voters-during-liberty-university-forum/|title=Key takeaways from the Republican gubernatorial forum in Lynchburg|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Mirshahi|first=Dean}}</ref> Two candidates, Octavia Johnson and Pete Snyder, did not attend the forum.<ref name=wric.nom/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/republicans-running-for-virginia-governor-appear-at-liberty-university-forum/2021/04/20/b94d408e-a1eb-11eb-a7ee-949c574a09ac_story.html|title=Republicans running for Virginia governor appear at Liberty University forum|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Vozzella|first=Laura}}</ref>

The state Republican convention to select the party's nominees for governor, lieutenant governor, and attorney general took place on May 8, 2021,<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/><ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> in "unassembled" format,<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> with ballots to be cast remotely at up to 37 locations statewide<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/> using [[instant-runoff voting|ranked-choice voting]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> The complex process fueled internal party disputes.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-convention/2021/04/04/4bfe8fc4-9228-11eb-a74e-1f4cf89fd948_story.html Unorthodox Republican contest for Virginia governor breeds confusion, suspicion], ''Washington Post'' (April 4, 2021).</ref> Up to 40,000 people were anticipated to become delegates, although not all would necessarily cast votes.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> Local Republican Party leaders control the application process to become a delegate, decide who can participate (voter registration in Virginia does not include a space to indicate party affiliation), and select the convention voting site.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox/> In the preceding Virginia Republican gubernatorial convention, 12,000 participated.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

[[Orthodox Jewish]] Virginia Republicans asked the party to allow absentee voting for religious reasons (May 8 is on the [[Jewish Sabbath]]), but the State Central Committee initially voted down the request, failing to achieve the 75% supermajority needed to change the rules.<ref>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-republican-convention-orthodox-jews/2021/04/23/3169c904-a442-11eb-85fc-06664ff4489d_story.html Virginia GOP won't let Orthodox Jews vote absentee in Sabbath-day convention], ''Washington Post'' (April 23, 2021).</ref> However, the Virginia GOP ultimately reversed course and allowed those with religious objections to vote in the May 8 convention via absentee ballots. Republican candidates Kirk Cox, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin had criticized the previous decision to not accommodate Orthodox Jews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/in-reversal-virginia-gop-will-allow-those-with-religious-obligations-to-vote-absentee-in-may-8-convention/|title=In reversal, Virginia GOP will allow those with religious obligations to vote absentee in May 8 convention|date=April 26, 2021}}</ref>

==General election==

On August 26, the Republican Party of Virginia filed a lawsuit to disqualify McAuliffe from appearing on the ballot in November. The suit alleges that McAuliffe did not sign his declaration of candidacy, which is needed to qualify in the primary and general election.<ref name=vgop.lawsuit>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/virginia-republican-party-terry-mcauliffe-lawsuit-governor-ballot-signature-2021-8|title=Virginia GOP files lawsuit to remove Democratic gubernatorial nominee Terry McAuliffe from the November ballot|date=2021-08-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> It was found that the declaration of candidacy was missing his signature, although it includes two witnesses' signatures. The suit also alleges the witnesses violated state law by witnessing a signing that didn't occur.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/virginia-election-2020-b0775646f6ca89d5f83106c86de59506|title=Virginia Republicans file suit over McAuliffe's paperwork|date=2021-08-26|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>
=== Debates ===
==== Cancelled debates ====

On July 12, Glenn Youngkin announced he would not take part in the July 24 debate hosted by the [[Virginia Bar Association]] because of a donation made by  one of the moderators, Judy Woodruff.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/government-and-politics-election-2020-522265ba9fd99fc0e96ce67c68c52cec|title=Youngkin declines debate in part over moderator Woodruff|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref><ref name=wsls.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsls.com/news/politics/2021/07/12/glenn-youngkin-not-participating-in-gubernatorial-debate-in-hot-springs-agrees-to-three-others/|title=Glenn Youngkin not participating in gubernatorial debate in Hot Springs, agrees to three others|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> Woodruff had made a $250 donation to the [[Clinton Foundation]] relief fund after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]. The foundation is run by [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] and [[Bill Clinton]], who are close allies to Terry McAuliffe.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1/> On July 28, after discovering that Youngkin would participate in an 'election integrity' rally at [[Liberty University]], McAuliffe declined a debate at the same university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.virginiascope.com/mcauliffes-campaign-says-he-is-declining-the-liberty-debate-due-to-youngkins-participation-in-election-integrity-rally/|title=McAuliffe's campaign says he is declining the Liberty/Hampton debate due to Youngkin's participation in election integrity rally|date=2021-07-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> On August 2, Youngkin declined participation in The People's Debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wtop.com/virginia/2021/08/youngkin-declines-va-gubernatorial-the-peoples-debate-event-canceled/|title=Youngkin declines Va. gubernatorial 'The People's Debate,' event canceled|date=2021-08-02|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> The two candidates pledged to two debates; one on September 16 and one on September 28.<ref name=nbcdebate.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/virginia-governor-candidates-mcauliffe-youngkin-face-first-debate-n1279327|title=Virginia governor candidates McAuliffe, Youngkin to face off in first debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>
==== First debate ====

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at [[Appalachian School of Law]] in [[Grundy, Virginia]] on September 16, 2021, one day before early voting began.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/local/mcauliffe-vs-youngkin-heres-what-you-missed-thursday-nights-debate-glenn-terry-virginia-governor|title=McAuliffe vs. Youngkin: Here's what you missed from Thursday night's debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref> The debate was hosted by [[USA Today]] Washington Bureau Chief, [[Susan Page]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/beyond-the-podium/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-face-off-thursday-september-16-2021-grundy-southwest-virginia-gubernatorial-debate|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin face-off tonight in first Virginia gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>

The debate started with discussion over a recent [[COVID-19 vaccination#Vaccine mandates|COVID-19 mandate]] President [[Joe Biden]] signed requiring federal workers, employees of large companies, and contractors to be vaccinated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/live-updates/biden-covid-19-vaccine-mandates-announcement/|title=Biden announces COVID-19 vaccine mandates that will affect 100 million Americans|date=2021-09-10|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref><ref name=cbs.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate-virginia-gubernatorial-race/|title=Vaccine mandates and abortion bans fuel Virginia's first gubernatorial race debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17|last=Navarro|first=Aaron}}</ref> Youngkin doubted if Biden had the power to authorize the mandate, and supported personal choice for receiving the vaccine. McAuliffe supported the mandate and accused Youngkin of spreading [[COVID-19 misinformation|"anti-vax" rhetoric]].<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Youngkin denied the claim.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> McAuliffe also supported requiring vaccines for students over the age of 12.<ref name=cnn.debate2>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/16/politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-virginia-governor-debate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin spar over Covid vaccine requirements in first Virginia debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-23|last1=Warren|first1=Michael|last2=Merica|first2=Dan}}</ref>

The discussion moved to [[climate change]], where Youngkin stated he would use all sources of energy to address climate change without "putting [the] entire energy grid at risk for political purposes." McAuliffe called for [[clean energy]] in the state by 2035 and stressed the idea for the state to be a production hub.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/>

The discussion then moved to abortion, specifically the recent [[Texas Heartbeat Act]] signed by Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]] (whom endorsed Youngkin).<ref name=abc.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-spar-vision-commonwealth-1st-va-gubernatorial/story?id=80057575|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin spar over vision for commonwealth in 1st Va. gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref> When asked whether or not Youngkin would sign a similar bill, Youngkin stated that he would not sign the bill, and that he was pro-life and supports exclusions in cases such as rape, incest, and when the life of the mother is endangered and also supports a "pain-threshold" bill that would ban most abortions at the point when a fetus can feel pain, which proponents of this type of law define as 20 weeks.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> In addition, Youngkin stated McAuliffe was "the most extreme pro-abortion candidate in America today".<ref name=abc.debate1/> In response to Youngkin, McAuliffe stated he was a "brick wall" to women's rights and would protect a woman's decision over abortion and supports reducing the number of doctors needed to certify a third-trimester abortion from three to one.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The next discussion topic was over election integrity. After supporting an "Election Integrity Taskforce", Youngkin stated he does not believe there has been "significant fraud", and stated the issue of fraud as "a democracy issue". Youngkin stressed that he believes that "Joe Biden's our president" and criticized the [[Withdrawal of the United States troops from Afghanistan (2020–2021)|withdrawal from Afghanistan]]. McAuliffe took note to Donald Trump's endorsement of Youngkin, calling him a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Both candidates stated they would concede the election if the other came out on top.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The final discussion topic was over the economy. McAuliffe attacked Youngkin on his top economic advisor, [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Stephen Moore]], who advised [[Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign]]. Youngkin defended Virginia's [[right-to-work law]].<ref name=abc.debate1/>
==== Second debate ====

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at the [[Northern Virginia Chamber of Commerce]] on September 28, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.cvent.com/event/5e9837a7-3094-4e39-9659-df9d79321875/summary|access-date=2021-09-23|title=Top of the Ticket 2021 Gubernatorial Debate}}</ref> The event was hosted by [[Chuck Todd]], moderator of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Meet the Press]]''. Less than a week before the debate, one of the panelists, [[Michael Fauntroy]], withdrew from the debate after tweets against the [[GOP]] and [[Evangelicalism|Evangelicals]] were found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/mcauliffe-youngkin-debate-michael-fauntroy|title=Panelist withdraws from upcoming McAuliffe-Youngkin debate after tweets attacking GOP, evangelicals surface|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-09-23|last=Wulfsohn|first=Joseph}}</ref>

On the discussion topic of COVID-19, Youngkin and McAuliffe reiterated their stances on the vaccines. Youngkin stated he believed in mandates for vaccines for diseases [[measles]], [[mumps]] and [[rubella]], but not for COVID-19, saying the "the data associated with those vaccines is something that we should absolutely understand the difference between this vaccine."<ref name=cnn.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/28/politics/virginia-governor-debate-covid-vaccine-mandate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin battle over Covid-19 vaccine mandates in Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> Youngkin said people should get vaccinated against COVID-19.<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/>

During the debate, Youngkin noted that Trump was regularly mentioned by McAuliffe, who again called Youngkin a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/><ref name=nbc4.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/politics/first-read-dmv/debate-takeaways-virginia-candidates-on-attack-from-start/2815808/|title=Virginia Gubernatorial Candidates on Attack From Start in Debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> When asked, Youngkin stated he would support Trump if he were to become the Republican nominee in [[2024 United States presidential election|2024]].<ref name=nbc4.debate2.1/>

Approximately 15 minutes into the debate, [[Third party (United States)|third party]] candidate Princess Blanding, who was in the audience, disrupted the debate, yelling that her exclusion from the debate was “unfair” and claiming that McAuliffe would not win the election.<ref name=fox.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/nbc-chuck-todd-princess-blanding-terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate|title=NBC's Chuck Todd calls for security as third-party Virginia candidate disrupts McAuliffe-Youngkin debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> After being escorted out by security, she claimed that being excluded from the debate was racist and sexist, and that it constituted "censorship".<ref name=hill.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/574407-vaccines-abortion-trump-dominate-final-virginia-governors-debate|title=Vaccines, abortion, Trump dominate final Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref>

A debate between the five candidates took place on April 6, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.progress-index.com/story/news/2021/04/05/virginia-state-university-chosen-host-upcoming-gubernatorial-democratic-debate/7092418002/|title=Virginia State University chosen to host upcoming gubernatorial Democratic debate|date=2021-04-05|access-date=2021-04-22}}</ref> Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax compared scrutiny of his sexual assault allegations to that of the cases of [[George Floyd]] and [[Emmett Till]] in the debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-democratic-governors-debate/2021/04/06/09221eac-96e0-11eb-962b-78c1d8228819_story.html|title=Justin Fairfax criticized for comparison to George Floyd, Emmett Till at debate|date=2021-04-07|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Schneider|first=Gregory}}</ref>

The Republican nomination process for the 2021 elections was the subject of a lengthy and acrimonious debate within the [[Republican Party of Virginia]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-governor-vote-counting/2021/04/21/fbb6760c-a2d6-11eb-a774-7b47ceb36ee8_story.html Three Republicans running for Virginia governor wary of vote-counting software], ''Washington Post'' (April 21, 2021).</ref><ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn>{{Cite web|title=Virginia GOP settles on nominating method with May convention looming|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/virginia-gop-settles-on-nominating-method-with-may-convention-looming/|date=April 22, 2021|author=Dean Mirshahi|publisher=WRIC}}</ref> On December 5, 2020, the state Republican Party voted to hold a convention instead of a primary by a vote of 41 to 28.<ref>{{Cite web|title=RPV State Central Committee Meeting;Voted Convention for 2021;Live Updates – Bearing Drift|url=https://bearingdrift.com/2020/12/05/rpv-state-central-committee-meeting-voted-convention-for-2021/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=bearingdrift.com|date=December 5, 2020}}</ref> State Senator [[Amanda Chase]] initially indicated that she would run as an independent,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last1=Oliver|first1=Ned|date=2020-12-05|title=Chase promises to run as independent for governor after Va. GOP opts for convention over primary|url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2020/12/05/chase-threatens-to-run-as-independent-for-governor-as-va-gop-opts-for-convention-over-primary/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=Virginia Mercury|language=en-US}}</ref> but later decided to seek nomination at the convention. (However, on the day of the convention, she acknowledged that if she did not win the nomination, she may reconsider and run as an independent, although she eventually decided against this.)<ref>{{cite tweet |last=Chase |first=Amanda |author-link=Amanda Chase |user=AmandaChaseVA |number=1391150084377677826 |date=May 8, 2021 |title=If RPV steals this election for Pete I still have plenty of time to run as an independent. Clear corruption by RPV, I will not honor a pledge if the Party cannot run a fair process. |language=en |access-date=June 12, 2021 |archive-url= |archive-date=June 12, 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref> Faced with pressure from the Chase campaign and activists to return to a primary, the state committee debated scrapping the convention on January 23, 2021. These efforts were unsuccessful and the party reaffirmed their decision to hold a convention.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Oliver |first1=Ned |title=Virginia Republicans stick with nominating convention |url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2021/01/24/virginia-republicans-stick-with-convention-as-messy-fight-continues/ |access-date=January 25, 2021 |work=Virginia Mercury |date=January 24, 2021}}</ref> On February 9, 2021, the Chase campaign sued the Republican Party of Virginia, arguing that the convention is illegal under [[COVID-19]]-related executive orders signed by Governor [[Ralph Northam]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manchester|first1=Julia|date=February 9, 2021|title=Republican gubernatorial candidate sues Virginia GOP over nominating process|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/538075-republican-state-senator-sues-virginia-gop-over-nominating-process|url-status=live|access-date=February 9, 2021|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref> The Richmond Circuit Court dismissed the Chase campaign's lawsuit on February 19, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manzanares|first1=Keyris|date=February 19, 2021|title=Judge blocks Sen. Amanda Chase's lawsuit challenging Virginia GOP nomination plans|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/judge-blocks-sen-amanda-chases-lawsuit-challenging-virginia-gop-nomination-plansw|url-status=live|access-date=February 19, 2021|website=[[WRIC-TV|WRIC]]}}</ref> The Republican Party of Virginia announced on March 26, 2021, that seven gubernatorial candidates had qualified to appear on the convention ballot.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|date=2021-03-26|title=RPV Announces Qualified Convention Candidates|url=https://virginia.gop/rpv-announces-qualified-convention-candidates/|access-date=2021-03-26|website=Republican Party of Virginia|language=en-US}}</ref> On April 11, 2021, the state Republican Party Rules Committee voted to tabulate the ballots by hand; three days later, however, the committee reversed itself and decided to use a vendor's software-based tabulation method.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

On April 20, 2021, five candidates (Amanda Chase, Kirk Cox, Sergio de la Peña, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin) participated in a forum at [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]].<ref name=wric.nom>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/5-republicans-in-virginia-governors-race-make-their-pitch-to-voters-during-liberty-university-forum/|title=Key takeaways from the Republican gubernatorial forum in Lynchburg|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Mirshahi|first=Dean}}</ref> Two candidates, Octavia Johnson and Pete Snyder, did not attend the forum.<ref name=wric.nom/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/republicans-running-for-virginia-governor-appear-at-liberty-university-forum/2021/04/20/b94d408e-a1eb-11eb-a7ee-949c574a09ac_story.html|title=Republicans running for Virginia governor appear at Liberty University forum|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Vozzella|first=Laura}}</ref>

The state Republican convention to select the party's nominees for governor, lieutenant governor, and attorney general took place on May 8, 2021,<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/><ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> in "unassembled" format,<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> with ballots to be cast remotely at up to 37 locations statewide<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/> using [[instant-runoff voting|ranked-choice voting]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> The complex process fueled internal party disputes.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-convention/2021/04/04/4bfe8fc4-9228-11eb-a74e-1f4cf89fd948_story.html Unorthodox Republican contest for Virginia governor breeds confusion, suspicion], ''Washington Post'' (April 4, 2021).</ref> Up to 40,000 people were anticipated to become delegates, although not all would necessarily cast votes.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> Local Republican Party leaders control the application process to become a delegate, decide who can participate (voter registration in Virginia does not include a space to indicate party affiliation), and select the convention voting site.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox/> In the preceding Virginia Republican gubernatorial convention, 12,000 participated.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

[[Orthodox Jewish]] Virginia Republicans asked the party to allow absentee voting for religious reasons (May 8 is on the [[Jewish Sabbath]]), but the State Central Committee initially voted down the request, failing to achieve the 75% supermajority needed to change the rules.<ref>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-republican-convention-orthodox-jews/2021/04/23/3169c904-a442-11eb-85fc-06664ff4489d_story.html Virginia GOP won't let Orthodox Jews vote absentee in Sabbath-day convention], ''Washington Post'' (April 23, 2021).</ref> However, the Virginia GOP ultimately reversed course and allowed those with religious objections to vote in the May 8 convention via absentee ballots. Republican candidates Kirk Cox, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin had criticized the previous decision to not accommodate Orthodox Jews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/in-reversal-virginia-gop-will-allow-those-with-religious-obligations-to-vote-absentee-in-may-8-convention/|title=In reversal, Virginia GOP will allow those with religious obligations to vote absentee in May 8 convention|date=April 26, 2021}}</ref>

Denver Riggleman is still thinking about independent run for governor|url=https://richmond.com/news/state-and-regional/govt-and-politics/former-rep-denver-riggleman-is-still-thinking-about-running-for-governor/article_e7880172-d06f-5f3c-a46c-097d000496ad.html|url-status=live|access-date=April 12, 2021|website=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|language=en}}</ref><ref name="BallotAccess"/>

On August 26, the Republican Party of Virginia filed a lawsuit to disqualify McAuliffe from appearing on the ballot in November. The suit alleges that McAuliffe did not sign his declaration of candidacy, which is needed to qualify in the primary and general election.<ref name=vgop.lawsuit>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/virginia-republican-party-terry-mcauliffe-lawsuit-governor-ballot-signature-2021-8|title=Virginia GOP files lawsuit to remove Democratic gubernatorial nominee Terry McAuliffe from the November ballot|date=2021-08-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> It was found that the declaration of candidacy was missing his signature, although it includes two witnesses' signatures. The suit also alleges the witnesses violated state law by witnessing a signing that didn't occur.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/virginia-election-2020-b0775646f6ca89d5f83106c86de59506|title=Virginia Republicans file suit over McAuliffe's paperwork|date=2021-08-26|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>

On July 12, Glenn Youngkin announced he would not take part in the July 24 debate hosted by the [[Virginia Bar Association]] because of a donation made by  one of the moderators, Judy Woodruff.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/government-and-politics-election-2020-522265ba9fd99fc0e96ce67c68c52cec|title=Youngkin declines debate in part over moderator Woodruff|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref><ref name=wsls.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsls.com/news/politics/2021/07/12/glenn-youngkin-not-participating-in-gubernatorial-debate-in-hot-springs-agrees-to-three-others/|title=Glenn Youngkin not participating in gubernatorial debate in Hot Springs, agrees to three others|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> Woodruff had made a $250 donation to the [[Clinton Foundation]] relief fund after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]. The foundation is run by [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] and [[Bill Clinton]], who are close allies to Terry McAuliffe.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1/> On July 28, after discovering that Youngkin would participate in an 'election integrity' rally at [[Liberty University]], McAuliffe declined a debate at the same university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.virginiascope.com/mcauliffes-campaign-says-he-is-declining-the-liberty-debate-due-to-youngkins-participation-in-election-integrity-rally/|title=McAuliffe's campaign says he is declining the Liberty/Hampton debate due to Youngkin's participation in election integrity rally|date=2021-07-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> On August 2, Youngkin declined participation in The People's Debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wtop.com/virginia/2021/08/youngkin-declines-va-gubernatorial-the-peoples-debate-event-canceled/|title=Youngkin declines Va. gubernatorial 'The People's Debate,' event canceled|date=2021-08-02|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> The two candidates pledged to two debates; one on September 16 and one on September 28.<ref name=nbcdebate.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/virginia-governor-candidates-mcauliffe-youngkin-face-first-debate-n1279327|title=Virginia governor candidates McAuliffe, Youngkin to face off in first debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at [[Appalachian School of Law]] in [[Grundy, Virginia]] on September 16, 2021, one day before early voting began.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/local/mcauliffe-vs-youngkin-heres-what-you-missed-thursday-nights-debate-glenn-terry-virginia-governor|title=McAuliffe vs. Youngkin: Here's what you missed from Thursday night's debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref> The debate was hosted by [[USA Today]] Washington Bureau Chief, [[Susan Page]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/beyond-the-podium/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-face-off-thursday-september-16-2021-grundy-southwest-virginia-gubernatorial-debate|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin face-off tonight in first Virginia gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>

The debate started with discussion over a recent [[COVID-19 vaccination#Vaccine mandates|COVID-19 mandate]] President [[Joe Biden]] signed requiring federal workers, employees of large companies, and contractors to be vaccinated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/live-updates/biden-covid-19-vaccine-mandates-announcement/|title=Biden announces COVID-19 vaccine mandates that will affect 100 million Americans|date=2021-09-10|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref><ref name=cbs.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate-virginia-gubernatorial-race/|title=Vaccine mandates and abortion bans fuel Virginia's first gubernatorial race debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17|last=Navarro|first=Aaron}}</ref> Youngkin doubted if Biden had the power to authorize the mandate, and supported personal choice for receiving the vaccine. McAuliffe supported the mandate and accused Youngkin of spreading [[COVID-19 misinformation|"anti-vax" rhetoric]].<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Youngkin denied the claim.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> McAuliffe also supported requiring vaccines for students over the age of 12.<ref name=cnn.debate2>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/16/politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-virginia-governor-debate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin spar over Covid vaccine requirements in first Virginia debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-23|last1=Warren|first1=Michael|last2=Merica|first2=Dan}}</ref>

The discussion moved to [[climate change]], where Youngkin stated he would use all sources of energy to address climate change without "putting [the] entire energy grid at risk for political purposes." McAuliffe called for [[clean energy]] in the state by 2035 and stressed the idea for the state to be a production hub.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/>

The discussion then moved to abortion, specifically the recent [[Texas Heartbeat Act]] signed by Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]] (whom endorsed Youngkin).<ref name=abc.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-spar-vision-commonwealth-1st-va-gubernatorial/story?id=80057575|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin spar over vision for commonwealth in 1st Va. gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref> When asked whether or not Youngkin would sign a similar bill, Youngkin stated that he would not sign the bill, and that he was pro-life and supports exclusions in cases such as rape, incest, and when the life of the mother is endangered and also supports a "pain-threshold" bill that would ban most abortions at the point when a fetus can feel pain, which proponents of this type of law define as 20 weeks.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> In addition, Youngkin stated McAuliffe was "the most extreme pro-abortion candidate in America today".<ref name=abc.debate1/> In response to Youngkin, McAuliffe stated he was a "brick wall" to women's rights and would protect a woman's decision over abortion and supports reducing the number of doctors needed to certify a third-trimester abortion from three to one.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The next discussion topic was over election integrity. After supporting an "Election Integrity Taskforce", Youngkin stated he does not believe there has been "significant fraud", and stated the issue of fraud as "a democracy issue". Youngkin stressed that he believes that "Joe Biden's our president" and criticized the [[Withdrawal of the United States troops from Afghanistan (2020–2021)|withdrawal from Afghanistan]]. McAuliffe took note to Donald Trump's endorsement of Youngkin, calling him a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Both candidates stated they would concede the election if the other came out on top.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The final discussion topic was over the economy. McAuliffe attacked Youngkin on his top economic advisor, [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Stephen Moore]], who advised [[Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign]]. Youngkin defended Virginia's [[right-to-work law]].<ref name=abc.debate1/>

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at the [[Northern Virginia Chamber of Commerce]] on September 28, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.cvent.com/event/5e9837a7-3094-4e39-9659-df9d79321875/summary|access-date=2021-09-23|title=Top of the Ticket 2021 Gubernatorial Debate}}</ref> The event was hosted by [[Chuck Todd]], moderator of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Meet the Press]]''. Less than a week before the debate, one of the panelists, [[Michael Fauntroy]], withdrew from the debate after tweets against the [[GOP]] and [[Evangelicalism|Evangelicals]] were found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/mcauliffe-youngkin-debate-michael-fauntroy|title=Panelist withdraws from upcoming McAuliffe-Youngkin debate after tweets attacking GOP, evangelicals surface|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-09-23|last=Wulfsohn|first=Joseph}}</ref>

On the discussion topic of COVID-19, Youngkin and McAuliffe reiterated their stances on the vaccines. Youngkin stated he believed in mandates for vaccines for diseases [[measles]], [[mumps]] and [[rubella]], but not for COVID-19, saying the "the data associated with those vaccines is something that we should absolutely understand the difference between this vaccine."<ref name=cnn.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/28/politics/virginia-governor-debate-covid-vaccine-mandate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin battle over Covid-19 vaccine mandates in Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> Youngkin said people should get vaccinated against COVID-19.<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/>

During the debate, Youngkin noted that Trump was regularly mentioned by McAuliffe, who again called Youngkin a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/><ref name=nbc4.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/politics/first-read-dmv/debate-takeaways-virginia-candidates-on-attack-from-start/2815808/|title=Virginia Gubernatorial Candidates on Attack From Start in Debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> When asked, Youngkin stated he would support Trump if he were to become the Republican nominee in [[2024 United States presidential election|2024]].<ref name=nbc4.debate2.1/>

Approximately 15 minutes into the debate, [[Third party (United States)|third party]] candidate Princess Blanding, who was in the audience, disrupted the debate, yelling that her exclusion from the debate was “unfair” and claiming that McAuliffe would not win the election.<ref name=fox.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/nbc-chuck-todd-princess-blanding-terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate|title=NBC's Chuck Todd calls for security as third-party Virginia candidate disrupts McAuliffe-Youngkin debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> After being escorted out by security, she claimed that being excluded from the debate was racist and sexist, and that it constituted "censorship".<ref name=hill.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/574407-vaccines-abortion-trump-dominate-final-virginia-governors-debate|title=Vaccines, abortion, Trump dominate final Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref>

title: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev
added: On 15 March 2020, due to the spread of the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Kazakhstan]], Tokayev signed a decree on the introduction of a state of emergency in the country. The state of emergency remained in effect from 16 March to 15 April. On 16 March 2020, during his televised address to the people of Kazakhstan, Tokayev stressed that he had signed a special decree on measures to ensure the stability of the state functioning. These documents enable us to increase the efficiency of state bodies, strengthen the vertical of power and make all necessary decisions promptly in a manual mode. In an attempt to stop the spread of the virus, Tokayev ordered the cancellations of both the [[Nowruz]] celebrations as well as the [[Victory Day (9 May)|Victory Day]] [[military parade]] in honour of the 75th anniversary of the end of [[World War II]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kazakh President Qasym-Jomart Toqayev Cancels May 9 Parade Amid Concerns Over COVID-19 - Spokesman|url=https://www.urdupoint.com/en/amp/world/kazakh-president-qasym-jomart-toqayev-cancels-862235.html|access-date=2020-03-17|website=UrduPoint|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Kazakhstan Cancels Norouz, Military Celebrations To Ward Off Coronavirus|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/kazakhstan-cancels-norouz-military-celebrations-to-ward-off-coronavirus/30483422.html|access-date=2020-03-17|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=В Казахстане из-за коронавируса отменили парад к 75-летию Победы - РИА Новости, 12.03.2020|url=https://ria.ru/amp/20200312/1568475464.html|access-date=2020-03-17|website=ria.ru}}</ref>
==== Bek Air Flight 2100 ====

After the [[Bek Air Flight 2100]] crash, Tokayev declared the following day, 28 December, a [[national day of mourning]] and said that "all those responsible will be severely punished in accordance with the law."<ref>{{Cite web|date=27 December 2019|title=President Tokayev declares December 28 a national day of mourning|url=https://www.inform.kz/en/article/3598991|website=www.inform.kz}}</ref> He also ordered the suspension of the flight authorisation of [[Bek Air]], the domestic airline involved.<ref>{{Cite web|date=27 December 2019|title=Bek Air grounded after fatal Fokker 100 accident at Almaty|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/bek-air-grounded-after-fatal-fokker-100-accident-at-almaty/135945.article|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191227111451/https://www.flightglobal.com/news/bek-air-grounded-after-fatal-fokker-100-accident-at-almaty/135945.article|archive-date=27 December 2019|access-date=27 December 2019|website=[[FlightGlobal]]}}</ref>
==== Release of Mukhtar Dzhakishev ====

On 29 February 2020, in an interview to Informburo news agency, Tokayev commented on the fate of [[Mukhtar Dzhakishev]]: "This issue is exclusively within the competence of the court. Of course, I am aware that Dzhakishev has repeatedly applied for parole on ill-health. The session of the court of first instance will be held on 3 March. Let’s wait for its decision, which I am sure will be fair." On 3 March 2020, the  Semey City Court upheld the motion to grant parole to Dzhakishev. He served a 14-year prison sentence since 2009.

title: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev
added: On 4 October 2021, Tokayev signed a bill, which aimed at protecting the ecosystem of the [[Caspian Sea]] by establishing a regular assessment for the state of marine environment and coastal areas of the sea, and an assessment to the level of sea pollution along the coastline.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-10-04|title=Токаев утвердил законопроект для защиты экосистемы Каспийского моря|url=https://informburo.kz/novosti/tokaev-utverdil-zakonoproekt-dlya-zashity-ekosistemy-kaspijskogo-morya|access-date=2021-10-05|website=informburo.kz|language=ru}}</ref>

title: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev
added: Following the breakout of the [[2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war]], Tokayev called on [[Armenia]] to withdraw from the disputed territory, citing the [[United Nations Security Council]] accordance to which he claimed that the Armenian government failed to fulfill for its past 30 years.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-10-09|title=Kazakhstan’s President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev said Armenia should withdraw from Nagorno-Karabakh|url=https://turkeygazette.com/kazakhstans-president-kassym-jomart-tokayev-said-armenia-should-withdraw-from-nagorno-karabakh/|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-18|website=turkeygazette.com}}</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
added: ==== Bahamas ====

After [[Hurricane Dorian]] hit the nearby nation of [[The Bahamas]], he would say to reporters that it was not the Florida government's responsibility to assist the  recovery of the country as it was more in the hands of the federal government. Although he would encourage donations to those who were affected by the hurricane through the Volunteer Florida website and did encourage Floridians to not cancel vacations to islands in the country that were less affected. On September 6, 2019 he would take an aerial tour of The Bahamas with the state's two US Senators: Marco Rubio and Rick Scott. After the tour he would say afterwards the US Coast Guard was "doing a great job". When he was asked on September 9, 2019 about if he would ask President Trump to support Florida's two US Senators requests about to either waive or suspend visa requirements and allow Bahamians to temporarily live with families in the United States he would say he was not in favor of it.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Klas|first=Mary|date=September 9, 2019|title=Ron DeSantis says feds, not Florida, have role to play in Bahamian crisis.|work=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|url=https://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2019/09/09/ron-desantis-says-feds-not-florida-have-role-to-play-in-bahamian-crisis/|access-date=September 15, 2021}}</ref>

title: Ron DeSantis
added: He did have a younger sister named Christina who died on May 12, 2015 in [[London]]. She graduated from Dunedin High School like her brother did in 2003. After graduating from high school she would attend Florida State University where she got a [[Bachelor of Science|BS]] degree in 2007 and an [[Master of Science|MS]] in 2010. Christina was engaged with Stephan Pasiewicz at the time of her death who was from London and had last worked as a financial advisor for [[KPMG]] in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 7, 2015|title=Christina Marie DeSANTIS|url=https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/tampabaytimes/name/christina-desantis-obituary?pid=175025946|url-status=live|access-date=September 17, 2021|website=[[Legacy.com]]}}</ref>
