title: Electoral fraud in the United States
added: '''Voter impersonation''', also sometimes called '''in-person voter fraud''',<ref name=booker>{{cite web |author=Booker, Cory |author-link=Cory Booker |url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/aug/18/cory-booker/lightning-strikes-more-common-person-voter-fraud-s/ |title=Lightning strikes more common in Texas than in-person voter fraud, says Cory Booker |work=Politifact |date=August 18, 2015 |access-date=March 2, 2016 }}</ref> is a form of [[electoral fraud]] in which a person who is eligible to vote in an election votes more than once, or a person who is not eligible to vote does so by voting under the name of an eligible voter.<ref name=booker /> In the United States, [[Voter ID laws in the United States|voter ID laws]] have been enacted in a number of states by Republican legislatures and governors since 2010 with the purported aim of preventing voter impersonation.<ref name="abc">{{cite web |author=Bingham, Amy |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/voter-fraud-real-rare/story?id=17213376|title=Voter Fraud: Non-Existent Problem or Election-Threatening Epidemic?|date=September 12, 2012|publisher=ABC News|access-date=December 9, 2015}}</ref> Existing research and evidence shows that voter impersonation is extremely rare. Between 2000 and 2014, there were only 31 documented instances of voter impersonation.<ref name="WaPo_voter_fraud_2014">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/10/13/the-disconnect-between-voter-id-laws-and-voter-fraud/|title=The disconnect between voter ID laws and voter fraud|author=Bump, Philip |date=October 13, 2014|work=The Washington Post The Fix blog|access-date=July 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Levitt|first=Justin|date=August 6, 2014|title=A comprehensive investigation of voter impersonation finds 31 credible incidents out of one billion ballots cast|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2014/08/06/a-comprehensive-investigation-of-voter-impersonation-finds-31-credible-incidents-out-of-one-billion-ballots-cast/?arc404=true|url-status=live|website=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Debunking the Voter Fraud Myth|url=https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/analysis/Briefing_Memo_Debunking_Voter_Fraud_Myth.pdf|url-status=live|access-date=June 22, 2021|website=Brennan Center}}</ref> There is no evidence that it has changed the result of any election. In April 2020, a voter fraud study covering 20 years by the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] found the level of mail-in ballot fraud "exceedingly rare" since it occurs only in "0.00006 percent" of instances nationally, and, in one state, "0.000004 percent — about five times less likely than getting hit by lightning in the United States."<ref name="MIT-20200428">{{cite news |author1=Charles Stewart III |author2=Amber McReynolds |title=Let's put the vote-by-mail 'fraud' myth to rest |date=April 28, 2020 |newspaper=The Hill |via=MIT School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences |url=https://shass.mit.edu/news/news-2020-pandemic-voting-mail-safe-honest-and-fair-stewart |access-date=July 28, 2020 }}</ref>
==Voter ID laws==

Voter ID laws target "in-person" voting fraud to deter impersonation by requiring some form of official ID.<ref name="columbialawreview_2014">{{cite journal|last=Gilbert|first=Michael D.|date=September 5, 2014|title=The Problem of Voter Fraud|url=https://ssrn.com/abstract=2488645|journal=Columbia Law Review|volume=115|issue=3|pages=739–75}}Virginia Public Law and Legal Theory Research Paper No. 2014-56; Virginia Law and Economics Research Paper No. 2014-15.</ref> In many states, voters have other options besides  "in-person" voting, such as absentee voting, or requesting an absentee ballot (which includes online voting and voting by mail).<ref name="NCSL_2017_absentee">{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/elections-and-campaigns/absentee-and-early-voting.aspx|title=Absentee and Early Voting|date=March 20, 2017 |agency=National Conference of State Legislatures |access-date=July 9, 2017}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |author=Bill Bradbury |author-link=Bill Bradbury |title=Vote-by-Mail: The Real Winner Is Democracy |date=January 1, 2005 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A40032-2004Dec31.html}}</ref> Absentee voting fraud, for example, is not "deterred by ID laws".<ref name="columbialawreview_2014"/><ref>{{Cite web|title=Oppose Voter ID Legislation - Fact Sheet|url=https://www.aclu.org/other/oppose-voter-id-legislation-fact-sheet |publisher=American Civil Liberties Union |access-date=2020-11-07}}</ref>

A 2015 article by [[University of Virginia|University of Virginia Law School]]'s Michael Gilbert in the ''[[Columbia Law Review]]'' described how voter ID laws are controversial in the United States in terms of both politics and public law. Gilbert contends that voter ID laws "increase the risk of vote fraud".<ref name="columbialawreview_2014"/> Those who support voter ID claim to want to protect election integrity by preventing voter fraud.<ref name="columbialawreview_2014"/> Opponents claim that voter ID laws, "like poll taxes and literacy tests before them, intentionally depress turnout by lawful voters."<ref name="columbialawreview_2014"/> Critics of voter ID laws have argued that voter impersonation is illogical from the perspective of the perpetrator, as if they are caught, they will face harsh criminal penalties, including up to 5 years in prison and a fine of up to $10,000 for citizens and possible deportation for non-citizens. Even if they are not caught, they will have cast only one vote for their candidate.<ref name=abc/>

It would be very difficult for someone to coordinate widespread voter impersonation to steal an election. Even if they paid people to vote for their preferred candidate, they could not confirm whether the people they paid voted at all, much less the way they were paid to.<ref name="columbialawreview_2014" />

The strictest voter ID law in the United States is Senate Bill 14, which was signed by the Governor of Texas [[Rick Perry]] in 2011 and came into effect on January 1, 2012, although it was blocked a few months later. It was reinstated in 2013, but was later found to be discriminatory against minorities in a July 2015 U.S. 5th Circuit Court of Appeals ruling.<ref name="texastribune_2015">{{cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2015/08/05/ruling-offers-texas-voter-id-critics-narrow-victor/|title=Court: Texas Voter ID Law Violates Voting Rights Act: Texas' four-year-old voter ID law violates the Voting Rights Act but is not a "poll tax" barred under the U.S. Constitution, a federal appeals court has ruled|last=Malewitz|first=Jim|date=August 5, 2015|newspaper=[[Texas Tribune]]|access-date=July 9, 2017}}</ref> A lower court was required to develop a fix for the law before the November 2016 elections.<ref name="WaPo_2017_voter_ID">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/appeals-ourt-says-texas-voter-id-law-has-discriminatory-effect/2016/07/20/781bf340-4cef-11e6-aa14-e0c1087f7583_story.html|title=Appeals court says Texas voter-ID law discriminates against minorities|last=Barnes|first=Robert|date=July 20, 2016|work=The Washington Post|access-date=July 9, 2017}}</ref> [[Jeff Sessions]] dropped challenges against Senate Bill 14 early in his tenure at the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]].<ref name="Salon_2017">{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2017/02/27/jeff-sessions-drops-doj-lawsuit-against-discriminatory-texas-voter-id-case-reversing-6-years-of-litigation/|title=Jeff Sessions drops DOJ lawsuit against discriminatory Texas voter ID case, reverses 6 years of litigation: The Department of Justice plans to abandon its claim that Texas GOP lawmakers targeted voters of color|last=Tesfaye|first=Sophia|date=February 27, 2017|work=Salon|access-date=July 9, 2017}}</ref>
==Estimates of frequency==

The vast majority of voter ID laws in the United States target only [[voter impersonation]], of which there are only 31 documented cases in the United States from the 2000–2014 period.<ref name="WaPo_voter_fraud_2014" /> According to ''[[PolitiFact.com|PolitiFact]]'', "in-person voter fraud—the kind targeted by the ID law—remains extremely rare".<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2016/mar/17/greg-abbott/light-match-greg-abbotts-claim-about-rampant-voter/|title=None|access-date=August 3, 2016}}</ref> According to the ''[[Associated Press]]'', the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]],'' [[NPR]], [[CNBC]], ''[[the Guardian]]'', and [[FactCheck.org|FactCheck.Org]], the available research and evidence point to the type of fraud that would be prevented by voter ID laws as "very rare" or "extremely rare".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/dafac088c90242ef8b282fbebddf5b56|title=In Wisconsin, ID law proved insurmountable for many voters |publisher=Associated Press |access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/24/us/supreme-court-rejects-challenge-to-wisconsin-voter-id-law.html|title=Wisconsin Decides Not to Enforce Voter ID Law|last=Liptak|first=Adam |author-link=Adam Liptak |date=2015-03-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/09/07/493001761/despite-court-ruling-voting-rights-fight-continues-in-north-carolina|title=Despite Court Ruling, Voting Rights Fight Continues In North Carolina|publisher=NPR|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2016/10/trumps-bogus-voter-fraud-claims/|title=Trump's Bogus Voter Fraud Claims - FactCheck.org|date=2016-10-19|work=FactCheck.org|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |author1=Ali Vitali |author2=Peter Alexander |author3=Kelly O'Donnell |title=Trump establishes vote fraud commission |date=2017-05-11 |publisher=CNBC  |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/11/trump-to-establish-vote-fraud-commission.html |access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/11/texas-voter-fraud-mexican-national|title=Trump voter fraud claim was '800lb gorilla in jury box' at Texas trial|agency=Associated Press|date=2017-02-11|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2016-10-17/trump-wrongly-insists-voter-fraud-is-very-very-common |title=Trump wrongly insists voter fraud is 'very, very common'; Donald Trump is insisting voter fraud does, indeed, pose a significant threat to the integrity of the U.S. electoral system |author=Jill Colvin |date=October 18, 2016 |agency=Associated Press |work=U.S. News & World Report |access-date=April 6, 2020}}</ref> PolitiFact finds the suggestion that "voter fraud is rampant" false, giving it its "Pants on Fire" rating.<ref name=":9" />

ABC News reported in 2012 that only four cases of voter impersonation had led to convictions in Texas over the previous decade.<ref name="abc" /> A study released the same year by [[News21]], an [[Arizona State University]] reporting project, identified a total of 10 cases of alleged voter impersonation in the United States since 2000.<ref name="upi">{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2012/08/12/Report-Voter-impersonation-a-rarity/UPI-57831344823032/?st_rec=4061414978930|title=Report: Voter impersonation a rarity|date=August 12, 2012|publisher=UPI|access-date=December 9, 2015}}</ref> The same study found that for every case of voter impersonation, there were 207 cases of other types of election fraud. This analysis has, in turn, been criticized by the executive director of the [[Republican National Lawyers Association]], who has said that the study was "highly flawed in its very approach to the issue."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/georgia/statements/2012/sep/19/naacp/-person-voter-fraud-very-rare-phenomenon/|title=In-person voter fraud 'a very rare phenomenon'|author=Davis, Janel|date=September 19, 2012|work=Politifact|access-date=December 9, 2015}}</ref> Also a 2012 study found no evidence that voter impersonation (in the form of people voting under the auspices of a dead voter) occurred in the 2006 Georgia general elections.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hood|first1=M. V.|last2=Gillespie|first2=William|date=March 2012|title=They Just Do Not Vote Like They Used To: A Methodology to Empirically Assess Election Fraud|journal=Social Science Quarterly|volume=93|issue=1|pages=76–94|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6237.2011.00837.x}}</ref>

In April 2014, Federal District Court Judge [[Lynn Adelman]] ruled in ''[[Frank v. Walker]]'' that Wisconsin's voter ID law was unconstitutional because "virtually no voter impersonation occurs in Wisconsin ...".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/29/voter-fraud-wisconsin_n_5235466.html|title=In-Person Voter Fraud Is Virtually Nonexistent, Federal Judge Rules|author=Reilly, Ryan|date=April 29, 2014|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=March 1, 2016}}</ref> In August 2014, [[Justin Levitt]], a professor at [[Loyola Law School]], reported in the Washington Post's [[Wonkblog]] that he had identified only 31 credible cases of voter impersonation since 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2014/08/06/a-comprehensive-investigation-of-voter-impersonation-finds-31-credible-incidents-out-of-one-billion-ballots-cast/|title=A comprehensive investigation of voter impersonation finds 31 credible incidents out of one billion ballots cast|author=Levitt, Justin|date=August 6, 2014|work=The Washington Post|access-date=December 9, 2015}}</ref> Levitt has also claimed that of these 31 cases, three of them occurred in Texas, while [[Lorraine Minnite]] of [[Rutgers University–Camden]] estimates there were actually four during the 2000–2014 period.<ref name="booker" /> The most serious incident identified involved as many as 24 people trying to vote under assumed names in [[Brooklyn]], but even this would not have made a significant difference in almost any American election.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/10/13/the-disconnect-between-voter-id-laws-and-voter-fraud/|title=The disconnect between voter ID laws and voter fraud|author=Bump, Philip|date=October 13, 2014|work=The Washington Post|access-date=February 7, 2016}}</ref> Also that year, a study in the ''[[Election Law Journal]]'' found that about the same percentage of the U.S. population (about 2.5%) admitted to having been abducted by aliens as admitted to committing voter impersonation. This study also concluded that "strict voter ID requirements address a problem that was certainly not common in the 2012 U.S. election."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Alien Abduction and Voter Impersonation in the 2012 U.S. General Election: Evidence from a Survey List Experiment|first1=John S.|last1=Ahlquist|first2=Kenneth R.|last2=Mayer|first3=Simon|last3=Jackman|date=December 1, 2014|journal=Election Law Journal: Rules, Politics, and Policy|volume=13|issue=4|pages=460–475|doi=10.1089/elj.2013.0231}}</ref> In 2016, News21 reviewed cases of possible voter impersonation in five states where politicians had expressed concerns about it. They found 38 successful fraud cases in these states from 2012 to 2016, none of which were for voter impersonation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.publicintegrity.org/2016/08/21/20078/review-key-states-voter-id-laws-found-no-voter-impersonation-fraud|title=A review of key states with Voter ID laws found no voter impersonation fraud|last=Edge|first=Sami|publisher=Center for Public Integrity|date=2016-08-21}}</ref>
==Outdated voter registration==
Based on 2008 data in the 2012 Pew report,<ref name="PEW_T100_votersystem_2012" />

In 2012 [[NPR]] published figures related to the Pew study claiming that over 1.8 million dead people were registered to vote nationwide and over 3 million voters were registered in multiple states.<ref name="NPR_2012">{{cite news|title=Study: 1.8 Million Dead People Still Registered to Vote |author=Pam Fessler |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/02/14/146827471/study-1-8-million-dead-people-still-registered-to-vote |publisher=NPR |date=February 14, 2012 |access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref> However, the PEW study to which the article referred had concluded that the "millions of out of date registration records due to people moving or dying" had "found no evidence that voter fraud resulted."<ref name="politifact_T100_Spicer_PEW_voter_fraud" />

Pew researchers found that military personnel were disproportionately affected by voter registration errors. Most often these involved members of the military and their families who were deployed overseas. For example, in 2008 alone, they reported almost "twice as many registration problems" as the general public.<ref name="PEW_T100_votersystem_2012" />{{rp|7}}

In an October 2016 article published in ''[[Business Insider]]'', the author noted these voter registration irregularities left some people concerned that the electoral system was vulnerable to the impersonation of dead voters. However, registration irregularities do not intrinsically constitute fraud: in most cases the states are simply slow to eliminate ineligible voters. By 2016, most states had addressed concerns raised by the Pew 2012 report.<ref name="businessinsider_2016">{{Cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/ap-ap-fact-check-voter-roll-problems-do-not-equate-to-fraud-2016-10 |title=AP Fact Check: Voter registration problems do not make system vulnerable to widespread fraud |last=Cassidy |first=Christina |website=Business Insider |date=2016-10-25}}</ref>
== Reporting and investigation ==

''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that 18 of the 36 people arrested were charged with absentee ballot fraud - which is not voter impersonation - in the 1997 Miami mayoral election.<ref name="NYT_1998_absentee_ballot_fraud">{{cite news|date=October 29, 1998|title=18 are arrested in 1997 Miami Ballot Fraud|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/us/18-are-arrested-in-1997-miami-ballot-fraud.html|access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref>

According to a ''[[Newsday]]'' report in 2013, since 2000, there had been 270 cases of 6,000 dead people previously registered to vote in [[Nassau County, NY]], who supposedly cast ballots at some point after their deaths. However, the paper explained: "The votes attributed to the dead are too few, and spread over 20 elections since 2000, to consider them a coordinated fraud attempt. More likely is what investigators in other states have found when examining dead voter records: Clerical errors are to blame, such as a person's vote being assigned to a dead person with a similar name."<ref name="NBC_2013_Cergol">{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Dead-Voter-List-Long-Island-Nassau-County-Newsday-230030371.html|title=More Than 200 Dead People Shown to Have Voted in NY County Elections: Report|last=Cergol|first=Greg|date=October 31, 2013|publisher=[[WNBC]] |access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsday.com/long-island/nassau/6-100-dead-people-on-nassau-voter-rolls-newsday-analysis-finds-1.6349860|title=Analysis: 100s of dead LIers voted in Nassau|website=Newsday}}</ref>
In October 2020, Republican [[election law]]yer [[Benjamin Ginsberg (lawyer)|Benjamin Ginsberg]] wrote:

<blockquote>I spent four decades in the Republican trenches, representing GOP presidential and congressional campaigns, working on Election Day operations, recounts, redistricting and other issues, including trying to lift the [[Ballot Security Task Force#1982 lawsuit and consent decree|consent decree]].... Nearly every Election Day since 1984 I've worked with Republican poll watchers, observers and lawyers to record and litigate any fraud or election irregularities discovered.

The truth is that over all those years Republicans found only isolated incidents of fraud. Proof of systematic fraud has become the Loch Ness Monster of the Republican Party. People have spent a lot of time looking for it, but it doesn't exist.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/11/01/ben-ginsberg-voter-suppression-republicans/|title=Opinion | My party is destroying itself on the altar of Trump|first=Benjamin L.|last=Ginsberg|work=The Washington Post}}
===Pew report (2012)===

Some alleging voter fraud have cited a 2012 report by the [[Pew Research Center|Pew]] Center on the States titled "Inaccurate, Costly, and Inefficient: Evidence That America's Voter Registration System Needs an Upgrade", which was based on data collected in 2008. However, the study was misinterpreted. As explained by [[PolitiFact]], the study investigated "outdated voter rolls, not fraudulent votes", and made "no mention of noncitizens voting or registering to vote". Pew's election program director also clarified: "We found millions of out of date registration records due to people moving or dying, but found no evidence that voter fraud resulted."<ref name="politifact_T100_Spicer_PEW_voter_fraud">{{cite web  |title=Sean Spicer wrongly uses Pew study to bolster claim that non-citizens vote in large numbers
===Old Dominion University study (2014)===

Proponents of voter ID laws have pointed to a 2014 study by [[Old Dominion University]] professors Jesse Richman and David Earnest as justification. The study, which used data developed by the Cooperative Congressional Election Study, concluded that more than 14 percent of self-identified [[non-citizens]] in 2008 and 2010 indicated that they were registered to vote, approximately 6.4% of surveyed non-citizens voted in 2008, and 2.2% of surveyed non-citizens voted in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2014/10/24/could-non-citizens-decide-the-november-election/|title=Washington Post: Could non-citizens decide the November election?|last=Richman|first=Jesse|date=October 24, 2014|work=The Washington Post|access-date=June 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Richman|first1=Jesse T.|last2=Chattha|first2=Gulshan A.|last3=Earnest|first3=David C.|date=December 1, 2014|title=Do non-citizens vote in U.S. elections?|journal=[[Electoral Studies]]|volume=36|pages=149–157|doi=10.1016/j.electstud.2014.09.001|url=https://digitalcommons.odu.edu/politicalscience_geography_pubs/11}}</ref> However, the study also concluded that voter ID requirements would be ineffective at reducing non-citizen voting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-mh-steal-your-election-20141031-column.html|title=Today's voting freakout: noncitizens are coming to steal your election|author=Hiltzik, Michael |author-link=Michael Hiltzik |date=October 31, 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=March 28, 2016}}</ref> This study has been criticized by numerous academics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2014/10/27/methodological-challenges-affect-study-of-non-citizens-voting/|title=Methodological challenges affect study of non-citizens' voting|author=Bump, Philip|date=October 27, 2014|work=The Washington Post|access-date=February 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{cite journal|last1=Ansolabehere|first1=Stephen|last2=Luks|first2=Samantha|last3=Schaffner|first3=Brian F.|date=December 2015|title=The perils of cherry picking low frequency events in large sample surveys|journal=Electoral Studies|volume=40|pages=409–10|doi=10.1016/j.electstud.2015.07.002}}</ref><ref name=":14">{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/11/donald-trump-illegal-votes-evidence-debunked-214487|title=Trump's Claims About Illegal Votes Are Nonsense. I Debunked the Study He Cites as 'Evidence.'|newspaper=Politico Magazine|access-date=January 27, 2017}}</ref> A 2015 study by the managers of the Cooperative Congressional Election Study found that Richman and Earnest's study was "almost certainly flawed" and that, in fact, it was most likely that 0% of non-citizens had voted in recent American elections.<ref name=":12" /> Richman and Earnest's findings were the result of measurement error; some individuals who answered the survey checked the wrong boxes in surveys. Richman and Earnest therefore extrapolated from a handful of wrongfully classified cases to achieve an exaggerated number of individuals who appeared to be non-citizen voters.<ref name=":12" /> Richman later conceded that "the response error issues ... may have biased our numbers".<ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/26/upshot/illegal-voting-claims-and-why-they-dont-hold-up.html|title=Illegal Voting Claims, and Why They Don't Hold Up|last=Cohn|first=Nate|date=January 26, 2017|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=January 26, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Richman has also rebuked President Trump for claiming that millions voted illegally in 2016.<ref name=":13" /> Brian Schaffner, Professor of Political Science at University of Massachusetts, Amherst, who was part of the team that debunked Richman and Earnest's study said that the study
===University of California, San Diego, study (2017)===

A 2017 study in ''[[The Journal of Politics]]'' "shows that strict identification laws have a differentially negative impact on the turnout of racial and ethnic minorities in primaries and general elections. Voter ID laws skew democracy in favor of whites and those on the political right"<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Hajnal|first1=Zoltan|last2=Lajevardi|first2=Nazita|last3=Nielson|first3=Lindsay|date=January 5, 2017|title=Voter Identification Laws and the Suppression of Minority Votes|journal=The Journal of Politics|volume=79|issue=2|pages=363–379|doi=10.1086/688343|s2cid=20943777|issn=0022-3816|url=https://semanticscholar.org/paper/9eb68912a991a481d4ba9b04a630048e4caae8cf}}</ref> The results of this study were challenged in a paper by Stanford political scientist Justin Grimmer and four other political scientists.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last1=Grimmer|first1=Justin|last2=Hersh|first2=Eitan|last3=Meredith|first3=Marc|last4=Mummolo|first4=Jonathan|last5=Nall|first5=Clayton|date=April 18, 2018|title=Obstacles to Estimating Voter ID Laws' Effect on Turnout|journal=The Journal of Politics|volume=80|issue=3|pages=1045–1051|doi=10.1086/696618|s2cid=158764888|issn=0022-3816}}</ref> The paper says that the findings in the aforementioned study "a product of data inaccuracies, the presented evidence does not support the stated conclusion, and alternative model specifications produce highly variable results. When errors are corrected, one can recover positive, negative, or null estimates of the effect of voter ID laws on turnout, precluding firm conclusions."<ref name=":15" /> In a response, the authors of the original study dismissed the aforementioned criticisms, and stood by the findings of the original article.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Hajnal|first1=Zoltan|last2=Kuk|first2=John|last3=Lajevardi|first3=Nazita|date=April 18, 2018|title=We All Agree: Strict Voter ID Laws Disproportionately Burden Minorities|journal=The Journal of Politics|volume=80|issue=3|pages=1052–1059|doi=10.1086/696617|s2cid=158480092|issn=0022-3816}}</ref> Columbia University statistician and political scientist Andrew Gelman said that the response by the authors of the original study "did not seem convincing" and that the finding of racial discrepancies in the original study does not stand.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/06/11/a-new-controversy-erupts-over-whether-voter-identification-laws-suppress-minority-turnout/|title=Analysis {{!}} A new controversy erupts over whether voter identification laws suppress minority turnout|last=Gelman|first=Andrew|date=2018-06-11|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>

''[[Fish v. Kobach]]'' was a bench trial in United States District Court for the District of Kansas in which five Kansas residents and the League of Women Voters contested the legality of the Documentary Proof of Citizenship (DPOC) requirement of the Kansas Secure and Fair Elections (SAFE) Act, enacted in 2011,<ref name=SAFEsigned>{{Cite press release |last=Kobach|first=Kris W.|date=2011-04-18|title=Kansas Secure and Fair Elections (SAFE) Act Signed by Governor|publisher=Kansas Secretary of State|url=https://www.kssos.org/other/news_releases/PR_2011/PR_2011-04-18_on_SAFE_Act_Signing.pdf|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref>  which took effect in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-02-24|title=Secure and Fair Elections (S.A.F.E.) Act Regulations|publisher=Kansas Secretary of State|url=http://www.kssos.org/elections/12elec/SAFE%20Act%20regs%20for%20website--final.pdf|access-date=2018-03-18 }}</ref>  Then-Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach claimed these procedures were needed to protect the nation from a supposedly massive problem of vote fraud by people not legally allowed to do so, including 11.3 percent of non-citizens residing in the US amounting to some 3.2 million votes in 2016, greater than Hillary Clinton's lead in the 2016 popular vote.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Lowry|first=Bryan|date=2018-03-13|title=His own witness doesn't back Kobach claims that illegal votes cost Trump popular vote|website=Kansas City Star|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article204976839.html|access-date=2018-03-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Official 2016 Presidential General Election Results|url=https://transition.fec.gov/pubrec/fe2016/federalelections2016.pdf|publisher=Federal Election Commission|date=December 2017|access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref>

On June 18 and 19, 2018, Judge Robinson, appointed to the bench by Republican President George W. Bush, published 118 pages of “Findings of fact and conclusions of law” in this case.{{sfn|Robinson|2018}} In broad strokes, she sided with the plaintiffs on most of the major points in question and with the defense on a few relatively minor points.

For example, “Defendant's expert Hans von Spakovsky is a senior legal fellow at The Heritage Foundation, 'a think tank whose mission [is to] formulate and promote conservative public policies. ... [He] cited a U.S. GAO study for the proposition that the GAO 'found that up to 3 percent of the 30,000 individuals called for jury duty from voter registration roles over a two-year period in just one U.S. district court were not U.S. citizens.' On cross-examination, however, he acknowledged that he omitted the following facts: the GAO study contained information on a total of 8 district courts; 4 of the 8 reported that there was not a single non-citizen who had been called for jury duty; and the 3 remaining district courts reported that less than 1% of those called for jury duty from voter rolls were noncitizens. Therefore, his report misleadingly described the only district court with the highest percentage of people reporting that they were noncitizens, while omitting mention of the 7 other courts described in the GAO report, including 4 that had no incidents of noncitizens on the rolls. ... In contrast, Plaintiffs offered Dr. Lorraine Minnite, an objective expert witness, who provided compelling testimony about Defendant's claims of noncitizen registration. Dr. Minnite ... has extensively researched and studied the incidence and effect of voter fraud in American elections. Her published research on the topic spans over a decade and includes her full-length, peer reviewed book, ''The Myth of Voter Fraud,'' ... .Dr. Minnite testified that when she began researching the issue of voter fraud, ..., she began with a 'blank slate' about the conclusions she would ultimately draw from the research. ... Although she admits that noncitizen registration and voting does at times occur, Dr. Minnite testified that there is no empirical evidence to support Defendant's claims in this case that noncitizen registration and voting in Kansas are largescale problems. ... [M]any of these cases reflect isolated incidents of avoidable administrative errors ... and / or misunderstanding on the part of applicants. ... For example, 100 individuals in ELVIS [the Kansas Election Voter Information System] have birth dates in the 1800s, indicating that they are older than 118. And 400 individuals have birth dates after their date of registration, indicating they registered to vote before they were born. ... The voting rate among purported noncitizen registrations on [a Kansas temporary drivers license] match list is around 1%, whereas the voting rate among registrants in Kansas more generally is around 70%.”{{sfn|Robinson|2018|pp=52-58}}
Judge Robinson saw no credible evidence to support the claims of substantive noncitizen voting, the key claim of the defendant.
== History ==
===In-person voter fraud (1968–1982)===

Conservative lawyer [[Hans von Spakovsky]] has claimed that significant in-person voter fraud occurred in Brooklyn from 1968 to 1982, but [[Richard Hasen]] has argued that this fraud, because it involved election officials colluding with one another, could not have been prevented by a voter ID law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/10/29/the-voter-fraud-myth|title=The Voter-Fraud Myth|author=Mayer, Jane |author-link=Jane Mayer |date=October 29, 2012|work=The New Yorker|access-date=March 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Voter fraud claims in the 2016 presidential election===

President [[Donald Trump]] claimed without evidence that between 3 and 5 million people cost him the [[Popular vote (representative democracy)|popular vote]] to [[Hillary Clinton]] by voting illegally. He claimed that he narrowly lost to Hillary Clinton in 2016 in New Hampshire (and that Senator [[Kelly Ayotte]] also lost her bid for re-election in New Hampshire) because thousands of people were illegally bused there from Massachusetts.<ref name="businessinsider_T100_Miller_Voter_fraud">{{cite web |title='You have provided absolutely no evidence': Stephanopoulos grills Trump adviser in a testy interview about voter fraud|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/stephen-miller-voter-fraud-allegations-abc-2017-2|website=Business Insider|author=Maxwell Tani|date=February 12, 2017 |access-date=February 12, 2017}}</ref> There is no evidence to support Trump's claims, which the New Hampshire Attorney General's Office determined were unfounded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2017/02/no-evidence-of-busing-voters-to-n-h/|title=No Evidence of Busing Voters to N.H.|work=FactCheck.org|publisher=Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania|first=Robert|last=Farley|date=February 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.concordmonitor.com/Attorney-General-s-office-No-evidence-out-of-state-voters-bused-into-New-Hampshire-17828373|title=Attorney general's office: No evidence out-of-state voters bused into New Hampshire|date=May 29, 2018|website=Concord Monitor}}</ref>

Trump claimed that "millions voted illegally in the election" based on "studies and evidence that people have presented him".<ref name="theguardian_T100_voterfraud">{{cite web |title=Trump plans 'major investigation into voter fraud' amid groundless claims|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/25/donald-trump-voter-fraud-investigation-illegal-voting|work=The Guardian|date=January 25, 2017 |access-date=February 12, 2017

}}</ref> At that time, CNN reported that Trump had based his fraud voter claims on information from [[Gregg Phillips]], VoteStand founder.<ref name="CNN_2017_fraud">{{cite news |last=Ryan |first=Josiah |date=January 27, 2017 |title=Trump-cited study author (still) refuses to show proof of voter fraud |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/27/politics/gregg-phillips-voter-fraud-donald-trump-cnntv/ |newspaper=CNN |access-date=January 27, 2017}}</ref><ref name="VOX_fraud_2017">{{cite news |first=German |last=Lopez |date=January 25, 2017 |title=It's official: Trump is taking his voter fraud myth to the White House — with real consequences |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/1/25/14382632/trump-voter-fraud-myth-investigation |newspaper=Vox |access-date=January 25, 2017}}</ref> While members of Trump's cabinet and family were registered to vote in multiple states, this was considered to be oversight, not fraud.<ref name="registration">{{cite web |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-01-25/tiffany-trump-steve-bannon-steve-mnuchin-registered-to-vote-in-multiple-states |title=Tiffany Trump, Steve Bannon, Steven Mnuchin Registered to Vote in Multiple States |author=Gabrielle Levy |website=[[US News and World Report]] |date=January 19, 2017}}</ref> In response to Trump's allegations, On February 10, [[Ellen L. Weintraub]], the [[Federal Election Commission]] (FEC) Commissioner, requested that Trump provide evidence of the "thousands of felony criminal offenses under New Hampshire law".<ref name="FEC_T100_Weintraub_2017">{{cite web|title=Statement of Commissioner Ellen L. Weintraub Regarding Allegations by the President of the United States of Widespread Voter Fraud in New Hampshire|url=https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/5381420/ELW-POTUS-voter-fraud-statement.pdf|location=Washington|publisher=[[Federal Election Commission]] (FEC)|author=Ellen L. Weintraub|date=February 10, 2017|access-date=February 12, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211011745/https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/5381420/ELW-POTUS-voter-fraud-statement.pdf|archive-date=February 11, 2017|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all|author-link=Ellen L. Weintraub}}</ref> In a CNN interview on February 12, [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]] seemed to refer to the 2012 [[Pew Research Center]] (PEW) study<ref name="PEW_T100_votersystem_2012">{{cite web |title=Inaccurate, Costly, and Inefficient Evidence That America's Voter Registration System Needs an Upgrade |url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/~/media/legacy/uploadedfiles/pcs_assets/2012/pewupgradingvoterregistrationpdf.pdf |location=Washington|publisher=[[Pew Research Center]] |author=Kate Kelly|date=February 2012 |page=12 |access-date=February 12, 2017}}</ref> but was unable at that time to support claims of voter fraud as evidence.<ref name="CNN_T100_voter_fraud">{{cite web |title=FEC commissioner asks Trump for voter fraud evidence |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/10/politics/fec-ellen-weintraub-new-hampshire/ |location=Washington|publisher=CNN|author=Eli Watkins|date=February 10, 2017 |access-date=February 12, 2017}}</ref><ref name="businessinsider_T100_Miller_Voter_fraud" /> There is no evidence to support Trump's assertion that there was substantial voter fraud in the 2016 election.
====Voter fraud commission (2017)====

On May 11, 2017, Trump signed an [[executive order]] to establish a voter fraud commission to conduct an investigation into voter fraud.<ref name="politico_2017">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/11/trump-voter-fraud-commission-238263 |title=Trump signs executive order creating voter fraud commission |first=Louis |last=Nelson |date=May 11, 2017 |work=[[Politico]] |access-date=July 9, 2017}}</ref> He had announced his intention to create the commission on January 25.<ref name="theguardian_T100_voterfraud"/> The commission's chairman was Vice President [[Mike Pence]] with [[Kris Kobach]] as vice chairman.<ref name="politico_2017"/> Kobach, who is the [[Secretary of State of Kansas|Secretary of State]] of [[Kansas]], calls for stricter [[voter ID laws in the United States]].<ref name="reuters_2017_Kobach">{{Cite news|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN13B05C?feedType=RSS|title=Immigration hardliner says Trump team preparing plans for wall, mulling Muslim registry|date=2016-11-16|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><ref name="politico_2017_Kobach">{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/kris-kobach-donald-trump-immigration-rigged-230000|title=Trump's immigration whisperer|newspaper=Politico|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> Kobach claims there is a voter fraud crisis in the United States.<ref name="WaPo_2017_voterfraud">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/02/12/stephen-millers-bushels-of-pinocchios-for-false-voter-fraud-claims|title=Stephen Miller's bushels of Pinocchios for false voter-fraud claims|website=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><ref name="politifact_Morris">{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2014/apr/10/dick-morris/dick-morris-theres-proof-over-1-million-people-vot|title=Dick Morris: There's proof that over 1 million people voted twice in 2012|newspaper=@politifact|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><ref name="kansas_noncitizens">{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansas.com/news/politics-government/election/article109346967.html|title=Kobach warns that noncitizens could tip election|newspaper=Kansas|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><ref name="kansascity_2017_voterfraud">{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article117957143.html|title=Kris Kobach agrees with Donald Trump that 'millions' voted illegally but offers no evidence|newspaper=kansascity|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><ref name="WaPo_nationalsecurity">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/the-conservative-gladiator-from-kansas-behind-restrictive-voting-laws/2016/04/06/57ad18d2-eaed-11e5-b0fd-073d5930a7b7_story.html|title=The conservative gladiator from Kansas behind restrictive voting laws|website=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> Trump's creation of the commission was criticized by [[voting rights]] advocates, scholars and experts, and newspaper editorial boards as a pretext for, and prelude to, [[voter suppression]].<ref name=WashingtonPost>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/trumps-voter-fraud-commission-itself-is-a-fraud-itself/2017/07/18/89ad1298-6b24-11e7-96ab-5f38140b38cc_story.html "Trump's voter-fraud commission itself is a fraud"]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. July 18, 2017. Retrieved July 19, 2017, "...In fact, the real fraud is the commission itself...."</ref><ref name="AshCenter">[https://ash.harvard.edu/news/qa-miles-rapoport-presidential-advisory-commission-election-integrity Miles Rapoport on the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity], [[Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation]], [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]], Harvard University (May 30, 2017): "President Trump's decision to establish a panel to study voter fraud and suppression, the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity, has been roundly criticized by voter rights advocates and Democrats." ... [Miles Rapoport, Senior Democracy Practice Fellow Ash Center]: "There are a number of really serious problems with the Commission as it has been announced and conceptualized, which have led many people to say that its conclusions are pre-determined and that it will be used as an excuse for new efforts to restrict access to voting."</ref><ref name="Waldman">[[Michael Waldman]], [http://www.brennancenter.org/blog/donald-trump-tells-his-voter-fraud-panel-find-me-%E2%80%98something%E2%80%99 Donald Trump Tells His Voter Fraud Panel: Find Me 'Something'], [[Brennan Center for Justice]], [[New York University School of Law]] (July 20, 2017) (also republished at [http://www.thedailybeast.com/donald-trump-tells-his-voter-fraud-panel-find-me-something The Daily Beast]): "The panel was created to justify one of the more outlandish presidential fibs ... After Trump was roundly mocked for his claim of 3 to 5 million illegal voters, the panel was launched in an effort to try to rustle up some evidence—any evidence—for the charge.... The purpose of the panel is not just to try to justify his laughable claims of millions of invisible illegal voters. It aims to stir fears, to lay the ground for new efforts to restrict voting. Trump's claims, after all, are just a cartoon version of the groundless arguments already used to justify restrictive voting laws."</ref><ref name="BermanWeigel">Mark Berman & [[David Weigel]], [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/trumps-voting-commission-asked-states-to-hand-over-election-data-theyre-pushing-back/2017/06/30/cd8f812a-5dce-11e7-9b7d-14576dc0f39d_story.html Trump’s voting commission asked states to hand over election data. Some are pushing back.], ''Washington Post'' (June 30, 2017): "Experts described the request as ... a recipe for potential voter suppression.... 'This is an attempt on a grand scale to purport to match voter rolls with other information in an apparent effort to try and show that the voter rolls are inaccurate and use that as a pretext to pass legislation that will make it harder for people to register to vote,' said [[Rick Hasen]], an election-law expert at the University of California, Irvine. Hasen said he has "no confidence" in whatever results the committee produces. He said the commission and its request create a number of concerns, including that it is an election group created by one candidate for office—Trump, who already is campaigning for reelection—and headed by Pence, another political candidate. 'It's just a recipe for a biased and unfair report,' Hasen said. "And it's completely different from the way that every other post-election commission has been done."</ref><ref>Max Greenwood, [http://thehill.com/homenews/news/340609-newspaper-editorial-boards-rip-trump-voter-fraud-panel-for-july-4 Newspapers rip Trump voter fraud panel in July Fourth editorials], ''The Hill'' (July 4, 2017).</ref>

In January 2018, Trump abruptly disbanded the commission,<ref name=TackettWines>Michael Tackett & Michael Wines, [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/03/us/politics/trump-voter-fraud-commission.html Trump Disbands Commission on Voter Fraud], ''New York Times'' (January 3, 2018).</ref> which met only twice.<ref name=Villeneuve>Marina Villeneuve, [https://apnews.com/f5f6a73b2af546ee97816bb35e82c18d/Report:-Trump-commission-did-not-find-widespread-voter-fraud Report: Trump commission did not find widespread voter fraud], Associated Press (August 3, 2018).</ref> The commission found no evidence of widespread voter fraud in the United States.<ref name=TackettWines/><ref name=Villeneuve/>
